column2:
Collision of Worlds 
Declaration of War Part 3 
By Michael DeBuse

Chapter 1 
“Kindred” 
Ceil
An unfamiliar chill blew through the white-blanketed mountain pass.
It was colder than Heivleil, Amel, the Gallanvale, Fiorrae, all of Melia, and the flatlands of northwest Vallen, colder than every place that Ceil had the pleasure--or displeasure--of visiting.
The biting cold nipped at Ceil’s exposed cheeks and nose, flushing them pink and making them sting.
She sat at the side of the uneven pass road beside the steep rocky slope of the forested mountain, her knees tucked to her chest and her shaking arms wrapped around them.
Coby set her here after fleeing Revlan at Sammy’s order, right when she was about to surrender herself to Tolmyur to spare what fairies remained and the lives of her friends.
She did not know where she was, only that it was the wilderlands.
Nowhere else nearby would be so mountainous and cold.

The trees along the road grew sturdy and broad with thick, spearheaded fronds of scaled needles, shielding her for the most part from the lightly drifting snow, but they could do nothing for the cutting wind.
It howled through the valleys and ravines, accelerating as it swam through the trees.
The wind must have been magic, because the chill it carried pierced her through her plated jack armor and leather skirt.
Ceil was exhausted, but she could not sleep.
The brief period of unconsciousness from the rapid ascent of her flight lasted until Coby set her down.
Her dead eyes stared blankly down the pass in the direction of Vallen’s flatlands too far beyond her vision to see, especially in snowfall.
Again she survived due to the sacrifice of others.
Again she alone lived to spread destruction as Tolmyur hunted her.
Why am I resisting them so?
To what end is my survival beneficial?
Ceil reached to her side and felt the fractured tip of her staff tucked in her belt, wood from a now deceased Hamadryad.
Not only the fairies but also the dryads were drawn into the conflict.
She ordered her own subjects to kill their former allies.
Subjects?
Ceil gritted her teeth.
She was no empress.
She was not royalty.
She was a farm girl of Heivleil on the very northeast border of the Amelian Empire.

She was bought by the emperor as a child, not to be loved but to be hidden away as a tool to produce impure offspring who would never be recognized in royal High Elf society due to her mixed fairy heritage.
Prophesy and protection?
That meant nothing.
Only now did she realize she was not an empress but a concubine who had even failed in that role being unable to bear Emperor Yuro a single child.
To think for a moment that she could take such an important responsibility as succeeding Emperor Yuro, even to the degree of announcing the rise of her own empire in Revlan, was the height of folly.
Her delusions of grandeur led to the destruction of the final fairy city and the deaths of her friends, of Sammy and Chloe.
No doubt Lemi and Justin would also die before the conclusion of that hopeless battle.
Perhaps they were already dead.
“You were supposed to protect her,” Ceil cursed at Justin’s memory.
A shrill cry sounded from above, and the branches of the tree shielding Ceil rustled.
Something no bigger than her hand fell onto the ground in front of her.
It lacked odor but was clearly cured meat of some kind.
Ceil ignored it.
She had no appetite, nor did she care where Coby happened to find cured meat in the middle of a mountain pass.
Coby dropped down in front of Ceil and lifted the meat in his beak, presenting it to her, but she would not take it.
He trilled worriedly through the gap in his beak from holding the meat.
Ceil’s eyes fell away from him.
She did not want to eat.
She was fine with starving or freezing to death here on the pass.
Maybe the army would head north in search of her after they finished purging the city of life as they had all the others and discover her corpse by the roadside.
Maybe that would finally end the war.
Coby set the meat at Ceils feet and trotted behind her.
His wings enveloped her, blocking the piercing wind, and he nuzzled his beak on the side of her head, nipping lightly at her ear.
Ceil stifled her cry out of habit as one who was supposed to lead the masses--a leader should never cry--and buried her head deeper into her arms.
Coby was warm, and she felt she did not deserve that warmth.
Ceil woke to the crunch of footsteps over snow and gravel.
The snowfall had subsided, but the few more inches covering the road showed it had fallen for most of the morning.
A man with a perplexed expression stood in the road.
“That explains the thieving Habha,” he grumbled, rubbing the side of his head.
He was about Ceil’s height.
His long brown hair was tied back into a long ponytail exposing his rounded ears.
Ceil’s eyes opened wide.

“Human…”
Ceil had committed herself to being captured by the humans should they find her, but seeing one alone, she grew apoplectic with rage.
If she could not take her revenge against the army, perhaps she could kill just one.
Ceil grabbed the small dagger sheathed at her hip and lunged out from Coby’s wings.
She swung wide, the tip of the dagger missing the man’s neck by a mere inch as he stepped back just enough to avoid it.
“Hold it,” he said, deflecting her next swing with a practiced palm to her forearm.
He placed his foot into the small of Ceil’s back and kicked out.
She tumbled over the snow collapsing back to the side of the road.
Coby cried out and opened his wings in hostility.
“Woah!
I mean no harm.” The man crouched with his arms spread out, palms turned away, and head bowed to Coby.
Ceil watched how his strange, submissive posture calmed Coby.
This man knew how to appease Habha.
He reached into the snow with one hand, not breaking the rest of his posture, and dug up a stone.
He gripped it in his fist, and it fell through the back of his hand.
Ceil stared in amazement.
“I have lived in the wilderlands all my life.
I am not human.
I am an oread.

My name is Zose.”
His hair wasn’t brown as she thought but a dark orange.
Male nymph hair lacked in vibrancy compared to women, especially adults.
Ceil sat up and sheathed her dagger.
“A male oread?

Shouldn’t you be sire to a village somewhere in Orest?”
Zose extended his hand to Ceil.
She gripped it, and he pulled her to her feet.

“By the grace and wisdom of my mother, I was saved of that fate when she fled the empire after learning she would bear a son.”
“Saved?
Are male nymphs not worshipped?
Your kind is so rare.

Only you can produce offspring with other nymphs.”
“That is precisely why the position of sire is a curse.
Come.
These mountains are dangerous.
A Lurr built a nest in the abandoned granite quarry to the west.

It was male.”
A shiver ran down Ceil’s spine stronger than the chill of the air.
Lurr could not reproduce with other Lurr, so they capture species of other races for that purpose.
Zose’s mention of the Lurr’s sex was a warning that she was in danger so close to the quarry.
“I killed it, but its spawn might still be around searching, not knowing their broodleader is dead, and your bright purple armor is quite visible in the snow.
The beast was a pixy’s tail shy of a Chimera.
It was beginning to control its evolution.
No doubt it had captured a handful of fairies in its life to grow so intelligent.” Zose beckoned Ceil to follow, and Coby trotted close behind.
“How could you kill a Chimera without magic?” Ceil asked.
“I am a hunter mercenary.
This is my job here in the wilderlands.
I took the request because its nest was a quarry.
I am an oread.
Infiltrating and killing it from the safety of the stone was simple.”
“But cords of hair cannot kill a Lurr, especially not a Chimera.”
“You seem to be well acquainted with Lurr but not with nymphs,” Zose smirked, glancing back over his shoulder at Ceil.
“I was born in Heivleil at the edge of the empire.
Lurr were always a danger there so close to the wilds, so we were taught about them as children.”
Zose reached to his thigh and removed a white knife from its sheath, handing it to Ceil.
She inspected it, noticing the porous texture.

“This is bone.”
“My mother’s femur.
I have an identical blade on my right.” Zose patted the sheath on his right leg.
“Oreads can take products of themselves with them into stone, and that ability also extends to close relatives, parents or siblings.
When my mother died, I turned her body into as many tools and equipment as was possible.”
Ceil stopped walking, staring at Zose in horror.
The knife fell from her fingers.
His shirt and trousers were clearly woven from his hair, but his leather vest, belt, and shoes were not of a type of leather she had seen before.
Zose was undisturbed by Ceil’s reaction.
He walked over to Ceil and retrieved the knife from the snow, placing it back in its sheath after wiping it down.
“Life in the wilderlands is often harsh.
To not use what resources are available to you is a waste and can lead to death.
My mother requested this of me on her deathbed.
It was her decision, although I may have done it anyway without her consent.”
“If life is so hard in the wilderlands, why did she take you here?
Why not live elsewhere in the empire?”
“What do you know of nymph culture?”
“Not much,” Ceil admitted, continuing after Zose.
“The sire rules the village and provides seed for the women.
Most of the nymph sires were assassinated before Tolmyur invaded.
Only the smallest villages avoided it.” Ceil recalled the messages that appeared one after the other when she waited in the fairy council room of the Gallanvale after escaping Amel.

“There was a fear that there would be too few sires and that much of the nymph population would die off due to the lack of males being born now that there are not enough to support the number of women.

Sires are protected because of that fear, and it actually happened.”
“Not protected.
Imprisoned.
My mother was one of the three caretakers for her village sire.
The caretakers run the village, not the sire.
The sire’s sole purpose is to produce offspring.
That is all.
They are not pampered.
They are not even educated.
Did you know that every oread sire was born to a caretaker?
The reason is that they have more access to the sire than the other nymphs.
Due to the drastic difference in numbers, any single nymph may only see the sire once or twice in her lifetime.
The caretakers bear as often as they are able.

It is not uncommon for a caretaker to flee once they discover that they bear a son because they know the horrible life he will live, but every sovereign state of the empire had a political agreement with the nymphs to slay the mother for attempted genocide and return the child should they discover them in their territory.
This is kept secret from most the general population.
The only state to end this agreement was Vallen, and only recently, after my mother fled to the wilderlands.”
“With the state of the nymphs after the assassinations, do you ever consider returning?”
“And give up my freedom for the sole purpose of producing offspring?

Never.”
Ceil’s steps slowed.
“We are the same… but I did not have a choice.
I was sold as a child by my father to nobility for the sole purpose of bearing children.
I was educated, but mostly to rid me of my peasant upbringing.
I escaped during… after Tolmyur’s invasion.”
“I hear concubinage is alive and well in Vallen although it is outlawed in most of the empire.
They were the most independent of the states under the Amelian Empire, after all.” Zose scratched the side of his head.

“Perhaps for you the invasion was a blessing.”
Ceil tensed.
Her hands gripped into tight fists.
She wanted to shout, to rebuke Zose for such a painfully ignorant statement, but instead held her breath until her face grew red.
Zose turned and grasped her trembling fist.
She shook it free in anger.
“That was inappropriate of me.
I do not hold the empire in high regard, but I do not know your circumstances either.
If I insulted you, I apologize.
I am headed for Ib’nua.
It is three days north from here.
My wife, Basara, will welcome you and your Habha.” Zose nodded to Coby who cried lightly.

“Will you join me?”
Ceil’s rigid fists relaxed.
She had nowhere to go, so she nodded her consent.
Chapter 2 “A Hidden History” Ceil
Ib’nua sat in the first open valley within the Nuanae Range that ran along the northern border of Vallen.
Although Zose called it a valley, multiple rolling hills like uniform mounds crowded together in what appeared to be only a lowland pocket before more steep mountains.
Ib’nua was visible from the mountain pass in the waning daylight, spread between the hills like water filling the creases in the topography.
The city was small but still too large to be called a town or village.
Ceil recalled it as a trading hub, the southernmost trade city of the wilderlands.
A traveling merchant that passed through Heivleil for Menneiv, the largest commerce city in the plains of Filinceil, began his route in Ib’nua.
He was the only merchant from the wilderlands to pass through such a small town, especially because Heivleil was a full two day’s walk off the main highway.
The foreign products he carried were a delicacy for her village, and any additional food was welcomed during the long famine of her childhood.
Ceil remembered fondly the taste of the sweetbark her mother would buy from him as a treat whenever he arrived through the summer.
A small piece could be chewed the entire day without losing its sweetness.
Sadly, sweetbark grew bitter in winter.
“Keep Coby close,” Zose warned.
“He is liable to be shot out of the air for his plumage should people see him without knowing he is yours.
And it is best to refer to yourself as a tamer to ease others’ worries.
Habha are dangerous, after all, and they do not live in this climate.

Some may scare.”
Ceil called Coby, and he landed beside her, leaning over to nip at her fingers.
“If you plan on staying in the wilderlands you should consider registering yourself as a tamer.

I have never seen a domesticated Habha.”
Ceil’s chest tightened.
It was not she who tamed him.
She scratched lightly the feathers beside Coby’s beak.
“Stay close.”
“That language you speak to him and he understands--”
“Fiorran, the language of the sprites,” Ceil interrupted.
English, she recalled, causing her chest to tighten further, choking her.
“Fiorrae… That explains his size.
The Habha in Dhuillir never grow this large.
Your situation must have been truly bizarre indeed.”
Over their three-day travel, Ceil refused to elaborate why she had fled to the wilderlands, so Zose stopped asking.
Most people who moved to the wilderlands often did so for somber reasons.
No one would want to live in a seemingly lawless and hostile land otherwise.
But as the size of Ib’nua could attest, even without formal laws community thrived.
The question still lingered of why Ceil wore such vibrant armor, but if she was a royal Vallen concubine, perhaps that answer could be explained.
Again, Zose did not ask further, especially after seeing Ceil’s distress at Tolmyur’s invasion of Vallen.
Ceil kept Coby close to her side as they entered town.
The city was bustling despite the drifting snow that was too wet to build on the ground at these lower elevations.
The roads were not paved nor were they packed earth.
Passersby--elfkind of almost every race, many of whom were mixed breeds--kicked mud with each step soiling Ceil’s armor and irritating Coby.
His cries of frustrations were quickly hushed by Ceil stroking his beak.
The people would start but soon ignored the large bird seeing that another held his metaphorical leash.
“I will clean your feathers later,” she promised.
Ceil was thankful that everyone kept to themselves.
Even those who knew Zose only cast him a glance with a twitch of their eyes being their only greeting.
Zose grabbed a thin meat skewer as he passed what looked like an open tavern window and handed it to Ceil.
It was clearly overcooked, reminding her again of Sammy, particularly Sammy’s early attempts to cook as they left Fiorrae for Melia.
She hesitated to take it from him.
“Did you just steal that,” she asked, not so much as an accusation but as an honest question.
“Food placed in open windows is for those who need it.
There are many destitute here.
The community takes care of each other.
I cannot expect Basara to feed an unplanned mouth on the day of my return, but do not worry.
We will accommodate you, if you do not mind sleeping in bed with my daughters.”
“The floor is fine enough.
I have Coby for warmth,” Ceil replied with a light shake of her head.
“I would hear no end from Basara if I made you sleep on the floor.
She would rather I do and share her bed with you,” Zose chuckled.
“You have a good wife…”
“Best in the wilderlands,” Zose boasted with a puffed chest.
“Is she also a nymph?”
“Yes, but no.
You will understand when you see her.”
Zose’s cryptic answer made Ceil’s brows furrow.
How could he have daughters if his wife was not a nymph?
Only nymphs could reproduce with other nymphs.
Past the first hill, the shabby wooden structures yielded to those built from layered stones.
Dress and apparel slightly improved as did the smell.
Here Ceil could stomach nibbling on her skewer, but it lacked any flavor.
The meat had burnt, making it slightly bitter, so it was probably set on the windowsill before wasting any seasoning.
Or perhaps there was to be no seasoning at all even if it was properly cooked.
She had been spoiled by Dharin during her short time in Revlan without realizing.
Her tongue yearned for something with flavor.
Coby nipped at Ceil’s hand.
“Fine, you can have some.” She slid half the remaining meat off the whittled stick and passed it to Coby.
She then realized that she was now doing the very same that she often scolded Sammy for in the past.
Sammy’s feeding of Coby was likely the reason he continued to stay with them.
“Here.” She handed Coby the rest of her skewer, now lacking the appetite for it.
Past the next hill, the structures improved once again.
The flat stones used in the masonry were now carved and mortared, leaving no gaps between.
What surprised Ceil the most was the appearance of the same types of ruins she found in Vallen’s flatlands buried partially in the hills.
The oddly uniform mounds may have all been ancient ruins of some form.
Zose led Ceil to a mortared building.
It seemed he was not wealthy enough or with enough influence to claim a structure repurposed from the ruins, but the building at least could ward off the cold.
Only a leather curtain blocked the entrance.
Zose held it back for Ceil to enter.
Two young girls with vibrant orange hair rushed to the entryway.
They were both oreads.

“Zose!”
“Father!”
The youngest looked to be half a year old and the eldest about a year if not a little older.
Zose knelt and embraced his daughters, one in each arm.
“Not until after he’s cleaned up,” a woman rebuked from the entry to another room.

“Now we will have to clean you up too.”
She was fair skinned and beautiful, strangely youthful for a mother of two children of their ages.
She appeared no older than Eydis.
Nymphs lived short lives, similar to humans, but kept much of their youth; however, she was not an oread, possibly not even a nymph.
Her hair was red, but it lacked a vibrant hue like a nymph’s should.
The color was dull, like Chloe’s if comparing Chloe’s orange color to an oread’s.
She looked human, but no humans of Whinhlem had pale skin and red hair.
Ceil did not know what she was.
Zose walked over to kiss Basara, but she held her fist to his chest preventing him from approaching.
“Clean yourself first.”
Ceil, Coby, Zose, and now his two daughters had the mud and filth of the streets on them.
“Let’s take a bath,” the eldest daughter said, pulling Zose’s hand.
The youngest, the only one who seemed to notice Ceil’s presence, grabbed her hand.
“No,” Ceil rejected, “I can wait until you are finished.”
“Hold,” Basara ordered before Zose could be pulled any further.

“No mud inside.”
The two girls immediately stripped as did Zose.
They then passed beside Basara with her nod of approval.
Ceil stood alone with Coby in the entryway.
“You too,” Basara said, not questioning who Ceil was, where she came from, or why she was with Zose.
“There is enough room for you all.”
Ceil did not want to intrude on the family more than needed.
“I am grateful, but I will wait.”
Basara tapped her foot in mild annoyance and then turned into the other room.
She quickly reappeared with a stool and a bucket of steaming water.
“Turn your back to me,” she ordered.
Ceil expected to be doused with the water but instead felt the ties on her jack being loosed.
“I despise jacks.
They are too difficult to remove on one’s own.
Yours is finely crafted.
I assume it was made by a troll?
Their stitching is an easy tell.
Turn, arms forward,” she ordered.
Ceil extended her arms, and Basara removed the Jack with precise movements.
She was as practiced in doffing armor as Thanysa.
Basara noticed Ceil’s surprise.
“I was a veteran hunter mercenary until my first daughter was born, if you were curious.
I also fought in the Coastal War in Tolmyur.”
Ceil pulled away before Basara could finish untying her leather skirt.
“You are human.”
“Half.” Basara beckoned Ceil to return and finished removing Ceil’s armor.
“Strip and sit on the stool.”
Ceil hesitated.
She couldn’t trust a half-human just as she couldn’t trust a human.
If Basara fought in the Coastal War, she would have fought on Tolmyur’s side, because only Tolmyur, the Sea Elves, and the merfolk participated in the war.
“Strip,” Basara ordered again, a little more sternly.
“If you must know, I am also half nymph.
My mother was a maenad.
My father was born in the wilderlands when my pregnant grandmother fled from Tolmyur.”
“Like Zose.”
“He told you?
Yes.
Very similar, although for different reasons.
Must I ask you again?”
“I can wash myself.
I do not want to trouble you.”
“Washing away the toils of a visitor’s travels is a form of welcome here.
Had you joined my husband and daughters in the bath, my eldest would have performed the same for you as I am now.”
Ceil removed her bind and untied her underskirt.
Basara did not question Ceil’s two tails, only tapping on the stool for Ceil to sit.
She then soaked a rag in the steaming water and began wiping Ceil down.
Coby trotted nearby, begging for similar treatment for his feathers.
“I never heard of maenads,” Ceil said.
“Most elves haven’t.
We are fire nymphs.
Maenads can be eccentric, violent, and difficult to interact with.
Like other nymphs, they cannot use magic, so they cannot produce fire, but when a maenad enters a flame, that flame cannot be extinguished no matter the methods used.
The Amelian Empire tried to eliminate them out of fear and hatred, so a war broke out.
The other nymphs sided with the empire, and the maenads lost.
Those few who avoided genocide fled to the wilderlands, my ancestors.
Thankfully my human side mellowed my maenad impulses, but those same violent tendencies helped me succeed as a hunter mercenary.”
“Genocide?
Why would the empire go so far-rrr…” Ceil cringed from overwhelming shivers as Basara forcefully wiped down her two tails.
“Turn,” Basara ordered, and Ceil rotated to face her.

“This is something you would never learn in the empire, but all nymphs were originally humans, slaves of the empire who refused to abandon their homeland after the elves took control of the fertile lands.
You are a High Elf, correct?”
“Yes, but also fairy,” Ceil explained.
“You know the great Amelian Palace?
I assume you know what High Elf architecture looks like.
That palace is nothing similar.
It was built by humans.
Although I assume the elves have embellished it to their taste over the millennia.”
Ceil grabbed Basara’s hand and lifted it off her stomach.
“That can’t be.”
“It is.” Basara pried Ceil’s hand off and continued.
“The Amelian Empire culled all humans with high magic proficiency, but they still feared an uprising.
Adept life mages as High Elves are, they saturated human slaves with ven outside the humans’ elemental affinities to weaken those affinities.
Treated as selectively bred livestock, female hair color grew more beautiful and vibrant, and though it lost its color when cut, it was quickly desired for textiles.
Men were stronger, thus more dangerous, and their hair less vibrant and coarser.
There was little appeal to a male other than for the purpose of breeding the females.
No one wanted to house and feed more males than absolutely necessary.
They saw three choices.
They had enough of a conscience to avoid the first, killing all infants born male that they did not need, although looking at the state of the nymphs now, that may have been the better option.
The last two fell back to breeding.
They could breed males to the same desired state as females, or they could reduce male birthrate.
After how many generations it took to produce the desired females, reducing birthrate was the quicker option.
“A hundred or more human generations later under such torture and the enslaved humans became elementals incapable of magic, and male birthrate plummeted to near-unsustainable levels.
The plight of the nymphs is one very much of the Amelian Empire’s making.
Eventually slavery was abolished, and the human elementals were rebranded as nymphs, another form of elfkind, but the maenads never forgave the empire.
That hostility, combined with maenad aggression, and the empire wanted them eliminated as a matter of course.”
Basara finished wiping Ceil’s feet and grabbed a long, silken nymph gown that would conceal Ceil’s tails.
“This is only temporary until we clean your underskirt.”
“Do you… also hate the Amelian Empire,” Ceil asked, unable or not wanting to comprehend what she just learned.
Basara began wiping Coby’s feathers, just as fastidious as she was with Ceil.
“Not as much as some.
I have done contracts for them in the past.
I do not have any personal grief with the empire, and my ancestral history is not enough reason to propagate the hatred.
At the same time, there are others not of Tolmyur who take upon themselves the mantle of Tolmyur’s vengeance.
I once travelled with such a man but could no longer bear it, so I left.
Shortly thereafter I met Zose and settled down.
My earnings as a mercenary in the Coastal War afforded us this home, and Zose is an adept hunter mercenary in his own right.
This life is far better than wasting away in pursuit of an ancestral feud.”
Ceil’s hands slowly closed into fists.
“I am sure…” She did not want to believe what Basara told her, but even if it was true, it happened tens of thousands of years ago.
No grudge should hold so long.
“I am sure that the empire wanted to forget the past, to put an end to the feud between elves and humans.
For the past thousands of years, not once did the Amelian Empire attack Tolmyur, and yet Tolmyur always tried to invade.
And now the assassinations.
The genocide of the fairies.”
“The modern Amelian Empire is not so innocent.
Oppression from another country need not include open warfare,” Basara admonished, “but if you feel your cause is just, you can supplicate Bydrofe.
As the Guardian of Whinhlem, he has often sided against unjust conflict to preserve the stability of our world.
From what I understand, he already favors the elves over other races.”
Bydrofe was a name all on Whinhlem knew.
There was a legend of a grand war before the founding of the Amelian Empire when the beastkin united to invade out of fear of the strength of the uniting elfkind.
Bydrofe alone withstood their might and turned them back to their continent.
Such a global war could have devastated Whinhlem.
After so long a time, Ceil felt that Tolmyur’s grudge was unjustifiable.
If Bydrofe was truly a protector of order, he should side with her in this conflict.
“I must speak with Bydrofe.” Ceil did not want vengeance.
Her heart and mind was sick with it, but Basara was right.
Avenging the dead will not end the conflict, only propagate it.
The war needed to end.
Basara emptied the bucket in the entryway, dropped the soiled rag inside, and grabbed the stool.
“It will be a hard journey, and you will need to convince the Afarit to allow you to meet him.
Without a guide and someone to provide an introduction, you have no chance.”
“I have nothing to offer but my armor and my body.”
“You could sell your Habha.
Many would pay a high price for him.”
Ceil looked to Coby who was preening his damp feathers.
“He is not mine to sell.
He accompanies me of his own will.”
“You can think on your options later.
It will grow dark soon, and you are welcome to stay.” Basara beckoned Ceil to follow her into the next room.
“Sit where comfortable.”
The room was not much larger than the entryway.
There was no furniture, only large cushions lining the base of the walls sitting atop a wide and thick rug of interchanging orange and red diamond patterns spreading out from the center.
The rug covered all but the entry-side of the room allowing for a path to walk without stepping on it.
Two identical but smaller rugs also spread across the right and far walls adding to the room’s warmth.
To the left was a stairway down to a lower room, the wall nearby open like a balcony above it.
Most of the home was underground.
Below, Basara’s two daughters dressed themselves while Zose carried two buckets of clouded water up the steps, dumping them out the entryway as Basara had.
Ceil sat back into a cushion in the corner and watched Zose return three more times with full buckets.
“Where do you draw your water?” she asked.
“We have a well in the room right below this one,” the eldest daughter explained pointing straight down.
She sat down on a cushion next to Ceil and tucked her legs under her and to the side, almost leaning on Ceil.
She wore a similar Nymph gown of pristine white that only made her now glistening orange hair even more vibrant.
“Zose dug it after mother bought the house.
She heats the water with magic for us when we need it.”
“Can Basara use magic?”
“I can,” Basara answered as she returned from the room below.
“Nymphs cannot use magic, but half-nymphs can.” She sat on the other side of her daughter who quickly shifted the position of her legs to now lean against her mother.
“My affinity to fire is stronger than both minums and elves because I am half fire nymph.”
Ceil’s eyes fell to the rug.
Chloe could have easily been considered a half-Maenad if she was from Whinhlem.
Her fire was so powerful, and because of that power, Ceil relied too heavily on her, leading to constant injury, capture, and eventually death, falling into that bottomless fissure.
Tolmyur didn’t kill Chloe.
She did.
Ceil didn’t want to say or hear anymore.
She pulled her legs to her chest and hid her face in her arms.
Coby approached with a light cry, and Ceil grabbed him, pulling him into an embrace as she once again fought back her tears.
He struggled at first but soon submitted to his fate.
“Dana, keep her company while your father and I talk,” Basara asked.
“You too,” Zose said as he pushed the youngest in Ceil’s direction after retrieving a bucket from her.
He had finished draining the bath, and his daughter wanted to help with the final bucket.
After dumping the final bucket, Zose and Basara walked together down to the lower rooms.

Chapter 3
“An Urgent Message”
Zose
Zose followed Basara down the steps and under the top room.
A small prep station with an oiled iron plate sat against the right wall for food preparation.
Basara only needed to heat the plate to cook, removing the need for kindling or fuel.
The well sat in the center of the room, and a large, raised bath was positioned in the corner to the left, large enough for the family to bathe together comfortably.
A spout at one end facilitated draining the bath water into a bucket, removing the need to draw the water out.
Across the kitchen an opening led to remnants of ruins dug out and repurposed into living quarters.
A large curtain divided the room between the parents’ and children’s portions.
Like the lounge above, both sides of the room were covered with large rugs and filled with plentiful cushions, only long and flat for sleep instead of relaxation.
Basara sat on their bed of piled cushions, and Zose sat beside her.
“That girl, she is the missing wife of Emperor Yuro,” she spoke in a quieted, worried voice.
Zose crossed his legs and leaned forward, fiddling with his fingers in his lap.
“She called herself a concubine, and I do not get the impression she was lying.
Concubines are outlawed in all but Vallen, and I heard her say she is part fairy.
The royal family would not take a mixed breed as a wife.
There was no lie in her voice, and she does not seem to be one skilled with lying.
She struggles enough to hide her own emotions.”
“She has two tails, as the wanted posters claim.”
“Could she not be another with two tails?”
“That would be rarer than even you, a renegade sire.
Where did you find her?”
“She fled north from Vallen to escape the Tolmyur invasion.
I found her huddled on the pass on my way back from exterminating the Lurr in Hurno Quarry.”
“You already suspected it, didn’t you.”
Zose nodded.
He suspected, but he did not want to believe his suspicions.
“The only reason Jethro would eliminate the fairies is if he was searching for her there.
His wrath was always direct, never indiscriminate.
He has fallen further in this past year.” Basara turned Zose to face her.
“We cannot hide her here.” Her existence was too potent a threat for their family, especially their young daughters.
“Abandoning her in the wilderlands is a death sentence.
Eventually someone will grow suspicious or assault her and learn who she is.
The bounty on her is a king’s treasury.”
“After I saw her tails, I suggested she seek out a guide to bring her to audience with Bydrofe,” Basara explained.
Zose thought in silence for a moment.
“She will never be permitted to see him.
She may be royalty, but royal visits to the titans must come with forward announcements.
They must come with gifts equivalent to the honor of meeting a guardian of Whinhlem.
They come with fanfare and processions enough for a festival.
Ceil has none of these.”
“That is why it may be easier for her.
Fallen royalty is no more than a commoner to the Afarit.
Wealth is not what the Afarit desire.”
“Proof of conviction…” Zose realized, his voice trailing off as the idea slowly grew in his mind.
This might be the surest option, especially if the Afarit would not see Ceil as royalty.
“But, in Ceil’s position, the only offering she could make that is great enough is her life.
Anything less would never pass Afarit scrutiny.”
Basara saw in Zose’s slowly falling brow that he was about to reject her suggestion.
He did not see the vital key Jethro gave them.
“We do not need Ceil to forfeit her life.
We only need the threat of it.”
Zose’s eyes widened as the brilliance of his wife filled in all the gaps.
He looked over at her, amazed.
The threat to Ceil had to be real and present.
Jethro and Tolmyur needed to be involved directly for the plan to work.
Basara’s voice grew weak.
“I understand Jethro’s ire, but he is ruining himself, Amel, and Tolmyur.
We should let Bydrofe decide if Jethro’s actions are justified.
Perhaps only he can turn him from his course.”
Basara leaned into Zose’s shoulder.
He knew she was committed to him and their daughters, and her love was true, but he also understood her longing and sorrow over her former companion.
She left Jethro because she could not stop him.
Basara suggested this route not only for Ceil but also for Jethro.

* * *
Zose woke early in the morning before Basara and his daughters.
Ceil lay between Dana and Emal wrapped in their arms with her Habha perched near her head.
He was awake staring at Zose but did not make a sound.
The creature was intelligent, at least enough not to disturb his master or the sleeping children.
To Zose, Coby almost appeared as Ceil’s guardian more than she his master.
Zose bowed lightly to the regal hawk who bowed back as he left the room.
It was truly a peculiar thing to see such a territorial and aggressive bird keeping watch over the young so silently.
Perhaps Coby was trained from an eyas, but to Zose’s knowledge the Amelian royalty had never employed taming practices like hawking although they did breed hounds.
Even if hawking was a recent development, no sane hawker would raise a Habha.
Zose had use for a bird, a message to be delivered, but he could not use Coby.
Ib’nua trained birds, and he was leaving early to claim the swiftest before others could.
On his way through the prep room, Zose grabbed a roll from a small box at the end of the counter.
Its dry crust cracked in his teeth, but the dark bitter bread underneath was soft.
In the next room, he penned out his message by tallow candlelight on a thin strip of parchment that could be fastened around a messenger bird’s leg.
It was brief, but the recipient would understand the meaning.
Zose grabbed his cloak from a rack by the entryway.
Both his and Ceil’s armor and equipment hung on similar racks to dry, Basara and he having cleaned them after their private discussion the previous evening.
Ceil’s armor contained plates of resfahil intermixed with the other metals--a critical find.
Taking Ceil through a portal would be fatal, although there was little chance of that happening yet.
There were no spatial mages in Ib’nua and very few in the wilderlands.
Anyone with spatial magic proficiency would easily be able to secure employment elsewhere, so those in the wilderlands were often dangerous sorts in the employment of even more dangerous company.
At least the amount of resfahil would provide excellent magic resistance so long as it was not precision magic aimed where the metal did not cover.
Much of the mud frosted over at night, crunching beneath Zose’s boots.
The hard, uneven ground complicated his simple walk down the road.
He paid attention to where he set each foot in the dark so that he wouldn’t trip or roll his ankle.
Few were out in the dark of the early morning sending out puffs of breath in the frigid air, but more would appear the closer he got to the central commerce hub of Ib’nua.
Merchants and traders often woke early, and so he needed to as well.
The commerce hall was not a guild--such formal organizations did not exist in the wilderlands.

It was merely a location where the people of Ib’nua gathered for trade and other transactions between fellow businessmen and women outside their dealings with general customers, mostly to secure products for the day, pay debts, collect on contracts, and hire services.
Messenger birds were one of those services.
Half wood and half stone, it cut into one of the mounded hills to make use of the ruins underneath and resembled a warehouse more than a shop or home.
The deepest part of the structure was the home of a private lender.
Monetary exchanged did not use coins but rare metals weighted and stamped with the metal’s purity.
It was this lender and his stores of gold and silver that caused merchants and traders to congregate here for business.
For the sake of the community, he never charged for the use of his facilities for business.
The congregation of merchants earned him plenty through the exchange of the rare metals.
Mornings were often long and dark in the valley, but that did not stop the bustle of business.
The commerce hall was the busiest location in town before the sun rose high enough on the horizon beyond the mountains to light the sky.
Shortly after the valley was bathed in the shadow of the mountains, not the blanket of night, the hall would almost grow deserted as the merchants and traders moved to their shops.
Zose weaved through the crowd of boisterous voices and bulk product to stone steps in the back of the hall.
The aviary for messenger birds sat on the second floor.
The high-pitched calls of the birds pierced even the cacophony of business.
Like the merchants and traders, the birds too had learned to wake before the rise of the sun.
“Do you know of any spatial mages in town,” Zose asked Amor, the manager of the aviary, a rather elderly fairy who trained his birds by flying with them to their destinations.
“None to my knowledge, hunter,” Amor replied promptly.
“Have an urgent message?”
“I need a spik to Amel if you have one.
Your fastest.”
“We have one spik trained for Amel.
High cost, but it will get there in six days.”
Zose set his coin pouch on the table by the cage door.
Amor loosed the tie and emptied the shards of silver onto the table.
He inspected the stamped imprints and separated the shards into their four purity ranks, weighed them, and shook his head.
“You are short by over half.”

Zose thought he brought enough to hire four of the swiftest birds--all the disposable silver he and Basara had on hand--but Amel was far, so hiring a bird, especially one as fickle and troublesome to train as a spik, was sure to be expensive.
Every message sent was a possibility the messenger would not return, and he was paying that insurance.
“I have a contract still to collect.
Can you hold sale of the spik until I return?”
Amor claimed two of the smaller shards of low purity not caring to weigh them.
“Be quick.”
Zose rushed down the stairs and into the repurposed ruins.
The money lenders handled payments of hunter mercenary contracts.
The pay was deposited there in reserve for when the contract was completed, and the lender kept a small portion of the reward for bookkeeping and handling costs.
He cut to an empty counter before an approaching merchant had the chance to claim it.
“Zose, glad to see you returned safe.
After the first hunter failed, I was worried you might as well.
I assume you completed the contract instead of fleeing?” Jit, a pixy and owner of the commerce hall, smiled at Zose.
His light voice showed his confidence in Zose’s skill as a hunter mercenary.

Zose and Basara had bought their home from him, and Jit’s curiosity about a nymph couple relocating to Ib’nua led to a number of drink invitations and eventually a deep relationship between Zose’s family and the man who was the center of commerce in Ib’nua.
“The contract is complete.
A matter arose that requires me to claim the reward immediately.”
“We will send out inspectors to Hurno Quarry, but it will take about seven days.”
“Immediately,” Zose repeated.
Jit raised a judgmental eyebrow, so Zose clarified.
“I would like to take out a loan against the reward for the elimination of the chimera.”
Jit nodded and flew off to the back wall where piles of parchment sat atop rows and rows of shelves.
He grabbed a sheet larger than him and returned, setting the leger on the table.
“Here is your contract.
Please sign the amount to forward from the reward and provide a blood-print.”
Zose signed for double the estimated value the aviary manager said he lacked.
He did not want to short his reward by paying usury on more than what was needed.
In matters of business, Jit treated friends no different than any other customer.
Whatever remained he would return to Basara for home spending.
Zose pricked his forefinger on a provided knife and pressed it beside his name and loan value.
Jit waved his hand.
A spriggan quickly grabbed the ledger and retrieved the metal weight and purity, far too heavy for a pixy to carry.
“My thanks.”
Zose returned to the aviary and set the additional silver shards on the table to be weighed.
“The message,” Amor requested, and Zose handed over the tiny roll of parchment.
The fairy was about to walk through the door of the cage, but Zose clasped his hand on his shoulder.
“Amor, in front of me, please,” Zose asked.
The secrecy of the message was too important for him to take any chances of foul play, not that he had any doubt in the established aviary manager.
His request for visibility was more for peace of mind.
Amor handed back the message and retrieved the spik.
It was a small bird with sharp, angular wings in flight like the head of an arrow.
Like Habha, it had a natural wind affinity that further improved its speed but lacked the intelligence to utilize it outside of flight.
Spiks were certainly more agile, but Zose did not know who would win in an all-out race between a spik and a Habha.
The spik hopped off Amor’s hand onto the table.
Although its focus jittered about, it did not fly off.
Its curious inspection of its surroundings ceased immediately with a light whistled click of the fairy’s tongue.
It rolled onto its back sticking its feet up into the air--perfectly trained.
Amor retrieved Zose’s message and wrapped it around the spik’s leg.
He then wrapped another strip of parchment dyed black, the same color of the spik’s plumage, to the other leg to counterbalance the message.
As fast and agile as spiks were, even slight imbalances could complicate flight, at least enough to prevent it from flying at top speed.
“To calm your worries, you may be the one to release it.
Extend your hand.”
Zose held out his hand, and the spik hopped on it after a different tonal click from its trainer.
Zose followed to the aviary window and sent the bird off into the dark morning.
It immediately headed south out of view.
The spik rose high into the air until the cold wind chilled it through its feathers.
Spiks were a cold-weather, mountain-dwelling bird.
Unless hit directly with ice magic, no cold would hinder it.
It ignored the winding path for the earth-bound travelers and rose higher and higher over the first of many Nuanae ridges, only it did not travel much further.
It descended to a small shack post in the snow-dusted forest, entering the window.
“Inym, we have a black tag.
Urgent message,” a thickly robed spriggan announced.
He shivered in the airy shack, his race naturally unaccustomed to such cold climes.
The spik hopped along the windowsill waiting for someone to retrieve the message.
“Don’t just stand there,” an emaciated female troll rebuked.
“Read it, and if it’s personal, send the spik on its way.”
Known only to the influential heads of Ib’nua, all urgent messages were screened whether sent by land post or air to prepare against any information that might hint of danger to Ib’nua’s community.
The spriggan clicked his tongue, and the spik rolled to its back for him to retrieve the message.
“I cannot read it.
I think it’s a Tolmyurin tongue or similar, but not Minum.”
Inym snagged the thin strip of parchment away.
“Check the destination.”
Spreading the breast feathers of the spik revealed a small, branded scar.
“Amel.
What fool would be sending a message there?”
Inym did not know whether to be excited or scared.
“We have the one you seek at the Afarit.
No sender name.” The implications were indeed dangerous.
There was only one reason why this message would be sent to the Tolmyur-controlled former capital of the Amelian Empire, and spiks were too expensive to send unless the sender was absolutely sure.
The wife of Emperor Yuro was found.
She was at or near Ib’nua, and someone was planning on claiming the bounty, a king’s bounty, enough to buy all of Ib’nua thrice over.
“Does that mean Tolmyur will be coming to Ib’nua?” The spriggan rose in a panic.
He too had realized the meaning of the message.
“No,” she replied.
“No.
Ib’nua was not mentioned.
The sender did not want to burden the city or endanger whatever livelihood they have there.
They probably want to involve Hain-henel, the Lord of Contracts, to make certain Tolmyur would not cross them.” A grin spread on her face.
They were the only two other than the sender who knew the wife was here.
“We cannot send this message.
The wilderlands are not unified enough to defend against Tolmyur.
Keep the spik here for its duration.
I’ll inform Jit.”
Inym wrapped a thick leather cloak over her shoulders and walked out into the chill.
Her hunter mercenary blood that had long grown stale now boiled with adrenaline-fueled excitement.
She was too weak to capture or kill the wife and sender of the message, at least by force, but she had connections who would be more than willing to share in such a bounty.
She only needed to discover the identity of the sender.
Chapter 4 “Rumors” Ceil
“You should eat,” Basara ordered from over her shoulder as Dana and Emal hurried their emptied bowls to the small wash basin near the well.
Ceil sat on a cushion in the corner of the room between the bath and entry to the bedroom.

On the small, low table not unlike those she saw in Revlan sat a bitter dark roll, a bowl of stew, and a platter of thick cream almost exhausted from Basara and her daughters having used it to soften the flavor of their bitter rolls.
“I can tell how famished you are by your complexion.
Did Zose not feed you on your journey here?”
“He did… He tried,” Ceil corrected.
She did not want Basara to misunderstand.
“I do not have an appetite.”
“Because of what’s happening in Vallen?” Basara flash-heated her daughters’ washed earthenware bowls to dry them and set them back on the counter.
She nudged her daughters off to the adjacent room with the stairway where they immediately latched onto Coby.
She then knelt across the table from Ceil.
“If you plan on traveling north to see Bydrofe, you will need your strength.
Eat.” Basara held her hand over the bowl to heat it again.
“You are forbidden from leaving that cushion until your food is gone.”
Ceil shrunk under Basara’s gaze.
Her eyes had an immense weight to them, but at the same time they were comforting, like a heavy fur quilt.
Ceil snapped a piece off the roll’s crust and wiped it in the cream.
“Good,” Basara said.
This home of a nymph and half nymph was too comforting, too welcoming, and that terrified Ceil.
Ib’nua was close to Vallen, perhaps only seven or eight days away from Revlan.
Death and destruction followed her, and her very presence was a danger to this loving family.
They were not like the immortal sprites who had nothing to fear from Jethro or Tolmyur.
Ceil wanted to hide under that heavy, warm quilt, and let others deal with the evils of the world, but she would kill Zose, Basara, Dana, and Emal as she had everyone else if she stayed.
It was she whom those evils hunted.
Ceil swallowed a mouthful of the chunky stew.
It lacked flavor, much like the skewer from before.
Perhaps spices were not available in Ib’nua, or at least at a price Zose and Basara could afford.
“Where can I find a guide to take me to Bydrofe?” Ceil asked.
“You do not need to worry about that.
Zose and I talked last night, and he has agreed to guide you,” Basara explained.
The roll cracked in Ceil’s grip.
Her fear stuttered her reply.
“No… No, I can’t have you… I can’t let Zose guide me.
It would be--”
“Dangerous?” Basara interrupted.
“Wouldn’t it then be dangerous for any guide you hired?
What makes Zose different?
Because we took you in and welcomed you into our home?
Any guide you hire will have a life of their own and possibly a family of their own.
The only difference is that you do not know about them, so your conscience will be clearer.”
Ceil could not offer a rebuttal.
“And how would you pay?
Your body and armor as you said before?
Pay your guide the resfahil upfront and let him bed you every night of your journey?
Those small shards of fahil may help cover travel costs, but your guide can’t live off sex.
There is no guide who would take such payment, and anyone who would should not be trusted.
You will find yourself sold to a brothel or worse.”
“I’ve been sold before…”
Basara knelt back down and leaned over the table to look Ceil squarely in the eyes.
Ceil’s gaze reflexively drifted downward to stare at her still unfinished breakfast.
“Accept our offer.
It is the best you are going to get.”
“Why would you help me?
What would you gain from this?”
“We also want this war to end, but Zose or I supplicating Bydrofe will not sway him to action.
What would we complain about?
The decline of economic flow into Ib’nua from the fallen empire?
Stories we have heard from those who have fled into the wilderlands?
It must be you, someone displaced by Tolmyur’s invasion, and we want to help.”
Ceil considered telling Basara who she was.
If Basara knew, then she would better understand the danger her very presence would cause them and their family.
Tolmyur would continue hunting her down, and if Zose was there when they found her, he would not survive.
“Eat.” Basara lifted Ceil’s bowl and pushed it to her chest.
Again the stew reheated, and the hot bowl stung where it touched.
“Don’t make me ask again.
I will not reheat it a third time.
Eat it warm now or eat it cold.
Your choice.” She walked away to the next room to help Dana pull Emal off the distressed Habha.
Ceil quickly finished her meal.
She needed to leave, to be rid of this family before she could harm them.
They were too goodwilled, and their goodwill would ruin them if directed at her.
She dropped her bowl in the wash basin by the well and hurried up the stairs, calling Coby.
He rose with a flap of his wings, his wingspan nearly the width of the stairway room.
The gust that launched him up and over the main-floor balcony knocked Basara and her daughters to the floor.
Ceil turned into the entryway and ran face-first into Zose, knocking her to her back.
Zose’s footing was solid.
He did not move.
“Running off?” he asked.
Basara rushed up the stairs but slowed when she saw Zose.
Ceil could hear Emal whimpering below and Dana trying to console her.
“Here, this is what’s left over.” Zose handed Basara a small coin purse.
“I had to take out a small loan against the Lurr contract to pay for it.”
Ceil expected to be scolded, but Basara only retrieved the purse with a rigid hand and returned downstairs.
Zose extended his hand to Ceil.
She accepted it, and he pulled her to her feet.
“We can leave tomorrow as soon as preparations are made.
Going unprepared into the wilderlands is suicide, especially in winter.”
Coby hopped around anxiously fluttering his wings, not knowing what Ceil wanted to do.
“We are not leaving yet,” she told him while caressing the side of his beak.
She resigned herself to the goodwill of this odd nymph family.
For better or worse.
The next morning, Basara helped Ceil don her armor and even provided her a thin Tolmyurin sword.
“For when your staff cannot help you.

It was mine from the Coastal War.” The hamadryad staff was currently half of its full length and could be used as a weapon, but lacking its benefit of reach, a sword would be more practical in close-proximity combat.
At least growing the stubborn wood proved beneficial, yet difficult, practice of Ceil’s life magic.
“I will make certain Zose returns with it,” Ceil promised.
No matter what may come of her, she wanted Zose to return to his family.
I will die this time before I let anyone else.
Ceil retrieved the cloak Zose held out.
“Coby.”
Coby tried to hop forward into the entryway but was held back by Emal.
Despite the scare the previous day, the young girl had grown attached to the hawk that stood taller than her.
She cried out in protest when Basara pried her away.
Coby trilled at the crying girl and hopped backwards into the entryway, never breaking eye contact until the last moment when Ceil led him outside.
“Habha are far more affable than I could have ever imagined.
Emal is going to be heartbroken.
Perhaps we should think of taming one too.
I have made trips to Fiorrae before.”
“I advise against it.
Coby is an odd one, and the one who tamed him… Sammy, she was an odd one too…” Ceil’s pace slowed.
“Perhaps you could tell me the story of how you and Sammy met, and if you know, how she tamed Coby.
I would consider that payment enough for guiding you.”
“That cannot be enough compensation.”
“You will understand when you have children.
You can never put a price on your child’s happiness.
We will have plenty of time to talk on our way.”
Ceil kept Coby close to not bother the villagers.
The number of people who stared at her had decreased now that a heavy winter cloak hid her purple jack.
Zose led her between the mounded hills to the northern edge of town.
Only a few people acknowledged Zose, but there she saw it again, the twitch of the eyes between Zose and a few others as if it was some odd form of greeting.
They exited the city north on a far more traveled road than the one leading south.
There were few who traveled to Vallen now that Tolmyur had invaded, and perhaps there were few even before.

Ceil’s only experience with the people from the wilderlands were Zose’s family and the traveling merchant who used to visit Heivleil, so she could not say for certain, but there seemed to be a general disdain for the Amelian Empire among people who lived in the wilderlands.
“So, all Sammy did was save Coby from Tolmyur soldiers and then take care of him?” Zose summarized, rather surprised.
“It was more than that, I think.
Her care and asserting authority over him might have been part of it.
Maybe speaking the language of the sprites also helped.
I do not know if all Habha can understand it or just him.
He is still independent and often hunts on his own like he is doing now.”

Coby cried from above, and Ceil thought he was about to drop his most recent catch near her as he had done so often in the past--she suspected it was on purpose to get a rise out of her--but this cry was different.
Ceil stopped.
“Something is wrong,” she said.
Coby flew down and hovered just above them, his large flapping wings spreading the snow on the pass road.
Zose quickly grew attentive and retrieved the bow from his back, nocking an arrow on the string.
Ceil looked around at the trees lining the road and the steep rock crags behind them.
She desperately wished Sammy was here to understand Coby’s cry.
A pale man walked out from behind one of the trees.
His hair was blond but with a faint green sheen.
He was not as tall as a High Elf, and his ears were not long and angular but instead curved back until becoming thin, dangling cartilage.
His thick and freely waving tail had a leaf-like fin.
Ceil had never seen a Sea Elf, a fresh-water siren, before.
“Keep thinking of something, anything,” Zose warned in a whisper.
“Do not let your mind go blank.”
“Zose, sorry to startle you,” the Sea Elf said, holding his hands up and palms turned away to show he was not armed.
“I do not want trouble.
I only want to know the identity of this girl.
I am sure you understand why.
A female elf of about two to three years in age.”
Ceil knew what the Sea Elf was suggesting.
The age was off, but she was shorter than other High Elves, so reducing her age by a year would make identifying her easier.
The wilderlands also knew Tolmyur was searching for her.
Tolmyur was not her only enemy here.
“She is unrelated.
Gein is the daughter of an acquaintance of Basara’s from Vallen.
She’s five years old, half Fairy.”
Coby fell from the air into a snowbank his flapping created beside the road.
No weapon or magic hit him.
Ceil hurried to him and quickly found herself growing dizzy.
She had heard that the voices of sirens were their greatest weapons.
The voice could not be lethal, but they could produce debilitating sounds and have even been known to knock others unconscious with tones unnoticeable to the ears.
Perhaps Zose’s warning was a countermeasure against such an attack.
She fell to her knees.
“I only want to make sure.
Others in Ib’nua have been talking, and if you don’t want them growing any more suspicious, they need proof.
Show me her tail.”
“What kind of degenerate siren would ask a young elf to reveal her tail?” Even Zose began showing signs of nausea and exhaustion.
His hands gripped the bow, but he could not draw it.
Instead, he reached for his blade, but his fingers soon grew too weak to remove it from its sheath.
“Better than her being attacked by mistake,” the Sea Elf reasoned.
His hand reached down towards Ceil.
An arrow flew from atop the crags and hit the Sea Elf in the back.
A second quickly followed.
A fairy appeared on the other side of the road and hurled an earthen spike at Zose, but he recovered in time to dodge it and fired an arrow of his own.
It hit center in the chest of the fairy.
Coby flailed about atop the snow drift and flew back into the air with a cry, but there was nothing for him to attack.
“Zose!” A Forrest Elf jumped down the crag and approached.
Zose did not show any hostility, so neither did Coby.
Ceil sat on the snow wondering what happened, her mind foggy from the imperceptible sounds of the siren.
Another elf ran to them from down the road, this one a Mountain Elf, but he was neither as tall nor with enough physique to be a normal Mountain Elf.
Mountain Elves could not grow facial hair, much like High Elves, but he had growth on his chin.
Ceil recognized him as one of the people with whom Zose exchanged those eye-movement greetings both the evening they arrived in Ib’nua and right before they left the city.
“Jeddin, Dyson, you cut that too close,” Zose said with a shake of his head.
“To think they would grow suspicious that fast.”
“I expected you to be followed, not ambushed.
I wouldn’t have caught up in time,” Dyson replied with a small-fanged grin.
“You are lucky spriggans are quick on their feet.”
“When you told us that danger might be following you, I wondered what kind of mess you got yourself into.
You should know that with such a bounty on the widow of Yuro that traveling with an elf girl would be dangerous,” the other rebuked.
“She’s half fairy and fled from Vallen.
I am taking her where she will be safe.
We already had that attack on an elf girl in Ib’nua a few days before I headed for Hurno Quarry.
I didn’t want Gein to be caught up in all that.”
“Who are they,” Ceil asked, unable to understand the wilderlands language they conversed in.
A few of the words were similar to Elven, but the grammar was different enough that Ceil could not make any sense of it.
“Hunter mercenary acquaintances of mine, Jeddin and Dyson,” Zose introduced pointing to the Forrest Elf and Mountain Elf respectively.
“I told them trouble might follow me and asked them to watch for suspicious activity as we left Ib’nua.”
“You could at least call us friends,” Dyson chided.
“There are no friends among hunter mercenaries.
You know that,” Jeddin replied while stripping the Sea Elf of what usable equipment he had.
Clearly this was the case, baffling to Ceil as it was.
The Sea Elf seemed to know Zose, but Zose and his acquaintances did not hesitate to kill him just as he did not hesitate to attack Zose.
Now the two bodies were being stripped.
“What about your brother,” Dyson retorted.
“Family is different.”
“When did you speak with them,” Ceil asked Zose.
The Mountain Elf, if that was his race, knelt down and extended his hand.
“Saccadic speech.
Hunter mercenary code, miss.” His eyes twitched with slight but very specific movements.
She grabbed his hand, and he pulled her back to her feet.
“You need only glance at someone to relay a message.”
As Dyson stared into Ceil’s eyes, his expression warmed, pulling a light smile across his cheeks.
It was a strange mix of light surprise and endearment.
The more she stared, the more she found the smile blatantly flirtatious.
“Take a few breaths, and the siren fatigue will wear off,” he said.
“We should move before others come.”
Coby soared above them, now vigilant, and Zose lead their group down the road.
“Are you a Mountain Elf,” Ceil asked without realizing her question might be insulting, her mind still foggy.
Dyson laughed.
“Don’t look it, eh?
Not built enough?
You are new to the wilderlands, so I think you should know.
Drop those monikers here.
I am not an elf.
You are an elf.
Well, half-elf.
I am a troll, but also quarter human.
My grandmother was human.”
“You will find very few with pure blood outside the Amelian Empire,” Zose followed.
“Like Basara and Dyson, many in the wilderlands have human in them somewhere in their ancestry and are further mixed with other races where compatibility is possible.”
“Jeddin is a purebred spriggan, although his brother is different,” Dyson said.
“Spriggans have trouble breeding with other races except the afarit and I guess Lurr.”
“Don’t speak of me as if I am some animal,” Jeddin chided.
The light conversation helped Ceil’s mind find ground and recover, but with that recovery came a grave worry.
“If the Sea Elf… I mean siren… If he and that fairy suspected me of being the emperor’s widow, and they knew I was staying with you and Basara, wouldn’t that endanger her and your daughters?”
Ceil’s anxiety bubbled up within her.
She stopped walking.
As she feared, she placed Zose’s family in danger.
Dyson laughed again.
“I consider myself skilled in fire magic, but I do not think anyone, even an afarit, could compete with Basara.
No one would dare attack her or her daughters.
The last thief that broke into their home was left outside her entryway in an unrecognizable burning husk as a warning to anyone else that might try the same.”
“Stunk up the house for days,” Zose added.
“And my daughters know to hide in the stone at the first sign of danger.
They will be safe.”
“Never anger a maenad,” Jeddin advised.
“The more level-headed maenads will give warnings when you irritate them, but set one off and you will be fighting for your life.
How Zose managed a stable family with one is beyond me.”
“It’s quite easy,” Zose boasted.
“Just keep her happy, and you will never find a more loyal and beautiful wife!”
“Where are you planning to take Gein?” Dyson asked.
Ceil was glad they were now speaking to each other in Elven.
“The Afarit,” Zose replied.
“After the murder of that poor elf in Ib’nua, Basara and I knew she would not be safe there.
So long as we can make the right deal with Hain-henel, they will shelter her there and protect her with the full power of the city if needed.”
Ceil’s heart sank.
An innocent girl had been mistaken as her and killed.
She recalled the young girl the Gallanvale marshal tried to pass off as her to Jethro.
She recalled the girls impaled and set erect in the raised cities of Vallen.
The same was happening even in the wilderlands.
“Fleeing to the wilderlands was foolish,” Jeddin sighed.
“Where else could I have gone?
I did not have a choice,” Ceil mumbled.
“What’s your story,” Dyson asked with an expression of care.
“Basara knows the details better than me, and Gein won’t open up about it.
She was a concubine, but that’s about all I know.”
“I am the great-granddaughter of Thorn General Dharin and cousin to Royal Chief Advisor Kiri.” Ceil explained, much to Zose’s surprise.
His reply was a clear hint for her to keep silent, but she thought best that if she was to play to her fairy blood to hide her identity, she should be honest about it.
If that knowledge somehow revealed her identity, she no longer cared.
The group halted.
“Dharin?
The Dharin of Kellendale?
He is Thorn General again?
I thought he retired,” Zose said in exasperation.
“He did.
Kiri’s husband was Thorn General until he fell in defense of Amel.
Dharin reclaimed the position to fight back against the genocide in Vallen.”
“Dharin is twin to Dhurin, the late Fairy High King.
So you weren’t just any concubine but a royal consort?
By the gods…” Zose rubbed his forehead.
“It’s almost every season I learn Basara has some connection to another major power.
Now Vallen royalty?”
Ceil did not know what Basara had told him in her discussions with Zose.
She knew Zose’s claim that Basara knew Ceil was a lie, and he had even hidden her name, but his frustrations did not seem like an act.
Or if it was an act, it was terribly convincing.
Did Basara perhaps have connections with Vallen royalty and then told Zose she knew Ceil to convince him to take her to Bydrofe?
Ceil wanted to explain that she did not know Basara to try and clear up any misunderstanding that might cause tension in their family, but the ruse was now too far matured.
Dyson shook his head, seemingly understanding of Zose’s grief.
“What did you expect marrying the most famous hunter mercenary?
I’m sure she’s been all over the continent and has connections in every corner.”
“I am abstaining from contracts until winter ends, so I can help you take Gein north,” Jeddin offered.
“I was close to the elf who was murdered, so I understand why you want Gein to be safe.”
“I thought there were no friends among hunter mercenaries,” Dyson quipped.
“I hate this war as much as anyone else.
Its consequences are spreading beyond the empire’s borders.
This is my way of alleviating some of the pain caused by the warfare.”
“But war is profitable.
That’s how Zose and Basara made their fortune,” Dyson laughed.
“I don’t take mercenary work, only hunting contracts,” Jeddin said.
“I am taking contracts,” Dyson said with a smile.
“How about hiring me as a bodyguard?
I can’t do too many favors.”
“I have nothing to pay you with,” Ceil admitted.
Dyson’s warm smile returned, this time with a hint of playfulness.
“How about a taste of your skill as a royal consort?”
Zose glared at Dyson.
“A Joke,” Dyson deflected with his small-fanged grin.
“There are no good contracts in Ib’nua right now, so I was planning on heading north anyway.
I’ll travel with you, and if someone attacks you, that also puts me in danger, so I will have no choice but to fight back, right?”
“Thank you…” Ceil replied, but secretly she did not want them involved.
They were endangering themselves more than they knew by associating with her.
“One would think that with so much air on the surface, a siren would be able to think more clearly,” Inym spat.
“Now Zose will be more guarded, and that Habha is no longer leaving them.”
Inym knew the siren, Fenon.
He was only one of many who had grown suspicious of the girl Zose brought into Ib’nua.

She heard the rumors of the new arrival when she returned, and after confirming the identity of the sender through the aviary manager with a promise to take the vital message to Jit, she knew her target.
Of course, she neither told the manager the contents of the message nor inform Jit.
She did not want the information to spread too far, only to those in whom she felt she could confide and would be willing to share the bounty.
Inym took a swig of her liquid meal.
She could not approach too near because of the Habha, but she had a pixy keeping watch.
She and her three accomplices would not lose them.
Even if they did, she still had insurance.
Chapter 5 “Snuffing out Embers"
“Benab!
Kill that scout!” Thanysa hollered in a coarse voice, her chest still burning from the mud that had drowned her.
She hacked out the phlegm that clogged her throat.
She left the stone blade in the human scout beside her and spat into the grass.
The phlegm was discolored, and specks of soil remained.
Her body burned with a fever, its incessant complaint at the foreign matter lingering in her lungs.
The water mages washed both Chloe and her out to the best of their ability, but both fine silt and sharp grains remained for her body to slowly work out.
Life magic could do little against fevers unrelated to sickness.
The effects could be mitigated, but until the physical causes were removed, the fever would return.
Benab rushed ahead after the fleeing scout.
It was far in the distance on the open field barely within eyesight of the one Thanysa killed, and that scout had barely been within eyesight of another that Benab killed not moments before.
Worst off, there was a fourth that they could not reach.
Thanysa had never seen scouting tactics such as this: one scout within eyesight of two or more others to relay information using hand signals.
The information traveled between the scouts as fast as sight, impossible to stop.
Tolmyur set a net outside Revlan, and they were caught.
Thanysa sat in the yellowed grass awaiting the bad news.
“I couldn’t kill him, and there were three more who saw his flight,” Benab reported upon his return.
As she feared.
“We must speed our flight.”
“Lady Chloe cannot keep our current pace,” Benab protested.
Chloe was worse off than Thanysa, lapsing in and out of consciousness from her high fever, which was odd for a fire mage of Chloe’s caliber.
Her body had withstood far higher temperatures, but the heat was not connected to her ven.
It was biological and weakened her.
She could not tolerate the fever, even if she was unable to feel the heat because of her fire affinity.
At least that was the explanation from Tyree.
“Would you rather Tolmyur catch us?” Thanysa asked.
“No army can move as fast as a small party.”
“No, but individual platoons can.
You are a hunter Benab, not a soldier.
An army can catch fleeing injured quite easily.”
If the only injured were Thanysa with the endurance-crushing debilitation of her lungs and Tyree with her missing leg, their group could abandon them to flee faster, but Chloe could not walk.
Even though everyone was sharing the burden of carrying Chloe, she was heavy, and they could not move faster than a brisk walk for too long.
Soon, the path would grow more difficult once they reached the mountain pass.
They had fled south and then east bordering the dense forest the dryads gathered around Revlan, past the Tolmyur Camp, and then north for a day.
The road from Revlan to the wilderlands was near, and the pass through Nuanae was just beyond.
The mountains stood like a wall in an illusion of being so near due to their size but remained half a day away at pace.
The pass to Ib’nua was steep but the soil was packed.
Their pace would slow, but so would their pursuers’.
Benab extended his hand and Thanysa clasped it.
She fought the burn of her lungs as they ran north back to Kiri and the others.
Justin did not know where Coby took Ceil.
Sammy did not give the Habha a location or direction.
Their only information came from a sprite’s order to Kiri to pursue Ceil north.
With providence, Ceil was hiding or being sheltered in Ib’nua.
Tallon weaved with all haste through the trees surrounding Revlan.
The net of scouts General Bregon set when he arrived at Captain--now General--Byurk’s camp had succeeded in discovering a group of elfkind running north with abandon.
They were not citizens of Revlan but soldiers, organized in their flight.
They had a purpose, and each scout that relayed the message knew that passing this discovery to their commanders was of utmost importance.
Many of the trees closest to the north wall were uprooted by the massive vines that tore through the outer wall.
A group of soldiers stood guard on the thickest vine that their army had used to enter the city.
“Urgent message for General Bregon,” Tallon shouted as he passed the group along the top of the vine.
He was glad that the scouts sent without the city were not the ones relaying the message.
Although they too likely felt the tremors of the vines, most would not have seen the destruction of the city.
The message had travelled to the camp, and Tallon was the fastest, so Lieutenant Mackrum ordered him to inform General Bregon.
A day after the vines tore through the city, many of the vines smoldered in the flames that spread, choking the sky and darkening the city in an umber shade.
The battle against the Thorn General’s army finished earlier that morning, and the city was currently being purged.
From atop the vine, Tallon could see Tolmyur soldiers weaving like insects through the rubble killing the scattering residents.
The rubble trapped most of the residents in and prevented the remaining Revlan conscripts at the outer walls from entering to defend them.
He was glad not to be part of the massacre.
Tallon hated fighting and loathed to take a life.
Scouts never fought.
They were specifically ordered not to unless for personal survival.
This was why Tallon struggled so hard training to be fast.
His tall, lanky body was ill-suited for combat anyway, at least in his mind.
Tallon climbed the shallow incline of the vine to the central district and entered through the broken northeast curtain wall.
General Bregon remained in the largest manor while General Byurk finished his campaign by personally leading the purge of the city.
The giant at the front door opened it when Tallon approached.
General Bregon stood in the center of the entry hall where tables were moved in to create a tactical base.
A scalped ponytail was fastened to his waist, the incredible length of the hair wound into three long loops.
Tallon grimaced at the sight of such a gruesome trophy.
“General Bregon, urgent report,” Tallon announced upon his approach.
General Bregon looked up from the large, sprawled out fabric map of Vallen and the surrounding territories.
It was beautifully made, likely something that hung somewhere in the manor.
“Speak,” he ordered.
“A band of Revlan soldiers were spotted fleeing north towards the Nuanae pass.”
“Have you informed General Byurk of this?”
“No, sir.
You are the superior officer.”
“I will hold you to secrecy in what I am about to tell you.
Inform no one but General Byurk.
Tell him the humans from the other world have fled after the widow into the wilderlands.
He is ordered to assemble a swift elite squad of fifty soldiers who could survive without support from our armies.
He will lead that squad personally in recompense for letting the widow escape.
Revlan is almost cleared.
His men will not need his command to complete their task.”
Shivers trickled down Tallon’s back.
Bregon’s deep voice was calm, but the aura of his internal fury seeped throughout the room.
Tallon did not know the wife had escaped yet again.
The entire Vallen campaign began for the purpose of her capture.
So many Tolmyurin soldiers died, some Tallon knew personally, and now the wife fled the Amelian Empire.
Were they planning to begin a war against the wilderlands next?

Did Commanding General Jethro even have enough soldiers this side of the Stollmuk Mountains to begin such a harrowing campaign into hostile lands where every inhabitant was combat-hardened by their own struggle for survival?
Byurk sent away the scout.
General Bregon was indeed angry.
It was by Byurk’s suggestion that General Bregon had halted the battle between the sides of the deep fissure to negotiate the widow’s surrender.

While it was true that Byurk feared that the fairies might secret away the widow amid the conflict, he also wanted to offer her one final opportunity to end the genocide, because the stubborn fairies certainly would not surrender.
His bare feet crossed the rubble on the outer second tier of southwest Revlan.
A large vine had torn through the wall on its way to the forges and craftshops of the bottom tier before it snaked towards the central district.
All life on the surface was extinguished--he and his men made certain of it--but because of the sections of wall and buildings that cascaded from the first tier, much of the second tier was buried.
The city was full to bursting, and many had been crushed under the rubble, but there were also many pockets of air.
Survivors without an earth affinity struggled to find escape, and there was no hope for them.
Byurk felt a small body moving in the stone deep beneath his feet.
He could not tell if it was a fairy or a child.
The ven he used to search the stone pinpointed the precise location of the survivor, and he tapped his heel.
The body fell still from the spike that impaled it from above.
At this point, a quick death was a mercy for the trapped.
Lieutenant Soppet relished in the destruction of the fairies, but Byurk didn’t.

So much of Tolmyur directed their hatred to all elfkind in the Amelian Empire, but the ancestral hatred was not between Tolmyur and elfkind but between humans and elves, at least until the Coastal War that drew all Tolmyur into the conflict.
The minums’ ancestors did not originate from the ancient territory the Amelian Empire occupied.
They were from the verdant strip in northern Tolmyur between the swamplands of the north and the endless deserts of the south, and that was where they had always lived until this day.
