The giants were coastal-dwelling seamen living along the southern and eastern coasts of the desert, and like the minums, they had resided there since ancient history.

The dwarves perhaps had reason to hate elfkind, because they once shared the Stollmuk range with the golems, and by providing passage as the humans fled their homeland, the dwarves were branded as enemies and forced eastward to the already dwarven-controlled foothills of Stollmuk along the desert and verdant strip.

The minums took in the human refugees and let them settle the deserts, providing aid where possible until they officially accepted them as part of the Tolmyur Kingdom along with the partially displaced dwarves.
The giants did not join until thousands of years later.
The elves drove the humans out, not the trolls, not the spriggans or sirens or fairies or pixies or sprites or dryads or any other race of elfkind.
The Amelian Empire was not established until after the elves drove out the humans and unified the other elfkind under their banner.
Byurk followed through with the genocide because Jethro had ordered it, but it still left a bitter taste in his mouth.
Although the fairies were a member of the Amelian Empire and racial cousins of the elves, they were innocent of those ancient crimes.

Byurk estimated that there could only be a couple tens of thousands of fairies remaining on the continent, and like he had warned the widow before the assault on Revlan, fairies will surely go extinct as they are absorbed into the other races, being biologically compatible with nearly every race of elfkind, nymphs and dryads aside.
“I want to involve the wilderlands even less,” Byurk mumbled to himself.
Jethro was from the wilderlands, or at least from the time he arrived on Whinhlem.
He would never order an attack on those who dwelled there, many who also disliked the Amelian Empire.
Although the races of Tolmyur were not openly welcomed, they were tolerated in the wilderlands, which was why humans quite often tried to flee there.
With enough effort, they could secure a life in the wilds far better than they could in the barren desert.
At least two of the humans from the other world would not be with the widow.
The impossibly powerful fire mage fell to her death into the bottomless fissure.
Another of those humans, the one who controlled the Habha, was killed by General Bregon.
That only left the time mage Byurk failed to kill even in his best efforts.
He was Byurk’s sole hindrance, that and finding the widow.
Hopefully the bounty led others to capture or kill her for him.
Even without Jethro, he could pay the bounty by taking those seeking to claim it to Amel personally.
More chasing…
Byurk sighed with a deeply rooted mental exhaustion.
Now that Zose left with Ceil, Basara could no longer send him out to run errands.
She had stockpiled enough for the six or seven days he would be gone to exterminate the Lurr, but now those supplies were running thin.
She would need to trudge through the city.
Ib’nua was arguably one of the best cities in the wilderlands, but much of it was still filthy.

Both Sen’uon and the Afarit were larger and cleaner, but Sen’uon was no place to raise a family, and the Afarit would not let her set up permanent residence after she already left it to become a hunter mercenary.
The Afarit did not view highly those who took lives for profit.
Ib’nua snaked through the mounded hills, but not every valley was equal in elevation.
The lower sectors were horrendously muddy and would often flood when the snow first melted.
The wooden structures were refurbished every year because of this.
Only the residences avoid damage, being built up the sides of the hills.
The tops of the hills were spared construction and used for much needed orchards and other edible plants to help feed the populous.
The valley Basara and Zose bought their home on sat higher in elevation, so it would never come near to flooding and was far less muddy.
But still, it was filthy.
“Watch your sister while I am gone.
I won’t be long.”
Basara grabbed her purse of silver shards and walked barefoot into the muddy street.
Each step of her feet flash-dried the mud, sending steam out in her wake and hardening the ground like baked clay in a kiln.

Those on the street heading the same direction neared Basara enough to bask in her radiant warmth to ward off the cold but not close enough that their own footsteps in the mud would splatter her pristinely white nymph gown.
The few small flecks of mud that did speckle her gown dried instantly and flaked off, but a small mark of dust remained.
The city both respected and feared Basara.
If someone drenched her in mud, no one doubted the city would burn.

Flour, legumes, and root vegetables, the only vegetables that survived storage over the long winters, could be bought without traversing the muddier sections of Ib’nua, but she had run out of winter’s staple food, meat, and the butchery was in the worse section of town.
Worst meaning dirtiest.
The mud was deepest there.
The butchery never flooded in the snowmelt because it too sat just high enough up the hillside, but the valley beneath it had a small running stream year-round.

There was no bridge over the stream there--the villagers just walked through the shallow water and mud--so she made certain to cross in a finer, cleaner, part of town so that she could be on the correct side when the mud ran deep.
The amount of steam that spread with each of Basara’s steps on the softer, deeper mud greatly increased, creating a trail of fog behind her.
The smell grew foul enough to wrinkle her nose.
Refuse often pooled where the mud was deepest, and in addition, there were a few dark red streams trickling from the butchery.
The butchers let the blood and filth of their product drain into the mud and stream to be washed away.
On Basara’s way up the slick, muddy slope, a young shop-hand left the building carrying a bucket that sloshed of liquid waste from the slaughter.
He was part spriggan from his budding horns but too short, possibly half fairy.
A spriggan’s senses were keen and could be used to detect when meat was growing foul long before any other race could.
His legs were slightly deformed, common for half spriggans due to the difference in bone structure.
Spriggans were quite fast and agile, but the curse of a half-spriggan prevented them from ever running.
Many could only limp and shuffle around lacking the ability to match a normal walking pace.
At least the boy appeared to have one working knee.
Basara did not recognize him, possibly a new hire or apprentice.
The butcher was a spriggan, so perhaps the boy was her relative, a grandchild maybe, now old enough to be put to work.
The shop-hand struggled under the weight of his bucket and tipped it, spilling its crimson waste down the slope.
Before the bucket could empty, the boy’s stiff leg slipped in the slick mud, sending him and his half-emptied bucket down the hill into Basara.
His back collided with Basara’s legs, bucket and all, and she immediately dropped her heat.
The boy cried out.
He was badly burnt; his tunic fused to his back where it touched her legs.
Those who saw feared not for the boy but for themselves and fled.
The elderly butcher, Habail, peaked out the door and frightened.
She agilely slid down the mud to Basara and the boy.
“I am terribly sorry,” she pleaded, pulling the boy away and staring at Basara’s now bloody and muddied gown.
“No matter,” Basara assured her, but her heart raced in her chest, and she struggled to keep her heat from flaring out of control in her temper.
Like when Ceil tried to flee and Coby blew her and her daughters to the ground, she had to remind herself that no harm was meant.
This was only an accident.
“He’s hurt.”
“We deal with mud and bloodstains all the time.
I can clean your gown,” Habail continued, ignoring Basara’s assurance that she was not angry.
It was clear to all that she was, no matter how hard Basara tried to hide it.
“It will be as white as it was when you first wove it.”
Seeing her fellow villagers fear her to such a degree hurt, but Basara understood why.
It was the fate of a maenad’s temperament.
More than a few times Basara had injured someone in Ib’nua who triggered her temper.

Twice she had even killed: a fairy who attempted to burglarize her home and a troll who thought he could take advantage of a nymph’s hyperactive libido to sleep with her despite her claims that she was committed to her husband alone.
His argument of, “You cannot become pregnant from me, so your husband will never know,” was enough for her to bathe him in fire.
Unfortunately for him, he had an earth affinity and could not endure the heat.
“I will accept your offer, but first take him to a healer so his burns will not grow infected.” Basara wanted to pay for the treatment, but she knew Habail would not accept.
“His health is more important than my gown.” She had enough of her hair stored away to weave two more full gowns anyway.
Her hair did not grow as fast as a full-blooded nymph’s, but it grew fast enough.
Habail thanked Basara and carried the boy off.
Buying meat would have to wait for another day.
Basara did not want to walk around town in a filthy gown, so she decided to return home.
As she neared the southern side of town where the bridge across the stream was located, noisy commotion filled the air.
The sound bustled of curiosity, not conflict, so Basara chose to ignore it, at least until she saw the heads of armored elves over the crowd.
Vallen armor.
There was only one reason Vallen soldiers would be in Ib’nua, and that reason had left for the Afarit two days ago.
When those at the back of the crowd noticed Basara, they gave room for her to walk to the front of the crowd.
If she wanted to see the procession, there were none in Ib’nua who would deny her.
Most of the procession was dressed in Vallen armor, but there was only one fairy, a woman with regal demeanor who led the group through the streets.
It was the most bizarre group Basara had seen, even in the wilderlands.
There were two trolls, four elves, a spriggan, a fairy, three Melian dryads, an oread carried in a stretcher, and strangest of all, a blond-haired and fair-skinned human who should be their enemy.
He was not bound but in the center of the group beside the oread as if the group was protecting them.
The oread’s hair was not vibrant, so perhaps the woman was like Basara, half human.
Basara rushed back out of the crowd and circled around ahead of the group.
The mud had little time to dry in her hastened steps, so her feet and the hem of her gown dirtied, much to her annoyance, but she could not slow down.
The noble fairy was leading them directly to the commerce building.
They sought information, but Basara could not let them inform the brokers that Ceil was in the wilderlands.
Most the city would have known about the girl Zose brought, and those at the commerce hall would make the connection.
She could trust Jit with her life, but that trust did not extend to those who worked for him or dealt business on his property.
She slowed and walked out ahead of the group, steam in her wake, and stood in the middle of the road to block their path.
The onlookers grew nervous, especially seeing Basara’s dirtied appearance, and many of them fled.
The fairy’s eyes narrowed then widened.
“Basara,” she said.
Basara was not surprised this noble fairy knew of her.
Maenads were rare this far south, and to her knowledge, there was only one who became renown, her.
“Come,” she ordered and turned to walk down an adjacent path, diverging from the fairy’s course.
She did not look back at the fairy to see if she would follow.
She soon heard the march continue after her.
Basara stopped the party ahead of her doorway.
“Choose a select few of you to enter to speak with me, but know that no mud is allowed in my home.
I have blankets for cover.”
The fairy did not question Basara’s instructions.
She looked over her party.
“Chloe, can you walk?”
“Yes,” the oread spoke weakly.
“And Justin, Thanysa, and myself.
The rest of you, wait here.”
“I want to come too,” one of the young Melians, an anthousai, protested.
“Ib’nua homes are burrows and caves, you will not be comfortable.
Stay here.” The fairy gave no further room for argument.
The male troll lifted Chloe off the stretcher and set her down at the doorway.
Her clothes were clear of mud, having been carried by the stretcher.
The female troll entered with her, the human next, and then the fairy.
Basara entered last.
“Did you kill someone?” Dana stood in the opening to the inner home and stared confusedly at the new guests and the dried blood on her mother’s gown.
“Retrieve blankets,” Basara ordered.
Her daughter disappeared into the house.
Her guests removed their dirty armor, footwear, and leggings, wrapping themselves in the blankets Basara handed them.
Dana led each to their place in the cushioned top room to sit.
Without care for the sole man in the group, Basara removed her gown in the entryway and donned a new one Dana brought her, pristinely white, calming the anxious drum of Basara’s heart.
She tossed the soiled gown on one of the many racks.
If it could not be cleaned as promised, she would have to weave another.
Basara joined the group and sat with her back facing the stairway.
Dana had done well sitting their guests against the wall but not in the corners.
She even set the fairy in the correct position at the head, directly across from where Basara would sit.
Authority determined sitting positions.
The troll, clearly a warrior or guard, sat against the wall adjacent to Basara in the lowest guest position.
The human sat on the fairy’s left, the second highest, and the oread on the right, the third.
Basara, the host, sat without a cushion at her back and Dana beside her.
Emal, still too young to mind manners, found Chloe’s lap.
This was the first oread the girl had seen outside her family, so curiosity took over.
“Mother, I think she’s sick,” the young girl said, looking up worriedly into Chloe’s pale face.
Chloe looked pleased to have Emal in her lap and held her tightly with a smile.
If Chloe was ill, it had to be something the Melians with them could not cure, something either genetic or foreign to the biological body.
The fairy formally introduced herself as Kiri, the Chief Advisor of Vallen, and named the three accompanying her.
“May I request our discussions be in Elven,” Kiri asked, well knowing that Basara invited her into her home to relay information vital to them.
She directed her hands at the two beside her.
“These two are limited in what they can understand here, and Elven is their better language.”
As Basara expected, the oread was at least part human and likely not from the Amelian Empire.
“I can translate for them into whatever Tolmyurin tongue they are most comfortable.”
“They are not of Tolmyur,” Kiri replied, solving another curiosity.
“Unless you can speak the language of Fiorrae, of the sprites, Elven is all else they know.”
The two must be uneducated to only know two languages.
Even at a year old, Dana spoke six, and Emal was currently growing accustomed to her third.
“Understood.
We will speak in Elven,” Basara replied, changing from the Vallen tongue of the Gallanvale to Elven.
“First, I must know why you have come to the wilderlands.”
“We are searching for a kin of mine who fled the destruction of Revlan.”
Basara’s eyes fell to the diamond pattern in the very center of the carpet.
She was not aware the genocide found Revlan and that the city fell.
That news had not yet reached Ib’nua.
The noble fairy race fell to Jethro’s vengeance when they were unconnected to the source of his wrath.
As she feared, Jethro fell into madness, and her heart ached for him.
“You seek Ceil, the widow of Emperor Yuro.”
Kiri’s eyes glanced to Thanysa who kept her calm demeanor, but Basara’s experience as a hunter mercenary caught the subtle change in tension in Thanysa’s hands.
The troll was readying an attack depending on how the discussion continued.
“Thanysa, I will not tolerate hostility in my home.
I am a maenad.
To not test me,” Basara warned.
Dana shook her head lightly in caution to Thanysa and Kiri.
She would know her mother’s temper best.
Thanysa’s hands relaxed.
“I mention Ceil because she was here in my home not two days ago,” Basara continued.
“My husband found her in the pass.
He now takes her to the Afarit to supplicate Bydrofe for aid against Jethro’s armies.”

Basara told of the short time Ceil was with her family and their agreement to help her end the war, using as much detail as she could to convince her guests that this was not a fabrication and that her family was indeed aiding her.
Kiri’s face grew a mixture of surprise and relief.
She recounted the events of the fall of Revlan, including how Sammy sacrificed her life to save Ceil and send her to the wilderlands.
She was glad that even after the fall of Vallen, Ceil had not given up hope, but Basara knew the truth.
Ceil was not acting out of hope but desperation.
The girl was broken inside, and if her pleas to Bydrofe fell on deaf ears, she would not recover.
Basara’s worst fear was the creation of another Jethro, a monster of vengeance.
“If Ceil is headed for the Afarit and Bydrofe, then we must follow, but Ib’nua is all I know of the wilderlands.
Can we hire you as our guide?” Kiri asked.
“I am retired, fairy.
My daughters are my employment now.”
“You have shown that you care about our struggle, and I cannot trust another to take us,” Kiri pleaded, now on her knees.
Basara looked at Dana beside her and then an Emal playing unknown hand games she learned from Chloe during the discussions.
Dana was nearly an adult, and she could be trusted to take care of Emal.
She was not worried on her daughters’ account.
What worried her was that something might happen to the home she created with Zose.
True, Ib’nua feared her, but within that fear there were several people who hated her and wished she had not moved to Ib’nua.
The anonymity of actions taken in her absence may embolden the few.
However, the war spread beyond the race of Jethro’s ire and destroyed the fairies.
Now it spread into the wilderlands.
If she continued to ignore it, how long would she have before it came to Ib’nua and destroyed her home?
Would Zose and her daughters be safe?
Would Jethro recognize and remember her?
Would he even care enough about their history to spare her after she and her husband chose to aid his target?
The fire in Basara flickered.
It was aggravating.
The moment Zose discovered Ceil, she felt that fate was forcing her involvement, drawing her back to the past she left behind.
The fate of the maenads was to lose control, of their emotions, of their actions, of their lives and livelihoods.
Even being half-maenad, that fate clung to her, and she fought it every day.
Basara struggled so hard to create the life she now lived.
Maenads never lived among other races.
Most lived in isolation or in small covens far in the barren north so that they would not be a danger to others.
The fire inside Basara flared, heating the room.
Dana quickly stood and knelt in front of Kiri.
“Basara already declined.
Do not pressure her.” Dana’s words were a warning, not to protect Kiri and the other guests but to protect Basara from her own emotions.
Basara understood this, and the quick action of her daughter helped Basara regain composure.
Basara felt she had three choices: try to end Jethro’s destruction, wait for Jethro’s destruction to reach the life she built, or flee with her family and throw away all she had built.
Awaiting destruction was a non-option, even if there was the possibility of the war not heavily affecting the wilderlands.
If it did, it would be too late.
Likewise, fleeing was not an option because Basara felt that the war could drown the entire continent if Jethro was willing to eliminate an entire race for harboring a single person.
If the continent was to be engulfed in war, where would she flee with her family?
The rest of the world was controlled by the beastkin, and they despised both humankind and elfkind alike.
Her only choice was to stop Jethro, but deep in her heart she did not want to be involved.
That was why she wanted Ceil to supplicate Bydrofe to intervene for her.
She knew why Jethro suffered and what drove him mad.
She knew, and because she knew, she understood that had the same happened to her and her family, she would have gone mad or worse.
She was a maenad.
It would have been much worse.
But perhaps because she knew, she was the only one who could stop him.
If not by words, she might be the only person powerful enough to kill him.
The room cooled.
“I will guide you.”
Basara held Emal as she marched through the commerce hall with Dana matching each step on the hot, baked mud Basara left behind.
The few monetary exchanges being conducted in the back halted when Basara entered.
She was an odd face here.
Zose was always the one to collect on contracts or make loans or deposits.
“Jit, a word,” Basara called out.
An elderly pixy flitted over to Basara and waved for her to follow to a back room for privacy.
If Basara, not Zose, was visiting with her daughters, he feared something dire had happened.
“I have a request,” Basara began once seated.
Emal remained in her lap, and Dana stood beside her as if a partner in business.
Inside the home, Dana played like any child, but when guests visited or when outside, she acted mature, an imitation of the mother she admired.
“A contract has fallen into my hands that cannot be ignored.
Zose is out on another, so I need my daughters cared for.”
Jit flew over to Emal and tousled her hair.
In front of Basara and Zose’s daughters he was not a businessman but their godfather, one to whom both Zose and Basara had agreed to leave their daughters should something happen.
In the worst-case outcome, that may be the future awaiting them.
“How long will I be watching them,” Jit asked, already agreeing to their care.
He did not ask for payment.
This was a family request, not a business transaction.
“I cannot say.
Perhaps Zose will return before me.” Basara lifted and turned Emal to face her on her lap.
“While you are staying with Grandpa Jit, finish learning your numbers and arithmetic.
You will find no better teacher.
And Dana,” Basara continued, looking to her eldest standing beside her, “work enough for both you and your sister.
I am sure Jit could use another hand at the scales or tables.
Now, take your sister upstairs.”
Dana extended her hand and led Emal through a door leading to the stairway to Jit’s home buried deep within the hill.
Basara forgot to tell her daughters she loved them, but they knew.
“I will seal up my home when I leave, but keep an eye on it.” Basara breathed deep and exhaled slowly.
“Jit, in not too many days there may be an army from Tolmyur marching north from Vallen.
Do not hinder them.
Send them north to the Afarit.”
Jit sat cross-legged on the table in consternation.
His face twisted into a frown that soon melted into worry.
“Your contract, it is mercenary work.”
“It is.
Emal is still too young to understand, but Dana knows, as well as the possibility that I might not return.
She is a year wiser than her appearance.”
“I thought you gave up mercenary work after you left Tolmyur.”
“So did I… But, this is connected to what I left unfinished back then.”
“Do not tell me that this contract is your own,” Jit spoke slowly out of both worry and pity.
Basara could not answer.
Jit flew out of his commerce hall with haste after instructing Dana to take Emal and hide deep in his home.
Two days.
That was how long Basara’s forewarned army took to arrive at the southern entrance to Ib’nua.
When Basara had said in not too many days, Jit had assumed ten times as long at minimum.
For this army of fifty or so strong to arrive so quickly, this was no search operation or platoon sent out to scout information.
This was a pursuit party.
Jit had a hunch.
A lot of information reached his ears in his commerce center.
Zose left with a young elf woman after sending an urgent message, a message whose contents never made it to his ears by the usual secret channels.
Basara left shortly thereafter with Vallen soldiers.
Now the arrival of Tolmyur proved that Zose and Basara were involved with the missing widow of Emperor Yuro.
That was who Zose was escorting north.
The company was composed primarily of humans and a few giants dressed in light leather for mobility.
A minum led the group, his expression discontent as he stood at the front staring down into the city whose populous would not permit them to pass.
Dirm, an elderly fairy merchant who alone could nearly compete with Jit in wealth, had rallied the citizens to turn back the army.
She stood arguing with Nythem, an elderly troll and retired hunter mercenary, one of the most influential people in the city.
Nythem was advising Dirm not to make enemies of Tolmyur, but Dirm would not yield.
She had family in Vallen that she lost during the early days of the campaign.
Their argument prompted a messenger to summon Jit to break the contest of opinions, he being the third of the influential heads of Ib’nua.
“To the skies with your fairy pride, Dirm,” Jit chastised, fluttering in front of Dirm’s face and breaking up the argument.
“Do you not realize that if you turn them away, they will only come back with a greater force?”
“We are not a nation.
How can we hope to face them when all of Vallen fell,” Nythem finished.
“We are decided.
You are the minority.”
“Nythem, calm the people while I talk to the commander.
I have the information he seeks,” Jit said.
“Your information networks are a blessing, Jit.
Come,” Nythem ordered Dirm with a nudge of his shin to her hip.
Dirm drew a dagger and swiped at his leg, but the knife of an old fairy would never touch one who spent most his life as a hunter mercenary, even in Nythem’s withered years.
“Touch me again and I will remove your leg at the knee.” She glared back at the minum commander before returning with Nythem to the gathered populous.
“I apologize for the commotion, commander of Tolmyur,” Jit said as greeting to the patient minum.
“We do not mean any hostility to you or yours, despite appearances.
I assume you know, but the wilderlands are a rough territory, and so its people are just as rough.
Expect the same at any city you find in your pursuits and know they do not mean harm.” Jit bowed.
“I am Jit, money lender and exchanger of Ib’nua.”
“I know the wilds all too well.
I was a hunter mercenary in my younger years.
I am General Byurk of Tolmyur.
We are here in pursuit of--”
“Do not speak further,” Jit interrupted, angering the soldiers listening intently to the discussion.
Their hands reached for their blades, which Jit found comical.
They must have quite the confidence in their skill to strike down a pixie.
“I mean no offence, General Byurk.
You do not know where hidden ears may be located here in the wilds.
I want to avoid unnecessary conflict in Ib’nua.
I know why you are here and carry a message for you.”
General Byurk’s expression immediately improved.
“Speak.”
“Head north to the Afarit.”
Byurk’s lips curled back into a frown.
“Is that all to the message,” he asked after swallowing his annoyance.
“I can guarantee its credibility, as well as the credibility of the sender who requested I inform you when you arrived.”
“Who is the sender,” he asked in return, his eyes not accepting silence as an answer.
“You will likely meet her if you travel north.”
Jit did not speak further to protect those who are living in Ib’nua, especially Dana and Emal.
The general could understand the “she” as being the widow or the identity of the sender or perhaps that they were both one and the same.
It did not matter.
“Keep to the main road as you pass through Ib’nua.
Few will bother you, but do not expect a welcome here.
Go north,” Jit repeated as he flew off.
He prayed that Basara and Zose would survive this, and deep down he was livid that they involved themselves in something as dangerous as a war when they had a family.
Mercenary work was the job of those without a home to return to.
Basara should know this.
She retired immediately when she started a family and even forbade Zose from mercenary work.
“What are you two thinking?”

Chapter 6
“Decisions Made in Secret”
Miriam
Back on Earth, Miriam was fighting desperately for her life.
A blade broke through her hastily conjured stone baton with ease and collided with the side of her face.
The blade slid across the side of her head to her cheek and flicked off the edge of her jaw.
If her body wasn’t reinforced with earth magic, she did not doubt that the sharp stone would have cut deep into her skull, killing her instantly.
Even with Eydis’s skill in life magic, Miriam could not be raised from the dead.
She grabbed the wrist of her opponent’s outstretched arm.

Ven surged through her core, enhanced through the orientation of the wellpoints of her groin to her stomach, right breast and shoulder, and then extending down her right arm into the fist that struck her opponent’s side.
The wave recoiled through her system numbing her arm up to her shoulder.
Only about half the force passed to her target.
Her opponent was not only reinforced like her, but she knew the stances to counter the ven of her strike.
Miriam received just as much damage as she dealt.
A second blade ran into her stomach.
It did not penetrate, but the force of the impact nearly made her vomit again.
She had twice already during the fight.
Another thrust and Miriam was forced to release her grip.
The two blades, now free, returned in a flurry of strikes at her stomach, chest, and forearms as she desperately fought to block her face.
The blades could not cut her nor would they leave a bruise so long as her ven lasted, but each strike hurt nearly as much as if they had cut.
Her nerves reacted to the strikes all the same.
Miriam could feel the onset of shivers, the signs of her ven running low.
Again, she couldn’t last the entire session.
One final kick to her stomach, and Miriam was sent tumbling over the mat.
She sprawled on her back, momentarily lacking the energy to stand.
“You fail again.” Symra extended her hand to Miriam who clasped it and rose to her shaking legs.
Meanwhile, two sanitation personnel quickly entered the arena to clean the vomit and sterilized the mat.
“This is your sixth failure.
You are barred from advancement exams for…” Symra paused to calculate the time by Earth’s reckoning, “two months and fourteen days.
Use that time to improve yourself.”
“Damn, I thought I could do it this time,” Miriam grumbled.
“Are you still against giving me some pointers?”
“You are a yeth in fourth.
Advancement to nenin in first must be done through your own efforts.
It is a mountain one must climb alone.
There are many whose practice ends here, but you have potential.
I trust you will overcome it.”
“You don’t show any mercy.
Makes me nervous for my advancement examination,” one of the observers mused.
“That blow to the head would have killed me.”
“It most certainly would have, Alexander, but you are not an earth mage as she is.
Advancement examinations must be as close to true combat as possible, or they are meaningless.
At its core, this art is meant to kill, but I will be using blunt weaponry for you.
Even so, permanent injury is always a possibility.

Come.”
Miriam walked off the mat and raised her hand.
Alexander swatted it lightly as he passed.
“Good luck,” she said before standing beside the remaining three observers and rinsing her mouth out with her water bottle.
She had grown accustomed to the taste of her own sick over these intense matches, something she would never admit to anyone, but there was one person who would notice the taste or smell, Sean.
“Does Symra ever tire,” Kim asked, one of Eydis’s former students from the self-defense class.
Miriam had tried to contact as many of Eydis’s students as possible as potential candidates for the government’s secret magic lessons.
Some of them died in the attack on Gullivan, most refused to get involved, and in the end only Kim agreed to join.
“Must be something about being a Mountain Elf.
If not, she is just far more fit than us,” Miriam replied while watching Alexander, a former Navy SEAL, hit the mat after only a few seconds of sparring.
He was one of the few hand-selected military personnel who were found to have an affinity, water.
Barring any use of ven or wellpoints, he could spar with Symra nearly as her equal, but without handicaps he was nothing more than a punching bag.
He was a bem in fourth, the degree below Miriam and attempting to become a yeth.
Yeth was only the second rank.
Each rank had four stages before one could attempt advancement to the next rank.
Advancement was terribly difficult, involving staged death-matches.
On Whinhlem, such matches were no cause for concern due to life magic.
Symra explained that the pain of combat was an important teacher, and the fear of death was a barrier to overcome quickly.
But she was going easier on them because life magic was not accessible on Earth, and Earth’s medical capabilities were “primitive” by Symra’s assessment.
Miriam could not believe that Eydis endured such extreme training despite being the first princess and heir to the Amelian Empire.
Eydis was a lin, two ranks above Miriam and four below Symra.
“Has Symra told you the name of the art,” Thomas asked.
This was his first day as a student, but instead of instruction, he was ordered to observe the two scheduled advancement matches.
“Alex said it reminded him a little of Kali, but it is still rather different.”
“It has a name, but no one is ever taught it,” Miriam replied.
“Apparently, once you reach avein, the highest rank, you will know its name without being told.
I think that knowledge is actually required in order to reach that rank,” she elaborated, recalling what the Sylph had told her when she asked about the rankings.
The Sylph seemed to have knowledge not only about Earth but also Whinhlem.
Regrettably, even the Sylph would not give her feedback to help her improve and become a nenin.
“Is Symra an avein,” the final observer, Paul, asked.
Miriam shook her head.
“No, Symra is stuck just below it.
There was no living avein on Whinhlem that she knew about, so perhaps she is skilled enough to be one but she herself does not feel she is.”
“You pass,” Symra announced.
In the short span of their conversation, Alex had turned his initial defeat at the beginning of the match into a victory, at least a victory matching the level of his advancement.
This was his first attempt when Miriam had taken five, almost locking her into a two month ban on advancement examinations, and now she was not the only yeth.
She felt slightly disheartened because of his rate of advancement, but he had also trained in other martial arts and only needed to learn to control his ven and utilize ven wellpoints.
Miriam was his superior in that aspect, but she did not doubt he would catch up before long.
Miriam smirked to herself thinking about how much he would struggle advancing to nenin.
Wellpoints were the focus of that particular advancement, and the higher the rank, the more ven and wellpoints were integrated into combat.
If she was struggling this much, he would struggle even more.
Symra led the battered man to the edge of the mat and stood before Thomas.
“What are your opinions?
Do you want to begin training after what you have seen?”
“Yes sir,” he replied promptly.
Symra’s eyes narrowed.
“I am asking you personally.
Do you want to learn?”
“It is not a matter of wanting, I have been ordered to.”
Symra shook her head.
“Even among the palace guard, one must willfully choose to learn.
If it is by order, I refuse to teach you.
Let us leave.” Symra patted Miriam’s shoulder, beckoning her to follow.
“That is all for today,” she told the military officers who stood on the balcony observing.
The soldiers manning the cameras and other recording devices quickly began dismantling their equipment.
“You do realize that the reason you have so few students is because you always make them watch you try to kill me,” Miriam said with a smirk.
“It’s almost the same as asking if they want you to kill them.
The military keeps pleading for you to teach more of them.”
“I understand that they are trying to increase their might by combining knowledge from both our worlds, but this art is dangerous if learned through conscription.
The basics can be taught to anyone, as Her Highness has taught in your former self-defense class, but advancement requires immense willpower and drive.
Without a strong will, skills learned in later ranks can debilitate the user.
Your own world’s martial skills are sufficient enough to contend against yeth on their own.
If one does not desire to learn it, they should master this world’s arts instead.
Your world’s power is not in ven or martial skill but in its technology, is it not?
Perhaps you can improve with magic, and we have no shortage of magic students, but no matter how hard you train, your bodies will remain weaker compared to humans from Whinhlem.
You should focus instead on advancing your technology.
Tolmyur could never compete against it.”
“But Jethro’s magic can.”
“Jethro is only one man, and there is only so much one man can do alone.
I firmly believe that even if he employed the same tactics he used to conquer Amel, he would ultimately fail in your world.”

“Teleporting an army into a city…” Miriam recalled the attack on Gullivan that resulted in over 5000 deaths including Sammy, Chloe, and Justin, lives that she still felt she could have saved if she foresaw the events of the invasion better, even though the Sylph assured her that nothing would have changed the outcome.

From Symra’s account, the number of soldiers Jethro sent into Amel was many magnitudes larger than the thousand he used to attack Gullivan, and the army appeared within the city, not on the edges to fight their way in.
If he sent multiple hundreds of thousands into Gullivan, the entire city would have been destroyed before the Army had time to respond.

Nothing was stopping Jethro from attacking again, and the doppelganger of Eydis once warned that Jethro would destroy city after city looking for Eydis, so Miriam could not feel at ease no matter how much confidence Symra had in Earth’s technology.
“You were only caught unawares.
That is all.
It will be different next time if your military truly is the best in this world,” Symra assured Miriam, noticing her unease.
“I must speak with the commanders, so you are free to return home.
Rest up.
Your ven is depleted, and you do not want to grow ill from your weakened state.”
“Will you be discussing the fate of Oyak and Borgrum again?”
“Yes.
Eydis is pushing for execution, and I agree.
Your nation’s aversion to capital punishment is dangerous.
We are running out of time.
Once Oyak’s waning health claims her, nothing will stop Borgrum from rampaging.”
“You can add my agreement in your discussions if it helps.”
“I will mention it.”
Miriam parted from Symra at the end of the hallway where two National Guard personnel waited.
She watched their backs as they walked away to wherever the secret meeting would be held.
Symra acted unaffected, but she was well aware that she was being watched with nearly the same scrutiny as Oyak and Borgrum.
Symra and Eydis were not imprisoned, but Symra was required to have an armed military escort wherever she went.
The escort was not for her protection.
She was very capable on her own.
It was to subdue her or even eliminate her if she showed any sign of hostility, and Symra understood this.
Miriam was also included in the military’s list of accepted escorts, of which Miriam was grateful.
It at least meant that Symra could be at ease some of the time without suspicion breathing down her neck constantly.

Miriam left the seemingly unremarkable building into the Washington D.C. night and walked along the sidewalk with others who were completely oblivious to the otherworldly lessons in the building they passed.
The world was slowly changing in secret.
Magic was real, and another world was now in contact with Earth, but this was not known to those she passed.

Chill was beginning to return to the air as the seasons changed, but it was not strong enough for Miriam to require a jacket, especially after the intense struggle of her advancement match that still made her sweat.
She took the nearest subway and stood silently in the corner of her car until her stop.
Moments when she was alone to herself were important.
If her mind was too active on other things, she often found hearing the Sylph difficult.
Although the Sylph could appear in front of her and converse with her if needed, most communication came through messages in her mind, often as quiet as a whisper.
The Sylph was the north wind.
She had responsibilities elsewhere and could not be with Miriam at all times.
Miriam did not want to miss any warnings or hints of danger.
She was Earth’s oracle, the only one who could hear the Sylph’s prophesies of the future.
The condo provided for Miriam and Sean was certainly not high class, but it was also not decrepit.
They were lower-middle-class condos owned by the government where the military was able to promise security for Sean and her.
All the tenants were government employees, and most worked for the Pentagon or another federal agency.
They had to pay rent like any other, but the price was reasonable enough for what the Pentagon paid them, considering both she and Sean worked.

Sean was Eydis’s secretary and the go-between for communications between Eydis and any other government agencies, mostly to filter the information to leave out any mention of top-secret topics when communicating with those outside proper clearance.

After the press conference where Eydis directly told the world about her identity as an elf and that the invasions would continue, the government no longer trusted Eydis to withhold sensitive information.
He was also involved with a taskforce trying to track Eydis’s doppelganger.
There was a lot the Department of Defense placed and Sean’s plate.
By comparison, Miriam’s jobs only involved helping Symra with magic and combat training as well as acting as Eydis’s caretaker.
Miriam entered the door code for the complex and walked towards the elevator.
The ride was brief, only to the second of four floors, and her walk to her door was just as brief being right beside the elevator.
She fumbled in her purse for the key with fingers that still shook from her advancement exam, but the door opened first.
“Figured that was you,” Sean said with a faint smile.
“Heard the elevator.” He held the door open for Miriam to pass, and she kissed him lightly on the lips as she did.
She was glad she remembered to wash her mouth out this time.
“How’d it go?”
“Failed again,” Miriam sighed.
“Can’t try again for two and a half months.
It’s frustrating.
Symra won’t let me help instruct until I become a nenin, so I’m getting paid to just be a student.
Doesn’t feel right.”
Sean closed the door and followed Miriam to the living room.
“You are still complaining about that?
Job training is part of any employment.
And you are taking care of Eydis.
It’s not like I’m doing a whole lot myself now that the doppelganger’s trail has gone cold.”
He watched Miriam set her purse on the back of the dining table against the wall with a shaking hand.
“I put dinner in the fridge.
I can heat it up for you before you shower.”
A small smile curled on the side of Miriam’s lips.
“I’m not all that hungry, and we can take a shower after.
I used too much ven today and could use a recharge.”
Sean shook his head lightly.
“Am I just your charging station?”
“More like a portable power bank,” Miriam quipped while latching onto his arm.
“You don’t use your ven, and it takes me three days to fully recover mine on my own.”
“Why not ask Eydis,” Sean suggested, returning Miriam’s smirk with a downward glance.
Miriam released his arm and skipped away a step.
“While I’ll admit that I would love to try it at least once, I am not a lesbian.”
Sean sighed, exasperated.
“I meant asking her to simply give you some of her ven.
She could recharge you ten times over.”
Miriam giggled.
“Are you complaining?
She could recharge you ten times over.”
At least we are at home this time.”
Sean reached over and grabbed Miriam by the arm.
She shrieked playfully as he pulled her down onto the couch.
“I used to be such an upright person before I met you.”
“You mean stuck up?
I know.”
Miriam awoke in her bed with no recollection of how she got there.
She couldn’t remember if she had fallen asleep during or after sex, and she hoped it wasn’t during.
That had happened more than just a few times since dating Sean, and it was quite a blow to any man’s self-esteem, but it certainly wasn’t Sean’s fault.

He knew exactly how to please her due to how often she requested a “recharge.” Conversion of natural ven to earth ven was physically taxing, and she had exhausted her available ven during her advancement exam, converting all of it, so she was rather exhausted.
After assessing her ven level, it was lower than expected.
Had she lasted longer, it would have been higher.
She once told him that he could continue if she fell asleep, but he refused.
He was not the type of man who would enjoy sex with a sleeping woman.
Miriam looked at Sean sleeping peacefully beside her.
He would sleep in for a while longer.
“I’ll have to apologize again,” she whispered to herself.
She kissed Sean lightly on the forehead and slid out of bed, walking naked across the room to the main bathroom for the shower she missed the evening before.
The condo had two bathrooms and three bedrooms total.
It was meant for a family, so it was a bit large for the two of them, but Eydis refused to live with them.
At least they had room for children should they ever come, but Miriam had no immediate plans for them.
She didn’t want any--not yet--and she had not been with Sean for long, but the only preventative measure they were using was her birth control pills.
Condoms blocked ven transfer by preventing the contact of the well points that facilitated it.
Pills weren’t 100% effective, so Miriam reasoned that if she did get pregnant, that was nature telling her it was time.
She would need an heir to the position of Earth’s oracle eventually anyway, and if she was being honest with herself, that responsibility was the sole reason she would ever consider having children.
Miriam dressed quickly, donned light but professional makeup, and headed out the door.
She dropped by a convenience store before heading to the subway and picked up breakfast for two.
Miriam knocked on the door to Eydis’s private office in the Pentagon, but she did not expect an answer.
It was simply out of courtesy.
After all, this office was Eydis’s home for the time being.
She unlocked and entered the dark room, flipping on the light and locking the door behind her.
There were no windows to the hallways like many of the other private offices.
There had been windows, but they were removed and replaced with noise-cancelling walls.
Much of what was openly discussed in this room should not be heard by the average employee, high security clearance or not.
“I brought breakfast,” Miriam announced, but the blanket on the couch did not stir.
She set the two plastic cases on the desk.
“I have a garden sandwich and a sausage and egg muffin.
Which one do you want?”
Miriam walked over to the loveseat and peeled back the blanket.
Eydis was curled into a ball with her knees to her chest.
She was six and a half feet tall, and the loveseat was only about four feet wide, hardly long enough for her to rest comfortably across let alone sleep on.
Eydis’s eyes were open but stared at nothing.
She wasn’t asleep, and from the shade under her eyes, she slept little.
“If you keep not sleeping, I will have no choice but to make you use one of our rooms.
We have a bed already set up for you.”
“I made Justin sleep on the couch for months, did I not?” Eydis said in a tired voice.
“This is a loveseat, not a couch.
The couch in his apartment was wider and Justin was much shorter than you.
How much did you sleep?”
“About two hours.
Maybe three.”
Miriam sighed.
“It is no problem.
Your days are much shorter on Earth.
I spent most my life staying awake longer.”
“But your nights were also longer, so you slept more.
Dr. Hengen told you to get a full night’s sleep every night or you won’t recover.”
“She knows nothing of elven biology.”
Miriam pulled Eydis to sit up and walked over to retrieve the two plastic cases.
“She’s a psychologist, and I don’t think our minds work all that different.
Which one?” She held the selection in front of Eydis.
Normally Eydis would choose the garden sandwich, but this time Eydis selected the other.
Miriam was relieved because the sausage and egg muffin was far more filling.
Eydis did not eat yesterday.
“Did you at least do your memory exercises last night while I was training with Symra?”
“They hurt, so no,” Eydis replied flatly.
“You do realize that your headaches mean that you are unwell and need to continue your treatment, right?
Recalling your past should not cause physical pain.”
“I know my past,” Eydis retorted after swallowing a small bite of her English muffin.
“I only lack the fine details, and I can do without those.
I remember Sammy, Chloe, you, Sean, and everyone else now.
I am no different than I was before I was captured.”
“Eydis FeAmel is following a dark path that will see to her ruin and the loss of many lives,” the Sylph had warned Miriam about Eydis.
“She must return to how she once was if we are to survive the coming calamity.”
The disaster that befell Gullivan was only the beginning.
Something worse, something the Sylph called a calamity was coming.
As Earth’s oracle, Miriam was tasked with preventing disaster.
The only warning she had received was about Eydis, so she needed to put all her effort into helping her recover.

So far, Sean was the only one she had revealed the prophesy to, and his suggestion was to help Eydis with her memory loss and make sure she continued meeting with Dr. Hengen, the military psychiatrist selected by the government for her specialization in PTSD and combat-related head trauma.
Miriam thought that a memory-loss specialist would be best, but Eydis was coping with far more than just memory-loss.

She was imprisoned and abused by her doppelganger, only recovering just in time to watch her best friend and the man she loved be killed in such a gruesome manner that there was nothing left of them but a shower of gore.
Eydis was clearly still unwell, shown by her lingering and strong guilt, lack of appetite, unstable emotions, insomnia, and the list went on.
Miriam was sure that if Sean had also been caught in Jethro’s blast, she would not be as calm as she was now, although she too was seeing a psychiatrist weekly.
She attributed Sean and her mental fortitude to both being even-tempered and logically minded.
Sean appeared least affected by the disaster on the outside, but Miriam knew he was handling it a little worse than her.
His nightmares persisted longer and talk of war made him tense.
He was skilled at hiding his emotions, so she was probably the only one who noticed.
“Did you pass,” Eydis asked after another bite.
Miriam chuckled.
Not even a month ago, Eydis failed to care about the daily lives of others, even her friends, so her question was a sign of recovery.
Or it could have been simple curiosity due to having gone through the same advancement process at some point in the past.
She sat down next to Eydis on the loveseat and cracked open the thin plastic casing of her sandwich.
“I am barred from advancement for two and a half months.”
Eydis nodded lightly.
“It took me over twenty tries to advance to nenin.”
The garden sandwich froze an inch from Miriam’s mouth.
“You’re joking.” If an elf trained in magic from childhood took over twenty attempts to pass, how long would it take someone with not a year’s worth of education and practice?
“I was also the human equivalent to 13 or 14 years old, so my own immaturity had much to do with it.
Symra speaks highly of you, so you should not take as long.
She had nothing but criticism for me.”
“Why did you decide to train in such a dangerous martial style?
I would have thought that they wouldn’t want to put the heir to the throne in danger.”
“I didn’t decide.
My father made me,” Eydis said with a mild scowl.
“Symra said that study had to be voluntary.”
“Normally that is the case, but it was an order from the emperor, so neither Symra nor I could refuse.
My reluctance was part of the reason she was so critical.
Once Symra realized I could no longer advance because my heart was not in it, she demanded that my father end my training.
She almost lost her position and standing because of that, but the unanimous voices of both the council and officers of the guard convinced him against it.
“My father… he was rather paranoid, almost manic, about some things.
As I got older, he began acting stranger and stranger.
He accelerated my education, but I did not mind.
I enjoy study.
He forced me to train with the elite guard under Symra when I hated fighting.
He took a young child to wife and silenced any who protested.
The only time my father ever struck me was when I complained to him after seeing how terrified Ceil was about her situation in the palace.
He even made me supply blood for creation of that doppelganger knowing well how dangerous it would be.”
Eydis stared down at her half-eaten muffin, her mind drowning in her memories.
She had not been so vocal since before the doppelganger captured her.
Her downcast gaze hidden partly behind her disheveled hair made Miriam’s chest tighten.
There was sadness and longing in her eyes.
Eydis’s father was dead, as was her mother and her brothers.
Thinking logically, much of what her father did was for Eydis’s protection.
She learned how to fight, and the doppelganger was meant as a body double.
No doubt he had done more of which Eydis was unaware.
She was alive now because of her father’s paranoia, although creating a doppelganger had backfired.
“Have you heard of the decision from last night’s meeting?” Eydis looked at Miriam through the strands of her hair hanging over her face.
Her expression was calm, but a seething flame burned behind her eyes.
“Sean should be bringing the decision when he comes later today.
For now, finish your breakfast, and I’ll take you to the public showers so you can get cleaned up.”
Eydis stood in the cold water of the shower.
The room was open and well ventilated, but heavy steam was still problematic for Eydis’s breathing.
At least close to sea-level, the air was not as thin as in Gullivan.
The chill of the water helped calm the anger burning inside but did not extinguish it.
It still smoldered with the thoughts of every person Eydis loved that was killed because of Jethro and Tolmyur.
Yesterday was the fourth time the government of this country had discussed the fate of the two Tolmyur officers captured during the attack on Gullivan.
Each time they had decided to further postpone execution, claiming that they may still be of use and citing their peaceful demeanor.
She leaned against the cement wall with her forehead resting in her arms.
The cold water cascaded down her back and ran as a thin stream from the tip of her tail that slowly grew numb from the chill.
If this government continues to let them live, I will have Symra execute them on behalf of the Amelian Empire.
Every single human of Tolmyur needed to be eradicated before they could kill anyone else.

Chapter 7
“Those Left Behind”
Fect
Fect swirled the gin in his glass lightly, the single rock of ice clanking against the sides.

His coworkers from the garage were shouting in drunken revelry already, and their night at the bar had only just begun; a bunch of lightweights, but then again, most people on Earth were from what Fect could see from the other tables.
They were celebrating Fect’s quick promotion to senior welder after only two months of working.
By chance he had walked by a maintenance welding shop as he trudged through some run-down town and noticed a small torch from the open shopfront.
Its flame bore striking similarity to the magic Jethro had taught him using a combination of wind and fire magic.
The gas flame was not as hot, so it did not cut the metal but fused it together.
One of the shop hands noticed Fect watching their work from the road and called him over.
They were surprised by his stature just as much as he was of their work.

They knew he was not a child because he let his beard grow out over the months of directionless wandering after being swept down the river away from the battle at Gullivan, his facial hair growing fuller than any of the men in the garage.
Fect asked if he could try their shop-work, and they humored him, giving simple explanations once they realized that his English was poor and that he could not understand Spanish either.
Fect picked up the skill almost immediately, and the supervisor hired him on the spot not caring that he lacked identification.
Then again, another employee at that garage also lacked identification, so that did not seem to be an issue for them.
Fect hopped off the bar stool he used instead of a chair at his table for the added height and walked to the bar counter for a refill.
His coworkers did not seem to mind his absence despite him being the reason for the trip to the bar.
They were only looking for another excuse to go out drinking.

Fect was glad to have some employment so he could legally purchase food and other necessities instead of utilizing his concealment magic to steal it, but at the same time he found it hard to feel at home here.
The garage welcomed him, but he did not feel welcome, perhaps because he came to this world as an invading soldier, killing their people.

He was their enemy, and try as he might, he could not remove that wedge driven between accepting a new life in this world and knowing that at any moment he could be discovered by this nation’s government and executed.

He was a captain of Tolmyur’s armies, not some maintenance welder, and so long as that remained true, those laughing back at the table speaking unintelligible babble in some unknown language could never truly become his comrades.
Fect felt alone.
“You have stronger than gin,” he asked once sitting atop a barstool at the counter, determined to get drunk.
“For a small guy, you can throw it back,” the bartender praised.
“You have a preference?
Vodka, whiskey, rum?”
“Strongest.”
The bartender nodded and grabbed a bottle near the top of one of the back shelves and showed it to Fect, but Fect could not read the label.
“This Bacardi is a bit more expensive, but it’ll knock you flat.
How would you like it?”
“The bottle.” Fect patted the counter.
“It’ll taste like gasoline.
How about this.
If you want rum, I’ll give you a Kryptonite.” The bartender grabbed two more bottles of rum from behind the counter.
He added spiced rum, coconut rum, and then gently poured pineapple juice and melon liqueur, finally topping it with the Bacardi.
Fect eyed the odd green drink and then downed it without so much as a slight reaction, much to the surprise of the bartender.
It was far better than the gin, not only in flavor but also because of the burn he sought, different from a flame.

Fire mages often struggled getting drunk because alcohol tricked their bodies into thinking that they were in distress, making them convert raw ven to fire ven naturally to fight that distress and burn off most the alcohol, so strong drink was always needed.
“You like it?” the bartender asked.
“Leave the bottles.
I will pay,” Fect replied.
The bartender did as asked, expecting to come back to the small man knocked out on the counter.
In this small-town bar, no one would criticize him for allowing a customer to let loose.
So long as the customer did not go overboard, no harm done.
Fect mixed the drink skillfully as he had seen and downed two more glasses, finally noticing the light buzz of drunkenness.
As he was pouring his fourth, the bottle of spiced rum slipped from his hand, but he promptly righted it before too much spilled.
It did not slip from his drunkenness.
The television in the corner of the bar displayed two familiar faces on the screen.
The first was General Oyak, and the second was unmistakably a giant.
Subtitles displayed on the screen, but Fect could not read this country’s language.
He waved over the bartender again to turn up the television.
The bartender immediately complied and raised the volume to max.
The moment the news on the television sounded over the revelry, many people grew attentive, some far too attentive, glaring at the screen.
It became clear to Fect that most people in this country had great interest in the attack on one of their cities and those involved, an attack that he took part in.
His feelings were not wrong.
These people were not his comrades.
“Where is Carswell,” Fect asked the bartender, feigning only mild interest.
“The FMC?

It’s in Fort Worth, about two hundred miles south of here.” The bartender rattled on about his uncle’s family that lived in Fort Worth, and his opinions of the attack and how his family thinks the government should just torture information out of them or execute them to appease the people.
All the while Fect listened to the brief news segment until it ended, the volume of the television was turned down, and everyone returned to their revelry.
Fect paid his bill in cash, leaving extra for the bartender’s service.
He then left without his coworkers noticing he was gone.
These people were not his comrades.
Two of his actual comrades were trapped in this world like him but imprisoned.
Fect was a captain of Tolmyur.
He had the responsibility to free them.
Walking to Fort Worth took six days.
Having abandoned his short employment, he carried only his clothes, provisions, and a fair amount of this country’s paper currency in his backpack.
Fect learned nothing about the prison complex other than its location.
He did not know where General Oyak or the giant was held in the complex or what security measures were present for their detainment.
Someone of General Oyak’s skill could not be held easily, and a giant could overpower any human of this world with little effort, but they could not escape, or they would have already.
General Oyak was one of the most loyal of the generals to Jethro, bordering religious fanaticism, so he was certain she had not struck a deal with their enemy.
Fect feared that their captors may have done something to them that would complicate the escape or make any attempt at escape impossible.
Two rows of high fence bordered most of the prison complex with bladed wire coiled about their lengths.
Two gated vehicle entrances on opposite sides gave access through the fences but were likewise just as guarded with the bladed wires.
The wire was certainly to prevent climbing, but Fect could simply cut through without issue.
He only worried about the astounding surveillance powers of this world.
He did not doubt he would be discovered if he did so, even if concealed using his magic.
A public entrance sat at one side, but visitors were not regular.

He could slip in with one of the employees of the complex using his concealment magic, but civilian buildings in the complex were not where he needed to go, and he doubted they would connect directly to the cells where the prisoners would be kept.
Good prisons had many levels of security between areas of civilian access and the deepest dungeons where the highest of security prisoners were kept.
General Oyak certainly fell into that category.
He did not know if prisons in this world had dungeons, but regardless, he needed a more direct route.

Fect observed the complex at a distance for three days while hiding in a rather unkempt plot of land containing abandoned shacks and dumped garbage, being careful to stay out of sight without his concealment magic active.
He did not want the complex to increase security if they noticed someone suspicious inspecting the perimeter.

The outer perimeter beyond a third smaller, less defensible fence seemed to be public, but the two loiterers he saw over the three days were quickly met by security personnel and questioned before being sent on their way.
Had he acted like a civilian as well, he would be unable to explain himself when questioned.
Fect determined the actual prison within the complex rather quickly: a dull, multistory cement structure with small, uniform windows.
The grander structure beside it must have had a different purpose than housing prisoners.
He would check there last if his initial assumptions were wrong.
While observing the far side on his fourth day, Fect happened to catch a vehicle passing through.
He felt this was his only chance.
Fect scaled the low, outer fence with ease using his light weight in this world and approached the gate under the shroud of his concealment magic.

The former blur of his magic caused by motion weakening the illusory effect was nearly imperceptible now due to his constant use and practice of the magic over the past months out of necessity, now no more visible than the waves of heat that can be seen atop sand baking in the desert sun.
It was still imperfect but far safer than before.
He only needed to be careful not to approach too near someone.
The magic was not hot enough to burn instantly, but someone would surely feel the heat and grow suspicious.
Fect slipped in through the first gate as it opened and crept slowly along with the vehicle, waiting as the guard and driver did business.
He then passed through the final gate.
His concealment magic would not last too long, so he needed to either find somewhere to hide and meditate to recover his ven or locate his comrades quickly and escape.
Fect hurried to the prison structure and walked along the wall.
The windows were far too high for him to reach, and they were closed, preventing him from listening in.
He noticed a group of four groundskeeping at the end of the structure.
One woman separated a little from the others as she picked up a scrap of paper that had been blown in by the wind.
She sung a spirited tune, her arms and legs moving to the rhythm as she worked.
Fect quickly approached her before she could return to the group.
He needed information most of all.
Now that he was inside, he had no idea where to go or what to do.
“You have good voice,” Fect whispered without removing his invisible veil, testing the woman’s response.
The woman’s song immediately ceased, and she looked around her in confusion.
“Do you know of Oyak?
She is old woman here,” Fect asked next.
“Oh, god,” the woman said, backing into nowhere as she continually changed directions looking for the origin of the unseen voice.
“Do you know Oyak?” Fect repeated.
“Listen, I don’t want no trouble, you hear?” the woman said in a quiet voice, fearing that if she spoke up and alerted anyone, she would be in danger.
“Do you know location of Oyak and Borgrum?
If you help, maybe I free you too,” Fect offered.
Given that her attire was vastly different than that of the guards Fect had seen, he could only assume she was a prisoner.
“Free me?
No, I am here for the hospital.
I have this operation, and taxes will pay for it here,” she refused.
The woman’s reply was a startling revelation.
Fect set fire to a hospital in Gullivan where he was treated after he fell injured during the fight with Princess Eydis in their first failed attempt to capture her.
He was their prisoner and yet they treated him.
Did all medical facilities double as prisons?
This meant that once again he would be attacking a hospital, a crime that would undoubtedly result in his execution if caught.
For a moment, Fect reconsidered the possibility of returning to that small, forgotten town and continuing his life as a welder.
He was most likely thought dead along with the many other soldiers who fell in the assault on Gullivan.
General Oyak was certainly not expecting him to rescue her.
Once he did rescue them, what then would he do?
He trusted that he could conceal them long enough to escape the facility, but giants did not exist on Earth.
Small people did, allowing him to live somewhat normally aside from the initial surprise of people he encountered.
“Tell me location of Oyak or I kill you,” Fect ordered.
He would see their condition and decide then whether the rescue was possible.
He still did not know why they allowed themselves to remain imprisoned.
The woman did not know the exact location of Oyak, but she knew the name and the general location where the high security prisoners were kept.
Fect sped across the grounds to what he believed was the hospital, the grand structure of quality build just to the north.
General Oyak was not imprisoned there, but he needed a distraction large enough to clear whatever guards might be at the cells.
If this instead increased security, his only other option was to blast and burn his way through.
He ran by the windows, glancing in long enough for his sight-based fire magic to set each room alight with an intense fire not caring for who or what may be inside.
Once he finished the length of the structure, the entire side of the hospital was ablaze with a billowing flame far too large to quell.
The hospital in Gullivan had the means to suppress and control fire, so he did not want to take the chance that a small fire would die too quickly.
This structure needed to burn.
He then hastened to the location told him by the singing woman.
The sound of a battle could be heard from inside.
General Oyak and the giant must have noticed the commotion and realized this was their moment to escape.
If that was the case, they might be healthy enough to flee.
Fect blew open the entrance, killing any personnel or prisoners that met his gaze, and followed the noise of the conflict.
After blowing open the final door, Fect saw the giant fighting a familiar troll in the hall.
She was the same troll who had escaped him in Gullivan during Jethro’s teleportation experiments.
The door to the cell where the giant had been confined was blown out and in a bent heap on the other side of the wall.
The giant protected the entrance from the troll.
General Oyak was likely still inside.
Fect rushed to assist.
Fect shot a beam of concentrated fire ven from his eyes at the troll.
She conjured a slab of stone at her side the moment she felt the intense heat, and the slab exploded, showering her in shrapnel.
A black and blistering burn remained just below her ribs.
The giant exploited the opening to land a powerful blow in her center, sending her into and through the cell door opposite them.
She quickly recovered without much damage.
Instead, the giant’s arm fell limp and broken at his side.
Fect heard rumors about the elven martial arts, but to rebound a blow as powerful as a giant’s felt to Fect like sorcery.
Such should not be possible.
Fect lit a wall of flame between the troll and giant.
“We must escape,” he called, but the giant quickly signed the hand-signal for injured.
He was not referring to himself.
The reason why he had not escaped was because General Oyak could not.
This was a hospital prison, and General Oyak was here for both confinement and treatment.
If they wanted to escape, they needed to eliminate or at least incapacitate the troll.
The troll bounded through the flame only lightly singed and targeted Fect with two stone scimitars raised.
Fect ignited a flame pillar in front of her approach, but she kicked out the stone beneath the floor, sending the pillar’s column erupting to the side.
The blades lowered for an execution.
A powerfully thrown slab of concrete hit the troll’s arm, deflecting the blade enough for Fect to just barely dodge.
The troll’s arm hung broken above the elbow, but the pain did not slow her assault.
Fect erupted flames from his body, forcing the troll back, and then activated his concealment magic.
Meanwhile, the giant charged and grappled the troll to the hot ground.
Fect was about to execute her when gunshots fired from the entrance.
Reinforcements arrived faster than Fect had expected.
The giant shielded his head.
One of the bullets hit his arm and the other landed in his side.
Not a moment later, he was off the troll with her on his back and her good arm locked around his neck.
A small stone knife appeared in her hand, and she swiftly ran it across his throat.
Now with reinforcements and the only other combatant eliminated, Fect’s sole option was to flee.
He ran in the shroud of his concealment magic to the other side of the hall, stopping briefly in front of the destroyed cell.
There he saw General Oyak on a hospital bed with a stone spike impaling both the bed and her from below.
She lived but was fading.
Her glazed eyes noticed the wavering air of Fect’s concealment magic.
“Young Captain Fect, flee this place.
You should not have come,” she said in a weak voice.
“Our death was inevitable.
Wait for Jethro to find you.
He will not abandon you in this world.”
Light flashed behind Fect, and all fire in the hallway extinguished.
General Oyak’s eyes filled with tears.
“I wondered where you were hiding,” spoke a familiar voice.
Fect turned as multiple gunshots rang out, but none of the bullets reached Jethro.
His simple barrier deflected them away.
Fect saw that the giant was no longer in the hall.
The troll stood in front of the guards in a defensive stance.
She would not forget the master of Tolmyur’s forces, nor his power.
“Flee this place,” Fect heard the troll order quietly to the guards.
“Flee or you will die.”
Jethro paid her no concern, and with a flick of his hand, General Oyak vanished next.
“Fect,” he spoke jovially, “I had hoped beyond hope that you survived.
You are far too crafty to die in battle.” He turned, patted Fect’s invisible head, and after shaking off the sting of the heat, walked towards the troll.
“Symra, was it?”
“Flee,” the troll ordered again, this time shouting, and the guards fled with haste.
Every step Jethro advanced, Symra receded back at even pace.
She dared not turn her back to him.
“I had thought you would not be a nuisance if left in this world, but you surprise me,” Jethro laughed.
“I trust that you are here under order of Princess Eydis FeAmel?
I have a message for her.”
The troll’s eyes narrowed.
“The Gods of this world have interfered with our feud, and so long as Eydis remains in this world, I am forbidden from touching her.
Likewise, I do not doubt they would interfere with her should she decide to use this world’s power to attack me.
I give her a choice.
Once my probation here is over, I can send her back to your world.
We can then kill each other at our leisure.
If she decides to stay here, so be it, but once I am back on Whinhlem, I will use the full power of Tolmyur to eliminate the last member of the royal family, Ceil.
They were as close as sisters, if I am not mistaken.
If she wants to save that girl, she must accept my offer.
If she chooses to remain in this world and abandon Ceil to death, know that if I ever discover the means to thwart the Gods of this world, I will return here and end her next.”
Jethro eyed the troll who had escaped him once before and now stood before him after potentially killing two more of his commanders.
“Fect, have your fire ready to cauterize two wounds,” he spoke quietly.
Fect readied his sight-based magic for whatever Jethro had in mind.
It happened in an instant.
With only the slightest movement from Jethro, the troll’s left leg severed from just above the knee and right arm from just above the elbow.
Fect immediately focused his gaze on the wounds, igniting them briefly.
The troll fell to her back, writhing and howling in agony.
Fect then set the severed arm and leg alight, preventing them from being reattached if life magic was used quickly.
“Seek treatment from your princess, and do not forget to relay my message.
Oh, and one last message for her.” Jethro’s joviality vanished, replaced with pure rancor.
“Remind her that she brought all this upon herself.”
The hallway vanished, and Fect found himself in a cement room with pillars and high, barred windows.
Borgrum lay motionless on the floor having bled out from his neck.
General Oyak remained alive but waning.
Fect did not doubt she would soon pass.
“My Lord, thank you for sparing a thought for this old woman.
I know young Captain Fect was your true aim.”
“He was,” Jethro admitted.
“No one but him would think to set one of the higher security prisons in that nation ablaze.
Had it been a lesser prison, it would not have made immediate international news.”
“You already knew General Oyak was there and where in the prison she was located,” Fect realized.
“I did, and I have been in regular contact with them.
She and Lieutenant Borgrum chose to remain there instead of rescue because they could feed me information they glean from the periodic interrogations.
I must apologize for my past comments about you needing to focus more on cowardly tactics.
I only wished for your safety.
You are a braver man than most, and you have proven that once again today.”
Jethro knelt on the cold floor to look Fect level in the eyes.
“Your father, Temmet, was a good friend of mine, the first companion I made after my hunter mercenary party arrived in Tolmyur.
You spent most your life living in the shadow of his accomplishments.
I supported your military career in honor of his memory, but you are not your father.
You are smarter, more cunning, and a fair bit more powerful.”
Fect trembled.
He was used to Jethro’s casual and amiable speech when they were alone together, but now Jethro’s tone had an air of seriousness that scared Fect.
“I have personally instructed you in magic.
I gave you dangerous missions to both test and train your wits and mettle.
Several of the top generals of Tolmyur are aware and have given their full support of my decision.”
General Oyak turned on her broken body and bowed her face to the blood-soaked cement floor.
She did not bow at Jethro but at both Fect and Jethro.
As Fect stared at her in stunned silence, she drew her last breath, frozen in reverence.
Jethro directed Fect’s focus back to him.

“You still require more mentoring and education, and I do not have any plans to give up my position just yet, but whether I die or become king, you will succeed me as Commanding General when that time comes.”
Eydis sat in a single lone chair in the center of an unadorned room across from a table populated by five of the highest-ranking military officials of the country.
She did not want to be here, and she could leave at any time she wanted with teleportation magic, but that would only worsen her current situation.

Symra had called Eydis’s order to subvert the due processes of this world to execute the two Tolmyur prisoners foolishness, but Eydis ignored those sound warnings and ordered their execution on behalf of the Amelian Empire nonetheless.
Now Symra was in critical condition, and the whereabouts of the prisoners were unknown.
“We now know that Jethro is still hiding somewhere on Earth and cannot return to Whinhlem,” Eydis asserted, justifying her rash actions.
“At what cost?
Knowing that Jethro is still here does not help us find him,” the man in the center of the table rebuked.
“He gave invitation for me to contact him.”
“Will you take his offer, to use his magic to return to your world?” the official on the far left asked.
Eydis could read clearly the expressions of three of the officials.
They wanted her gone to remove the blade hovering over their country’s throat.
“I would be returning on his terms, by his power.
