The moment I take such a deal, my life is forfeit.
The only reason I would agree would be to cross him and fight.”
“And do you believe we have any hope of capturing or killing him?”
“Your technology is great, but your lack of understanding and ability in magic will be your downfall.
You cannot fight him.
None of us can.”
“We have lost a valuable instructor due to your rash actions, one who could have helped us to that end,” the man in the center rebuked though his voice was calm.
“You only see Symra as a tool.”
“As did you when you ordered that assassination,” rebuked another, not denying their exploitation of her skills.
Eydis steeled her expression.
She did not regret her order, nor would she ever admit it was in error.
She had to play to their fears, or they would not understand.
“Had you done what I asked and executed those two long ago, the thirty-two people at that prison would not have died.
I did not set fire to that hospital.
Someone from Tolmyur did, and only because there were prisoners in your custody whom they could rescue.
You continually underestimate their abilities, and this is the result.
They assassinated my entire family in one night and dissolved my empire in half a month of your world’s time.
Do not think for a moment that they could not do the same to your country.”
The panel of officers behind the table fell silent.
“If you are finished with me, I will leave.”
“Our decision has not changed,” the man in the center spoke as Eydis stood from her lone chair.
“Your privileges to information will be heavily restricted as will those of your friends.
You will work with Ms. Schruder to instruct both magic and combat in Symra’s place until her recovery finishes.”
“Miriam is not sufficient rank to instruct,” Eydis reminded.
“You are, and Miriam only needs one more advancement.
Get her that advancement immediately.”
Eydis marched to the table and stood erect, glaring down at the sitting military officers.
“I am not yours to command.
I am working with you solely to fight a common enemy.
That is all.
Miriam will not help instruct until she advances, and she is prohibited from advancement for two months.
I will see to Symra’s quick recovery.
In the future, heed my warnings or expect more lives to be lost to your hubris.”
Eydis turned and walked from the room.

Chapter 8
“A Lurr Village”
“How many are there,” Ceil asked from the center of the defensive perimeter.
Zose, Jeddin, and Dyson stood guard around her in the deep snow nearly up to their waists.
Coby hovered nervously above.
The flapping of his massive wings did not clear the snow on the ground around them because the top, sun-melted layer had frozen overnight.
“Five at least, but that’s not the issue.
We are in Lurr country now,” Dyson cautioned.
A snarled howl bellowed from deep inside the dense conifers a short distance away.
A second answered from the rising cliff behind them.
“Regular wolves are not much of a threat unless you are alone, but Lurr are far more powerful.
Mistake a Lurr for a regular wolf, and that will be the end of you.”
Ceil readied her hamadryad staff, now full length after her days of nurturing it.
Aside from their initial ambush after setting off from Ib’nua, the seven days of travel had been uneventful.

They stayed in a small hovel outside a run-down village two days ago to weather a blizzard passing through, covering the road in two to three feet of snow overnight, but that alone was the only hindrance of their journey north for the Afarit, until now.
Dyson noticed a light bulge in the snow from the edge of their perimeter between him and Zose.
He yanked Ceil aside into Jeddin as a wolf lunged up from beneath the snow, nearly biting Ceil’s face.
His follow-up kick sent the beast tumbling into Zose who finished it with his twin bone knives.
Ceil shook off the impact of colliding with Jeddin and immediately grew cautious of the deep snow around her.
The frozen layer prevented her from seeing where the wolves would appear until just before the strike.
“Don’t worry about the snow,” Jeddin said, pulling Ceil to her feet.
“That was an arrogant pup.
Wolves normally do not attack unless they are certain they can avoid pointless losses.”
That pup was a large as the palace hounds.
If a pup was that large, how much larger were the grown wolves?
Coby flapped his wings sending two wide blades of wind into the thick trees, cutting three of them down.
As the towering pines crashed to the ground, four massive wolves fled to the safety of the open roadside.
They were much larger than her, large enough for their entire head and most of their back to rise above the deep snow.
While three of them circled the road snarling, the largest of them receded, almost afraid.
“The one in the back is a Lurr,” Zose cautioned, “but it does not seem a threat.”
“Two more from the cliff,” Jeddin announced, drawing his bow.
“When I signal, go.”
Ceil’s heart thundered in anticipation.
She had fought predators in Fiorrae, including several the smaller Habha, but she had never personally fought anything this large.
“Now!”
Jeddin loosed his arrow, striking the nearest wolf in the neck near the shoulder, but that alone was not enough to drop the beast.
It charged.
Jeddin had another arrow nocked and fired before it could approach.
It penetrated the beast’s open maw.
He stepped aside as it crashed past him next to Ceil.
She slammed the butt of her staff into its writhing head, blackening its fur and killing it.
She then turned to the three charging from her back.
Two ran for Dyson and the third for Zose.
Dyson was forced away, unable to challenge two at once.
Zose shallowly ran his blade across his opponent’s chest to deflect the beast aside.
Ceil was exposed, but the Lurr receded further back, snarling directly at Ceil with its red eyes and its tail tucked between its legs.
Coby dove after the Lurr.
With one massive flap if his wings, the snow blew away in a white cloud, and the Lurr tumbled back through the deep snow.
It righted itself quickly and lunged, jumping an impossible height.
Its teeth sank into the flight feathers of Coby’s right wing and pulled him to the ground.
“Coby!” Ceil ran after her friend, not wanting him to die protecting her.
Even for a large Habha, a Lurr of that size was too powerful an opponent.
“Ceil!
Don’t stray,” Zose called out after successfully running off his injured wolf.
The Lurr was about to carry the wildly fluttering Habha off but then noticed Ceil’s approach.
It yipped in fear, releasing Coby’s wing, and frantically scurried away.
Ceil was not mistaken.
The Lurr was terrified of her.
She ran to Coby and saw that only his feathers were damaged, not his wing, much to her relief.
Zose quickly ran after Ceil to cover her against the other wolves, but when Ceil looked back, the other wolves were in retreat after their leader, the Lurr, fled.
“What were you thinking,” Zose scolded, grabbing Ceil’s arm.
Ceil wrenched her arm free.
“Coby is all I have left!
I will not let him die while I yet breathe.”
“Let it go,” Dyson said as he approached, wiping down the large scratch on his arm with an alcohol-soaked rag.
“Can Coby fly?”
Ceil straightened out Coby’s feathers to the best of her ability and repeated Dyson’s question to him in English.
Coby cried out and flapped his wings.
He rose into the air unstable, but he could still fly.
“You can ride my shoulders if flying with that wing tires you,” she told him while stroking his breast feathers after he landed.
Coby nipped playfully at her fingers in reply.
“We are nearly at Hen’anin, an old fahil mining outpost.
We can tend our wounds there,” Jeddin said after bleeding the two wolves they managed to kill.
“We should be able to sell these for their meat and pelts.”
Zose extended his hand to Ceil.
He was still angry at her for leaving their protection, and she spent the next hour listening to him berate her for her foolishness.
He was her protector and she his charge.
If she acted on her own, he could not fulfill his duty.
Hen’anin consisted of worn and dilapidated shacks set along the slope of a mountain.
The tiered slope, clearly carved by hand, stood on the side of a massive pit further down the mountain, so deep that Ceil could not see the bottom from her angle.
The pit itself, the fahil mine, was eroded and crumbling, showing several centuries of abandonment.
Whatever fahil, and possibly resfahil, that may have been in that mine had long been extracted.
Unlike Ib’nua, no ruins were present, at least that Ceil could see.
The recent heavy snowfall had collapsed parts of weakened structures, and they were left in disrepair.
The populous trudged with faces downcast through snow-packed streets, paying no attention to the new arrivals just entering town.

The only people who walked through the city with confidence had the essence of a warrior about them, much like Zose, Jeddin, and Dyson, other hunter mercenaries here to seek contracts or simply passing through.
A woman of odd characteristics as if she was a mixed breed of many of the elfkind chanced a glance up at Ceil’s party as they passed and screamed.
Her eyes flared red and locked onto Ceil, but as she stared, Ceil could not help but think the terrified woman looked not at her but through or past her to something behind.
The woman scrambled to her nearby hut to get inside, tearing down the meager cloth covering the entry.
Ceil stopped walking, startled by the sudden display.
Inside the hut she heard a crash and then sobbing.
“Was that a Lurr,” Ceil asked, now worried and a bit scared herself.
“Yes, but I do not know why she would be so scared,” Jeddin replied.
“Lurr here have no need to fear hunter mercenaries.”
“Are Lurr not dangerous?”
“Bestial Lurr certainly are, but those who have fed solely on common folk enough to become one of us are able to live among us under certain conditions.
They abstain from uncooked meat to prevent further evolution and the interference of bestial instincts that may develop from the inclusion of that blood.”
“It is those bestial tendencies that warp the mind and when combined with high intelligence create the possibility for the development of a chimera,” Zose explained.
A man who looked nearly elven carried a heavy sack across the road.
He glanced over at Ceil’s party and hollered.
He dropped his sack and scrambled in a panic to distance himself.
He tripped on the sloping road and slid over the packed snow.
He collided with the support beam of a hut elevated against the slope, breaking it and sending the hut careening onto the road atop him and another resident.
The terrified man broke free with ease and fled, but the other resident remained under the heap.
Nearby villagers hurried to unbury the poor victim caught in the collapse.

Jeddin and Dyson rushed to their aid, but the astounding strength of a few of the villagers cleared the rubble with ease before they arrived, freeing the man as well as a woman and child who had been inside the hut.
Ceil and Zose approached the group slowly.
Ceil wanted to apologize for the destruction, but as they neared, the eyes of three of the villagers flared up in deep crimson.
Like the two before, they fled in a raving panic.
In the distance out of sight somewhere down the sloped village, Ceil heard another crash.
The woman with her child looked up at Ceil and screamed.
Instead of fleeing, she stood and shielded her child, her arms out and fingers rigid like claws, ready to attack Ceil if Ceil so much as took another step forward.
Zose drew his twin blades and stood in front of Ceil while Jeddin and Dyson tried to calm the woman who refused to be calmed.
“They are just like the wolf Lurr from before.
She is scared of me,” Ceil realized.
“Are you sure it’s not Coby,” Zose replied.
“Habha are mostly unknown in these parts, especially one so large.”
The woman’s terrified crimson eyes continued staring into Ceil, not at Coby to her side.
“If it was Coby, why are only the Lurr frightened?
It is me she fears, but why?”
“Zose!
What have you done to these people?” A burly troll with a thick fur cloak and his coarse red mane of hair braided down his back marched over the road to stand between him and the mother.
His height, not lacking compared to elf men, dwarfed Zose and made Ceil anxious.
She did not know if he was friend or foe.
“We have done nothing,” Dyson assured from behind him, finally managing to turn the mother away with her child now that a powerful presence stood between her and the source of her fear.
“Silence whelp,” the troll roared.
“The villagers would not have reason for such fear of Zose unless he had done something to them.”
“I have not taken a red contract, if that’s what you mean,” Zose protested.
“I know as well as anyone that these Lurr are harmless.”
“And yet you brandish your blades against them.”
Zose sheathed his blades.
“I am under contract to protect this woman on her way to the Afarit.
The Lurr are only scared of her Habha companion.
As her protector, I must draw my weapon against any who might mean harm, even if out of misplaced fear.
I am sure you understand.”
The troll’s gaze bore down on Ceil and then Coby beside her who rustled his wings in irritation.
His feathers puffed up, making him appear slightly larger than he already was.
Ceil stroked Coby’s head lightly to calm him down, but she was still anxious about the antagonistic man before them and the conversation she could not fully understand.
“It’s all been a misunderstanding, Pyn,” Jeddin said as he dragged the two wolves over and thrust them in front of the troll.
“We were planning on selling these to you, but take them for the village as apology for the commotion and damage we caused the people.
Two wolves should be more than enough to compensate for a single hut.”
“Make it one wolf,” Dyson argued.
“We must still trade for supplies.”
Pyn growled when Dyson spoke, but Dyson remained unperturbed.
He was used to the belittling treatment from other trolls who saw him as weak due to his thinner physique.
Pyn slung the larger wolf over his shoulder by the rope and bade everyone follow.
“Come.”
“Have you seen that reaction with Lurr you have encountered before,” Zose asked quietly to Ceil after another Lurr in the village fled from them as they traveled to Pyn’s tavern.
Ceil was unsure if he believed her or if he was trying to find the truth in her suspicion.
“I have never encountered a Lurr until now,” Ceil admitted.
“I thought they were a problem in your village.
You told me as such when we met.”
“They were, or so the villagers told us.
There was a sighting every few days, and about twice a season someone fell prey to them.
But after my family moved there, never once had a Lurr approached the town that I can remember.
The village thought it odd too, but at the same time a famine began that destroyed the land, so the lack of Lurr could be explained there.”
They had not traveled far before reaching a sturdier structure than most, the likely reason Pyn arrived after the commotion so quickly.
The foundation of the tavern was built of layered stone with slightly higher quality wood for the walls and shingling on the roof.
The shingling had been cleared of snow to remove the heavy weight.
“Your habha waits outside,” Pyn ordered, breaking up Ceil and Zose’s conversation.
“I do not want it scaring the customers.”
Ceil explained Pyn’s order to Coby, and he flapped briefly into the air to land on the roof, dislodging two loose shingles.
Pyn grunted in annoyance.
Dyson and Jeddin entered first, but Ceil hesitated.
If there were many Lurr in this village, there was sure to be some inside.
Evening was approaching, and she could hear light commotion from the entryway.
“I will wait out here.”
Zose looked at Ceil’s worry-pained face.
“I would prefer you take this time to warm your feet and hands.
We have been traveling through snow for too long.” He placed his hand on her back and led her through the entry.
A chair toppled on one side of the tavern, and a table tipped on the other, sending its earthenware dishes to the floor.
The thin spriggan who toppled his chair sprung out the nearby window.
The other, a mix of different elfkind like the woman before, drew a hatchet from his belt and backed into a corner behind his table, brandishing it in fearful defense of his life.
“It is me!” Ceil protested.
“What manner of woman are you escorting,” Pyn hollered.
He marched over to the Lurr in the corner.
“What do you know of this woman,” he asked.
“Let me out,” the man mumbled.
“Protect me from that thing.”
Unsure of the reason and not wanting to cause a regular customer any more trouble, Pyn escorted the man to the door.
The three other patrons watched the scene from their tables with a mix of astonishment and confusion.
Pyn then marched in irritation to the back and returned with a sack, tossing it into Dyson’s arms.
“Trade for the wolf pup.
That should be enough, and I will not haggle.
Leave this city before that woman causes any more harm.
She is not welcome here.” Unlike Pyn’s previous conversations with Zose, he spoke in elven so Ceil could understand.
Ceil’s heart sank.

She knew that her very existence was a plague that killed anyone who associated with her, but even here deep in the wilderlands where her true identity was not known, people feared her and wanted her gone.
Her life was a sick joke.
Ceil wanted to collapse there on the ground and rot.
She slowly trudged out the door only to have another Lurr on the road run in fright.
“Your hospitality is lacking from my last visit, Pynthos,” Zose sneered.
“Hen’anin has always cast out those who cannot coexist with the peaceful Lurr who live here.
I’m sure you understand.”
“The Lurr are afraid of her?” Inym repeated back to Kep, a female pixie she employed to monitor Ceil.
Kep spun around Inym’s head once.
“Every single one who saw the girl either bared their fangs or fled at the sight of her.”
Inym walked past a pile of wood that had been a hut just the day before.
As she walked, she spotted a similar pile just down the slope.
“We can use this.
There is a Lurr city Zose will likely have to pass through to reach the Afarit by the safest and quickest road.
Fly ahead and tell Deinan to stir up the Lurr there.
Warn them that an evil is approaching their city and should be eliminated at all cost.
They will know her when they see her.
I’ll investigate here.
Once finished, head back to Zose’s party to continue observation.”
Kep flashed an excited grin and shot like an arrow out of town.
Inym was amazed every time she saw Kep’s speed.
Pixies with an affinity for wind were extremely common, but like all other pixie affinities, they could only practice manipulation.
Those who could conjure wind were nearly unheard of, rarer than spatial pixies.
Manipulating the wind around them made pixies extremely agile in flight, but add in the ability to conjure wind for propulsion, and a pixie was unmatched in the air.
Kep was one such pixie, and her price was exorbitant.
If the bounty on Ceil was anything less than a king’s bounty, Inym would never have been able to convince Kep to help without any payment upfront.
Inym pulled the leather curtain back from the entry of Pyn’s tavern and knocked on the sideboard.
“Pyn, you here?”
Pyn walked from the back room with his hands bloodied up to his elbows.
“Inym?
What brings you back to Hen’anin?
Have you finally settled somewhere?”
“I’m living near Ib’nua, working for Jit.” Inym entered and leaned back against a table next to Pyn.
“Want breakfast?
Got my hands on a wolf pup yesterday.
The meat should be soft enough for you.”
Inym peeled back her cloak and lifted her thick fur armor to expose her midsection.
A deep scar cut across her stomach and abdomen from the left, leaving a large chunk of flesh missing from her right side.
Pyn already knew her scar from back when it was fresh, but he would not know just how emaciated she had become over time because of it.
Her stomach was sunken and both ribs and hip bones were pronounced.
“Can’t eat solid foods anymore.”
“By the god’s.
That is no way for a troll to live.” Pyn wiped his arms off on a rag he pulled from his waist and then slung the bloodied rag over his shoulders.
“If I stew it for you, could you manage?
No charge.”
Inym smiled, and her drooping ears twitched lightly.
“I do not have the time.
I am on errand right now.
I am only here for information.
From what I understand, you had a dangerous party pass through here yesterday, led by Zose.”
“Aye.
Right made a mess of things.
Terrified every Lurr who saw them.”
“That same party caused havoc in Ib’nua as well.
Killed Fenon and Burdhu.”
“Never cared for that shrewd siren, but I am sad to hear Burdhu is dead.
Listen, if that party is as dangerous as you say, you should leave them be.

Lurr are generally unshakable, given their strength and all, but that girl with Zose had them jumping right out my windows.” Pyn grabbed Inym’s arm, and he could feel the bone directly beneath her fur covering.
“Stay here.
I’ll take care of you.”
Inym’s ears twitched again, and she peeled his fingers off her arm.
“I was already run from this village after the incident, if you remember.
It was a Lurr that did this to me.
I still can’t feel comfortable here, or I might have returned.”
“Not any Lurr.
It was a chimera, two of them.” Pyn corrected.
“Very few could ever hope to fight two chimera and survive, let alone kill them both.”
“All the same.
Besides, if this job goes well, perhaps I can be the one saving you from this run-down village.
I need to know what scared the Lurr.
Do you know one I can ask?”
“Ask the spriggan next door.
I’ll have soup for you when you finish,” Pyn said, returning to the back to continue his work.
Inym shook her head and then grabbed her ears.
They wouldn’t stop twitching, and for sure Pyn noticed.
That was likely why he continued being so adamant about her staying.
Male trolls always competed for the best warrior women.
Inym was certainly quite skilled among hunter mercenaries before her injury, but she felt he could do far better than the emaciated woman she had become.
Inym flicked her ears to stop them from twitching as she walked out of the tavern.
The shack next door was shapelier than most, and the furs peaking from below the fabric covering the entrance hinted this Lurr was better off than many in Hen’anin.
She parted the fabric and patted the sideboard.
“May I enter?
I need information on the woman you saw in Pyn’s tavern.”
A mound of furs stirred in the corner of the hut, and a face with glowing red eyes peeked out from below.
Inym’s heart raced, and for a moment, she almost fled out the door despite herself.
Even years after her subjugation of the two chimera, the mental scars remained just as clear as her physical ones.
Inym’s body shook, but she forced herself to enter and kneel beside the fur mound.
“What did you see that frightened you so?” She suspected that this spriggan Lurr had not left his furs since he fled the tavern the day before.
“That girl,” the Lurr hissed, “she has death about her.
Death is in her and stands behind her.”
“Death?
Surely no one here in the wilderlands is unacquainted with it.”
“No!
This is different!” The Lurr’s head shot out from under the furs.
His left antler caught and snapped off the corner of his forehead.
Inym lunged back in fright and collided against the far wall, causing the sturdy hut to creak.
“This is different,” the Lurr repeated, ignoring his broken antler and the blood leaking down his face onto the furs.
“Death emanates from her and poisons the ven in the air.
The earth blackens where she steps.”
The Lurr’s fears sounded like the ramblings of a mad man, but according to Kep, many Lurr had the same reaction.
Inym left and ran to the rubble of the first collapsed hut.

After asking for any Lurr involved, Inym met a Lurr mother with a non-Lurr elf child, showing that the mother’s evolution had progressed enough that she did not simply bear larva, likely being supplied blood regularly by her willing mate.
Her answer was the same; the woman with Zose was death, and she felt she had to kill the woman before that death claimed her child.
The third Lurr Inym asked gave the same answer.
The fourth was no different.
They all spoke as if the woman under Zose’s protection would bring death or was death itself, indescribably dangerous.
Perhaps there was more to that wanted poster than anyone realized.
If that woman was Ceil, the widow of the late emperor, would her life truly be worth enough riches to make one a king?
No sane person would solicit such a reward.
What if the bounty was so high because of the danger that individual possessed?
The most dangerous of bounties always came with higher reward or there would be little incentive to take on such dangers.
And now that danger has entered the wilderlands.
Inym ran back to Pyn’s tavern and slid a table in front of the entry to show to others the tavern was closed.
Pyn exited the back room hearing the noise.
Inym grabbed his arm and pulled him to the back.
“We must talk.”
“First you should eat.”
“No.” Inym spun Pyn and pushed him back against the wall.
She could not continue this discussion as old friends.
This was a hunter mercenary matter of greatest importance.
Pyn immediately understood, and his face grew rigid.
“How much can you vouch for Zose’s honor?”
“When it comes to his work, he is among the most reliable,” Pyn answered.
“Did he mention where he was taking that woman?
Was it to the Afarit?”
“He mentioned he was guarding her on her way there, yes.”
Inym removed her hand from Pyn’s chest.
“I am sure you have heard of the bounty on the widow of Emperor Yuro, an elf girl appearing about three years in age.”
“Are you saying that is the girl he is protecting?”
“At first I thought he was going to collect the bounty.
He sent an urgent message from Ib’nua to Amel hinting he would make the exchange at the Afarit, or at least that was how it seemed.
That is what I am investigating, but why would he travel so far?
Amel is just as far but an incomparably easier journey than the Afarit.”
“You are wondering if Zose would be the type to deceive an employer for a bounty.
I cannot say for certain, but I do not think he would.
If anything, Basara would roast him if he tried.
Her honor is unmistakable.”
Inym took a deep breath.
“What if there was a greater purpose that would lead him to do so nonetheless?”
She explained what she learned from the Lurr of the village, and as she did so, Pyn grew more and more troubled.
“The Amelian Empire has fallen, and Tolmyur controls Amel.
The war should be over, and yet Tolmyur has mustered all its armies to kill the widow.
Why?
Why target a single woman?
Why have they not succeeded despite their efforts?”
“Perhaps they cannot kill her,” Pyn realized.
“Because she is death.
Death would never claim one of its own, but it may be even worse than that.
The Lurr claim she kills the ven around her, that death spreads from her.
She is a living plague.
Emperor Yuro discovered the girl and must have taken her to wife to claim that power for himself, the wretched man he was.
Tolmyur’s invasion released that calamity into the world, and now they are trying in desperation to contain it.
Their feud is with the elves, so why would they choose to wage war against the fairies to pursue her?”
Before Pyn could answer, Inym continued.

“If the other races learn they have released a calamity upon them, it would worsen their already hostile relations with the bordering nations that were never members of the Amelian Empire, sealing Tolmyur’s destruction.
That must be the reason for such an enormous bounty.
No doubt it is half the coffers of the Amelian palace, half the spoils of their victory long sought since ages past.

They are giving all that up to hunt one girl.”
“Zose is headed for the Afarit…” Pyn stood in pensive thought.
“His message stated that he has her at the Afarit.
Now that I know what kind of monster that woman is, I doubt he is turning in the bounty.
The length of message a spik can carry is small, so you cannot give lengthy explanations.
Zose is not presenting her to the Afarit for her protection to dissuade the Tolmyur kingdom from their pursuit.
He was informing Tolmyur that he knows a way to kill her.”
Pyn reached the same conclusion as Inym.
“Bydrofe.
If she is a living calamity, perhaps the titan knows a way.”
“I have made a terrible mistake.
My initial goal was to secret away the widow to claim the bounty instead, and I have accomplices in waiting ahead down the highway to the Afarit.
I sent out an order to rally the Lurr of Sen’uon against Zose’s party.”
If her ill-formed attempts to capture the widow led to the widow fleeing or becoming lost--a direct repeat of Tolmyur’s mistake in Amel--it could spell disaster for the wilderlands.
She should not be hindering Zose but helping him in his quest to kill her.
Pyn grew angry, but he did not chastise Inym’s actions.
“I will send someone after Zose’s party to explain the situation.”

Inym waited anxiously at Pyn’s tavern for two days to hear back from Pyn’s messenger only to learn that Zose’s party left the road at the valley to travel cross-country, and the heavy snowfall had covered their tracks.
Chapter 9
“The Worst News Possible”
Three blizzards, one after the other.
If Byurk was not under direct orders from a higher general, he never would have marched into the wilderlands in the height of winter.
He wanted to be done with the war in Vallen, but now he had to lead his frost-bitten men through frigid mountains they were ill-equipped to endure.
Like Ib’nua, the second village they passed gave them no welcome, would not house his freezing soldiers, and refused to sell supplies.
In a day or so pending fair weather, they would happen upon another village from an explanation of the road that he was able to force out of a trio of travelers headed back the other way.
It was a Lurr village, and although he knew they were not uncommon in the wilderlands, the thought of relying on one made Byurk’s skin crawl.
“Keep march.
If you stop, I will abandon you at the Lurr village.
You can live your life with them in this frozen wasteland.”
Several of his men whose feet had grown sluggish picked up pace.
The giants were more than tall and strong enough to plow through the deep snow, and the humans who marched behind them struggled little.
Byurk led the group, often through drifts reaching his neck.
If not for his water magic parting the snow in front of him, he would not be able to walk.
As their leader, he certainly would not make his giants march in front of him.

Every five-hundred-yard stretch felt like a shuffle of the last five-hundred yards: the same white-capped peaks towering in the distance, the same rocky crags and steep ravines, and the same sturdy pines immune to the cold and elevation growing wherever their roots could grab hold.
At least his large numbers deterred any would-be predators from ambushing them from the innumerable crevices and ridges.
When pursuing the widow of the emperor through Melia, he felt his mission had purpose.
When assaulting Revlan in the plains of western Vallen, he knew the exhausting campaign would soon end.
Every second the frozen air numbed his fingers and the snow chilled his feet, Byurk questioned why pursuit of the widow was so important.
He knew Jethro’s reasons, and they made sense, but the Amelian Empire would never be reborn.
The fairies had rallied behind her, but they were eliminated.
The hamadryad had taken her side but was eliminated by an even greater power among the dryads of Dhuillir.
No other nation would dare support the widow in striking back against Tolmyur.
Jethro should secure his hold in Amel, work to create networks for communication and travel between Amel and Tolmyur, and let the widow hide away in isolation.
Surely she had seen enough of the destruction that followed her to rid any lingering thought of rebellion or retaliation.
Byurk would abandon the pursuit if not for a fear lingering in his mind.
The widow was willing to surrender to Tolmyur during the standoff in Revlan’s central district, but she was rescued by her Habha at the cost of her otherworld companion’s life.
If the message given to the pixie in Ib’nua could be trusted, she was headed north, but to what end?
Why was he given that message if not to ensure he pursued?
Did she give him the message for him to follow, or was it another who knew of her identity?
Was it the party that fled Revlan?
Byurk wanted to speak with the widow, not in hostility or as a commander of an army ready to wage war for her capture.
He wanted to speak with her person to person, as two people who tired of seeing lives lost over one woman.
Hopefully this time, the fourth time, he could convince her to surrender.
As these thoughts occupied Byurk’s mind, he spotted his forward scout hunkered in the elbow of a rock at the bend ahead.
He doubted his scout would succumb to a frozen death.
As he neared, he could just see faint puffs of breath.
If the scout did not return immediately, there was little chance it was an emergency.
He was observing and waiting for Byurk to catch up to report.
Before Byurk could reach the bend, the scout signaled: target party ahead, visible.
The widow was their true target, but what caused the excursion into the wilderlands was the party that fled Revlan during the battle.
The Revlan party was ahead, perhaps with the widow, and should he approach the bend, his army would be visible to them.
The three blizzards had slowed them down.
Without being able to take shelter in the villages he passed, Byurk had forced his men to march through the blizzards to find an area of sufficient cover.
Those frigid marches caught them up to that party.
The snow was deep, and the Revlan party would be unable to flee so easily.
Should he confront them here, he could facilitate their immediate surrender, if they were willing.
Byurk raised his hand and signaled preparation for battle, silent approach.
Weapons unsheathed behind him, but little other noise was made.
Ranks reorganized.
Byurk signaled to the scout asking for distance.
The scout signaled back: three hundred yards.
They were close.
Of course, in such winding mountain roads, visibility down the road was seldom far.
Thankfully the deep snow had muffled the approach of his fifty men.
Next he asked for terrain.
The reply: shallow valley, light bend east, enemy on the rise.
The road lowered in elevation briefly as it bent around the ravine to the right and then rose again.
The other party was atop the rise on the other side.
Enemy status: camp, preparations for departure.
Perfect, he could catch them unawares, increasing his chance at persuading their surrender.
This was the perfect opportunity.
Byurk sent his rangers up the ridge to circle above the road as a precaution and led his remaining soldiers around the bend.
“Pack up quickly,” Basara ordered.
“If we can keep our pace, we will reach Hen’anin by tomorrow evening.”
Their camp was little more than a few oiled tarps suspended over cleared ground.
The three Melians managed the cold just fine without clothing, albeit a tad sluggish in their movements, and the two trolls took care of most of the heavy work and any fires that were needed.
Surprisingly, the oread woman, Chloe, seemed able to ignore the cold just as easily as she could.
Perhaps like Zose, she was accustomed to it.
The remaining members of the party, the elves, fairy, spriggan, and human struggled with the many days of travel in the snowy mountains.
They had left in pursuit of Ceil without any preparation, and Basara prepared what she could with the funds handed her by Zose before he left, but they still lacked.
“Is there any way we could send someone more mobile ahead to intercept your husband’s party to inform them to wait for us,” Kiri asked.
“You would need to hire a skilled tracker in Hen’anin, but we do not have the funds.”
Basara looked ahead over the far ridge in the distance behind which Hen’anin was located.
Past that ridge, the mountains opened into miles of plains before another steep range, worse than the Nuanae.

Much of the geography of the western wilderlands resembled ripples of mountains that only grew steeper and more dangerous the closer one traveled to the center, beginning with the Nuanae range on the border, then the Nuafonen, Hemenonan, and at the center, the Afarit.
“And even a skilled tracker would have little hope of catching Zose past Hen’anin unless we hired a Lurr.
He takes a different path over the plains, avoiding the common road.
His trail is much faster but is seldom used because the mountain pass it connects too is treacherous, and lycon hunting parties often attack any lone travelers who leave the common road.”
“There are beastkin in the wilderlands?”
Basara understood Kiri’s surprise.
Beastkin and elfkind never coexisted, and any attempt to settle in lands owned by the other led to war and eventual extermination.
The mostly lawless wilderlands were the only exception on this continent, and only in the northern wilderlands that were too inhospitable for most to live.
“Lycon are more common in the tundra north of the wilderlands, but a few tribes migrate along the plains between the ranges.
Sending a lone tracker after Zose would be a death sentence.
Besides, the snow would have covered his tracks anyway.
His goal is to reach the Afarit as quickly as possible.
If there was any location we could catch him, it would be at Sen’uon, and only if he has trouble securing passage through the city.
That city is the only feasible way through this side of the Hemenonan range.”
Basara glanced past Kiri and sighed.
She approached Justin who was trying to tie the oiled fabric of his tent back into a tight bundle to be carried.
His cold-numbed fingers combined with the waterproofing oils on the fabric made his attempts futile.
When in camp or during rest periods he only meditated, emitting an unfamiliar ven signature from rare affinity use.
He clearly had no survival experience and was incredibly weak compared to the others.
He could only carry as much as Kiri who was half his size.
She grabbed the leather straps from him and quickly bound up the tarp.
“Sorry,” Justin said, dejected.
Basara smiled reassuringly at him.
Much of his apparent weakness was emotional.
From what she learned, he had lost someone most dear to him in Revlan, another human who stood with them against Tolmyur in protection of Ceil.
No matter how much Kiri tried to stop him from working, to let others take care of his burden, he refused their aid.
“Tolmyur soldiers!” Benab called from higher on the nearby ridge.
The camp immediately scrambled to their arms.
Down the road behind them, about forty Tolmyur soldiers marched around the bend.
A lone minum led the party.
From what Basara could see, there were no bowmen present in the group.
“Benab, Lemi, Tae, eyes on the rocks,” Basara called.
“They sent their rangers ahead.”
Lemi drew her bow, nearly as tall as she and grown from one of the great pines when they set out from Ib’nua.
“I see one!” She loosed her arrow at some enemy Basara could not see far up the ridgeline.
“Hit him,” she announced.
“Keep watching for rangers,” Basara ordered.
Thanysa stood as vanguard with Hethyro.
Kiri took flight out and away from the road for a better vantage.
Basara drew her sword, ready to fight at the front with the trolls when the enemy platoon halted just before the dip in the road.
The minum alone walked forward.
“Is that…” Chloe spoke up from behind Basara.
Basara did not understand the brief words in an unknown language, but Chloe clearly recognized the minum.
The air around Chloe heated so fast that Basara felt it even with her heat tolerance.
Chloe’s usually mild demeanor vanished in an instant, replaced with rage.
Basara recognized the signs immediately, having lost control of her own emotions many times in the past.
When Chloe erupted in flames, Basara knew she had been terribly mistaken.
Chloe was not an oread.
She was a maenad like her.
“Byurk!” Chloe ran enflamed past the troll vanguard down the road.
Impossible.
Byurk had seen Chloe Hearn fall into that bottomless black fissure.
There was no way that otherworlder could have survived.
First that time mage survived buried in water under a ton of earth and stone.
Now it happened again.
Were these otherworlders immortal?
“Retreat!” Byurk ordered but too late.
A massive fireball soared over him, colliding with the soldiers in the back ranks.
The force of the blast sent Byurk tumbling forward over the snow down the road.
His head ached and his ears rang.
When he righted himself, he saw a black plume billowing into the sky.
His entire platoon was either engulfed in flame or motionless on and off the road.
Their path of escape was gone.
Had he stood with them instead of approaching to solicit discourse, he would have died.
Another fireball approached.
Byurk propelled himself over the snow to the bottom of the shallow valley of the road.
That last fireball finished off what few of his men might have survived the first.
Byurk looked up the road at the harbinger of death engulfed in flames glaring down at him.
One last flame grew in her hands.
“Chloe, stop!
That is enough!” A nymph ran after the otherworlder and grabbed her flaming arms.
“Cease this!
I must speak with their commander!”
In the brief struggle, the flame the otherworlder conjured erupted in her hands between her and the nymph, bathing them and the entire road in fire.
Their party up the road called out for the safety of their members.
The flame swirled and gathered in the center of the road.
The nymph spun her arms, and the flame followed her motions, perfectly under her control.

She swept her arms to the side, and the fire arched as a large ribbon over and down the slope of the mountainside, leaving none remaining on the road or covering the otherworlder who now knelt naked and afraid on the hot ground.
Byurk had seen this level of flame control mastery before.
The woman who led this party through the wilderlands was none other than Jethro’s former companion, Basara.
“Basara, I surrender to you,” Byurk called, prostrating himself in the snow.
“I’m sorry.
I’m sorry,” Chloe repeated again and again in an apologetic fit.
Basara coddled the young woman.
Losing to one’s anger was a terrifying experience, especially when the destructive power of fire was included.
Had Basara not been half maenad, she would not have survived that explosion, dooming their party in the wilderlands.
Even a skilled fire mage would have been severely injured if not killed by the heat of Chloe’s flame.
Chloe’s heat surpassed her own and lacked any control.
“Chloe, are you alright?” Justin ran down the road beside Benab, nearly slipping on the melting snow, but they could not cross the red-hot road to Chloe.
Hethyro hurried past him, cloak in hand, and draped it over Chloe’s naked shoulders.
He alone was the only other fire mage in their party and could handle Chloe’s radiating heat.
After only a few seconds of resting on Chloe’s back, the cloak caught flame.
“Grab one of my gowns,” Basara ordered.
She waited until Hethyro returned and then dressed Chloe.
Unlike the cloak and Chloe’s former clothing, the fabric woven from Basara’s hair perfectly resisted Chloe’s heat.
“Cool her down with the snow while I speak with the enemy commander.”
Basara walked down the road to the minum who remained with his head bowed into the melting snow.
“It has been quite some time since we last saw each other,” Basara said standing over the minum.
“You can rise.
I will not harm you.”
Byurk lifted his head to look into Basara’s smiling face.
She knelt down to speak level with Byurk.
“I am glad you are well, old friend.”
“Thank you for sparing me,” Byurk replied.
“At least for now.
I do not doubt those behind you will demand my execution.
I plead that you convince them to take me prisoner.
I will cooperate in any way needed.”
“Gather your archers on the ridge and whoever might have survived.
I would prefer we speak officially with all members present.
I will try to convince the Melians with me to aid your men,” Basara said.
“I must inform you that my scout will have retreated to report what just transpired.”
“Even if he survives traveling on his own through the wilderlands back to your main forces, it will make little difference.
I will wait for you at our camp.
I trust you will not flee.
There is much I wish to know, and I am sure you are the same.”
Byurk bowed again, silently praising his good fortune in meeting a former ally and hero of Tolmyur, someone who would not outright want him dead.
While Byurk gathered the survivors among his men, Basara returned to Chloe and Justin to ask them all they knew about Byurk and his involvement in the war from their perspective.
She did not fear Byurk would flee with his remaining men.
Having been hunter mercenaries together for a brief time before serving together through the Coastal War, she had a deep trust in him, and no doubt he had the same unshakable trust in her.
Questioning Chloe and Justin took time due to their poor language abilities.
At least Chloe showed some aptitude in Elven due to her constant practice with Benab who seemed quite attached to the woman.
Justin’s ability was to a lesser degree, possibly because he did not talk much to anyone.
Basara learned of Byurk’s pursuit of Ceil in Melia, that he led the campaign in Vallen, and that because of him and his armies, Chloe’s friend and Justin’s lover, Sammy, had died.
Basara now understood Chloe’s rage-filled assault against Byurk and his soldiers.
Byurk pleaded for Basara to spare him, but she was unsure that would be possible given the circumstances and the level of Byurk’s involvement.

Byurk was promoted to lieutenant at the end of the Coastal War, but as the leader of the Vallen campaign, he was likely a general now, and generals were never spared if captured as a matter of course.
Their hands bore the blood of all whom their soldiers killed in the many battles over which they presided.
Basara’s personal feelings may not be enough to spare his life, and she also needed to take caution for her own safety.

Over the days of travel, she never once mentioned her connections to Tolmyur, Jethro, and now Byurk, all sources of this group’s suffering, and those connections would likely become known in their discussion with Byurk.
Shortly after Basara’s questioning of Chloe and Justin finished, Byurk marched slowly up the road with eight human rangers behind him.
Not one of his men in formation had survived Chloe’s ruthless assault.
At least this meant she would not have to convince Tyree to treat the injured.
Thanysa and Hethyro stood guard before the camp with one of the elves, but Byurk did not approach.
Instead, he bowed his head to the ground.
Basara walked out to meet him and then escorted him to the camp where Benab bound Byurk’s wrists to his ankles behind his back.
Byurk was forced to kneel before Kiri, Justin, and Basara while two elves pointed spears at his back.
Chloe sat off to the side between the exchange, the gown she borrowed from Basara billowing in her radiating heat that melted the snow around her.
Chloe’s wrath was palpable, but she did not lash out and remained as composed as Justin.
Perhaps the woman had more control over her maenad impulses than Basara thought.
When Basara was Chloe’s age, Jethro often had to lock her in a barrier the moment something set her off until she calmed down.
Kiri led the interrogation as sponsor and leader of the party.
“General Byurk, Basara tells me that you are fully willing to cooperate in any way we demand.
Is that true?” She emphasized the word “any” to make certain he understood that his life depended on his full cooperation.

“I cannot reveal critical information that could potentially endanger the Tolmyur Kingdom, even under pain of death, but as for my involvement here in the wilderlands and the campaign in Vallen, I am willing to speak.”
Kiri stared down Byurk.
Secrets of the Tolmyur Kingdom would benefit her little now that the fairies lost in Vallen, so Basara hoped Byurk’s reservations were acceptable.
She did not want to see her friend executed, and being a maenad, witnessing such an act might set her off and endanger the party.
Perhaps informing Kiri of their connection was the safest route.
“Before we continue,” Basara cut in, “I must inform you that Byurk and I are former companions and fought together for Tolmyur in the Coastal War back in my mercenary days.
For your safety and the safety of your party, I must warn you that, as a maenad, I do not believe my emotions could bear watching his torture or execution.
He has promised me his cooperation as a friend, so I implore that you trust that promise.”
Kiri glared at Basara, now realizing that her party had been at the mercy of a guide with direct connections to the generals of Tolmyur.
“Do not fault her,” Byurk pleaded.
“Basara abandoned Tolmyur two years ago and has made no attempt at communication since.”
“I will leave the matter of whether or not I can believe your claim and trust that our guide is true for later.
General Byurk, what is your exact mission here in the wilderlands.”
“To pursue the party that fled Revlan, your party, and if possible, find the widow of Emperor Yuro.
My mission was given as punishment for my failings in Revlan in letting her escape from me once again.”
Justin tensed beside Basara, the knuckles of his fists growing white atop his lap.
He understood more of the conversation in Elven than Basara previously assumed.
Perhaps his conversation skills only lacked.
Basara understood Byurk’s mission.
“The one who gave you this mission was a higher ranked general.
He disapproves of Byurk’s failure and so he gave him a mission he could not possibly complete.
His goal is not so much the capture of Ceil but Byurk’s possible death in the wilderlands.
Byurk’s soldiers are ill-equipped for such a task.
Suicide missions are not uncommon for commanders in Tolmyur to regain honor lost in battle,” she explained to Kiri.

“Kiri, daughter of Thorn General Dharin, Royal Chief Advisor of Vallen, it was by my order against the demands of General Bregon to cease the battle across the ravine for a final attempt at negotiation to spare what remained of your people in Revlan.
Like my futile attempts to move the conflict away from Dhuillir to prevent the involvement of the dryads, the genocide of your people was never my aim, but I was duty-bound to continue the campaign.
Thrice I tried convincing Ceil to surrender herself to end the slaughter, not just for my own desire to end the war but for the sake of those who should never have been part of it.
The ancestral feud is between Tolmyur and the elves, not all races under the empire’s banner.”
“And yet your commanding general has chosen to involve us nonetheless,” Kiri replied, refuting Byurk’s meager plea of goodwill.
“I cannot speak of Jethro’s reasoning in all of this.”
Basara’s heart sank.
She felt she could speak for Jethro, because she knew what happened.
“It is as I feared.
Jethro has gone mad.”
Byurk glared at Basara.
“You can only see his actions from the outside, but know that while you fled from the tribulations of the people of Tolmyur, Jethro has worked tirelessly for their benefit.”
A fire lit within Basara, and she fought to contain it before it erupted out of her control.
Kiri and Justin felt Basara’s radiant heat and readied to distance themselves if needed.
“My allegiance was never to Tolmyur,” Basara retorted, half shouting.
“When I left, it was not Tolmyur I abandoned but Jethro to his madness.

If I had known what he would become and that he would not hesitate to plunge this world into chaos in pursuit of the life of a single terrified girl, I would have killed him there in Tolmyur’s archives and burned the history of your nation’s ire against the elves down with him.”
“Basara,” Kiri reprimanded.
Basara took several deep and troubled breaths.
Eventually her temperature regulated, and the flame cooled to embers.
She was dangerously close, and there was none here save maybe Chloe who could have protected everyone from her emotional rampage.
“You see it too, Byurk.
In your desire not to involve the dryads or unjustly punish the fairies, you know Jethro is lost.”
“What is Jethro’s aim in seeking the life of Empress Ceil,” Kiri asked to redirect the topic back to gaining information from their prisoner.
She had a lot of questions about Basara’s involvement with Jethro, but that would need to wait for another time and place.

“He seeks the extermination of the royal line, to eliminate the family of the one to whom his anger is most directed, Eydis FeAmel, and by doing so, prepare the way for Tolmyur’s eventual recovery from the crimes of the elves in generations past.
The Tolmyur Kingdom, the nation of the minums, predates the Amelian Empire by thousands of years.
The creation of your empire led to the destitution of my nation through no fault of our own.
So long as your empire stood and their prejudices remained, so long as your empire had the slightest chance of being reborn, Tolmyur would continue to suffer.

Tell me, Royal Chief Advisor Kiri, in your desire to fight to the very last fairy in protection of one whom you call Empress Ceil, was it out of a desire to protect a terrified girl pursued by an entire nation or was it with the hope of reviving your empire with little care to the girl’s own wishes on the matter.”
Kiri raised her hand, and the two elves pressed Byurk’s face into the frigid mud with the hafts of the spears crossed over his neck.
Basara feared Byurk’s execution would soon follow and almost intervened, but Kiri’s hand lowered.
The spears eased off Byurk’s neck, and he was allowed to kneel once more.
Kiri smiled, almost laughing.
“You are ignorant of the truth of what is happening.
The extermination of the fairies is but a trifle thing compared to the life of Empress Ceil.
I do not protect her because of duty to a fallen empire or familial obligation.
I protect her because the very beings who observe and oversee not only this world but countless worlds in the infinite cosmos have demanded it of me.
Should Empress Ceil die, Whinhlem may be doomed.”
Byurk’s eyes widened and shot between Justin and Chloe.
“Then these otherworlders…”
“Perhaps you are not as ill-informed.
Yes, these two not of our world are like Empress Ceil, protected by the sprites, and you in your ignorance you have killed one of them, which very well could spell disaster for us all.”
“The controller of the habha…” Byurk’s eyes stared into nowhere in front of him as he made connections in his own mind.
His lips parted, and in nothing but a whisper, he spoke, “Then Jethro is…” in his native tongue.
Byurk’s words bridged the same connection in Basara’s mind.
“Kiri, if what you claim is true, there is something you should know.
Jethro is not of our world, not of Whinhlem.
He comes from a world he calls Trattnou.”
Kiri’s haughty attitude vanished in an instant, replaced by the shock of what might be the worst possible revelation.

The conversation in Elven was terribly difficult for Chloe to follow, but she felt eternally grateful to Benab for personally tutoring her over their days of travel in the wilderlands out of his desire to communicate with her.
She understood enough.
The revelation about Jethro brought a terrifying curiosity to her mind that for a moment replaced her rage against Byurk.
“Ephora or Arkhon, are you listening,” Chloe called up into the sky, confusing the others who could not understand her words.
After a moment of silence, she called again.
The silhouette of a small figure appeared in the center of the group.
Because Justin shied away or perhaps did not want to look at or acknowledge her, Chloe knew this was Ephora.
The others grew astonished at the sudden appearance of a sprite.
“You have a question?” Ephora asked.
“Although I have a feeling that I know what it is, and you will not like the answer.”
“Is Jethro like Ceil, Justin, and me?
Is he important to whatever disaster that’s going to come?”
Ephora smiled.
The advent of the calamity was nearly upon them, but she could not reveal this without endangering the sprites’ foresight.

Revealing the time would create such a distortion that it may take a hundred years for the Sprite’s foresight to become accurate once more, instead of a manner of minutes, hours, or days as their former involvement had done.
She reasoned that she could, however, answer Chloe’s question, because that information had already been revealed to some.
At the worst, it would only cause a few days of blindness, a risk she felt justified to prevent them from taking any undesired or dangerous actions.
She turned to all who stared and spoke into their minds in their own native languages.
“Like Ceil, Jethro is important not only to the survival of your world but that of other worlds.
If Jethro dies, billions of lives may be lost.”
Without another word, Ephora vanished.
Her final statement was the worst news for Justin, Chloe, and all those in opposition to Jethro.
For Basara and Byurk who both knew of Jethro’s tenacity and madness, the problem was even greater.
They had to convince Jethro to spare Ceil.
If not, they had to somehow stop him without killing him.
For all Jethro’s apparent reason or lack thereof, neither of them knew if he would stop his attempts to kill Ceil knowing that countless lives could be lost should he succeed.
After all, he willingly ordered the genocide of the fairies--millions of lives--for his goals.
Chapter 10
“The Path of Least Resistance”
Ceil
The cold winds of the mountains were nothing compared to the gusts of the plains.
The mountain winds chilled Ceil, but these constant violent winds nearly swept Ceil off her feet, and the chill cut her through her cloak to her core.
She felt naked in a storm despite her armor and many layers.
Coby huddled close, guarded under her cloak because the winds were too much even for him.
The first day across the plains he managed with his wind magic directing the wind around him, but by the second day he could not keep his ven levels high enough to continue.
The winds peeled his wings open and threatened to pull him away into the unknown.
Her cloak could barely hold them both, but Ceil could not trust Zose or the others to care for Coby the same way.
Zose had already chastised her for attempting to save him from the Lurr wolf, so she did not doubt that they would abandon him to the winds in an emergency.
“Burster incoming,” Dyson shouted.
Ceil glanced upwind to the snowless sky and saw the clouds in the distance roll like an inverted wave approaching at incredible speed.
She immediately dropped to the ground with Coby under her and buried down as far as she could into the snow.
Zose dropped next to her and clung tight to her cloak.
No more than a few seconds later a deafening wind roared over her that peeled away the top layer of snow and nearly her along with it.
Coby cried in protest at being smothered, but Ceil only held him tighter in fear.
The burster only lasted a minute, much shorter than any previous.
Zose rose and lifted Ceil and Coby from the snow, brushing off her cloak so that the ongoing wind wouldn’t freeze the snow to her.
Coby rustled under her cloak in irritation, so Chloe stroked his feathers to calm him down.
The last thing she wanted was for him to peel her cloak open in frustration and be carried away.
“Could we not have taken the road,” Ceil protested for the umpteenth time.
The road meandered through the various trenches and ravines across the plains to protect travelers from the winds.
Zose claimed his route was much faster, but Ceil could not see how with how often the bursters appeared.
“How do you even know where we are going?”
Zose pulled Ceil forward without a word, so she did not know if he heard her over the deafening wind.
“A trick we learned from the lycon,” Zose eventually shouted back.
He stood and angled himself so the wind directly hit his side.
“The winds always follow parallel to the plains, so if you walk perpendicular to them, you will eventually reach the Nuafonen range.”
“If you are accustomed enough,” Dyson continued from just behind Ceil, “you can angle yourself to the wind and count your paces to chart a specific course.
Zose has a pass he uses through the Nuafonen that he learned from the lycon.
He is taking us there.”
“It will bring us closer to Sen’uon than the pass the main road travels through Nuafonen,” Zose finished.
Ceil welcomed a fast route, but she did not know how much longer she could last.
Zose was not so much leading her as he was pulling her along.
She was sore and tired, not just from the cold but from fighting the wind for the past three days.
She wanted to stop and rest, to set camp, but that would be impossible unless they reached a ravine.
As far as Ceil could see, the plains were a perfectly flat, white expanse until the horizon or at least until distant snow or frozen humidity in the wind cut off further visibility.
Only a few barren trees sparsely dotted the landscape giving it some character.
It almost made her miss the home of her childhood.
She could imagine that in the summer when the snow was gone and the winds were milder these plains were covered with golden grass not unlike the never-ending grain of Filinceil.
“Burster,” Jeddin shouted this time.
Ceil half-moaned, half-whimpered as she dove again into the snow.
This burster lasted far longer than the former, burying Coby and her under a drift of snow.
Ceil collapsed in the shelter of the crevice of a rock as Dyson lit a fire for camp.
Coby hopped around full of energy to rid himself of the irritation he felt being smothered over and over again for the third day in a row.
Ceil hated that he had so much energy.
She more or less had carried him under her cloak all day without food.
They could only spare time to eat when they set up camp, and they only set up camp in the evening before they slept for the night.
A light meal in the evening and a heavy meal in the morning were all Ceil had to build her energy for an entire day of fighting unrelenting winds and deathly cold.
“Cheer up, Gein,” Dyson said as he moved some heated stones next to Ceil.
She immediately grabbed them and held them to her core.
“Once we pass the Hemenonan, the temperature will get much warmer.
You might even start missing the cold.”
Preposterous, Ceil almost spat back at him.
Dyson only laughed with his small-fanged grin, seemingly predicting what Ceil wanted to say.
“If you want to warm up faster, I could always hold you.
Maybe take me up on the offer to show me your consort skills?”
Ceil scowled at him.
She could not believe that diluting troll blood with humans could create something so debonair, but his unwanted advances were a never-ending source of irritation for her.
Once their campfire roared, Ceil left the crevice and joined Jeddin and Dyson by the fireside.
Zose was out keeping first watch.
He assured them that so long as he was there, they would have little issue with lycon, but there was still a risk.
At least knowing that Lurr feared Ceil, there was even less risk of one lurking in the ravine attacking them.
“How many more days,” Ceil asked to break the silence.
“Until we are off the plains or until we reach the Afarit?” Dyson asked.
“Two on the plains,” Jeddin answered, “and then another three until Sen’uon.
If we are lucky, we can find a spatial mage there to teleport us to the Afarit.
Otherwise, it will be another ten days after that.”
“There is a major issue, though,” Dyson continued.
He pointed at Ceil.
“You.
Sen’uon is the second largest city in the whole of the wilderlands, and it is run by Lurr.
It’s not like Hen’anin where Lurr simply live together with others.
Lurr rule that city.”
“I wish we could avoid it, but that is simply not possible,” Jeddin said.
“Coby could fly me over the city.
I could meet you on the other side,” Ceil suggested.
“Zose will never agree to that,” Dyson rejected.
“You are his charge, and he would never part from you.
The Lurr flee at the sight of you, so we should be safe simply passing through.
Although we would have to abandon any hope of finding a spatial mage.”
“No, I feel Gein’s plan is the best course of action,” Jeddin said as he added to the fire another strange coal from the satchel traded to them by Pyn, making it roar once again.
“It would be best to avoid Sen’uon altogether.
I will convince Zose.”
Ceil heard a high-pitched whistle from up the ravine.
Shortly afterwards Zose descended to the camp.
“Lycon parties are out tonight,” he said while pocketing a small, thin brass whistle.
“What was that whistle?” Ceil asked, slightly panicked.
“Would that not give us away?”
“The opposite of what you think,” he replied.
“It tells them I am a friend and to not mind us.
They likely already noticed the glow of our fire here in the ravine long ago.
We might get a visit, which is why I am informing you.”
Ceil was about to tell Zose her plan for Sen’uon, but Zose quickly returned up the ravine after relaying his message.
“You are lucky to have Zose as a guide,” Dyson said once Zose was out of sight.
“Very few gain favor with lycon.”
“The whistle is gifted by the lycon,” Jeddin elaborated.
“The pitch of each is distinct to the one gifted.
A personal article is given in exchange, and the lycon distribute it so all the tribes remember the scent.
When a whistle is blown, a lycon commonly appears if in the area to make certain the pitch matches their memory of the scent.
If it does not, the tribes rally to kill the imposter and reclaim the whistle.”
“If one of us had blown Zose’s whistle and a lycon visited, we would be ambushed by no less than a hundred lycon before morning,” Dyson finished.
“Kill one with a whistle, and the lycon treat it as killing one of their own.”
“How does one gain the lycons’ favor,” Ceil asked.
“You must save the life of one of them without thought of reward,” Jeddin replied.
“Beastkin are despised by most, and I am no different in my feelings towards their ilk.”
“Many have tried to play the lycons’ favor, creating or searching for situations where they could save a lycon’s life.
All have ended in failure and the death of the fool who tried.
They appear as kin of beasts, but they are no less intelligent than you or I,” Dyson continued.
“How did Zose gain their favor then?”
“I do not know,” Jeddin admitted.
“You had best ask him.”
“It is because he saved a young lycon when completing one of his contracts,” Dyson answered.
Ceil’s eyes widened in astonishment.
She could imagine the situation was not all that different from how she met Zose.
She felt it odd that he would go to such lengths to help her like this, but perhaps Zose was such a person.
“It happened like this.
A small group of bandits had made a camp in a steep ravine, well-hidden and nigh impervious to assault.” Dyson leaned into the fire and cleaved the flame in two with his hand.
There it held in its new position as Dyson gathered smaller flames to sit along the cloven slopes.
“Travelers, hunter mercenaries, and merchants alike fell prey to ambush.
They left none alive.” He removed a fresh coal from their provisions and moved it slowly between the flames.
All at once the smaller flames dove onto the coal setting it alight.
Dyson dropped it into the other coals, and the fire resumed its natural shape.
“If they left none alive, how did anyone learn of the bandits?
And don’t waste the coals,” Jeddin admonished.
“That’s the key to the tale,” Dyson replied.
“People were disappearing somewhere between two villages.” Dyson raised his hand towards the top of their ravine in the direction of where Zose kept watch.
“Zose took the contract that no one else dared to claim to investigate the disappearances.
People feared that a powerful chimera was at fault.
The terrain was rocky, so an oread was the best choice--the only choice.
Had they sent a larger hunter party, the bandits would never show.
Any other small party would fall prey like all the others.
“Zose travelled the pass like all the former victims, but when the ambush happened, he vanished.
None of the bandits knew how and why.
They searched for a time but eventually returned to their camp.
Little did they know, Zose followed them within the rocks.
That was how Zose found the base.
That was how he found the victims.
“The bandits were a terrible sort, cannibals with refined tastes.
Not Lurr, if you could believe.
Zose never expected to find the victims alive, but there was little remaining of them.
There was only one sole survivor, a lycon child chained by her neck to a tree.” Zose wrapped the strap of his bag around his neck and pulled it taut.
“Zose thought her dead at first, a possible meal for later, but lycon were not for their tastes it seemed.
They made sport of her, tossing rocks and knives and whatever small objects fell into their grasp when the urge arrived.”
Dyson spoke with the melodic flair and gesticulation of a practice storyteller, enrapturing Ceil.
His storytelling enveloped her, and she yearned to hear more, although she hid her desires under her tired expression.
“Zose quickly and quietly eliminated the bandits while they slept as an assassin who could swim unseen through stone.
He rescued the lycon child and nursed her back to health in secret at a nearby village.
Not wanting to leave her to become prey to others, he brought her to the same storm-tossed plains we now travel and found a lycon pack to take her in.
“The girl wanted to gift him a whistle then and there with the goodwill of the pack, a reward for his heroism, but Zose declined.
His claim: that he had no proof for them that his rescue was out of goodwill or if his sole desire was safer passage over the plains.” Dyson pressed his hand to his forehead in feigned astonishment.
He shook his head and continued the tale.
“He left them stunned and returned home.
A later contract sent Zose between the Nuanae and Nuafonen once more.
A large pack built of four tribes hunted him down, trapping him on the road through the many ravines.”
Dyson’s voice bled urgency as his rate of speech accelerated.
Ceil’s heart beat with anticipation.
“He could simply escape by stepping into the stone as he did with the bandits,” Jeddin interrupted.
“Let me guess, the pup was among them and presented him with the whistle, not giving him the option to refuse.”
“Don’t spoil the end,” Dyson rebuked, now back to his regular manner of speech.
He pushed Jeddin’s shoulder hard enough to topple Jeddin over.
Ceil felt deflated that the tale ended so abruptly.
She could hardly remember the last time she had any entertainment, and she was loathed to admit that Dyson’s charisma only made her desire it more.
“Could you not see I was winning Gein over?” Dyson moaned.
“Is the story true,” Ceil cut in, wishing she had not heard that last statement.
“It is,” Dyson replied.
“Zose told me the tale when I went drinking with him and Basara not long after he returned with the whistle.
It was just last summer, shortly after Emal was born.
You could always confirm it if some lycon do happen to visit us tonight.”
As soon as Ceil was sufficiently warmed from the fire, sleep took her readily.
If there was a visit that night, no one woke her, not even Coby.
The next morning Ceil could barely find the will to hike out of the ravine back onto the wind-tormented plains.
Another day of trudging through snow drifts ranging from her calves to her hip in frigid, endless flatlands.
By midday, she was more frustrated by the bursters than afraid of them.
Her mantra of “only one more day” was all that kept her moving, that and Zose’s tight grip on her wrist pulling her onward.
She did not even want to think about the plains on the other side of the Nuafonen range.
Zose never told her if they were the same.
She could not bear the thought that they were similar or worse.
“Burster!”
Ceil dove into the shallow snow and covered Coby the best she could to wait out the violent winds.
Something snagged Ceil’s cloak by her neck and ripped her from the snow.
She tumbled at incredible speed at the mercy of the burster unable to tell up from down, screaming with her eyes shut tight out of fear.
A solid impact, and everything went dark.
A lycon shot like lightning towards their party in the burster.
Zose noticed too late, and Ceil was ripped from his grasp.
In the fraction of a second it took for Zose to lift his head, Ceil and her captor were nothing but a black dot in the distance and growing ever smaller.
He pulled out his whistle and blew it as hard as he could, hoping that the lycon could hear it and know they were not enemies.
Coby flapped up in confusion, the wind of his wings just barely cutting through the lingering burster.
He rose into the air and spotted the shrinking speck in the distance now mostly obscured by drifting snow caught in the high winds.
With a great flap of his wings, he shot after Ceil.
Zose removed his cloak and grabbed the far corners in each hand.
His cloak unfurled, and the burster caught it, ripping him from the snow and dragging him speedily away.
He prayed he could reach her before ill befell her.
She was the smallest of their party and inexperience on the plains.
The lycon must have thought that she would be easy prey.
At least the wind blew him the exact same direction it blew her.
The speck in the distance slowly grew.
Zose could see Coby fluttering around in the air just above, attacking the lycon.
The lycon pinned Ceil to the snow with one arm while brandishing a crude sword at Coby with the other.
Coby’s blades of wind could not hit without fear of striking Ceil, so he dove and attacked with his talons in a frantic, aggravated assault.
The burster died, allowing Zose to right himself, and held both ends of his cloak in one hand to let it pull him instead of drag him.
He blew the whistle, now close enough that the lycon would surely hear it, but the assault in the distance did not end.
Zose blew his whistle again but soon noticed something peculiar about this lycon.
The left ear atop the lycon’s head was missing.
He snarled at Zose’s approach with his hairless, almost wolf-like face.
This lycon did not respect the whistles.
It was an aberrant or outcast of the tribes.
Zose released his cloak, letting the wind carry it away, and drew his twin blades.
Instead of preparing for a confrontation with Zose, the lycon grabbed Ceil under his sword arm and fled over the snow, half using his free hand as another leg to move faster.
Even with the wind’s aid, Zose had no hope of catching him.
Coby continued trying to grasp and claw at the lycon, but even he did little to impede the lycon’s flight.
Once the next burster arrived, Zose did not doubt that he would lose Ceil.
He simply did not have the same bestial strength to allow him to control his movements in the burster’s might.
Zose sheathed his swords and blew through the other end of the whistle.
He heard no sound but knew that this distinct tone would pierce through the wind much further than the whistle’s normal tune.
As he chased for another mile, he blew over and over again, glancing upwind behind him both to see if Jeddin and Dyson were following and out of fear of a possible burster.
A shadow approached from the south low along the snow.
It grew into several distinct bipedal forms seemingly running on their hands and feet.
They heard.
A pack of lycon was approaching.
The pack ran ahead and intercepted the fleeing lycon.
Coby flew into the air, not knowing if he should continue attacking or whether these arrivals were friend or foe.
Zose glanced back behind him one last time and saw the rolling clouds.
“Coby!
Burster,” he called as loud as he could.
Coby looked towards him, and the intelligent hawk saw the approaching sign in the clouds.
He dove down into the snow just in time for the burster to blow over them.
The lycon stayed rooted in place against the burster.
They had the rogue lycon and Ceil pinned to the ground.
Zose waited out the burster and then approached once it passed.
Behind him he saw Jeddin and Dyson a ways off far in the distance.
They had ridden the second burster to catch up.
An elder lycon from the hunting party approached Zose.
Behind him, another lycon carried Ceil in his arms.
She looked heavily battered with numerous cuts on her face from the icy snow, but she was alive.
“Is this companion of you,” the elderly lycon asked.
“It is.
Thank you for coming to my aid.” Zose handed his whistle to the elder.
The elder accepted it and reached for Zose.
Zose stepped forward, and the elder embraced him, sniffing Zose’s neck and confirming ownership of the whistle.
When they parted, the elder returned Zose’s whistle.
“No, the debt has been repaid.
I cannot accept it.
I called for your aid, and you answered.
By custom, the whistle should be returned to you.”
“No, this one is our sin,” the elder replied with a growl.
“We hunt him for nine days, and he escape us.
Your bird help us catch him.”
The lycon carrying Ceil set her down beside Zose.
Coby immediately landed and lifted her to sit with his beak, wrapping her within the warmth of his wings.
The lycon watched the strange hawk in admiration.
The lycons’ attention focused behind Zose, and they drew their weapons.
“Wait, those two are my allies,” Zose called quickly.
Dyson quickly ran to Ceil, but Jeddin stayed at a distance, his disgust of the lycon showing on his face.
Dyson’s fire magic quickly warmed Ceil, but she remained unconscious.
“Friend of lycon, we will escort you to safe camp,” the elder announced.
Ceil awoke to the crackling of a warm fire.
Her body ached terribly, and her face and hands stung.
She could hear a heated discussion around her, but Coby’s cry broke it up.
She blinked to clear her vision and saw Zose and Jeddin looking down at her.
Dyson sat frustrated on the other side of the fire.
“How are you feeling,” Zose asked.
“What happened?” Ceil tried to sit up, but she could barely move without pain wracking her entire body.
She stifled the cry that almost escaped and lay back down.
Her inability to move troubled her three escorts.
“You were abducted by one of those beasts,” Jeddin replied.
Zose scowled at him.
He then explained what happened, including that the lycon had saved her.
“I apologize, but without your leave I investigated your injuries thoroughly.
Be assured that neither Dyson nor Jeddin saw.
You are battered, but nothing seems broken that I could tell,” he finished.
Ceil looked up from the camp to the dark sky above the steep ravine, far steeper than their last camp and partially covered by overhanging rock.
A harsh snow was falling, but the high winds kept most of it out of the ravine.
“How long was I out?”
“The sun only just set,” Jeddin answered.
“We are about ten miles off course, but that is not much of a problem.
If that was all, it would only be a minor delay.”
Ceil wanted to ask what also was the problem, but she felt she knew.
“Do you think you can stand,” Zose asked.
Ceil tried once more to sit up, but moving her core sent a surge of pain throughout her body.
She whimpered despite herself and lay back down.
“You are in no shape to travel,” Zose announced.
“We can rest here for another two days to give you time to recover, but after that we will need to move if we want our supplies to last until Sen’uon.
I know your life magic is weak, but do what you can in that time.”
“I can carry you on my back to Sen’uon,” Dyson offered.
“I am the strongest among us.
We can seek treatment for you there.”
“No, because of Gein’s injuries, we will avoid Sen’uon and seek treatment for her at the Afarit.”
Dyson grew livid.
“You cannot seriously be considering following Jeddin’s plan.
Gein needs help, and Sen’uon is only a few days away.”
“It is Gein’s plan,” Jeddin retorted.
