“Dyson, we cannot know how the Lurr will react to Gein in Sen’uon.
Finding help for her may be impossible.
The only life mages we could hire there will be Lurr.
Her injuries place her at even greater risk.
She was almost attacked in Hen’anin.
If they see her injured, more might take the opportunity in their fright.”
“What says our party’s sponsor,” Jeddin asked, glancing down at Ceil.
Ceil wanted to retort that she was not sponsoring the party.

Zose volunteered to help, and Jeddin and Dyson were only helping for their own reasons, but she was their charge, so perhaps it was common to leave such decisions to her to rid them of liability should the worst happen.
They were professionals, after all.
“We avoid Sen’uon,” Ceil decided.
Danger was certainly a part, but for more personal reasons, she did not think she could emotionally endure passing through an entire city that was terrified of her very existence.
Inym huddled in against the wall of a ravine behind an outcrop of rock for a barrier against the wind and snow.
This was the first time since her injury she had attempted to cross the plains.

She could manage the cold with her fire magic for a time, but on her liquid diet, her body could not store enough nutrients to sustain her fire magic for long, even something as simple as regulating her body heat.
She may as well not have a fire affinity at all.
She cursed her ill fortune catching a blizzard shortly after setting out from Hen’anin.
In her healthy years, she could have run the long, winding road and arrived at the pass through the Nuafonen in eight days, blizzard or no.
Now for the sake of warmth, she had spent two days traveling the distance she should have in one.
Inym questioned returning to Hen’anin.
She could never hope to catch Zose now.
Kep hadn’t returned to report, so either that pixie was still monitoring Zose, lost him across the plains, or was having trouble finding her.
Even if Kep came to report, Inym knew that it would be too late to calm the Lurr she had Deinan rile up in preparation for Zose’s arrival at Sen’uon.
Perhaps a city of Lurr could successfully kill that living calamity without the need for Bydrofe’s aid.
She could only hope.
A march from back down the road echoed through the ravine.
Inym peeked out from her cover to see a procession of various races led by a nymph.

The regal Vallen armor of the elves towering over the rest suggested that perhaps they were headed for the Afarit to pay respects to Bydrofe as so many royals usually did, but the longer she watched, the stranger the party appeared.
A fair human and fairy marched behind the nymph accompanied by two dryads.
Behind them the three elves followed.
A minum and line of humans, Tolmyur soldiers, came next with two trolls and an oread taking up the rear.
Why would Tolmyur march with Vallen north through the wilderlands?
“Do not move!”
Inym looked above her to see a sickly looking anthousai with bow drawn.
She never heard the young dryad approach.
“I am not an enemy,” Inym replied with haste, her hands up and palms facing away.
A spriggan Inym had not seen with the procession arrived quickly to pull Inym onto the road.
She was forced to kneel before the nymph guide.
Inym recognized the guide.
“Basara, I am not an enemy,” Inym pleaded.
“What is your name,” Basara asked.
“I am Inym.
I work for Jit.”
Basara ordered the anthousai to lower her bow.
“What is your business alone on the road?
Are you in need of assistance?”
“No.
I am in pursuit of your husband, Zose, and his party.”
The air around Basara heated immediately.
“Why,” she demanded.
“I mean him no harm,” Inym replied quickly, although that was only true now.
She could not tell her folly to Basara, a maenad, without fear of swift retribution.
“I learned of a ploy to use the Lurr against him and his party in Sen’uon to kill the one he escorts.
I was on my way to warn him, but in my health, I cannot reach him in time.
I had Pyn send a tracker after Zose from Hen’anin, but Zose left the road and could not be followed.
If you visited Pyn on your way through Hen’anin, you might have heard similar news of your husband.”
Basara calmed and lifted Inym to her feet.
“Byurk, Kiri,” she called.
The minum and fairy ran to the front.
The minum was clearly a commander of high standing given the markings on his armor visible just between the break in the front of his cloak, and the fairy had a regal air about her.
The elves brandished their spears against the minum as he passed, guarding the fair human.
The two parties were traveling together, but they were not allies.
Basara explained the situation to the troubled expression of the fairy.
“How sure is the road ahead,” Byurk asked.
“Thanysa and I can travel faster than the rest.”
Kiri called one of the trolls from the back of the procession, and Basara once again explained Inym’s warning.
The troll grew even more troubled than had the minum.
“Am I and the minum general to run ahead to protect her?” she asked.
“Yes,” Kiri responded.
“The road weaves, but there are no forks,” Basara explained.
“You will not go astray, but be warry of the shallower ravines.
Keep an eye to the clouds upwind.
When they roll, drop to the ground immediately or you will be carried away.
At the Nuafonen pass, keep left on the road.
The plains beyond are no different, but there are markers, obelisks, leading to Sen’uon.
I pray you make it in time.”
The troll and minum quickly gathered a bag of provisions and then sped down the road with their feet propelled by the earth beneath them.
Inym’s hands trembled.
Both Vallen and Tolmyur were working together to protect the emperor’s widow who, according to her knowledge, was the reason for the war in Vallen.
Why?
Was Tolmyur’s goal not to kill her?
Was that not why Zose was taking her to the titan, Bydrofe?
She was clearly the embodiment of disaster as the Lurrs’ unanimous testimonies made known.
Inym’s frantic thoughts froze as the testimonies of the various Lurr repeated in her mind.
She had thought they claimed she was death, but that was wrong.
Never once did they say the widow was death.
They claimed she carried it.
Death was about her.
Death was in her.
Death emanated from her.
What if the widow only contained the evil within, and if she died that same evil would be released upon the world?
What if killing her was not the goal, but instead Zose wanted to discover with Bydrofe’s aid a means of eliminating or containing the evil she bore?
Inym’s face grew pale.
“Basara, tell me, please.
If that woman dies, if the one Zose is escorting dies, what will happen?”
“Billions of lives could be lost,” Basara replied flatly.
Inym fell to her knees.
She felt sick, nauseous, and had she a stomach, she would have vomited.
She mouthed her lament to the frigid ground beneath her.
I have doomed us all.
Chapter 11
“Life and Death”
Ceil
After two days, Ceil could stand and walk but not without a lot of pain.
Her injuries from tumbling over the frozen plains at the mercy of the burster were far more severe internally than her paltry healing magic could address.
She was hesitant about Dyson carrying her at first, but he was gentlemanly about his handling of her and personally covered her during every burster.
Coby was fine without Ceil’s protection as he was the first day and a half, and that was how long it took them to finally clear the plains and reach the hidden pass through the Nuafonen range.
Ceil never thought she would be so happy to see mountains again.
Zose blew his whistle at the entrance to the pass once clear of the wind’s might.
A figure jumped down from the rocks almost immediately, and Ceil got her first look at a lycon, a beastkin.
The lycon appeared half between a wolf and an elf.
His nearly wolf-like face was hairless, but the rest of his head was covered with thick fur.
Alert canine ears twitched atop his head.
He wore tight leather armor that helped cleave the wind around him, leaving his long, hairy tail fluttering behind.
Lycon digitigrade legs were not unlike a spriggan’s, and had she not seen his head and tail, she might have suspected him of being a spriggan solely from his body shape.
Zose approached, and the lycon embraced him, sniffing his neck.
As ceil waited for the exchange, several lycon appeared from the rocks above the pass.
“Friend of lycon, you may pass.”
Zose beckoned his party to follow, and they entered the pass.
Unlike the Nuanae range, the Nuafonen was much shorter, but the paths were far steeper.
Despite Dyson’s struggle to carry Ceil for the length, they cleared it in a single day.
From Zose’s explanation, this pass was where the Nuafonen range was thinnest.
The pass the formal road traveled would have taken two or three days, most likely three or more with Ceil’s condition.
They made camp on the other side before near-identical plains aside from what appeared to be ruins jutting from the snow in the distance.
They seemed familiar.
As Ceil pondered on them, she made the connection.
They looked just like the ruins rising from the flatlands of western Vallen.
“They are the same,” Jeddin explained in place of Zose who was once again on first watch because they were in lycon territory.
“The topology of the wilderlands does not begin with the Nuanae.
The flatlands of Vallen and the Filinceil plains are a part.
Buried beneath them you will find the same ruins.
You would have seen ruins along the road had we taken it over the plains.
Legends say the land was far less mountainous in ages long past, but the gods grew angry and scarred the continent.
It is believed that the ancient civilization was the cause.”
“Your destination, the Afarit, is at the epicenter,” Dyson added.
“It was the location of the ancient civilization’s capital, a city once larger and grander than any existing in the world today.”
“Is the Afarit a people or a place?” Ceil asked.
“Both,” Jeddin replied.
“It is a name given them by others, although no one can remember whether they were named for the location or the location for them.
They are cousins of us spriggans but more at home in fire wastes than forests.
They are not the ancients, if you were wondering.
No tales have survived of the people from that time as if their history was destroyed with their civilization.”
Ceil heard Zose’s whistle, and Coby cried out in annoyance of it, growing tired of hearing it constantly over the past day.
He trotted over to Ceil and enveloped her in his wings as if to protect her from the beastkin he associated with the whistle.
“Sleep,” Jeddin ordered.
“We will leave at first light.”
Jeddin nestled down for sleep himself because he would replace Zose at next watch.

Dyson was allowed to sleep through the night like Ceil because of his role as her carrier, but despite Jeddin’s order for Dyson to sleep as well, he stayed awake staring out in the approximate direction of Sen’uon far from view, at least until Ceil fell asleep and could no longer watch him.
Bursters were far less frequent between the Nuafonen and Hemenonan, but in exchange the winds were overall faster.
The benefit of Zose’s route was that they could travel perpendicular to or with the wind whereas if they took the road, much of the way to Sen’uon was against the wind.
The distance across the plains was not much shorter than the last, but without needing to wait out constant bursters, they traveled much greater distances in less time.
And without frequent bursters, Coby managed the wind just fine.
For their single camp on the plains, they used ancient ruins, much to Ceil’s relief.
A roof overhead and surrounding walls helped her feel secure for the first night since she left Zose’s home in Ib’nua.
That morning she felt for the first time crossing the plains that she had the energy to set out, if only her injured body was able to carry her.
Only one more day across the plains, a flight over Sen’uon, and then she would finally enter the Afarit.
Her eagerness for the journey to be over made her forget the days of travel that were still needed after passing Sen’uon before reaching the Afarit.
As they crossed the last stretch of frigid plains, the ruins grew in number and density.
Crumbled towers and walls of structures scattered across the plains all buried deep into the soil.
In the distance, a mountain ridgeline rose.
The Nuafonen was steep, but the Hemenonan was steeper still, like a jagged wall created by an impossibly powerful earth mage.
As they neared, Ceil could see the plains rise as if the cliff bent them upwards along its face.
Closer still she noticed ruins protruding from the face of the mountains as if the plains themselves were upheaved into the cliffs.
These ruins were unburied, crumbling off the mountainsides in their steep slants.

She had seen the similarities between the Temple of the Gods in Amel and Revlan, but here she noticed that the crumbling architecture was not too dissimilar to the Amelian Palace, as if the palace was constructed using the ruins of the wilderlands as vague inspiration.
“This is as far as we go,” Zose announced.
“We will send Gein from here.”
Zose led them to shelter among the ruins at the face of the steep mountain cliffs.
A discernable road approached from the east lined with obelisks and then turned up through a ravine in the mountains.
“Sen’uon is just beyond, and if we approach any nearer, Lurr are bound to notice,” he explained.
“They tend not to leave the safety of the mountains.”
“We should travel through the city together,” Dyson protested again after setting Ceil down.
“Why are you so adamant about passing through the city,” Jeddin prodded.
“Because it would be safer,” Dyson half-shouted.
“We have made our decision,” Zose said.
Dyson grumbled and paced around the circular room.
“Then send me to meet Gein on the other side.”
“No,” Ceil refused quickly.
Dyson froze and looked at her, shocked and betrayed.
She did not want to say she lacked trust in him after the days he carried her--quite the opposite--but she could not explain it another way.
She felt conflicted.
While Zose and Jeddin acted professional in all things pertaining to her and escorting her north, Dyson was different.
He was clearly infatuated, and though gentlemanly aside from his annoying flirtatious quips, the difference in treatment he gave her left a lingering feeling of doubt itching in her mind.
“It will take half a day or longer for Zose and Jeddin to catch up, and I do not want to be alone with you for that long.
Please understand,” Ceil finally said.
“Maybe if you were not so persistent in gaining her affection, she would trust you more,” Jeddin chided with a sideways glance.
I do trust him, she wanted to retort, but she swallowed her words.
Zose and Jeddin planned where Coby would carry Ceil with Zose making the final decision and then had Ceil explain the location in detail to Coby.
Jeddin then left for Sen’uon and their meeting point beyond the city.
After some time of pensive waiting, Dyson also left.
“I have business in Sen’uon.
Perhaps I will meet you with Jeddin on the other side.”
Ceil watched Dyson leave with a tinge of regret.
He was accompanying Ceil for her sake without requesting payment.
He went out of his way to care for her, and yet she sided with Jeddin’s plan, her suggestion, over his.
She started questioning whether she had made the correct choice.
As the sun set, the time came for Zose to send Ceil off.
They climbed the steps to the second story of the ruins where the ceiling and walls had long crumbled.
Ceil was bundled and laid in her cloak.
Zose then tied the ends and bound them in cords to give holds for Coby’s talons.
“Make haste,” Zose said as Coby rose into the air with a powerful flap of his massive wings.
Zose readied his supplies, slung Ceil staff over his back, and ran up the road towards Sen’uon.
At the narrow pass, a mob of guards blocked his path.
“Are you Zose,” one of them called, a mostly-troll Lurr of massive stature as if part giant.
“I am,” he replied with anxiety pricking the back of his mind.
“I am sorry, but the Lord of Sen’uon has forbidden your passage.”
It was then that Zose realized he had made a terrible mistake.
Of the few times Ceil had been carried by Coby, this was the worst.
The frozen winds of the high altitudes cut deeper to her core than even the plains despite her bundled layers.
She was painfully curled up on her back and could only look up at Coby above her as she swayed in his grasp.
She could not see where she was going, and the ever-darkening night worsened both her fears and sea-drunkenness.
At least snow was not falling or Ceil would fear Coby might miss their destination.
The swift flight only took an hour, and Ceil counted out every second in her mind.
She finally felt the altitude decrease and regretted not choosing Dyson to receive her on the other side to warm her immediately.
Hopefully he would be waiting for her with Jeddin.
Coby landed a bit harder than Ceil’s injuries could handle because of the curled position she was forced to endure for the hour, and she cried out weakly.
Coby released her and hopped back, picking at the cords with his beak to free her.
Jeddin nudged him away and cut them.
He then unraveled her from the spare cloaks Zose bundled her in to keep her warm, but she quickly covered herself in them again.
Her jaw quivered and her teeth clattered.
She did not know how to use life magic to heat her body because she was never expected to need such magic.
Coby instead enveloped her in his wings.
“F-f-fire,” Ceil begged.
“No, not this close to Sen’uon.”
Ceil cursed Jeddin in her mind, but she understood.
Up the road back towards Sen’uon, Ceil noticed someone running towards them.
She about called to Jeddin in case he had not noticed but then realized it was Dyson.
Relief welled within her, and that same relief showed on Dyson’s face.
“You are safe,” he said, a little winded.
“Why wouldn’t she be,” Jeddin replied, but Dyson could not answer.
“Can you warm Gein?
She is suffering from hypothermia.”
“Of course.” Dyson rushed over and knelt before Ceil.
A pair of glowing red eyes appeared from the rocks in the distance.
“Dyson!” Ceil called but too late.
An arrow struck Dyson’s back quickly followed by a second.
Dyson pushed Ceil to the ground away from him before a third hit.
Coby scrambled out from under Ceil and flapped into the air only to have a net tossed over him from behind.
The one who tossed the net was Jeddin.
“Coby!” Ceil cried.
Jeddin spun and kicked Dyson across the face, sending him crumbling back onto the road.
Without wasting any motion, he stomped Ceil in the stomach.
Her breath erupted from her throat, and she could taste blood in her mouth.
She gasped for the air that her lungs could not find, unable to cry out from the pain of her former injuries.
The Lurr from the shadows walked onto the road, another arrow nocked and ready to fire.
He was too afraid to approach any closer to Ceil.
“Brother, get away from that monster before it gets you,” the Lurr pleaded to Jeddin.
“Deinan,” Dyson spat, blood spilling from his mouth.
“Curse you, Jeddin!
I knew you were scheming!”
The readied arrow fired into Dyson’s chest.
Ceil cried out for him through her winded breath.
“You knew but did nothing?” Jeddin shook his head.
“Deinan said you were snooping.
You were unsure; that is all, so you did not want to create doubt within our party if you might have been wrong.
If you suspected, you should have told Zose.
There are no friends among hunter mercenaries, Dyson.
You are too good-natured.” He glanced down at Ceil beside him.
“This is the widow of Emperor Yuro.
With this woman dead, no one else has to die because of her.”
Ceil recalled in a flash the day she first met Jeddin and Dyson.
Jeddin was close with the elf girl who had been mistaken for her and killed.
From the rocks, more red eyes appeared and crowded the road.
Ceil quickly pulled her knife and began cutting at the net trapping Coby.
Jeddin noticed and kicked Ceil in the side.
The pain was unbearable, and Ceil’s consciousness slipped for a moment.
Coby struggled harder under the net, and when one of his wings had the slightest bit of movement, his wind cut through.
He rose into the air with an enormous flap, drawing the attention of all the Lurr.
“Flee,” Ceil screamed to Coby the best she could.
“Find Zose.”
Coby hesitated but then flew high into the sky the moment the Lurr barraged him with magic.
Nothing could touch him in his ascent.
Jeddin stomped on Ceil again.
“Gein!” Dyson conjured a roaring flame, but the Lurr spriggan grabbed him by his thick hair and carved a knife across his neck.
The fire in Dyson’s hand dispersed, and he was kicked to the road.
The Lurr swarmed.
Ceil watched in gruesome horror as they slowly tore Dyson apart and devoured him in front of her.
More than terror, Ceil seethed.
Another had died because of her.
She felt the same from his death as she had when she thought Eydis had died in the assassinations.
She felt the same as when she saw Sammy impaled by the spear in Revlan.
She hated that she doubted him when he only ever had her best interests at heart.
She knew his quips about her fictitious consort skills were never meant in earnest.
He had always been true.
The gruesome scene ate at her.
It overwhelmed her, but instead of drowning in sorrow, she wanted to curse Jeddin.
She wanted to kill him.
A swift death would be too kind.
She wanted him to suffer.
Ceil reached for Jeddin’s nearby ankle.
If she could only touch him, she knew that deathly skeletal hand would grant her wish.
“Brother!” Deinan rushed to Jeddin and pulled him away from Ceil with such ferocity that they tumbled to the ground together.
The Lurr’s terrified eyes glowed bright red in the dark, brighter than Ceil had ever seen, enough to tint the frozen earth around her red.
Jeddin separated himself from Deinan.
He looked at the numerous Lurr around the road.
They all had cowered the moment Ceil reached out her hand towards him.
“What did you see?”
“An apparition of death.
The monster reached for you through that woman.
Its presence is powerful.
The sight of it choked my heart, and I felt I was nothing.
No Lurr can stand against that.”
Jeddin eyed Deinan’s cryptic words with doubt.
He had born personal witness to Ceil’s weakness and frailty.
He grabbed Deinan’s bow because his was beside Ceil, but Deinan stopped him.
“No!
The Lord wants her alive, and I fear what might happen if that thing within her is released.”
The ground slowly blackened around Ceil, and as Jeddin watched, the blight grew and extended further.
Stone grew brittle and crumbled.
Plants blackened and turned to dust.
He grabbed a large stone from the roadside.
Ceil glared at him in pure hatred as he threw it at her head.
Kep flitted down from above the road and spun around Jeddin.
“Well, this’s unfortunate.
Are we going to have to negotiate with the Lord of Sen’uon to be able to claim her bounty?
That chimera gives me the creeps.”
“I do not care about the bounty,” Jeddin spat.
“So long as you can assure me that it is collected, you can split my share.”
“You really liked that elf girl from Ib’nua,” Kep chuckled.
“I’ll inform Inym of our success.
Deinan, have the Lurr keep an eye out for Zose.
No number of guards can stop him from entering a city of stone.”
Ceil awoke to powerful and painful shivers, but they were not from the cold.
The air around her and the stone beneath her were quite warm, and after enduring cold for so long the heat wrought havoc on every injured nerve in her body.
Ceil lay on the hard floor able to move but lacking the will to do so, staring at the pointed arch ceiling of an ancient and grand hall.

She could not understand much of the conversation between Jeddin and Deinan, only picking out a few words and phrases that were similar enough to Elven, so she entirely expected to be killed, but instead she lived again while another died.
Her wrath towards Jeddin was gone, replaced by numb emptiness.
She was past feeling now, accepting the reality that so long as she lived others would die because of her.
There was no longer any point in fighting her fate.
There was no longer any point in mourning her fate.
She was done fighting, done resisting, done struggling, hurting, crying, feeling, done living.
A little magic, simple life magic--that is all it would take.
Ceil placed her hand on the side of her head.
It would be painless, peaceful, and then no one else would die.
The Sprite Archon was not here to stop her.
There was no one left alive who would care enough to stop her, at least care enough about her, not her position or identity or what purpose chosen for her that she would accomplish in the future.
No one remained who would stop her for her sake.
But, she couldn’t do it.
Ceil let her hand fall slack beside her head.
She didn’t know if she was just too weak-willed or if in her numbness she simply did not care enough to end her life anymore.
She only stared at the ceiling in the sickly-warm stone room as an unknown number of hours passed by.
The sound of strange steps echoed in the hall, like large bare feet accompanied by scraping and clacking, but the clacking was not from wood or metal.
As the sound neared, Ceil realized that the approaching being was much larger than any elf or troll or giant.
Claws on its feet scraped across the stone at the rise of each step.
Each step was followed by that odd clack, as if someone was walking with two staves.
She could hear the rhythmic thump of a powerful heartbeat.
Ceil opened her eyes out of curiosity to see the monster that might end her life for her.
It was about thrice the length a giant was tall, and its tail was longer still.
It was so gaunt that it appeared as if its smooth hide clung directly to its bones, allowing Ceil to see the shape and pulsing of each organ in its narrow core.
Each of its bony arms had two elbows.
The fore-elbow was bent so that it grasped its own arm with its long fingers.
Protruding from that elbow was a long spike or horn that it used to walk or support its long upper body.
The only loose skin on its body hung from its long neck where at the end sat a sparsely hairy head with strands of long silver hair hanging and dragging on the floor.
Its face was a mix of all races from elf to human to beastkin, but its jaw split into three distinct mandibles.
The moment she looked at it, she felt as if its very presence pressed her into the floor.
There was an immense weight in its glowing red eyes.
This was a chimera, but not just any chimera.
Ceil did not know how she knew, but this being was ancient.
The chimera’s neck elongated, stretching the sagging skin taut, and brought its head near.
It looked Ceil over, inspecting her from many angles.
Its breath was pleasant, like freshly tilled soil ready for sowing.
She was not scared.
Ceil reached up for the hope of death that it brought, but the moment her fingers extended, the creature vanished.
Ceil blinked her eyes, wondering if she had seen a phantom or illusion.
For the first time since she woke up in the grand hall, she lifted her head to look around.
Thin, pointed arch windows along its length glowed with the radiant orange of flame, both lighting and warming the hall.
She had not cared to notice before, but the grand hall was exquisite.
It was not a throne room but possibly a banquet hall cleared of all furnishings.
Although antiquated, the architecture bore similarity to the halls of the Amelian palace.
It only lacked the intricate elven carvings and over-embellished Amelian flair.
She spotted it--or him, now that she saw him in full view.
His hands no longer gripped his arm but clung to the far corner of the ceiling like an insect.
This creature had jumped to the ceiling so quickly her eyes could not see it.
Once again, his neck elongated to about twice the length of his sizable body, worming in the air as he inspected Ceil from a distance this time.
He did not show fear of her like the other Lurr.
She was not sure if she could correctly interpret his expressions, but he seemed curious of her.
“Am I to be your breeding bed,” Ceil asked, voicing the sole worry on her mind of a fate worse than death.
“She speaks,” the chimera answered.

“I worried that your head injury may have ruined your mind and I could get no answer to your existence.” His voice was deep but smooth, an impossible feat, Ceil thought, for one without a common mouth and lacking a tongue.
As he spoke, his three mandibles did not move, but his long throat undulated, somehow perfectly mimicking the sound of speech.
“I have no more need of offspring, and the one behind you would never let me touch you.
We repel each other--opposites, he and I.”
“He?” Ceil tried sitting, but her core burned with pain, so she remained laying on the hard stone floor.
“Are you not aware?
Have you not seen the apparition that you bear, the very Aspect of Death?”
“You can see it?” Ceil asked, surprised.
“A grim skeletal form of a man, human.”
Ceil’s heart raced, and she forced herself to sit despite her pain.
“It is human?
Did they curse me with this?”
“I have devoured countless over the ages, so many that I can no longer endure the taste of flesh.
I know the bones of all races.
Yes, he is human, but of an ancient kind, an ancestor, one of the first civilization in whose ruins we now reside.”
“The ancient civilization was human, not elf?” Ceil was taught in the palace that high elves were the eldest race.
Then again, they never taught that Amel once belonged to the humans before they were driven out into Tolmyur.
“Yes.” The chimera climbed down slowly from his corner of the ceiling and crawled his lanky body across the floor.
Although he approached, he kept his extended face from Ceil.
“Yes,” he repeated.
“A civilization emboldened by the power of their god-king, Surmal, to commit the greatest of atrocities, to kill the gods that created them.
Their king was no god but a man who had obtained the secret to immortality--a task all too simple for the pride it gave him--and he used his long life across the ages to amass power.
But he was not content, no.
He delved into taboo, seeking out the knowledge of countless other worlds to further his power, and when warned to cease by the two gods of this world, he turned his power against them.
He did not know that the created could never harm their creator, for such is natural law.
The gods punished him and destroyed all he had built in his long, ageless life, creating what you now call the barren wilderlands from what was once the most fertile of all Whinhlem.
He was not without some success, however, for even though he could not harm his creator, he ripped the other from godhood, and in so doing was killed for his crime before he could kill the god.”

Ceil had thought that Jeddin’s tale about how the ancient people angered the gods was just a fable, but now hearing the same tale from one who was just as ancient or possibly more ancient than the past civilization, the story could not be a lie.
Perhaps Jeddin learned of it because his brother was a Lurr living in Sen’uon.
“Who are you?”
“I am Ni’inca Ab’pul, the first of my kind to be brought to Whinhlem by my creator when my former world collapsed.
All the Lurr of Whinhlem are my descendants.”
If not for the knowledge that Sammy and her companions were from another world, Ceil would not have believed what she heard.
If this chimera was not of Whinhlem, what was her connection to him?
Why was this ancient human attached to her, and what made them opposites?
She asked.
“I do not know why such an apparition possesses you, and that is what I want to learn, if possible.
Your existence is an anomaly.
Lurr was my creator, and so I gave our kind that name.
Lurr was not of the corporeal, not of physical existence nor elemental.
Lurr was a concept taken form unto itself, given will of itself, an embodiment, an Aspect of Being.
You carry with you the Aspect of Death, but Lurr was the Aspect of Life, a godly existence of purpose to find the means to surpass the limits of creation.
By the very air and stone that slowly withers around you, your sole purpose is the end of creation.
Should you linger in my lands for long, I do not doubt the very land would grow barren and die.”
The three-year famine of the Filinceil plains…
Events of Ceil’s past found connection in the chimera’s words.
That famine began shortly after she was born and her family moved to Heivleil and lingered for over a year after she was brought to the Amelian palace.
All those towns that suffered, all those who starved and died, it was because she was there.
Those words now affirmed what Ceil had felt all along: so long as she lived, others would die.
“Kill me,” Ceil begged.
“I am too weak to do it myself.
Please kill me!”
“The Aspect of Death is bound to you, and as you weaken its presence grows stronger.
Its purpose is the end of all creation.
I know not how or why, but bound to you its effects are limited.
You are its prison.
I fear what may happen should your death release it.”
Each time the apparition took action, it always acted through her hand or other form of contact, similar to life magic.
The chimera’s words bore an immense weight.
Ceil wanted to die to end the deaths that would inevitably continue because of her existence, but should she die, the Aspect of Death could cause even greater destruction.
Ceil had no tears to cry.
She laughed a numb, empty laugh.
The Sprite Arkhon was just as ancient as this Chimera.
He had his foresight.
He knew everything about her already.
She finally understood the title the sprites bestowed upon her, the Herald of Calamity.
She had no choice but to exist as a plague upon the world.
“What will you do with me if I cannot die, cannot stay, and cannot be used for breeding?
Are you going to set me free?”
“Others seek your life, and that is a greater immediate threat than the harm your presence will eventually cause Sen’uon.
I have an army of Lurr under my command.
Those who pursue you will not have you, and your friends will not take you from the safety of my halls.
The chimera vanished down a corridor to the right of the hall as quickly as when he jumped to the corner of the ceiling.
You are my prisoner until a time I can learn how to deal with the Aspect of Death within you.”
Ceil knew Zose and Coby would be looking for her, and should they encounter this Chimera, they would be killed before they ever saw his approach.
There was nothing she could do to stop him.
Ceil collapsed to her back and stared up at the grand hall’s ceiling.
Chapter 12
“The Guarded Lurr City of Stone”
Traveling against the wind on the last day on the plains proved nigh impossible for one of Byurk’s stature.
Even with upheaved stone boosting each step, the blustering gales threatened to carry him back down the road the other way if he so much as lost the slightest focus or misstepped.
Numerous times Thanysa had to grab his cloak to root him.

By midday, Byurk devised a plan to use a thin wedge of stone to cut the wind around them, and together they shared the burden of pushing the wedge trapped in the tight confines with Thanysa standing over him.
They progressed faster with their combined magic, but the exertion of earth magic was no less exhausting.

No doubt Thanysa would have wished for Byurk to be carried away by the winds across the plains into the unknown to die in the frozen wilds, especially after conquering and purging her city, but she never brought up the topic nor let her inner ire show on the surface.
She was a soldier devoted to her obligations, never letting personal feelings hinder the rescue of the widow of the emperor, and Byurk respected her all the more for it.
Byurk knew he would ultimately be punished for his role in Vallen, but until that day came or he found means to avoid it, he felt he could trust Thanysa as much as any one of his men.
Once inside the ruins sloping up the steep mountain face, Thanysa requested pause in the windbreak so they could recover energy and ven.
The narrow pass up into the mountain was in sight, and they would be upon Sen’uon soon.
Without knowing what they might encounter in a Lurr city, Thanysa wanted to be prepared.
Byurk hunkered down in the corner of a small crumbling abode and removed his sack of provisions.
He handed Thanysa a strip of dried meat, and she in turn passed him the water skin.
The water was warm--Thanysa kept the water skin under her armor close to her core--so it helped take the edge off the chill.
“Thank you for your assistance against the winds,” Byurk said, handing back the water skin.
Thanysa did not reply or even acknowledge his words, but he expected as such.
“How long do you need to recover your ven?”
“I should be sufficient by evening,” she replied now that the topic of conversation changed to their mission.
“Humans are slower in their recovery.
Do you require longer?”
“Humans are, but minums are not,” Byurk replied, wanting to correct her for her general use of human for all the races of Tolmyur.
“We are not unlike you elves in that respect.”
“Trolls are different than elves,” Thanysa replied mimicking Byurk’s light rebuke.
“We are slower in our recovery, so if you are equal to elves, we should be ready by nightfall.”
Byurk patted the stone to send a pulse to wake Thanysa against the far wall.
The sun had set, and the time for departure arrived.
Thanysa roused quickly, and they set out without a word only a few seconds later.
Approaching a potentially hostile city at night was worrisome, but neither of them wanted to delay.
The widow’s party would have reached Sen’uon five days ago, and if the plot Inym mentioned was real, the widow might already be captured or worse.

Basara held immense faith in her husband’s skill, so she trusted he could protect the girl until they arrived, but when Lurr were involved, there were limits to what one single oread could accomplish.
Thanysa’s night vision was better than Byurk’s but still not as powerful as a spriggan’s.
Byurk’s earth magic was of the school of manipulation, not conjuration, so he could sense the surrounding area through the earth beneath him.
Thanysa could employ both manipulation and conjuration, but her manipulation was much weaker.
At night, Byurk could affectively see better than her.
He hoped that the clouds would thin to let faint moonlight pass through, but he knew that was a fool’s hope.
Like every night previous, the plains were dark.
Byurk followed the feeling of the obelisks lining the road and led Thanysa to the pass.
Neither of them knew what to expect, and Basara never informed them about Sen’uon’s defenses or level of guard.
Thanysa grabbed Byurk by the back of his cloak.
“Something approaches.
Multiple.”
Byurk forgot about one of Thanysa’s senses that far surpassed his, her hearing.
She picked up on someone long before his earth magic.
After a moment of pause, he felt six distinct pairs of footsteps, one quite large.
They did not approach in hostility, at least that he could tell.
Soon there were others.
“Two on the rocks above on the left, three on the right,” he informed.
A deep voice called out from up the pass, but Byurk did not know the language.
He was more familiar with the tongues of the eastern wilderlands.
“We request passage to Sen’uon,” Thanysa called in Elven.
“You travel without light to approach the city,” the voice replied in perfect Elven.
“What business do you have here?”
“The plains have been harsh,” Byurk replied.
“We lost our light on our journey.
We are earth mages, so the stony road is our eyes.”
Firelight lit in the distance illuminating the six bodies.
The one in the center holding the flame was a massive troll as tall as a giant, perhaps a Lurr combination of those two races.
He alone approached.
“You are not of the wilderlands.
What business do you have here,” he repeated.
“We only seek provisions and shelter to recover from the plains as we travel north for the Afarit,” Thanysa replied.
Byurk cursed Thanysa’s ignorance.
The guard was now too close for them to make use of fabrications.
The Lurr raised his unlit hand.
Weapons unsheathed from the rocks above.
Two of the bodies in the distance down the road drew their bows.
“I will ask again.
You cannot lie to a Lurr’s ears.”
Byurk stepped forward.
“Forgive the error of my companion.
She is not of the wilderlands as you say.
My origins are of the eastern wilderlands, but I am familiar with the customs of you and yours.
My commander has placed a bounty on an individual, and I have received word this individual has either passed through Sen’uon or is contained there.
I am here to ascertain the status of that claim.”
The demeanor of the Lurr changed, but in the dark firelight Byurk could not tell if the change was positive.
He spoke the truth, and the Lurr should know.
“You, minum, are from Tolmyur.”
Byurk parted his winter cloak to reveal his Tolmyurin armor and general insignia above his right breast.
He felt this would earn them passage so that the enormous bounty could be claimed, but instead the bodies on the rocks began to move.
“Under orders of Ni’inca Ab’pul, Lord of Sen’uon, all those who desire Ceil, widow of Yuro, are to be repelled or killed whether ally to her or enemy.”
Byurk and Thanysa immediately hardened their bodies.
Arrows flew and bounced off them or got stuck in their armor.
The Lurr troll threw the fire in his hand at Byurk, but he had an earthen wall raised before it made impact.
The mild explosion showered them in shrapnel, and their light vanished.
Three Lurr jumped down from the rock, the red of their eyes barely visible in the dark.
Thanysa conjured two stone blades and parried the swift attack of a Lurr’s sword.
The force of the enemy blade shattered Thanysa’s weapon on second impact.
Byurk was a mage, ill-practiced in martial combat, so he had little choice but to let Thanysa be vanguard.
He hesitated to use his water magic, his highest proficiency, due to the frigid weather.
Should they get wet, they could die of hypothermia.
He was unsure if the more resilient Lurr had the same weakness.
He could not conjure ice due to a difference in his water affinity attunement and specialization.
With only earth manipulation as his available weapon, the support he could provide was limited.
He thrust a spike from the left rock face to impale a Lurr approaching from Thanysa’s flank, but the Lurr dodged it with its superior agility.
Byurk could not see, but it was likely part spriggan or similar.
Byurk felt one of the Lurr troll’s hands touch the ground.
“The large one is charging,” Byurk warned.
He conjured a wall in front of the Lurr just as the Lurr took off.
The wall did not slow down the massive body in the slightest.
All the other Lurr quickly cleared away off the narrow pass.
Byurk readied a spike hoping to impale the Lurr, but he knew the momentum would still send the Lurr straight through them, injured or not.
The road was too narrow to dodge the massive body, and they could not outrun him.
Just as Byurk was about to release the spike from beneath the ground, Thanysa kicked her foot back into the road.
A column of stone several yards in length shot back from under Byurk, launching him into the air.
The last sensation Byurk felt before his feet left the stone was the massive body colliding with Thanysa.
He spun in darkness through the air out of the pass, and the powerful wind immediately caught him.
It blew him east and downward until he collided with one of the many ruins and tumbled onto the frozen ground.
“Every single time,” Byurk cursed, having been thrown again.
He knew immediately his right forearm was broken despite his reinforcement magic, and he had a light sprain in his left ankle, but he survived.
If he had landed on his head and not his arm, he would have been in far worse shape, but he knew he fared better than Thanysa who could never contend with a troll-giant Lurr on her own.
Byurk struggled to his feet ignoring the pain and rushed back towards the pass.
He had flown much further than he thought in the high winds.
He must have caught a burster while in the air.
It took him the better part of an hour fighting against the wind between the ruins to return to the pass.
He felt the surrounding area through the ground to search for both Thanysa and any Lurr who might be searching for him, but he held little hope for her.
She saved him, and he could not comprehend why.
Not far from where the road rose into the narrow pass, Byurk felt the presence of a body lying on the ground off the road.
Given its location in the craggy rock face, it was either dumped there or hiding.
He hurried to the location and found Thanysa barely coherent, so broken that he wondered how she still lived.
He grabbed her and dragged her away from the pass and further potential danger into the ruins far west of the road.
There he laid her and covered her with his cloak.
“Did you escape or were you dumped there,” he asked, needing to know how likely the Lurr would be searching for them.
“Escaped,” Thanysa replied through a blood-seeping mouth.
“I would be devoured otherwise.”
Byurk removed the near-empty water skin from Thanysa’s armor and lifted her head to let her drink and wash out the blood.
“Do not waste it.
Keep it,” she ordered.
“Why would you protect me,” Byurk asked.
“Your life is more important than my own,” Thanysa replied.
“Your status as my enemy and your past crimes are of little importance now.
You, a friend of Jethro and General of Tolmyur, will have a better chance than any to persuade Jethro to spare Lady Ceil.”
Her words hurt Byurk’s pride as a commander of Tolmyur.
He exhaled long and slow.
She was as pure in her devotion to her duty as he had thought.
He could not abandon such valiance.
He checked his small bag of provisions.
“We have food for only a day more, two if rationed.
Basara’s party will arrive in four days at their pace.”
“I need no food or drink.”
“I will not permit you to die here,” Byurk said.
“I will not die.
I will hibernate.
Entomb and insulate me in stone.
In that state my body will heat and protect me from the cold.
I will not need nourishment, nor will I need much air.
Use our remaining provisions and bring warning to our party.”
“You trust me not to escape or take action on my own?”
“Before taking you into our company, Basara promised on her life that your honor could be trusted.
I will hold you to that honor on your Boromek name.”
Byurk cursed Basara as he ran half-carried by the wind back down the road.
He was originally an exile of Tolmyur, last of the noble Boromek house who stood in opposition to the oppressive Tolmyur king.
He was raised from youth by a clan of dwarves in the wilderlands north of the Stollmuk Kingdom.
The dwarves instilled in him a strong sense of honor and taught him to take pride in his people and heritage.
Like Basara, he was once a hunter mercenary with Jethro, lacking the same blind nationalism as the other soldiers and officers of Tolmyur.

While he strongly felt that the Amelian Empire should pay for their betrayal of the humans and crimes against Tolmyur, he also knew that many of the actions taken by Jethro and Tolmyur in this war were unjust.
Given his position, he had to follow through with those orders despite his personal feelings.
Basara saw that in him and must have revealed his past to the Vallen party.
This did not absolve him of his crimes, only showing that with a common aim he could be trusted to his role.
Only now did he realize that this was why he was never bound or treated as a prisoner as they traveled north.
In his ignorance he assumed they simply did not fear him because of Basara and Chloe’s presence, although that still may have been part.
Even though Byurk was Vallen’s enemy, they were not his.
Knowing the true weight of the widow’s life, he was fully prepared to do his part and help the Vallen party in any way he could.
For now, he needed to warn the party about Sen’uon and save that admirable troll’s life.
During camp, Inym often sat far from the three separate groups despite their assurance that she should join them.
She did not want to associate with the Tolmyur soldiers or the Vallen soldiers, and the diverse gathering of races with Basara was even less enticing, mostly because Basara was there.
Inym sat huddled in the rocks of the ravine beside the camp wrapped in a thicker fur cloak given her out of sympathy or perhaps pity.
She drank her meal that was stewed to mush over the fire by the troll soldier.
They were oddly considerate of her.
Right as Inym lay down to sleep for the night, she heard a faint whisper.
She resisted the urge to startle and continued acting as if she was readying to sleep.
“Kep, where have you been,” Inym whispered back.
She could not see Kep and did not worry that others in the camp might.
That pixie was skilled at staying hidden.
“I should ask you the same.
I have been searching for you for four days.
Never thought you would be in this aberrant party.
I passed you three times.
If you were going to use a new cloak, you should have at least worn your old one on the outside.”
“That’s not important.
What happened in Sen’uon?”
“Bad news, or at least another complication.
Lord Ab’pul has taken possession of our target.”
“What of Zose,” Inym asked, worried of what might happen if her plan killed Basara’s husband now that they were in company together.
“He disappeared, but we managed to kill Dyson.”
Inym could not yet breathe a sigh of relief.
“Is the girl alive?”
“I do not know.”
“Did you leave the very second the Lurr claimed the girl,” Inym hissed.
“You should have investigated first.
Are all the stories of your skill fabricated?”
“You are the one who ordered me to return immediately when any unforeseen conditions arose,” Kep replied, unperturbed.
Inym breathed her frustration out her nose.
“I have an unforeseen condition of my own.
The girl’s life is far too grave a risk.
We need to call off the mission and rescue her from Sen’uon.”
Kep left her hiding place among the rocks and flitted down in front of Inym’s face.
Her cheerful demeanor vanished.
“You cannot be serious.
I took this job without pay upfront, flew all over the frozen wilderlands for days on end under your orders, and you want to call it off?
Are you going to be able to pay me for my services, you who have lived the past years in a shack reading postage for Jit?”
Kep looked over Inym’s head to the rest of the camp, her vision lingering on the Tolmyur soldiers.
“You are leading Tolmyur to Sen’uon.
That is why you covered yourself to avoid me.
You never intended on sharing the bounty with any of us.”
“Don’t be foolish.
These soldiers are working with Vallen to save the girl.”
“And you expect me to believe that?” Kep laughed.
“If you will not pay me, perhaps the Lord of Sen’uon would pay well for news of your plan to steal the girl away from him to claim the bounty.”
Kep spun around Inym’s head.
Inym grabbed her knife and tried to cut Kep down, but she had no hope of striking a wind pixie.
“Sorry.
I mean your rescue operation,” Kep jeered, and then she was gone.
“Ancestors curse that pixie,” Inym spat.
She jumped to her feet and ran through the camp for Basara.
The camp was rousing, and Inym thought at first that they had heard the exchange, but their spriggan scout was calling from up the ravine.
Someone was approaching from down the road.
“Byurk,” the scout called.
“Byurk has returned without Thanysa.”
Basara ran out to meet Byurk who almost collapsed in her arms.
He was without his cloak, his face was ashen, and his lips were purple.
Basara grabbed him and carried him to camp.
The minum winced in pain as the maenad heated him slowly.
She removed his empty sack of provisions and frosted water skin.
“Where is your cloak,” she asked.
“With Thanysa,” Byurk replied with quivering lips.
Basara noticed that Byurk’s arm was heavily swollen and called over the eldest dryad.
“What happened to Thanysa,” the other nymph woman demanded in anger, but Basara motioned her to calm down.
“She is wrapped in my cloak and entombed by her request, hibernating,” Byurk replied.
“She is gravely injured.
We were attacked by Lurr as we entered the pass.
They are killing any who come seeking the widow.
We must hurry.
I do not think Thanysa will last.”
“If Thanysa is hibernating, she will survive,” Basara assured.
“That is not what I fear.
We escaped their attack, so they will be searching.
I hid her west of the pass, but they can still find her.”
“I also have a warning,” Inym spoke up.
“A pixie I hired to monitor Zose’s party has learned of the girl’s identity and came to me secretly this evening asking to share in the bounty.
When I refused and explained our goal to rescue her, she left to claim the bounty herself.
She is headed back to Sen’uon to warn Ni’inca Ab’pul of our arrival.”
“What else are you not telling us,” Basara demanded.
“I know very little,” Inym replied quickly.
“She told me Dyson is dead and Zose has gone missing.
Jeddin has likely sided with his brother Deinan and the Lurr of Sen’uon.”
The air of the camp warmed.
Byurk pulled himself away from the dryad’s treatment of his arm.
He grasped Basara’s painfully hot hand.
“Breathe,” he spoke slowly, looking into the flame of her eyes.
“Breathe.
I am sure Zose is safe.”
“Thank you, old friend,” Basara replied.
“I am better at controlling my emotions than when you last knew me.
I am fine.”
Although Basara gave her word, the air of the camp did not cool.
Inym began questioning her safety traveling with this group.
Basara was an active volcano threatening to erupt, and each piece of bitter news brought her ever closer.
Phasing through stone was an exhausting task, like moving through water without buoyancy.
Even remaining stationary was exhausting.
Female oread traits were stronger than male, so they could move almost effortlessly, but for Zose, he could not endure the strain for longer than a few hours at a time.

Add that most the stone was freezing cold, he had to fight hypothermia all the while or take time to rest within the walls of a heated home to recuperate, further decreasing the time he had to search Sen’uon for word of Ceil.
At least the city of stone enabled him to move almost anywhere.
Timber was scarce along the Hemenonan range, so little was used for construction, only for accent or furnishings for those wealthy enough to afford it.
No homes had paneling along the walls, ceiling, or floor like many affluent homes constructed from the ruins or stone further south.
This enabled Zose to peer into every room of every home as if the very wall surface was his eyes.
Any sound that traveled through the walls became his ears.
The stone itself was his senses, but after days of searching, he could not locate Ceil.
As Zose traveled back up through the mountain to a high and nearly inaccessible shelf near the summit, he feared that she had already been taken from the city or was killed.
He found bloody soil and tiny bits of flesh at their planned meeting location, but because there were no remains, he could not determine for certain the owner of that flesh.

The only hints he found were a large number of footsteps leading back towards Sen’uon with none leading down the road and a blackened, putrid corpse of melted flesh that was too large to be either Dyson or Ceil.
Zose rekindled his extinguished fire with the last remaining coals from the provisions he received in Hen’anin.
A few flint sparks and they sizzled to life, roaring with flame.
He did not fear his fire being spotted from below.
He was high and the shelf wide on the far face of the peak from Sen’uon.
Only mountains spread before him, and in the distance, the faint amber glow of the Afarit on the horizon.
Despite the chill and his numbed fingers, he was sweating.
The mountain peak was riddled with iron.
Metals were difficult even for female oreads to pass through, and refined metals were impassible even for them.
He was thoroughly exhausted from his days of searching through stone, and after sleeping for the night, he had a difficult decision.
He was out of supplies.
He no longer had food or coals for a fire.

This left him three options: steal supplies that he could not take into the stone with him and threaten getting caught trying to escape the city, leave the city for an unknown number of days to procure more supplies, or give up on Ceil altogether.
Due to the difficulty of the search, Zose had only covered about half of the city, and even then, conversations and hints could appear in locations he already searched.
The city was a maze of ruins both above and below ground.
He was an earth elemental, not an earth mage, so he could not use the stone to detect the presence of those in the structures.
Even if he did find Ceil, he could not take her into the stone with him.
His pride was on the line for letting a charge under his protection be captured.
More than this, Ceil was vital to ending the conflict that ate at Basara.
For both of them, he needed to find Ceil.
One more day.
He would search one more day before making the final decision of whether to abandon Ceil.
When Zose woke the next morning, he searched the ashes of his fire for any pieces of coal that might not have burned completely.
His cloak was frosted over, showing the fire had not lasted the night on the few coals he had left to give it.
Sure enough, nothing remained in the ash.
Zose mentally prepared himself for the cold and removed his cloak before diving into the stone beneath him.
He had his clothes woven from his own hair and his weak leather created from his mother’s skin, but in the stone, they provided no protection from the chill.
His body held no true shape in stone, so external coverings could not protect against the elements.
He only had them should he need to exit the stone at any time.
After the long descent through the mountain, Zose exited the stone into an empty pocket of air to rest.
He had used it to recover the exhaustion of meandering through the iron veins of the mountain after each descent, and now the stale air the pocket once held was becoming almost too thin to breathe.

There were a handful of caverns snaking through and around the city, but the Lurr used them, leaving this isolated pocket as the sole place he could rest comfortably without exiting into the cold or where a Lurr might smell him.
This truly was his last day of searching.
The limit to his rest was the lack of air in the pocket, so although he wanted to rest longer, he had little choice but to leave.
Zose left the pocket for the ruinous caverns under the city.
The market was below ground in the center of the city, and it was the only location he checked without fail each day.
Lurr were often lazy in the cold, so the market was not packed in the morning like in Ib’nua, but as the traders prepared their wares they often talked and gossiped.
There was also a chance that the meat of an elf girl might arrive for sale at any time.
He could not risk ignoring that possibility.

Those unaccustomed to the wilderlands and especially Lurr cultures might dread seeing a naked corpse hung by a hook on a meat rack, but for the Lurr, it was food like any other, and the only type of fresh meat that was truly safe for them to eat.
Civilized Lurr did not murder to stock their racks.
The bodies tended to be of those who could not endure the harsh life of the wilderlands and perished by other means or criminals who were captured and executed by Sen’uon.
Such meat was a delicacy and quite expensive due to its rarity.
Had Zose been killed trying to force his way through the pass when denied entry to Sen’uon, that would have been his fate.
The butcher, an odd character of stout body and long limbs like a dwarf with the arms and legs of an elf, dragged two sacks to his hooks and removed the contents.
Zose breathed a mental sigh of relief.
Ceil was not among them, just a lycon and a troll.
“Where’d you find a lycon?” Another merchant curious of the new meat walked over to the butcher.
“I don’t expect him to sell well,” the butcher replied, not answering about the source of the body.
“Too many are afraid that there might be some wolf in the meat.”
There were certainly very few civilized Lurr who were mutations of beastkin due to the fear that bestial instincts might make them lose themselves.
“The troll should sell fast.
They’re strong.
Found her frozen.
Even hibernation has its limits it seems.”
“Perhaps it will not sell as fast as you think.
Many already got their fill of troll a few days ago.”
Zose was about the leave the conversation, but that comment rooted him in place.
“I heard from Deinan.
A scrawny male.
Even troll women are stronger.
She should still sell.”
“I’ll buy her if you decrease the price.”
The butcher glared.
“If she does not sell today, I will drop the price.”
The merchant laughed and walked away.
Zose sped away.
Finally a clue.
Of course Deinan would be connected.
Zose never even consider that Deinan was not out completing numerous contracts.
He always was.
Jeddin’s father was a Lurr, unknown to his mother.
The man was advanced enough in his evolution into a spriggan that it was impossible to tell without life magic, at least until the second pregnancy which resulted in Lurr spawn.
Jeddin’s mother ran the man off, feeling betrayed that he would keep such an important secret.
Her father, not wanting his daughter to feel the emptiness of lacking a proper child after her pregnancy, created a doppelganger of himself with one of the larva she birthed.

She raised the Lurr as a spriggan, but when the village grew suspicious of her new son, especially his rate of growth and strength, she left the Amelian Empire with her two sons and settled in the wilderlands where Lurr were more accepted.
Zose knew Deinan lived in Sen’uon, but he did not know where.
If that was indeed the case--that Deinan knew of the attack--then Jeddin might still be alive and could explain what happened.
Deinan was a hunter mercenary, which meant he was wealthier than most given the advantages of Lurr strength enabling the completion of far more difficult contracts.
Wealthier Lurr lived underground in the northwest sector of the city where the ruins were grander.
Zose had not yet searched there out of fear of a guard with an earth affinity watching for thieves seeking to enter the affluent ruins.
An earth mage would likely not be expecting infiltration from within the stone, but they might still detect something odd about the stone if looking specifically for it.
Zose had no physical body when in stone, but the nature of the stone changed as he phased through it, so he still needed to take caution.
In the northwest sector, Zose searched beginning from the lowest-class ruins.
Deinan was not a lord or nabob or from a notable lineage.
He could simply afford the better accommodations.
With this in mind, the search was surprisingly quick, taking only a couple hours.
Zose did not find Deinan but someone he wanted to speak with even more, Jeddin.
Jeddin resided in a two-room ruin near the surface.
The rooms were mismatched and not level, as if one had toppled onto the other but kept most of its form before being buried underground.
It was not lavishly furnished, but Deinan spent most his time away on long contracts, so such furnishings and other embellishments were not needed.
Zose traversed the walls of the ruin to the sloped and uneven floor of the upper room.
He moved to the corner behind where Jeddin sat lazily on a stuffed fur.
“Jeddin,” Zose whispered.
Jeddin twitched but remained in his position.
“Took you long enough to find me,” he spoke back quietly without bringing attention to Zose.
It seemed that Jeddin might not be safe here if he had to keep Zose’s appearance secret, or perhaps he was simply protecting Zose.
“Where is Gein,” Zose asked, jumping right to topic.
“Why did you not tell us the truth of who you were escorting,” Jeddin replied with silent vitriol seeping through his voice.
“Dyson is dead, and I would be too if Deinan had not protected me.”
Somehow the truth of Ceil’s identity became known to the citizens of Sen’uon before their arrival.
That was the only explanation for why they were attacked at their planned meeting place.
It would not be difficult to track Jeddin or Dyson there and wait for Ceil to land.
“My job was the protection of my escort, and that protection required secrecy of her identity.
If you truly know who she is, you should understand.”
Jeddin exhaled through his nose.
“I am beginning to think that you are the one who does not know the truth of that woman.
I am not speaking of her identity as the widow of the Amelian Emperor that Tolmyur seeks.
Dyson was ignorant of this, but I knew from the day we set out from Ib’nua.”
Zose gathered the part of him that was his blades within the stone.
If Jeddin was a threat to Ceil, his hand would be forced.
“Lurr have abilities that we still do not understand.
Their eyes are better than ours in many ways.
They saw an evil omen darker than the night fly over their city.
The darkness of that woman is such that the Lurr could not find words to explain her, resorting to mad rambling as they trembled in terror at the sight of her.
You saw how the Lurr reacted in Hen’anin.”
“Where is she,” Zose demanded.
“The first Lurr who tried to carry her away unconscious melted the moment he drew close.
The Lurr saw what happened, but I could not.
I was made to drag her by rope in his place, and I thought I would meet the same fate, but whatever evil that struck him did not affect me.
Lord Ab’pul has her now.
I do not doubt she is dead.
I was to be executed as a criminal for bringing that girl to Sen’uon, but Deinan defended me.
I accepted a Lurr as my brother, so Lord Ab’pul gave me pass.
I am now here under Deinan’s watch for some unknown duration.”
“Where does the Lord of Sen’uon live?”
“I do not know.
Not in the city.
West.
I was led blind.
I admit that I only joined your party to make certain something was done so that no one else would die mistaken for her, but things have changed now.
Give up on her, Zose.
Whatever she is, for the sake of your wife and family, you should end your involvement here.”
“Thank you for your concern, friend.” Zose said before heading up towards the surface.
He barely heard Jeddin’s final reply muffled through the stone.
“There are no friends between hunter mercenaries.”
Zose expected the Lord of Sen’uon to have the largest and most lavish dwelling, perhaps a massive ruin still mostly intact or a large cave system snaking through multiple ruins.
He did not have the energy for an exhaustive search, and he did not doubt it would take many days to locate Ceil.
He had neither the time nor the resources, and should he find her, he did not have the ability to free her on his own.
As he was, he was powerless.
Zose returned to his camp high up on the mountain shelf.
He rummaged through his supplies and grabbed the small brass whistle.
Chapter 13
“Bartering with Lives”
Inym sat pensive in the camp as some of the party followed Byurk to where he had entombed the troll.
They camped far west of the road, further south of the supposed tomb and the steep Hemenonan range to reduce the risk of their party being spotted.
Inym did not know whether the Lurr would be searching for the party or if Kep did warn Sen’uon about their approach.
At the same time, she felt she could no longer remain with the group.
She was the cause of the incident in Sen’uon, and should Basara learn of it, her life was forfeit.
She was not simply balancing on the edge of a blade.
The blade itself was volatile as Basara’s emotional state became more and more suspect.
She could not turn back or flee because she no longer had supplies of her own to survive traveling back through the plains.
If she had any hope of survival, it was in undoing what she had done.

“I am going to scout the pass,” she told the sickly anthousai girl curled up by the fire, or perhaps she could no longer be called and anthousai after the harsh winds of the final stretch of road unprotected by any rocks or ravines rid her mossy hair of most her white blossoms.
“Then I will join you,” the girl replied.
“No, I am just checking if they have increased the guard to see if that pixie has actually given her warning and it was trusted.
I was a hunter mercenary, so I should be able to enter the pass without suspicion, possibly gaining access to the city.
You are one of the scouts of this party, so you are needed here for your watch.”
“Me being a scout is why I should help,” the girl protested further.
Her eyes showed a pain beyond her illness.
She had her own reasons to investigate.
“Let Lemi follow,” one of the elven soldiers ordered, having overheard the exchange.
“I can take her watch when the time comes.”
Inym sniffed in annoyance.
“Fine, but stay back, and should something happen to me, retreat back to camp.”
Lemi grabbed her bow and jumped to her feet.
She followed Inym through the maze of ruins to the road and then remained back as Inym traveled up towards the narrow pass.
When Inym looked back, she could not spot the girl.
Dryads were renowned for their stealth, so she had no way of knowing how close or far Lemi followed.
She had nothing to hide from Lemi.
She only cared for the young dryad’s safety.
Immediately when entering the pass, Inym heard motion among the rocks high above her.
She could not tell the number or location.
The sound echoed, muffled by the wind.
The number of hidden guards did not seem any greater than the last time she had visited Sen’uon many years ago.
At the narrowest section of the pass, like a massive knife cut down a sheer rock face, the same five guards from her memory stood watch.
A massive troll Lurr approached alone and stood before Inym on the pass.
“What business brings you to Sen’uon?”
“I am a retired hunter mercenary traveling north.
I request entrance into the city for my own safety,” Inym replied in Elven.
When speaking with a Lurr, truth must always be used or the Lurr would catch the lie.
Hunter mercenaries practiced hiding lies within truth when speaking to Lurr, but the Lurr were also aware of such tactics.
“Recent circumstances prohibit me from permitting entry into Sen’uon without explicit reason.”
“My supplies have run out.
Should you force me to return through the plains, I will surely perish.”
The Lurr’s lips rose to his nose in consternation, and then he glared down at Inym with his red eyes.
Inym shrunk back by reflex.
“You fear us.”
“My mind is still plagued by a severe injury caused by a chimera only a few years ago.” She parted her two cloaks and lifted her armor to reveal the horrid scar across her stomach and abdomen.
“I cannot help but cower at times.
It is beyond my control when in front of a Lurr.
I promise you I am no threat to civilized Lurr.”
The guard nodded in understanding.
“You say your life is in danger?
Are you aware that you are being followed?”
Inym couldn’t respond.

This was one risk she foresaw when accepting Lemi’s aid, but after the Vallen soldier ordered Lemi to follow, she could not turn down Lemi’s company without fear of their party growing suspicious of her and preventing her departure.
She had hoped a dryad’s stealth would remain unnoticed, but it seemed a Lurr’s senses were far too keen.
The guard raised his hand after enduring Inym’s silence long enough to ensure his answer.
Silence in front of a Lurr who could hear all lies was the same as affirmation.
Inym heard Lemi’s scream but did not turn around.
Much to her relief, the scream was not silenced immediately but drew closer as Lemi was carried before the guard.
“A few days ago, we met a strange pairing of a Tolmyur commander and Vallen soldier.
Now we find a Melian.
Girl, what connection do you have to this woman?”
Lemi remained silent.
The guard reached down and grabbed her moss-like hair with a hand as big as her head.
He forced the girl to look into his red eyes, but she did not fright.
The girl was willing to die rather than endanger Inym, but Inym could not let that happen.
“Spare her, I beg you.
She is no comrade of mine, but it was only through her company that I was able to reach Sen’uon.”
The guard released Lemi.
She fell to her knees and quickly bowed herself to the ground.
“What business does she have in Sen’uon,” the guard asked Inym, and again she could not answer, but given the threat to Lemi’s life, Inym could not remain silent either.
“Please, she is a child.
Let her go.”
The guard heard all he needed.
He knelt down and grasped Inym by the front of her cloak, pulling her face close.
“What is your name,” he asked with glowing red eyes.
Inym’s fear muted her tongue.
She knew now that Kep had warned the city of her arrival.
Whether she remained silent or told her name, she would be killed.
Her mind raced to find another name by which she was called at any time in the past, to give an old truth that might spare her life, but try as she might, she had none.
Unlike many who changed their name after fleeing to the wilderlands, she kept her birth name.
She was not a criminal, nor had she fled to the wilderlands for her life.
She only left the Amelian Empire in her youth because she could not tolerate its oppression of the trolls any longer.
“What is your name!” The guard’s eyes flared red, squeezing fearful tears from the corners of Inym’s eyes.
“Her name is Inym,” Lemi replied for her.
Inym wanted to curse the girl, but she knew Lemi spoke out of fear of the guard’s growing impatience and to protect Inym’s life.
Lemi did not know that Inym’s name would end her life just the same as silence.
The guard released Inym, and she immediately bowed to the ground.
Numerous Lurr circled them.
They could not escape.
“Inym, Lord Ni’inca Ab’pul of Sen’uon would like to express his utmost gratitude in your forewarning of the approach of Lady Ceil of the Amelian Empire.
He has ordered that should you arrive in Sen’uon, you are to be brought before him.
You have no right to refuse.”
“What happened to Ceil,” Lemi almost screamed.
“Do you have her?”
“Quiet,” Inym rebuked before bowing again to the guard.
“This dryad is a friend of Lady Ceil and is only here out of concern for her safety.
She is a child and can be no threat to your city.
Please spare her.”
“She will join you,” the guard ordered.
Forceful hands lifted Inym and Lemi to their feet from behind and pushed them forward into the narrow pass.
The moment the first ruins of the city of Sen’uon came into view, a blindfold was placed over their eyes.
Inym held confidence in her sense of direction, but the path she was led felt unnatural.
They left the city and traveled west, but the moment she descended underground, walking forwards felt like backstepping.
She felt as if she would fall backwards when descending and forwards when ascending.
Each left turn felt like a complete revolution ending the same direction she had originally faced, and each right turn hardly felt like a turn at all.
It was as if this very cavern or land or ruin was charmed to prevent any understanding of its structure.
After a final long corridor where she felt as if she would fall into the sky, all at once normalcy returned to her senses.
The following corridors were heated, and Inym began to sweat under her heavy cloaks.
They turned left and ascended a curved stairway, their steps echoing in the large room.
A draft caressed her face from what she assumed was a thinner corridor before her.
There they stood and waited as their former escorts were exchanged for others.
She was then led into the corridor.
This long, narrow corridor had no deviations.
It was perfectly straight and even.
The deeper she was led, the more she felt that the corridor had a pulse that grew louder and louder until it sounded no different than a massive heart beating.
The air warmed yet again, and the pulse echoed.
She now stood in a massive hall.
Her blindfold was removed, and she immediately screamed.
Terror, seeped in her past trauma, consumed Inym.
Visions flooded her mind of a moist cave filled with Lurr larva covering the walls so thick they pulsated like raw flesh.
Numerous red eyes appeared like phantoms.

She could hear the death rows of the rest of her party as the memory of her past self fled through the cave grasping the hand of the youngest member of her party not yet old enough to be called a man only to encounter a monstrous and mutated form, an unknown addition to the target of her ill-fated contract, a second chimera.
The first chimera was small but toxic, both poisonous and venomous.
Her party was ill-equipped to fight it.
They had no life mage.
The second was larger than her with dozens of arms sprouting from its hunched back, each with its own set of eyes.
She could only act as a distraction for the final member of her party to escape, Pyn’s younger brother.
She collapsed the cave behind him so the surviving brood could not make chase after the boy, sealing her inside.
There in her dark prison with her ven exhausted she fought for survival against two chimeras and their brood with only the red of Lurr eyes for visibility.
She fought for three days.

By the time she finished the last chimera, she was poisoned with her abdomen gored out, but the toxins prevented her hibernation until physical exhaustion broke her and she collapsed drowning in the terror of not knowing what would become of her.
She awoke in Pyn’s care.
He personally led a party of civilized Lurr to rescue her once he received word of the disaster from his brother.
She barely survived, and the extent of the damage and poison prevented full recovery, leaving her with a weakened body and physical scars just as severe as her emotional ones.
And now before Inym stood a chimera larger and more terrifying than the monsters of her past.
She tried to flee with all her might, but the grip of her escorts was iron.
She screamed and screamed, but when she could not free herself, she broke down into incoherent wailing sobs.
“Peace, Inym.
Do not fear,” the monster spoke through its undulating neck.
“I did not summon you here to harm you but to beg a favor of you for which you will be greatly rewarded.”
The terrifying monstrosity’s neck extended and his head lowered to the floor of the hall in supplication.
“I have none other to ask but you.
There are only four who are not Lurr in all of Sen’uon: Lady Ceil, Jeddin, you, and the Melian at your side.
Jeddin has refused me, wishing death before lending his aid.
I am in need of a caretaker for Lady Ceil.
She is weakening, and the evil within her is growing ever stronger because of it.
She refuses to eat or sleep.
I have forced food upon her, but the numerous Lurr I have sent die without fail while feeding her.”
“You wish death upon me!” Inym tried to escape again, but the grip on her remained fast.
“She is only a direct threat to us Lurr.
We are incompatible, opposites, and so we die if we draw close enough to touch.
But for you she should be no more than a starved woman too weak to lift a hand against you.
For now, she is only an immediate danger to Lurr, but should she die, even you will not escape the evil freed from its cage of flesh.”
A Lurr walked in from a side corridor and set a pedestal before Inym.
A second Lurr followed and placed a velvet satchel atop the pedestal.
She loosed the bands and displayed to Inym glimmering gemstones in a myriad of colors, each individual gem undoubtedly worth the entire satchel’s weight in precious metals.
“If that payment is insufficient, I will offer more.
Wealth means little when all are dead.
I will also reward the Melian in any manner she desires as I know precious stones mean nothing to her kind.
Who is she?”
Inym was too terrified to reply.
She turned her head away as if not seeing the wretched form would somehow make it disappear.
Receiving no answer, the chimera instead spoke with Lemi in a language Inym could not recognize.
Lemi grew excited and agreed immediately to whatever deal was struck between them.
“Inym, you and Lemi will care for Lady Ceil.
