My children will make all arrangements and provide whatever you request.” Without another word, the chimera vanished near-instantly down the left corridor.
The female Lurr fastened the ties of the satchel and handed it to Inym.
With or without her consent, she was now forced into her role.
“Follow me,” the Lurr ordered.
Lemi moved without question, and Inym reluctantly followed.
Their guide led them to the back of the hall and passed what at one time might have been grand stone doors but were now eroded and crumbling.
“I can go no further than here,” their guide informed them.
“You will find Lady Ceil at the end of the corridor.”
Lemi picked up pace into a jog, and Inym followed not to lose her.
The corridor was short and ended in a large and wide chamber of tiered seating.
The air was sickly, and each breath felt toxic but not with poison.
The air was dead.
Inym felt as if her very life was being drained away by standing in the room.
Adorned chairs circled each tier, and at the center in the back stood an elevated platform.
“Ceil!” Lemi ran for the center platform.
Inym backed away, wanting to flee down the corridor.
Bones piled at the base of the platform buried partially in black soot.
As the pile rose to meet the platform, the corpses became fresher as if melted into dark bile, their bones protruding from the sickly black mucus.
Ceil sat there on the platform, a Queen of Death atop a throne of corpses.
Her eyes were open, but there was no life in them.
She never heard her former comrade cry her name nor did she notice the young dryad scramble over the many bones and trudge through the filth to reach her.
Inym watched in anticipation, waiting for the moment that Lemi would melt like the rest, but when Lemi placed her hand on Ceil’s cheek, no harm befell her.
Seeing this, Inym walked forward slowly down the central steps of the tiered council room.
“She’s alive,” Ceil called back.
The closer Inym approached, the worse the smell grew and the thicker the death in the air became.
Breathing grew exhausting.
She could see Lemi’s moss hair wilt as the girl struggled to pull Ceil off the podium.
“Help me!”
Inym rushed down to the podium and held back her sick as she trudged through the putrid sludge up to her knees.
They grabbed Ceil and carried her up the steps to the entrance before laying her on the ground.
“Remove her armor.
I don’t know how.
She has been sitting in her own filth.
She is covered in rashes and her skin beneath her armor is diseased.
I will ask for a place we can wash her so I can treat her.” After giving her order, Lemi ran back down the corridor to where their guide waited.
Inym barely had time to remove the jack before Lemi returned and informed her that the Lurr would prepare a bath.
Inym was going to leave the filthy jack behind, but Lemi grabbed it and set it atop Ceil as they carried her.
Their guide kept a full five yards distant from them as she led them back through the large hall and down the right corridor.
The maze of ruins returned as if the structure was built from multiple ruins piled atop each other.
Some rooms were upside-down at odd angles as if toppled over the others, and the steps were often at slants that made footing difficult.
They were led to more of a cave than a ruin.
The humidity was thick.
Natural hot springs bubbled in the back.
Inym and Lemi were ordered to remain near the side wall of the cave as a tub was fashioned from earth magic and filled with water magic.
“You may use water from the spring to heat the bath, but take caution.
It will scald her if used directly,” the Lurr explained.
Inym helped bathe Ceil.
She then washed Ceil’s clothes and armor while Lemi treated Ceil’s illness and internal injuries that had not completely healed or healed incorrectly.
Inym quickly understood why Lemi did not leave the jack behind.
It was plated with resfahil.
This was regal armor of the Amelian Emperor’s widow.
She took extra care to clean the fabric and leather, using water that would terribly scald her if not for her fire affinity.
The dye washed out from the minerals of the spring, leaving the fabric a dull grey that barely kept a hint of purple.
“Watch Ceil.
I will ask for a bed and some food,” Lemi announced.
“Stop.
I will do it,” Inym said as she carried the dripping armor back and set it beside Ceil.
“Aren’t you scared of Lurr?
I can talk to them for you.
I won’t be in danger.
Lurr don’t bother with dryads.
We are like plants, so we are no use to them.”
“No, I mean…” Inym did not know how to explain, because she did not want the girl to fear her friend.
“You cannot see yourself.
You are wilting.
You should rest a while, away from Ceil.
I will speak with the Lurr for you.”
Lemi’s eyes widened.
“Oh, no.
I… There are no plants here, so… To be honest, I am under a lot of stress.
I have not felt well since we started crossing the plains.
I was fine crossing the Nuanae range, but after that, the trees, they just disappeared.
I’m fine.”
Inym wanted to tell her that was not the case.
She saw the visible wilting as Lemi stood amid the death in the council room.
Ceil was a danger to Lemi.

Even that chimera might not have expected this when he asked for Lemi’s aid, or perhaps he did not care and only needed someone to immediately help Ceil before she succumbed to starvation and illness.
At least away from that room, death no longer saturated the air.
“I will ask for them to bring any plants they can and place them in the room they will prepare for Ceil.
And clean water.”
Lemi flashed a wide but wilted smile.
“Thanks!”
Inym once again found their guide waiting not too distant outside the hot spring cave.
Room accommodation was already underway, and the guide agreed to do something about plants and water for Lemi.
She showed Inym the location and where any supplies they requested would be brought.
It would then be her task to bring the supplies to the room once Ceil was inside.
After seeing the pile of Lurr bones in the council room, Inym understood why the Lurr did not want to be anywhere near Ceil.
The room was large and built from three ruins that had crumbled together.
The walls that had separated the rooms were carved away leaving only the outer walls and floor of each room.
The floor was leveled, but each separate room sat on its own elevated shelf connected by slanted stairs.
The Lurr prepared a wide bed of stuffed firs on the highest shelf, enough for the three of them to rest comfortably.
Inym was apprehensive about sleeping in the same bed as the Queen of Death, but she could simply take her allotment of furs and move them to the second shelf.
There were no plants in the room yet.
Those would have to be gathered from outside, and even then, they would likely be without leaves due to the winter weather, so Lemi would need to nurture them to make them bloom out of season.
When Inym returned, she found Lemi beside the hot spring with Ceil’s head resting in her lap.
“She’s finally sleeping,” Lemi said as she caressed Ceil’s cheek with a shaking hand.
“She spoke, too.
She whispered Sammy’s name.” The girl forced a mournful smile and placed Ceil’s cheek against her abdomen.
“Don’t worry.
Sammy is still right here with us.”
“You are pregnant,” Inym realized.
Lemi nodded.
“It was a secret between Sammy and me.
Sammy let me name my daughter after her just before she died.
Sammy… she was Ceil’s closest friend, and she’s not lost.
My daughter has taken her place.” Lemi leaned down and rested her forehead against Ceil’s, bending in a manner that only a wilting plant could.
“I’m sorry I never told you,” she whispered to Ceil.
“The room is ready for us.
You should take care of yourself before you take care of Ceil.
I can watch over her for the time being.”
“Let me stay like this for a bit longer.
I do not want to wake her,” Lemi said with a warm smile.
When Justin knelt on the ground away from camp, everyone collectively understood that they should not bother him with anything trivial.
He spent whatever small amount of free time they had during camp meditating.

The purpose of their camps were to rest and eat in preparation for more travel, so free time was always short unless someone wanted to sacrifice sleep, but for Justin that free time was much longer, not because he was never given any tasks when setting up or taking down camp--he did his fair part--but because he slowed time to a crawl during his meditation.
What started as extending his hour or less of meditation into two or three hours soon became a week within his own mind every time they set up camp.
His many days traveling north through the wilderlands became months spent in meditation.
Meditating in the snow felt nostalgic, recalling the memory of the day his ignorance hurt Eydis and so Sammy took the mantle of that anger and punched him.
That was the day he learned he could manipulate time, but it was months later before he could control it even a little.
He used his time magic to take a bullet for Sammy when Jethro invaded Gullivan, but when that bullet became a spear in Revlan, he was powerless.
He could slow time for himself to increase his reaction speed, but that did not change the fact that he could not move any faster than his physical capabilities allowed.
He noticed the spear too late.
He slowed time immediately to heighten his reaction to try and grasp it, but he was too far away and too slow.
By the time he grasped the spear’s haft, it was already through Sammy’s chest, and she was gone.
Justin had mourned before.
He remembered vividly the passing of his high school girlfriend due to complications during pregnancy caused by his ven poisoning her.
Neither his parents nor hers seemed to notice or care about how much he was suffering.
They only pointed fingers and shouted blame at him for not only the loss of one life but two.
Failed relationship after failed relationship later, he met Sammy.
She was so vibrant and overflowing with love for him that the pains of his past started melting away.
He regretted hiding the truth from her and the unseen anguish that caused her, but he feared the loss of that beacon of light.
He was not completely honest when he revealed his past to Sammy in Revlan.
He was not saving up for a ring.
He already bought it and hid it away in his desk in his room, but in his anxiety and fear he still struggled to tell Sammy the truth.
His delay is what led to them breaking up when Sammy only wanted answers.
Sammy meant so much to him, more than his past girlfriends, more than Eydis, more than anyone.
She was the one he wanted to spend the rest of his life with.
Justin’s meditation was not only to improve his proficiency with time magic but also to give him time to mourn, to sort out his feelings and regrets, to heal…
And to make certain nothing like that happened ever again.
Justin was unsure how much time passed during his meditation.
Unlike the previous camps, the party had already reached their destination and was only waiting until a plan could be devised to enter Sen’uon and investigate for clues about Ceil.
This led to full freedom to meditate as long as he wanted, but being enshrouded in one’s own thoughts and only those thoughts for extended periods of time was draining and eventually led to numbness.
Justin estimated maybe a month or perhaps two had passed in his mind during his current meditation, and for the sake of his own sanity he opened his eyes.
A bizarre creature stood frozen before him, leaning over and reaching for his chest.
It was like a werewolf, bearing a distinctly canine face, though without fur, and ears but with a mostly anthropomorphic body.
It wore tight leather armor and was armed with a saber on its hip.
Had Justin stayed in meditation a day or two longer, the creature might have grasped him.
Justin slowly resumed time as he shifted his body out of the way of the beast’s grasp, but its reflexes were keen.
As he moved, the hand moved with him.
Justin changed tactics.
Time froze again, but only for the creature.
Justin stood and ran for the main camp.
“Intruders in the camp!” Justin shouted.
Outside, more of the same creatures stood guard atop other ruins.
He ran into the tilted archway of the neighboring structure and turned left down the short hallway to the center of the ruin where their main camp was set.
Chloe grabbed Justin as he entered the large circular room and pulled him to the side next to Benab.
Their entire party stood on one side of the room, and no less than thirty of those same beasts stood on the other.
Only the Tolmyur soldiers brandished their weapons, but Byurk was keeping them back.
Basara stood at the front before the gathering of wolf-people, conversing with them.
One approached and embraced her, sniffing her neck.
Benab whispered something to Chloe who then translated for Justin.
“Basara introduced herself as Zose’s wife.
They are comparing her scent.
Apparently Zose is an ally of these lycon.”
After some deliberation, the lycon who had checked Basara’s scent stood before her once more.
Something he said made Basara raise her hand to her mouth.
The gathering of lycon parted, and those who guarded the far entrance to the room left down the hall.
A few minutes later they returned escorting a man and a large bird.
“Coby!”
Chloe weaved through the tense onlookers towards the familiar large blue hawk.
Coby trilled happily as he trotted towards Chloe.
The man limped forward just behind Coby.
The second he was within arm’s reach of Basara, she embraced him.
Justin rushed forward to Chloe and Coby.
“This is the man who was escorting Ceil?
Where is she?”
The gathering of elfkind, humans, nymphs and lycon sat around the now roaring fire.
Basara introduced her party and their purpose in following after Zose.
Zose then explained the situation and how he used the lycons’ debt to him to enlist their aid; however, the lycon were not committed to the payment he asked of them.
“You rescued one of our kin, but we cannot risk the elimination of our pack to save one of yours,” the speaker for the lycon replied.
“I understand that.
I am not asking for you to lay down your lives for Ceil,” Zose replied.
“The risk is far greater than you realize, honorable lycon,” Basara replied.
“Lady Ceil’s death is as great a risk for your kind as it is for ours.”
“We do not trust in superstitions, mate of Zose,” the speaker announced flatly.
“The situation is dire enough to make allies of enemies,” Byurk replied.
He gestured to Chloe and Justin.
“We have little way of proof to our claims other than these two here that are not of our world.”
“Those two smell different than other humans, but we know nothing of other worlds.
This is a city of Lurr.
Lycon are strong, but Lurr are stronger.
You have not located the one you seek and have no plan to reclaim her.
We cannot attack a city to search for one woman.”
“Lemi and Inym are also gone,” Chloe added.
Her speaking was slow as she weaved together words in Elven.
“They might be there too.”
“Or killed,” Thanysa replied.
She was barely coherent having only just broken her hibernation after Tyree’s treatment, but she wanted to be part of the discussions nonetheless.
“Our debt is for one life, not three,” the Lycon speaker asserted.
Zose shook his head.
“Those two are the responsibility of Basara and her party.
My request is only for Ceil.”
“Inym is her own responsibility,” Basara corrected.
“We will do something about Lemi as we work to rescue Lady Ceil.
Forgive Lady Chloe’s comment, honorable lycon.
In her heart she would rescue all who are in need and does not realize that in the wilderlands a life is merely another provision to be dealt and traded.”
The lycon stared at Chloe who shrunk back shyly in return.
“A caring heart is a rare commodity in these lands.
The wilderlands devour the meek.
She should take caution.”
“Do not mistake meekness for frailty,” Byurk countered.
“Chloe may be our greatest asset and the strongest of us all.
She could destroy the city by her power alone.”
“Then why seek our aid,” the speaker asked, clearly skeptical of Byurk’s boasting on Chloe’s behalf.
“I do not want to,” Chloe responded in her defense.
“These Lurr are… are not bad.
They are people, right?
I do not want to hurt people that have not done wrong.”
“Ceil is held prisoner in the den of Lord Ni’inca Ab’pul.
We need only involve the city as little as possible,” Zose clarified.
“If we can find his hidden den, I can locate her, but we are without the numbers to extract her.”
The speaker growled.
“If she is possessed by that monster, she is lost.
He hunts lycon for sport when our numbers grow too large.
He is swifter than an arrow and deadlier than a dragon.
He cannot be killed.”
Justin whispered to Chloe who then relayed the message to Benab to translate.
“Sir Justin offers you a deal.
If he provides the means for you to kill the Lord of Sen’uon, will you aid us?”
The entire room turned to Justin in astonishment.
The lycon clearly thought him mad, and those who knew of his affinity fought within their minds to explain why he would make such a bewildering offer and how he could provide such an opportunity.
To Basara, he was an incompetent man who could hardly care for himself let alone kill a regular Lurr.
Byurk was the only one who seemed to catch onto a plausible reason or method or at least not question Justin’s statement.
“Do you take us for fools,” the speaker growled.
Justin again spoke to Chloe who then had Benab translate.
“Sir Justin requests that the honorable lycon follow him for proof of his claim.”
The speaker for the lycon stood.
When other lycon stood to follow, he growled at them.
Only he and Justin left the circular ruin.
After a few minutes of waiting, they returned with an additional lycon that was not present in the meeting.
The speaker sat Justin on the side of the lycon and placed his hand on Justin’s nape.
“A deal has been struck.
We will aid in your rescue.
This is a chimera hunt!”
Chapter 14
“A Skewed Challenge”
“You are not getting any better.” Inym stood in front of Lemi who sat in the corner of the lowest level of Ceil’s room surrounded by plants provided by the Lurr.
Lemi had succeeded in making leaves bloom on the shrubs’ branches, but they were wilting despite the clean water and care Lemi gave them.
The edges of few of the leaves were turning black and crumbling into powder.
Even Inym felt drained whenever she was near Ceil’s room.
The sick aura was not as strong as the aura of death in the council room, but it was still present and palpable.
“You said that you would recover quickly once you were surrounded by plants, but it’s been eight days.
You must realize that it is Ceil who is doing this to you.”
“I know,” Lemi said with a smile, stunning Inym.
“Plants are very sensitive to changes in their environment.
I realized something was wrong when I was traveling with Ceil through Vallen.
I spent most my time scouting ahead or with Sammy when my turn came for foraging, just to stay away from Ceil as much as possible.
I got really sick in Revlan, so I started staying outside in the garden instead of inside with Ceil, thinking that might have been related.”
Lemi’s hand rose to her mossy hair.
“My hair was so in bloom that you could only see white.
When an anthousai becomes pregnant, their petals don’t immediately fall.

Some petals fall shortly after childbirth, but usually it takes about a season or two for an anthousai to lose most her flowers after her first child is born, and she has a high chance of bearing more children during that time.
Now my hair is like this after only a few short days since leaving Melia.”
Inym held back her frown as she stared at Lemi’s wilting moss hair.
There were hardly any flowers left.
Lemi giggled.
“Of course, the cold and wind didn’t help.”
“You cannot stay here,” Inym said sternly.
“I can’t leave Ceil now that I finally found her.
Justin and Chloe and Kiri will find us and rescue us.
If not, as Ceil gets better, that evil power the chimera talked about will weaken.
That’s what he said, right?”
“Who knows how long that will take!
You saw that chimera.
No one can kill that thing, and he will not let Ceil go.”
Ceil was nothing more than a living doll.
Lemi had cured Ceil’s injuries and ailments to the best of her abilities being only an apprentice shaman, but Ceil’s heart and mind had shut down.
There was no amount of healing Lemi could do to fix her now.
She still could not recognize her friend despite how much time Lemi spent with her.
“Your role here is done.
Ceil is healthy.
If not for yourself, you need to leave for Sammy, your daughter.
Your waning health will affect her just as it affects you.”
Lemi tensed.
Sure enough, she realized this as well.
“Have you been checking on her development?
Is she fine?”
“She is fine,” Lemi said quickly, but her face lowered away from Inym’s stern gaze.
“But she is not as healthy as she should be, correct?” Lemi did not answer, so Inym took her silence as affirmation.
“You need to leave.
I have freedom of movement for much of these ruins.
I will search for the way back to that bewitched cave, but I am not sure how you will be able to get through it.”
“I know the way,” Lemi said, surprising Inym.
“The air in that cave was noxious.
It made you and the Lurr act weird, but dryad bodies are different.
We do not breathe the same air you breathe, so I was fine.
As children, dryads are sent alone to all the surrounding villages to deliver things or relay messages, so we become good with directions.
Even with a blindfold, I knew what direction we went and where we turned.
I know the way out.”
“Then go,” Inym ordered, but Lemi still hesitated.
She grabbed Lemi’s arm and pulled her to her feet.
“Your child will die if you stay.
Go!”
Inym thrust Lemi towards the entryway to the room.
Lemi stumbled but caught her footing before she fell.
She looked up one last time at the third level of the room where Ceil lay in bed out of sight and then ran from the room.
Inym climbed the uneven steps to Ceil’s bedside.
She sat down on the stuffed furs and gripped Ceil’s fur covering with rigid fingers.
“I could kill you now, and it would be so easy,” she grumbled.
“I always hated Amel and the royal family, and now that the last survivor of that wretched dynasty is before me and so weak and helpless, I can do nothing!”
Inym grabbed Ceil’s neck and lifted her so that they faced each other.
Ceil’s eyes looked at her, but they did not see her.
“Tell me.
Why are trolls limited to one litter per woman?
Why was my husband executed for trying to provide me another when my first was stillborn?
Tell me!
Are you high elves so afraid of trolls outnumbering you?
Why did the first thing that happened to me after fleeing your terrible empire leave me unable to bear children.
Tell me…” Inym set Ceil gently back onto her bed.
She wrapped her arms around her and buried her face into Ceil’s bosom.
“Please, give me my life back…”
Sneaking through the noxious cave was far easier than Lemi expected.
The gasses dulled the senses of the Lurr who patrolled the tunnels.
The cave itself was a maze of strange stone tubes within tubes as if the stone had somehow melted and then hardened over and over again as it flowed in every direction.
There were many shelves and holes to hide in until patrols passed, and the multi-layered tunnels often allowed her to move freely even when Lurr passed her above or below.
Lemi had never seen anything like this strange natural architecture.
If it was outside in a verdant forest, she could imagine it being terribly fun to play in with the other girls of her village.
The exit to the cave was guarded, but the two guards faced outwards, protecting against those who might try to sneak in, not out.

Neither of them stood close to the stone, so Lemi carefully crept along the side of the cave and slipped out to the left behind them, the howling wind of the canyon protecting her silent steps from the keen ears of the Lurr.
She climbed the canyon slope and crept along the ridge out of sight of the guards.
The ledge overhung the canyon path, shielding it from the sky and mountain tops.
As Lemi climbed, the path disappeared into its natural camouflage.
Unless one knew the entrance to the canyon valley, they would never know the cave or canyon was there.
Lemi continued towards Sen’uon and kept to the steep slopes of the city’s perimeter.
The Lurr who may have spotted her did not seem to care about a dryad in their city.
Most the populous were citizens and likely not connected to the chimera despite being Lurr, or at least Lemi assumed after one Lurr waved to her as she passed.
The only location Lemi could not avoid was the narrow pass leading out of the Hemenonan range.
The guards there knew of her and that she was taken.
The range itself near the pass was heavily guarded up the rocks, and should she be spotted climbing out of the range, that suspicion would be enough for them to attack her.
She had a single plan, and if that did not work, she did not know what else to do.
Lemi made no attempt to hide as she walked out of Sen’uon for the pass.
The guards took notice quickly, and the large Lurr troll approached.
“I was forced to leave,” Lemi explained before the massive guard could speak.
“I didn’t want to leave Ceil behind, but I was getting sick being in there.
I am pregnant, and so for my daughter’s sake, I was forced to leave.” Lemi let her honest, dejected heart show on her face.
The guard knelt and looked at the young, wilting dryad.
She was in far worse state than when she had tried to sneak into the pass eight days ago.
“Will you be safe leaving Sen’uon,” he asked.
“Dryads are less affected by the cold, and we can go days without food so long as there is sunlight.”
The guard lifted Lemi.
She panicked a little until he set her on his shoulder.
He carried her through the pass and south to the road.
Once he set her down in the shelter of one of the nearby ruins, he knelt to speak with her again.
“If you leave the road and head south, there is a shallow ravine that follows east along most the exposed stretch of road.
Once it reaches the surface, follow the wind, and you will reach the ravine the road passes through before long.
It is the safest path to return.”
“You are kind,” Lemi said, not expecting such treatment.
“As the gatekeeper of Sen’uon, I must protect the city from those who might mean harm.
We are not violent without reason.” The massive troll gently pushed Lemi’s back with his large hand.
“Thank you,” Lemi said before running south.
In her weakened state, the winds were almost too much for Lemi to endure.
Instead of traveling south, the winds forced her southeast, but she eventually reached the ravine the guard mentioned.
There the winds swept over her, allowing her to travel west.
She peeked up from time to time at the Hemenonan range to the north to gauge how far she needed to travel, looking for familiar markers on the steep peaks.
She passed where she believed her camp was located, hoping that they would still be there, and let the wind push her northeast as she traveled to meet it.
Before Lemi could meet the first ruins at the base of the Hemenonan range, a swift body dashed with the wind and pounced on her.
She tumbled with him across the snow until his hands and feet dug into the ground, slowing them to a stop.
The wolf-like beast was something Lemi had never seen before, and she feared it was a Lurr who caught her going against the guard’s instructions.
Two more similar persons arrived quickly and bound her.
Lemi stayed silent in fearful anxiety as they led her north for the ruins.
She quickly recognized the location and that they were headed for her camp.
“Are you with Basara,” she asked.
When she received no answer, her panic grew.
“What happened to everyone in the camp?”
Lemi feared that her party might have been attacked by these wolf-people.
She looked to the tops of the ruins and found more of them keeping watch.
The large, tilted, cylindrical ruin Basara chose for the camp came into view, and she saw Benab sitting atop one of the crumbled walls on the outside next to another of the wolf-people.
“Benab!” Lemi screamed his name with all her might.
The creature next to him nudged him with its leg and pointed down to Lemi.
Benab looked down at her and ran for the inside of the ruin with all haste.
Tears fell from Lemi’s eyes as she saw Chloe and Justin and others from her party flood out of the ruin to greet her.
She was quickly unbound and gathered in Chloe and Justin’s embrace.
Coby soared over the sheer peaks of the Hemenonan range with Lemi’s arms in his talons.
Kiri struggled behind, not only against the sharp winds and cold but also simply keeping pace with the large hawk.
“Down,” Lemi ordered, and Coby descended to the nearest mountain peak, setting Lemi on the rocky slope.
At this elevation, even she shivered, and the chill of the stone stung her feet.
Kiri landed beside her, and Coby quickly covered the two in his wings as a shield against the wind.
“Do you know where you are,” Kiri asked, fighting to keep her teeth from clattering.
“I know that mountain,” Lemi said, pointing to the east.
“Sen’uon is not far on the other side.
She scanned the mountains and steep valleys between.
The canyon was well hidden as she had seen from further below during her escape two days ago.
“There,” she pointed in excitement.
“It’s over there.”
Kiri looked where Lemi pointed but could not see anything that might even warrant suspicion.
A Melian’s vision was truly an astounding gift.
“If the canyon is there, then…” Lemi’s voice trailed off.
She followed some invisible trail west with her eyes.
“Coby, fly.”
Coby once again grabbed Lemi in his talons and took off in the direction Lemi pointed.
They crossed one ridge before Lemi asked to be set down again on the ridge’s far slope.
Now even Kiri could see what Lemi had likely been searching for.
Down in the valley past the slope, the crumbled top of a buried ruin stuck out above the ground as if it had been pinched between the mountains.
“It almost looked like the crested roof of the Amelian Palace,” Kiri explained to the gathering around the fire back at camp.
“That should be part of the same ruins.
The den is somewhere underneath, but it doesn’t look like there is a way in from above,” Lemi added.
“Did you see any Lurr guarding the top of the ruin,” the lycon speaker asked.
“If Lemi could not see any, then they are either well-hidden or there are none,” Kiri answered.
“Then my turn has come,” Zose announced.
Coby flew both Zose and Basara one at a time to the ruin Lemi located.
Basara was there both to protect Coby until Zose returned and keep Coby warm, as night was setting in and they were exposed.
“Be careful.
The Lord of Sen’uon is not like other Chimera,” Basara warned.
“You have never once asked me to take care when I go off on a subjugation contract.
No need to start now,” Zose replied with confidence.
“Besides, I am only searching for Ceil.
I’ll be fine.” He also planned to search for the chimera, but he kept that to himself.
“You injured your knee descending a mountain.
You are over four years old.
You are not as young as you once were.”
“I couldn’t take the whistle with me into the stone.
Coby heard my whistle and found me, so it’s fine.”
“And if he did not?
I do worry, a lot.
I have been thinking this for a while now, but you should retire from being a hunter mercenary.
I am sure Jit could employ you at the exchange.”
“Then I’ll quit,” Zose replied immediately.
“I can’t have you setting Ib’nua aflame worrying over me.”
Basara exhaled an exasperated sigh but then smiled.
“Go,” she said before leaning in to give Zose a kiss.
As their lips parted, Zose lightly pinched Basara’s side making her jolt.
“Go,” she ordered again with a glower, pushing Zose down through the stone.
The ruins below were just as Zose expected, crushed beyond comprehension.
There were small pockets of air, but if they wanted to infiltrate through these ruins, earth mages would be needed.
Thanysa was a conjurer with only weak alteration abilities, so the main bulk of the work would be shouldered by Byurk.
The destruction of the ruins made following them down much harder.
Zose spread his shapeless form as far as he could to search for where the ruins continued, but the more he searched, the more he felt that Lemi had been mistaken.
The lower he descended, the more metals he found, not ruins.
The ore veins were so thick that he couldn’t pass through most of them.
Nearly exhausting himself, he returned to the surface.
“No luck,” he told Basara as she warmed him.
“The ruins were crushed, and there is no sign of them below, almost as if this roof was dropped here from the sky.”
Basara watched the mountains slowly grow darker in the shade of the approaching night as she held Zose.
The more she stared at the beautiful mountain scenery, the more the mountains almost appeared tilted at an angle.
The south-facing slopes were far sheerer than the north.
“These mountains were created by the gods according to legend,” she mused.
“What if it was just an extremely powerful form of earth magic?”
“I would hate to meet the one who did it,” Zose laughed.
“Think about it.
The ruins on the south face of the Hemenonan range creep up the mountainside as if upheaved or plowed.
The mountains lean away from the Afarit, the center of the destruction.
What if they did not rise from the ground so much as they were forced outward from the epicenter?”
“Then the ruins might have been dragged by the mountains.
It wouldn’t continue directly below us but further south!
This roof is just what remained on the surface as it moved!”
Zose kissed Basara and dove back down into the ruins so quickly Coby gave a startled cry and stamped around in irritation.
He searched further south as he descended, and although there were still veins of ore, he also found stone matching the ruins crushed within the rocks.
He followed the trail of crushed stone and reached his first intact structure.
It was nothing more than an isolated tower, but he knew now he was headed in the right direction.
The number and completeness of the buried ruins increased.
Just as Basara had theorized, a massive temple or castle was buried deep underground at a southward slant as if pushed by the mountains.
The outer walls were obliterated, but the inner structure, its rooms and corridors and halls, were mostly intact, and Lurr inhabited them.
He found it.
Phasing through the aged stone was incredibly easy, but there was something Zose had not expected.
Channels for natural gas had been constructed creating massive furnaces along many of the walls for both light and heat.
The stone along the largest rooms was often so hot that Zose could not pass through.
While this did make inspecting the larger rooms difficult, it also meant that there should be vents to the surface to replace the air consumed by the plentiful flames, or perhaps another entrance.
If not, the noxious gas in the cave leading to the entrance would be sucked into the ruins, or so Zose assumed at least.
He was no architect.
He now had three goals: finding Ceil, finding the chimera, and finding the vents.
Zose’s newest goal ended up being the first completed.
While traveling along the ceiling of the grandest hall, he found several circular stone vents leading up through the mountain.
Following one brought him to the surface of the northward-facing slope of the ridge just south of the ruins.
From there he could just barely see the roof on the surface in the last remaining light of day, although he was too far away to see where Basara and Coby hid.
The vent was wide enough for a lithe body to enter and not too steep to descend.
If they brought a rope, they could be lowered into the grand hall.
The only problem was that whoever entered via the vents would be exposed there in the hall, and many of the lycon would not fit in the vent.
For now, it could serve as a secondary entrance.
After a short rest in the cold, Zose descended through the stone of the vent back to the large hall.
He moved through the corridor to the west but could not see what lay within the large room at the end.
Something was wrong with the stone.
He could not tell what it was.
Something permeated through it that felt off, almost sickly.
No sound vibrated through the stone, so the room was likely empty, but he could not move to the stone’s face to peer into the room.
Perhaps this was the chimera’s lair, and in the chimera’s long and ageless years it had developed the means to prevent oreads from spying.
Zose had no way of knowing.
Instead, he returned to the hall and traveled down the left corridor.

He did not travel far before the stone began to pulse, and the deeper he traveled into the maze of ruins interconnected by volcanic caves and tunnels, the louder the pulse became until it sounded like a heartbeat.
Zose quickly realized that the sound was indeed a heartbeat.
It moved through the tunnels and approached his location.
Zose held his nonexistent breath as a long and gangly chimera passed through the tunnel walking on bone spikes protruding from its fore-elbows.
Before leaving the tunnel, the chimera stopped and turned to look back down the tunnel.
His neck extended to an incredible length, and he began inspecting walls near where Zose resided.
The moment Zose phased back deeper into the stone to not be caught, the chimera vanished.
Zose could feel the reverberations of its swift movements down the tunnels.
Just as the lycon had warned, this chimera’s speed defied all reason.
Zose quickly left the area in the opposite direction, returning to the grand hall.
He needed to hurry.
The number of Lurr was already increasing.
He had been discovered, which could prove dangerous for Ceil whom he had yet to locate.
The corridor to the right of the hall was similar to the left, only there were far more ruins and fewer ancient lava caves.
The ruins plowed by the mountains seemed to gather here and perhaps cushioned the grand hall protecting it from complete destruction.
Those ruins were hollowed out into the most bizarre caves as if this was some mad architect’s life work.
Rooms and passageways spread in all directions creating a literal maze for any who could not simply pass through the stone like him.
The trouble became locating Ceil among this maze of ruins before his discovery could endanger her.
Lurr ran down nearly every passageway, and earth mages held their hands to the stone sending out pulses of ven to find him.
Zose could only distance himself, ridding him of his vision of the mazing passageways.
He could only feel the subtle and muffled vibrations of movement and the pulses that never quite propagated far enough to detect him.
It was like watching ripples in still water to determine the shape of the channels the water flowed through.
As Zose observed the sound and pulses, he noticed one area he was blind.
There were no steps or noises nor pulses of ven.
The Lurr avoided that location, but there were surely passageways leading to it.
Zose moved directly above the location and found it just wide enough that if he centered himself, the pulses searching for him could not reach him.
There he descended and found a single room.
Once again there was a sickly aura permeating the face of the stone, but it was nowhere near as strong as the larger room connected to the grand hall.
Moving to the face of the stone only made him feel nauseous, but that was the extent of it.
Inside, an anorexic troll woman wearing the bare minimum of coverings in the warm room tended to an elf girl.
It was Ceil.
He found her, but she did not look well.
The troll, likely Inym by Basara’s description, held Ceil’s head up and poured water slowly into her mouth with a wooden ladle.
Ceil was not limp and lifeless but at the same time, she did not take any action for herself.
“Inym,” Zose spoke quietly from the ceiling.
Inym’s drooping ears twitched, and she looked around the room for the source of the noise.
“Inym, I am Zose.”
The moment Zose mentioned his name, Inym acted as if she had never heard the noise and returned to Ceil, but the light pivoting of her ears showed she was waiting for when he would next speak.
“We are formulating a plan to rescue you and Ceil, but we will need your cooperation.
I was discovered by Lord Ab’pul, so you need to protect Ceil until we can reach you.” Zose knew he was asking the impossible.
If his discovery did endanger Ceil and Inym, Inym had no hope of fending off so many Lurr.
“The Lurr sure are noisy today,” Inym said as if speaking to Ceil.
“I guess I should be grateful that you repel them.
And I have no need to worry.
I am the only one they have to take care of you.”
Zose immediately realized that Inym meant both she and Ceil were in no danger.
“Maybe your friends discovered where you are,” Inym continued.
“They should give up on you.
You are safer here than with them.
Tolmyur cannot reach you here under the protection of Lord Ab’pul.”
“Inym!” A female Lurr stood in the entryway to the room, but she dared not enter.
She looked to the upper level of the room where Inym sat with Ceil.
“An oread has infiltrated the lair, likely Zose.
Have you been contacted by the intruder?”
Zose’s fears were unfolding before his eyes.
He quickly moved through the stone to the entryway and gathered the part of him that was his two bone blades.
“I have,” Inym replied promptly.
“Had you not asked, I would have kept it secret.
Zose informed me that he will attempt to rescue Ceil.”
Zose wanted to curse Inym.
The Lord of Sen’uon must have bribed her or otherwise forced her compliance.
“Do you know his plans or where he is now?”
“I do not.
His voice came from the stone but fell silent when you arrived.
Even if he told me his plan, I would not tell you.”
Zose was about to strike the Lurr down but stopped.
Inym had not completely sided with the Lurr.
“You betray Lord Ni’inca Ab’pul?” The Lurr’s eyes grew red.
“I was paid to protect and care for Ceil.
You succeeded in stealing her from Zose’s companions, and now he has come to reclaim her.
If he and those with him can best your lord, that proves she is safer with them.
If he cannot succeed despite his efforts, Ceil will remain your prisoner here.
Either way, I have no part in your competition with Zose.
My duty is Ceil’s care, and I will continue that charge no matter who holds her chains.”
Inym’s words were directed at both Zose and the Lurr equally.
She would provide neither with aid, and Zose could not fault her.
That was the best route for ensuring her safety.
However, the weight of her challenge was not distributed equally between Zose and the Lord of Sen’uon.
Having revealed that he was preparing to rescue Ceil, the defenses of the lair would increase.
Inym was clearly wagering on the side of whom she felt had the highest chance of victory.
The full power of the Ni’inca Ab’pul and his Lurr would be on display.
Such a barrier would not be overcome easily.
Should he fail, Ceil certainly would be better protected here, but such survival was not the same as living.
Protection should never be a shackle.
Zose wanted Ceil to be freed from her ever-tightening chains of pain and fear, not be devoured by them.
Zose’s arms appeared from the stone and beheaded the Lurr in one crossing stroke of his two blades.
Inym grunted and turned Ceil away from the headless body.
She was not silent in her challenge, so Zose did not doubt that other Lurr outside the room heard, but if there was any chance that they did not, he needed to take that glimmer of hope.
Zose quickly returned to Basara without further word to Inym.
She reached down and lifted him from the stone.
She was about to ask about his search but noticed the urgency in his eyes.
“I found Ceil, but there is a problem.”
Chapter 15
“Disturbing a Chimera’s Nest”
“When the brood-lord is killed, the other Lurr in the brood immediately lose their attachment to the location and flee.
With the place swarming in Lurr, the quickest and safest route is to kill the chimera first,” Benab asserted.
“That way of thinking only works in regular Lurr nests,” Basara countered.
“The Lurr here are no less intelligent than us, perhaps even more so, and Lord Ab’pul especially so.
Killing him does not guarantee that they will let us escape.
For most chimera nests, there are often other highly evolved Lurr in the brood that immediately claim control of the brood.
Sen’uon is an advanced Lurr society.
There is bound to be a command hierarchy.
Lord Ab’pul seems determined to keep Ceil contained at all cost, so whoever succeeds his position is bound to do the same.”
The leaders of the lycon, Tolmyur, and Vallen groups gathered around the campfire to discuss strategy.
The lycon were prepared to toss as many bodies as needed at the chance to kill Ni’inca Ab’pul, and more clans arrived by the day.
Byurk was likewise willing to sacrifice himself and his men if needed, but his survival was seen as a priority to everyone else due to his relationship with Jethro.
The Vallen party was also willing to lay down their lives to rescue Ceil, but they had two members whose lives were of greater value than them all, Justin and Chloe.
They should be involved as little as possible, but at the same time, they were this mission’s greatest assets.
Justin had already agreed to fight on the frontlines with the lycon, further complicating the issue because it was only through Justin’s involvement that the lycon agreed to help.
“Do you know the estimated population of Sen’uon,” Byurk asked.
“If striking down the leader will not stop them, we should at least know their numbers.”
“The city houses about a thousand Lurr, or maybe a little less,” Zose replied.
“Most of them should be civilians living there to avoid conflict with other races.
There were only about ten or so visible in the lair when I first searched it, but once I was discovered it increased to maybe a hundred in a manner of minutes.”
“Then we only have numbers to match the lair,” the speaker for the lycon announced.
“Your failure to remain hidden in your search has eliminated many options.
The chimera will not leave the nest now that he knows we seek his prey.”
“I admit my failure,” Zose apologized with his head bowed.
“I was unaware that he could detect me in the stone without using earth magic, but unplanned situations are common in any chimera subjugation, and an ancient chimera only increases that danger.
No matter how much we plan, trusting something to go as planned may be a fatal mistake.
If we cannot adapt immediately to whatever we encounter, we are dead.”

The meeting ended after drafting initial plans for infiltration and extraction with multiple variations for common occurrences in chimera subjugations based on Byurk, Zose, and Basara’s hunter mercenary experience.
On the eve of battle, only the most seasoned soldier or one with the most tranquil of spirits could sleep peacefully.
Justin spent much of the long night atop the ruins with the lycon staring out into the dark, monolithic peaks.
The night would have made them invisible if not for the very faint red-ochre alpenglow from the distant Afarit lining their silhouettes like a single jagged crack crossing the dark.
Byurk, Thanysa, and a single human soldier with weak earth magic were already at the slopes of the sheer mountain face working through the night to create a path up and through the mountain.
The lair was located to the northeast, so if they could scale the steepest outer face, they could hike to the lair and avoid Sen’uon altogether.

Lycon were incredibly athletic and could climb the mountain, but a path was needed to conserve as much energy as was possible for the upcoming confrontation against a species that far outclassed all of them in strength and endurance.
Justin’s thoughts fell upon Lurr Eydis, drawing up lingering and conflicting feelings of both disdain and longing.
The true Eydis was a little stronger than the average human, especially Justin, but Lurr Eydis was so powerful that she could charge through the brick wall of a house without slowing.
That was the strength they would face on the morrow, only multiplied many times over.
In truth, Justin pitied the Lurr.
The wilderlands were harsh, but other races were able to build cities and towns that were comfortable enough for the terrain and climate.
In Hen’anin, the Lurr who were seen as outcasts by most races lived in precarious and run-down shacks teetering on the slope of a mountain, just trying to eke out the most meager existence.
They never asked to be born as Lurr, to have to feast on flesh to grow and develop into something with the power to feel or reason.

The few lucky ones were like Lurr Eydis, given the chance to become a person, but most failed in their evolution, becoming nothing more than hungering beasts preying on whatever ecosystem they found themselves in, hunted by all out of fear, even their more successful kin.
Every Lurr initially had the potential to become a thinking, feeling individual like Lurr Eydis, able to hate, regret, learn, love, and more.
The Lurr of Sen’uon were not enemies.

They were the lucky ones among their kind just trying to live in a world that hated them, but for the sole crime of stealing away someone Justin was determined to protect, he would help lead a task force to kill them as if they were no different than those failed monsters.
The thought made Justin sick, as if he was killing Lurr Eydis with his own hands.
Justin closed his eyes and began meditating.
Perhaps another week or two with his thoughts would help sort out his feelings enough to allow some rest.
Sunrise.
Basara and Chloe left camp for the pass.
Zose had already gone ahead to monitor the movement of the Lurr within Sen’uon.
He had argued initially that the two most powerful among them should be a direct part of the mission, but Basara refused.
She and Chloe were too powerful to select for the fight inside the underground caves and ruins, especially for Chloe who lacked control of her explosive flame.
Basara had another plan that used their power just the same, and at least in her case, her power was known by the gatekeeper of Sen’uon.
Basara eyed the rocks above as she entered the pass.
Normally the Lurr stationed above would keep hidden until the visitors were proven to be a threat, but now there were many visible among the crags and outcroppings.
“Basara, it has been three years since you last visited Sen’uon,” the gatekeeper spoke in a loud echoing voice as he approached, using the maenad tongue of the northeastern wilderlands.
“Forgive my impertinence, but you are not permitted to enter Sen’uon.”
Basara shook her head and replied in Elven, setting the language for the discussion so Chloe could understand.
“You dare bar my path?”
The Lurr hidden among the rocks revealed themselves.
Sure enough, the guard had increased at least threefold.
The Lord of Sen’uon was wary after detecting Zose in his lair.
“Sen’uon is closed.
No matter the traveler or their business, none are permitted to enter or leave until Lord Ni’inca Ab’pul gives word.”
“My husband, Zose, has taken upon himself a contract without knowing the grave hidden dangers it posed.
I am here to see him safe and returned home to me.
I know he is in your city.
I ask you again… Do you dare block my path?”
Many Lurr appeared from the surrounding peaks and climbed or jumped down into the pass.
More filtered in through the narrow split through the rock acting as the gate to Sen’uon.
The massive Lurr took two steps forward and asserted his guard, seemingly growing even larger in stature.
“I have heard legend of your power, but you are still only two women.
I mean no disrespect to you or your husband, but unknown dangers are part of any hunter mercenary contract.
You cannot enter.
We will turn you away by force if necessary.”
“And I am willing to destroy your city if only to see my husband safely returned to me.
This woman at my side is a maenad whose flame surpasses my own.
No matter your numbers, we could raze your city to the ground.
Zose knows my temper.
Once he sees our flame, he will know to hide in the stone.
Only an oread could survive the wake of our destruction.”

A warning arrow was fired from behind the gatekeeper, aimed between Basara and Chloe’s heads, but the moment it approached within a foot of Basara, it burst out away from them into molten sparks and ash.
“I have given my demand.” Basara glared into the unwavering eyes of the gatekeeper.
A rush of heated wind blew out from Basara through the entire pass, instantly melting all the frost and snow into wafting vapor.
When the wind calmed, the air of the pass was as hot as a desert in the height of summer.
“Do not make me ask again.”
A column of frozen mist rose as the steam from the melted snow left the pass into the frigid air to be carried away by the wind.
Zose stared up at the signal to start the operation, one Basara would not have created if she had felt the number of Lurr in the pass insufficient.
Basara’s task was to hold them in the pass in a deadlock as long as possible.
Neither she nor Chloe wanted to fight them, and surely the Lurr would not want to fight Basara.

An impasse was the goal, but should violence break out, Basara felt better about killing the chimera’s brood--Lurr working directly for the Lord of Sen’uon--than killing the innocent civilians of the city.
Most the Lurr in Sen’uon were rapidly evacuating to the underground caves to hide from whatever threat just arrived in the pass.
Zose was pleased to see that his assumption was correct, that most the Lurr in Sen’uon were civilians that wanted to avoid conflict.
Any guards that were in the city acting on Lord Ab’pul’s command had rushed to the pass, and a group from the west that had possibly guarded the path to the canyon also joined.
With this, there would be fewer potential reinforcements in the lair.
Zose headed for the canyon following Lemi’s description of its location now that Basara had given her truthful excuse for her presence at the pass.
The entrance to the canyon was no more than a fissure in a rock face that anyone would easily miss, but once entered it opened into a deep chasm shielded above by overlapping outcroppings.
The cave entrance sat at the far end of the canyon, guarded by only two Lurr.
Zose crept through the stone to the rocks nearest the first guard.
He gathered his shapeless form and concentrated it at a single point on the rock’s surface.
With his blades in hand, he sprung from the rock face using the force of his body regaining its form, lunging far faster than what would otherwise be physically possible.
His blade plunged through the fur, leather, and muscle into the back of the first Lurr, piercing its heart.
The second Lurr turned for the cave about to run to report the attack.
If Zose let him go, he had no hope of catching him.
Zose sank his foot under the soil and sent it immediately below the Lurr’s anchor leg.
The very moment the Lurr sprung to dash into the cave, Zose’s foot rose beneath it at a skewed angle.
Instead of propelling the Lurr forward, the force of his lunge sent the Lurr to the side straight at Zose.
Using the Lurr’s own momentum and surprise, he slid his knife across the Lurr’s neck as it passed, carving deep and halfway severing its neck.
Lurr were powerful, but with skill and the right opportunity, that power could be used against them.
Zose pulled his foot back through the ground and winced as he wrapped it with a sash woven from his own hair.
His ankle was broken as were several bones in his foot.
So long as he sank his feet into the ground as he walked, the injury would not hinder him.
“Basara’s going to be furious,” Zose sighed.
He retrieved the blade lodged in the first Lurr’s back with strenuous effort and then moved the bodies out of sight of the cave entrance.
After clearing the blood to the best of his ability, he sank back into the ground by the entrance and waited.
Until the lycon replaced him, his first role was to guard the lair entrance so that no Lurr could request reinforcements from the pass.
“We have orders to move Lady Ceil,” the new Lurr attendant announced from the door.
Inym felt something was about to happen when the noise outside the room had slowly increased and all lights had quickly been extinguished.
Zose’s rescue mission had likely begun.
Inym scooped Ceil into her arms and carried her to the door.
Once she left the room, another two Lurr entered and extinguished the braziers.
The ruin cave quickly became blacker than night, and at the same time, two small rings of red appeared from where the new attendant stood.
Inym shrank as horrid memories of countless red eyes in abyssal blackness plagued her mind.
“Come,” the eyes ordered walking backwards, and Inym struggled to follow.

Every furnace, torch, and brazier had been extinguished.
Only a Lurr’s eye could pierce the darkness, led by their own subdued glow that was only powerful enough for them to see.
Inym could only make out the vague pattern of the walls near where the attendant walked and only if the attendant walked right beside the wall.
Even a spriggan would be troubled in this suffocating dark.
After following a maze of caverns, the noise of Lurr scrambling around the lair making preparations began to echo.
The red dots of eyes increased, and their location showed the hall she entered was vast, the grand hall where she met the Lord of Sen’uon.
Inym tried to follow the red of the attendant’s eyes, but the longer she remained in the dark hall with only red eyes moving all about her, the less her legs moved.
Her emotional strength failed her, and she dropped to her knees.
Her breath grew erratic.
She held Ceil tighter and tighter and suppressed the cry threatening to escape her throat.
“Move!

Inym’s cry broke out in fear.
She couldn’t move.
While Inym had expressed that she would not help either side in this conflict, the Lurr had not accounted for Inym’s trauma inhibiting their preparations.
“You, bring rope and bind her and the girl together!” the attendant ordered to another.

“No, let go of me,” Inym hollered.
She felt the rope wind around her and Ceil in her arms.
She soon felt hot, viscous moisture and smelled a rotten stench.
The rope fell slack, and the red eyes vanished.
“You and you, continue binding them until the rope is secure.”
Two more Lurr closed in.
Inym felt the rope tighten.
In time, one pair of eyes dimmed, and after one final tug that held Ceil painfully close against Inym’s chest, the second pair of eyes dimmed and vanished.
The final Lurr collapsed on Inym, and she felt his flesh melt over her.
Inym recalled the melted corpses in the council room.
A new trauma melded with her former.

Inym’s cries became frantic screams as the attendant dragged her across the hall to the same corridor down which the chimera left after their meeting days before, a corridor that led to that chimera’s nest.
“Please!
I’m sorry!
I’m sorry!
Forgive me!
Let me go!”
Beads of sweat ran down Byurk’s face.

Tyree was reserved in case of a medical emergency for Ceil, Chloe, or Justin.

Any soldier whose heart he did not trust fully was left to guard the camp during the rescue.
The rest, aside from this single earth mage, would join the lycon at the frontal assault that should begin soon.
Zose’s arrival from the cave entrance in the canyon would signal that the frontal assault had begun, and then Byurk would finish breaking through to Ceil’s room.

“The ruins are dark,” a voice spoke from the cave wall near Byurk.

Such was the life of a soldier.
At least after breaking in, he could rest as he waited for his role in the extraction.
Zose exited the stone and sat down on the ground, but he kept one of his feet inside the stone.
“Everything was quiet.
I could not see any Lurr, nor could I hear anything.
I doubt the lair has been evacuated.
They are ready for us.”

Byurk hopped to his feet and continued parting the stone diagonally downward, hardening it once he pushed it aside to reinforce the walls of the tunnel to prevent collapse.
The human earth mage then removed Tae’s hand from his forehead and ran back up the tunnel to inform the awaiting lycon.

“What happened?” Tae asked.

Tae placed her hand on his ankle.
“It’s badly broken.
I am not skilled enough to mend this severe of a break.
I can do a little, and I will need to use your ven to heal it.
Is that fine?”
“It is.
Just fix it enough to mitigate the pain.
So long as I keep my foot in stone, it loses its form and should not worsen as fast.”
“Will your injury hinder your search for the Lord of Sen’uon,” Byurk asked back over his shoulder.
“No.

“It is likely a trap.”

Several lycon brandished small, compressed metal bows strapped to their forearms that fired bolts; a peculiar technology they claimed would help contend against the Lurr’s superior strength and magic.
Not only did the small bows fire with the same power as a full-length wooden bow, but the bolts were also tipped with a numbing poison to counter a Lurr’s superior reflexes and speed, should it hit.

“There is a chance that the Chimera and Ceil switched places.”

Hold out until then,” Zose replied just before diving into the stone.
Byurk scanned for Zose, and seeing that he did not immediately return, he knew the room remained clear.
He took a deep breath, and wedged his fingers into the stone before him, tearing it apart to both sides.
A tunnel grew fifteen yards deep.
Byurk ran down to the stone at the end with the search party close behind.
After tearing the final fifteen yards open, he breached the room.
Byurk moved to the side as the elf party rushed past.
He then took up the rear, jumping down last.
When he landed, he immediately felt something wrong.
“They are collapsing the room!”
Earth ven surged through all the stone making it brittle.
Byurk gripped the ruin stone at his feet and countered the opposing ven with his, strengthening the walls and ceiling about the room, but it was a losing battle.
“They are in the passageways surrounding the room!

The lycon acted first, dashing from the room into the dark.

“The lycon will not last on their own without magic support.”

There should have only been about twenty more, but no less than fifty followed.
The largest force was supposed to be in battle at the cave entrance.
If the numbers there had not decreased unknown to him, then there may have been many more lycon than those who resided with them at camp.
Once the second party left to aid those already fighting in the ruin caves, Byurk was left alone in the room, struggling to hold their most advantageous entrance and exit intact.
He lacked the ven to dig another tunnel.
Should it be compromised, their only ways out were through the battle at the entrance or through the vents.
The vents were too narrow for most, and the fighting at the entrance was sure to be great and terrible.
Byurk knew that should he fail in his role, most of those involved in the rescue and subjugation would not be able to escape.
Justin propped himself up, legs spread against the sides of the ventilation shaft.
The shaft was angled just steep enough that he could not simply rest on the slope.
Five slim lycon stood below him just above the vent’s opening into the ruin cave system below.
They discussed between each other in their own language, but Justin could not make reason about any of it.
From their gesticulations, he assumed they were thinking about jumping down before Zose arrived to give them the signal.
Zose was late, and if something held him up at any of the chain of signals he was tasked with passing, unforeseen trouble was likely the cause.
Justin hoped that Zose would appear with the news that Ceil was safely extracted, but extraction or not, Justin was still committed to his role of support in the confrontation against the Chimera.
Whether Ceil was alive or dead, he would fight.
His party was separate from the rescue party.
With that in mind, they did not need to wait for Zose.
The lycon below jumped down into the cavern.
Justin had little choice but to follow their lead because there were many more just above him in a long line through the shaft up to the surface.
Justin was at the front in case the Chimera appeared immediately, but the cave was empty and dark.
There were no Lurr that he could see, but there was a sound.
Justin could not tell where it came from, but it sounded like a woman crying.
Perhaps that was why the Lycon decided to jump down.
He could not hear it from up in the vent, but they could.
“Ceil,” one of the lycon asked Justin.
“No,” he replied.
The voice was female, but it was too deep to be Ceil’s.
It was likely another victim of the Lurr.
The chimera was their goal, but much to Justin’s surprise, those with him seemed intent on investigating the source of the noise.
The lycon jumping down from the vent covered Justin’s back, and those with him raced to the source of the sound.
Justin could barely see in the light of the single small lantern carried on the hip of one of the forward lycon.
He turned a corner following behind the forward lycon into a large cavern.
Faint phosphorescent algae glowed blue in the steaming pools around the room’s perimeter.
In the center of the room atop a mound of moss and furs huddled a bound Mountain Elf woman.
Ceil was clenched tight in her arms.
Justin feared that the chimera and Ceil had swapped places, that the other parties would be forced to fight not only the chimera, but all the Lurr of the lair as well.
Three of the forward lycon vanished before Justin’s eyes, taking the portable light with them.
Justin did not see what happened, only that they seemed at first to twitch leftward before they vanished.
The rotten smell of iron reached Justin’s nose.
He peered left and saw the remains of the three lycon splattered against the far wall.
A hand grasped Justin from behind and pulled him backwards, but it was not fast enough.
Time slowed.
A long spike of bone swung from the left.
It protruded from the long, multi-jointed arm of the most horrid creature Justin had ever seen, the physical manifestation of a nightmare.
The spike traveled inhumanly fast.
He could not save the two lycon in its path.
Twisting his shoulder downward, Justin only just avoided the solid bone that cleaved the heads of the two lycon.
Support fire from the small, arm-mounted crossbows hit their mark, allowing Justin to escape back to the room’s entrance.
The chimera paused for a moment as the poison began its internal assault on the chimera’s body.
The bolts broke from the skin like festering splinters forced from swelling flesh.
The swells then shrunk and healed before Justin’s eyes.
The chimera, showing little emotion other than the cold will to massacre all the intruders in his lair, lunged for the center of Justin’s chest.
Justin had no time to think.
His body reacted immediately and froze time the moment the spike of the chimera’s elbow neared his chest.
The entire world fell still, at first.
Justin felt a strange sensation he could not describe.
It was foreign but familiar all the same.
He knew it, or at least his body recognized it.
The frozen impasse ended only for him and the Chimera.
The dripping moisture of the cave hung suspended in the air.
The hot puffs of breath of the lycon remained frozen in their clouds.
The lycon remained unblinking and unmoving.
Justin and the Chimera were the only life in the time-frozen world.
The chimera’s cold expression changed to mild surprise, and he extracted his spike the moment it touched Justin’s chest.
His long neck extended, and he examined Justin in his time-frozen world.
A deep, undulating laugh escaped his three-mandibled mouth.
Justin felt confident in his plan that if the chimera was so fast, he could freeze the chimera in time long enough to create the opportunity for the lycon to kill it.
The greatest danger of disturbing a chimera nest is not knowing the abilities of the chimera.

Life magic was not outside the realm of possibility, but a complication that Justin, the lycon, Basara, Zose, Byurk, and all those of the various parties had never accounted for in their planning stood before him.
Like Justin, the Chimera was a time mage.
Chapter 16
“Memories of Tragedy”
Ni’inca Ab’pul eyed the strange human with curiosity.
Many centuries had passed since he last encountered a time mage.
He certainly could not be of Tolmyur.
Those desert dwellers lost their magic proficiency when the elves culled them before their exodus.
But if not Tolmyur, from where did this pale-faced human originate?
Curious.
All the more curious due to his seemingly instant use of time magic.

Had this man’s proficiency aligned with speed like Ni’inca Ab’pul, he may have been a threat, but speed was the natural enemy of those who could only slow time, since their magic meant little when their opponent could negate their effects.
Perhaps Zose requested the aid of the lycon, and the lycon were emboldened by having this time mage on their side.
Regrettably, they were all ill-fated in their attempt to rescue Ceil.
Ni’inca Ab’pul channeled his speed magic.
The man reacted, having felt the unnatural ven signature, but he could do nothing to stop him.
No matter how much the man slowed time in the room, Ni’inca Ab’pul could move faster still.
“A pity I must kill one of your ability.”
The channeling finished.
Ni’inca Ab’pul jumped instantly to the wall left of the entrance, raised the spike of his fore-elbow, and lunged for the man.
The man’s reaction felt slow, but only because Ni’inca Ab’pul’s speed was incomparable.
The man only managed to raise his hand to his face in futile desperation to block the strike.
The moment the bone of the spike touched the flesh of the man’s hand, the man vanished.
Ni’inca Ab’pul struck the ground with one hand and slid to a stop, tearing up the stone of the cavern floor.
Not only was the man gone, but only two lycon remained, knocked to the ground.
He turned to his bedding in the middle of the cavern.
Both Ceil and Inym were missing.
Ni’inca Ab’pul realized what had happened immediately, and it was only possible if that man could defy the laws of time magic by circumventing channeling time.
In a contest of speed, one who could ignore channeling time would always be faster than one who was bound to it.
Justin ran behind a lycon carrying Ceil.
A shaking hand pushing Justin’s back urged him to move faster.
Inym wanted to run as far from the chimera as possible, but in her terror, she at least had the composure to ensure her rescuers did not fall behind.
Justin cursed himself.
His plan to kill the chimera relied on the lycon’s ability to attack the chimera while it remained frozen.

When Justin caught it off guard and stopped its time in that last attack, he resumed time in the cavern to allow the lycon to strike it down, but the moment any weapon made contact, both the weapon and its wielder also froze in time.
Nothing could be done for the two lycon who attacked the chimera.
If Justin resumed time for them, he feared that the chimera would recover with them.
He needed to rescue Ceil, pass her off to Thanysa’s team, and devise another plan of attack.
His time magic was no longer a trump card.
The standoff at the gateway to Sen’uon remained at impasse, but the attitude of the gatekeeper was slowly, visibly changing.
Basara noticed over time several Lurr on the cliffs disappear into the city or elsewhere, and they never returned.
The more that were sent away, the more irritable the gatekeeper became until his stern gaze became a crimson glare focused on Basara.
“I know what you are planning, maenad, and you will not be successful,” he growled.
“Lord Ni’inca Ab’pul will never relinquish that girl.

“And yet you seem troubled.

Are you wondering why your messengers have not returned?

It is only out of goodwill that I am not fighting my way into your city,” Basara spoke frankly.
The gatekeeper’s glare darkened.
“Lycon!” a Lurr high on the rocks called.

“There are maybe one hundred lycon.
They hold weapons,” Chloe whispered.

The lycon were taking independent action.
“Are those yours,” the gatekeeper bellowed.

That did not mean that they were not connected.
Without a doubt these lycon were associated with the chimera extermination team.
A scream echoed from the narrow gap cleaved through the rock face behind the gatekeeper.
He turned around to catch the moment when an armed lycon pounced on a fleeing woman, a civilian, and bit deep into her neck killing her.
Numerous metal bolts protruded from her back.
Lycon were already in the city.

Basara did not answer.
She did not know.
The city wasn’t to be touched.
She turned south to the approaching lycon in time to see them charge, firing both arrows and bolts at the Lurr on the slopes of the pass.
All at once the pass was drowned in battle, and Basara did not know which side she should take.

Chloe eyed the lycon bounding up the steep slopes of the pass amid arrows and magic to reach the perched Lurr.
She never once startled or frightened at the attacks flying around her, much to Basara’s surprise.
This young woman had a rigid mettle only seen in one who had experienced many arduous battles.
“The Mountain Elf is moving,” Chloe warned.
And situational awareness, Basara thought.
The gatekeeper was only in her peripheral, and yet she noticed at the same time Basara had.
Basara became a hunter mercenary out of necessity for her survival at just under a year old after killing her mother.
After a grueling year had passed and she was about the age Chloe was now, she was not even half the warrior Chloe appeared to be.
The sprites stated Chloe was vital for the survival of the future, and Basara was starting to see why.
Given another year, Chloe would become a warrior of unmatched caliber.
“The gatekeeper has made his decision.

I am flame.
Do it now!” Basara ordered.

Viscous fire grew in Chloe’s hands, and she thrust it at her feet.
Instead of an explosion, the fire spread like oil clinging to the road.

Fire or not, injured or not, he would plow through them.

With a swing of her arm, a ribbon of flame latched onto the charging Lurr, and there she detonated it.
Fire engulfed the gatekeeper.
Bound in flame, Basara pulled the gatekeeper with the fire over their heads.
He tumbled across the ground behind them, rolling over Chloe’s fire.
He roared and writhed but was soon reduced to a flaming husk.

One hundred or fewer lycon could not contest against the number of Lurr guarding the pass.
Basara knew it was a diversion force.
The lycon that entered the pass chasing after the civilian was gone, vanishing back into the city.
These lycon were only here to hold the Lurr at the gateway as long as was possible.
Basara feared what machinations the lycon devised while the Lord of Sen’uon was occupied by the extraction and extermination forces.
Once again, her hand was forced.
If she fought the lycon here, she would have to fight all the lycon, and doing so would endanger Zose and the Vallen party.
If she did not act, the lycon at the pass would be exterminated, and the Lurr would come for her next.
No matter what happened, she would have to kill the Lurr guarding Sen’uon.
Better now to spare what lycon she could.
Basara spun slowly with outstretched arms.
Threads of Chloe’s flame rose around her from the road.
She rapidly swung her hands directing them one after another into the numerous Lurr.
Each one touched by the thin trail of fire bloomed into flame.
Even those with a fire affinity succumbed to Chloe’s superior heat.
Chloe watched in astonishment the control of one who appeared human but was half flame elemental.
In no longer than a minute, all Lurr guarding the gateway were dead.
Basara gathered the remaining flame on the road and launched it into the sky.
It burst into sparks that fizzled harmlessly into the cold wind.
That was the signal to all across the mountains west of Sen’uon that she was forced to eliminate the gate guard.
It was the prearranged warning for the worst outcome, that all Sen’uon may now be their enemy.
Zose sped through the stone as fast as possible to the vent where Justin should have been waiting only to find it empty.
The party of twenty-eight lycon was nowhere near the vent opening.
Unlike Ceil’s room, there were no Lurr either.
Zose cursed himself for choosing to take the quickest route instead of following the caves and ruin passageways.
If he had, he might have spotted them either fighting or fleeing.
If fortune blessed Justin’s party, perhaps they had already dispatched the chimera and were rushing back to help Thanysa’s overwhelmed rescue team.
He remained motionless, silent, and listened.
Fortune had not favored them.
Zose heard the faint and distant pulse of the chimera’s powerful heartbeat, and it was rapidly growing weaker.
The Chimera was on the move at haste.
Either it was pursuing Justin’s party or had already eliminated them.
The chimera was headed back towards the main hall and to the rescue team.
If the Chimera met that team, they would be doomed.
Zose left the stone and sprinted through the caves, ignoring the sharp pain of his only partially mended foot.
He could move faster on foot than in stone.
“Faster!” Inym screamed.
Justin could hear a thundering beat approach louder and nearer, and he knew it belonged to the Chimera.
When they infiltrated the lair, the Chimera never made such a sound, hiding silently, but now he was on the hunt, and Justin was his target.
“Ceil!” Justin called to the lycon ahead of him.
Ceil was conscious, but she did not react to his voice, nor the jarring haste of their flight, nor the drumming beat that would soon be upon them.
She could not aid their rescue.
A thunderous pulse hit Justin’s back not muffled by stone.
He turned to see a pair of red rings in the distant dark.
“Go,” he ordered, pushing Inym in front of him and allowing the remaining eight lycon to pass.

The very moment he stood alone in the dark of the cave, a stone spike appeared from the ground aimed at his chest.
Time stopped, and yet the spike still moved with the speed of a swift jab.
Justin twisted to the side just enough for the spike to only snag his leather breastplate, pulling him with it.
The leather tore, pinning him with it to the rough volcanic stone.
Justin could only shield his head from the impact that felt as if he had been hit by a car.
The chimera, moving at what could be perceived as a normal speed in this time-frozen world, ignored Justin and continued on after Ceil.
If Justin could only touch the chimera, he could temporarily freeze it again, and the chimera knew this.
“Damn it,” Justin cursed as he fought to free himself from his armor to chase after the chimera.
Ceil would soon reach the main hall, and in that large room the chimera would have full range of movement, no longer restricted to the tight confines of the caves.
The lycon would be eliminated swiftly, and no doubt the rescue party would soon follow.
“Not again,” Justin screamed.
He promised himself that he would never fail to save someone ever again.
He would not fail to rescue Ceil.
Free from his breastplate, he made chase, knowing well that he would not catch up in time.
Inym heard the chimera’s pulsing heart quiet for only a moment.
Justin had failed to even slow him down.
“Left,” she ordered the lycon just as they were about to follow the wider cave straight ahead.
