Inym thought they were safe just outside the chimera’s reach and urged the lycon on, but an orange glow behind her drew her back.
The elongated neck of the chimera stretching as far as it could into the passage glimmered like embers.
His three mandibles parted.
Only now did she realize that his strange, lanky form was because he was part dragon.
He wouldn’t blow fire.
Ceil is here, she thought, but she could see the yellow glow deep within the chimera’s maw.
Inym stood as a shield against the fleeing lycon as a swirling fire engulfed the passage.
She could not compete flame against flame as weak as she was, especially against a monster of such power.
Instead, she rapidly dropped the temperature of the fire that reached her, regulating the heat to the best of her ability.
She stood firm against the flame with her own fire affinity.
She hoped the weakened flames that passed her would only singe ceil, not kill her.
After the flames passed, she looked behind her and saw that the fire stopped at the final lycon carrying Ceil.
The others had not endured the heat and flailed their enflamed bodies at the steaming walls of the passage.
The final lycon hurried deeper, the leather on his back smoldering.
Inym followed.
The beat of the chimera’s heart reverberated through the stone, and Inym did not know where he was or how soon she would encounter him again.
She did not know the layout of this side of the ruins.
She only knew the large hall was close.
They exited the narrow corridor back into a wide cave tunnel that veered right.
The entryway to the large hall was located just after the turn.
Inym urged the lycon to move faster, but even with his burns, he still ran faster than Inym.
Right as they passed the turn, the earth rumbled.
A stone wall rose from the ground before Inym could see through to the grand hall.
She silently cursed the chimera.

She thought of every excuse she could use to spare herself from the anger of the chimera.
She had told the Lurr that she would not aid in Ceil’s rescue or pick a side.
She could tell him that she feared for Ceil’s life and only aided the rescue party to protect her.
She could tell him that she was only following Ceil because of her agreement.
If none of that worked, she could tell him that because the rescue failed, she is still the only person he had who can take care of Ceil.
The heartbeat thundered louder and louder.
Inym was at the end of her endurance.
“Make certain she escapes,” Inym ordered the lycon.
She conjured the largest fireball within her power.
Her body ached.
Her head grew light.
She was far too malnourished to start, and the fire ven conversion was draining what little energy her body had remaining.
Before she collapsed to the ground, she threw the fireball at the stone wall, only serving to create a crumbling hole through which the lycon could crawl with Ceil.
Inym collapsed to the ground.
A different chimera den and a different chimera, but history repeated itself the same.
Inym survived once before with a shredded abdomen, but she knew she would not survive again, not once Lord Ni’inca Ab’pul reached her.
Thanysa hardened her shoulder to absorb the blow of a Lurr.
Her body was weak, not fully recovered after her short hibernation, but the Lurr was also weakened severely from no less than eight lycon bolts protruding from his body.
In addition to the numbing power, she quickly learned that the poison seized the ven in the Lurr’s body preventing them from using magic.
The idea that such a poison existed was terrifying.
She could block the flow of ven with her martial skills, but that poison could be safely utilized from a distance when applied to projectiles fired from those small, arm-mounted bows.
Against Lurr or elfkind, the lycon would easily gain the advantage despite their inability to use magic.
Their apothecary skills surpassed that of the High Elves, and their craftsmanship surpassed that of her fellow Mountain Elves.
Lycon technology was beyond Thanysa’s comprehension.
At first, her infiltration party was outnumbered ten-to-one, but slowly that number decreased to five-to-one and then to only double.
Lurr were resilient and difficult to kill, so their numbers were not dropping fast.
The power balance shift came from the tunnel Byurk still struggled to keep open.
Lycon continued to pass through the tunnel from the surface.
The constant increase in numbers combined with the debilitating lycon poison pushed the Lurr back, and soon Thanysa saw a tall, pointed arch entryway to a grand hall.
From Zose’s explanation of the den’s layout, that hall was at the center of the caverns, and the chimera’s lair was on the other side.
However, the passageway across from her was missing.
A matching entryway was there, but a wall of black volcanic stone barely visible in the dark blocked the path.
A flash of firelight blew a small opening in the volcanic rock, and something crawled through.
Thanysa strained her eyes to peer through the dark to see who or what it was.
“Lady Ceil,” Benab called from behind her.
“A lycon is carrying Lady Ceil from the far passage!”
Many Lurr from the back line heard Benab’s call and turned towards the lone lycon.
Thanysa wanted to curse him for his lack of forethought or experience, but at the same time, she never would have noticed Ceil was there if he had not called.
“Push forward!
Form a wedge!
We must get through!” she called.
Lycon in the back line focused their fire on the Lurr blocking the entrance to the grand hall.
Thanysa kept point, brandishing curved stone blades to cut through the weakened Lurr.
The more Lurr that fell, the more that amassed at the entrance.
The numbers in the back thinned as many rushed for the lycon carrying Ceil, allowing Thanysa, Benab, and a few lycon to break through.
The lycon holding Ceil dropped her to the ground and stood before her against the Lurr.
Thanysa knew she would not reach them in time.
All at once the wall of volcanic stone burst outward to the sides, the debris splitting to avoid the lycon and Ceil.

Standing in the broken archway was Lord Ni’inca Ab’pul with one long, double-jointed arm grasping the top of the crumbling arch and the other hesitating to reach for Ceil or strike down the lycon crouching over her to protect her.
Dread filled Thanysa’s heart.
The subjugation party had failed.
They found Ceil, but only one lycon remained.
Justin and Zose were gone, possibly felled by the monster.
Ceil sat alone in her own personal, secluded balcony seat watching a play performed on a distant stage down below, a play in which she had little interest.
It was a time-worn piece about a band of heroes rescuing some captive empress from an ageless horror.
These stories were always tragedies, and so she knew how it would end.
Eydis had once invited her to one such performance shortly after Ceil first arrive at the Amelian palace, and in her youth she was enthralled by the masterful storytelling and extravagant acting.
The props and stage decorations were beautiful to behold, grandeur painstakingly crafted for a play performed before the Amelian royalty, minus the emperor who was elsewhere.
But at the end, Ceil’s heart was crushed watching the heroes ultimately fail.

She cried in Eydis’s arms that evening as Eydis apologized, not realizing at the time that Ceil felt captured and imprisoned in the palace, and that watching the rescue fail and the empress die in captivity would cause such emotional pain.
Once Ceil had calmed, Eydis promised to talk to her father, Emperor Yuro, and demand Ceil be released.
Of course, that too failed.
Unlike that play so long ago, the one she now watched was a farce, poorly scripted and without endearing actors.
The empress had no redeeming qualities that would make a spectator desire her rescue.
She was dull and pessimistic, a defeatist.
The empress was only being rescued because of her position and nothing else.
If Ceil had to pick, she preferred Dyson’s emotive storytelling by the campfire.
The way he played with the flames was mesmerizing and did not lack compared to any royal play.
Ceil’s heart sank in a painful ache remembering how Dyson died because of her, just like so many before him.
In the end, he was just another name to add to an impossibly long list that was growing ever longer.

She watched the stage with weary eyes as the chimera ignored the empress and charged the heroes with impossible speed unhindered by the numerous poisoned barbs and magic fired at him, killing many of them with a single swipe of his long arm.
They would meet the same tragic fate as those heroes from the time-worn stories.
She watched the chimera spring over the rescue party to the far entryway.
His thin but powerful, whip-like tail slapped the ground, raising a wall of stone in the passage that crushed two high elves and a few lycon between the stone.
Those remaining in the hall spread out and continued their attacks, trying in futile desperation to react to the chimera’s impossible speed.
Another wide swing of his arm cleaved three dispersed lycon in half.
Amid the destruction, Ceil felt hands on her arms, back, and legs.
She felt a new rope, less crude than the one with which she was formerly bound, wind around her.
Her hands gripped the railing of the balcony.
Something unexpected happened.
Four lycon had rappelled along the wall from the ceiling of the grand hall unknown to the master of the hall.
They readied to hoist the captive empress up and out to freedom.
For the first time in the unknown days since Ceil had been watching this play, she grew mildly attentive.
Unlike the past tragedies, they just might succeed so long as the chimera remained blinded by his slaughter.
As soon as the empress first rose into the air, the chimera noticed.
He had been monitoring her through the stone of the hall’s floor.
As he was about to attack, raucous cries bellowed from the main entrance to the hall.
Lycon swarmed into the hall, a hundred at least.
Intermixed were five or six Tolmyur soldiers, causing no shortage of confusion in Ceil’s mind.
She leaned toward the balcony railing as what she once thought was a dull and lifeless play became a bit more perplexing.
She expected the lycon allied with Tolmyur to fight those allied with Vallen, but they joined together to fight the chimera, spriggan beside human.
One lone Mountain Elf ran to the closed passage to reopen it, allowing more into the hall.
Ceil watched as she rose higher into the air, moving for the first time in days to lean into the taught rope to better view the assault as if she was leaning over the balcony railing.
Magic of fire and wind assaulted the chimera but grazed off without harm as if his leathery skin was like dragon scales.
Innumerable poisoned bolts pelted and penetrated the skin but were pushed out as fast as they entered.
Every sweep of the chimera’s tail sent out a flurry of stone spikes penetrating through multiple bodies in line.
Every swipe of his arms cleaved flesh and splattered remains against the walls.
When the chimera breathed a massive column of flame from his snaking throat, filling the floor of the hall in fire, Ceil sat back in her balcony chair.
The timeless horror could not be harmed.
He could not be killed.
When the chimera took but a moment to lunge to the ceiling to snag the rope and pull Ceil away, she once again stopped paying attention.

She felt the rush of the air as she swung and was placed gently atop the mantel of one of the large windows that once bore a powerful furnace’s flame at the back of the hall beside the corridor to the council room.
As she thought, there would be no victory here.
This would be a tragedy like all the others.
“You look bored.”
Ceil looked beside her to find a second seat in the formerly empty balcony.
Sammy sat there watching the play, but Ceil did not startle, nor did she think it odd Sammy was there.
Ceil felt dead, and so she did not question seeing someone she knew was dead.
“Don’t like the show?” Sammy smirked and leaned into the railing, resting her chin on her folded arms.
“It’s just getting good.”
Ceil did not answer.
Sammy was from another world, so perhaps such performances were new to her.
She did not know it would end in tragedy.
“My favorite part is about to start,” Sammy said, confusing Ceil.
There was no way Sammy had seen this play before.
Sammy peered over her shoulder at Ceil and nudged her chin down towards the stage.
Ceil begrudgingly sat up on the window’s mantel to watch the massacre.
Immediately she noticed Zose phase through the crumbling passageway that led to the chimera’s lair.
He reached his hand into the small opening in the volcanic stone and pulled Justin through.
Ceil thought she heard his voice when the lycon fled with her from the lair, but she was slouching in her seat at the time, not watching the stage.
She doubted her ears more than her reason, because she knew Justin could not have escaped Tolmyur’s armies in Revlan.
He was a human from another world known personally by the Tolmyur commander.
Justin had no feasible way to survive that battle, unless once Sammy died, he used his time magic to flee for his own life, leaving everyone else to die.
That very thought made Ceil’s arms tense with anger.
“He did not run away,” Sammy replied, knowing Ceil’s thoughts.
She watched Justin with an endearing smile.
“He’s not that kind of person.”
“What does it matter?
They are all going to die,” Ceil retorted, but Sammy smiled ever brighter.
“Maybe, from how things look.”
Sammy turned back to the stage to watch the performance, so Ceil’s gaze followed.
The lycon pouring in from the hall’s main entrance were mildly disoriented, but they replenished the lycons’ numbers at about the rate that the chimera felled them.
Throughout the massacre, Justin tried and tried again to approach the monster, but each time the chimera avoided him.
The chimera breathed fire or attacked with spikes of stone, but Justin’s impossible reflexes kept him safe.
The chimera never once tried to touch him, which Ceil felt odd.
Justin did not have the Aspect of Death about him, so what did the Chimera fear?
A dim flicker of hope lit in Ceil’s numbed heart, but she quickly extinguished it before it could grow and hurt her further.
Numbness prevented pain, and she was tired of hurting.
Sammy watched her with pity for a moment but then returned to watching Justin.
Noticing that the chimera actively avoided him, Justin changed tactics and weaved through the massacre for Ceil.
The chimera did not want to be frozen in time again.
Using that fear to his advantage, perhaps he was the only one who could safely reach Ceil.
If not, it should at least force the chimera to focus on him, both sparing the lycon and the few elves that remained from slaughter as well as giving him a chance to make use of his time magic.
If he could freeze the chimera in time long enough for Ceil to be extracted, they won.
But then what?
Once Justin reached the wall just below Ceil, he realized the futility of it all.
He could not kill the Chimera with his time magic.
The lycon could not kill the chimera even when frozen in time.
If he managed to freeze it in time, once that time ran out, the chimera would escape and continue pursuing Ceil to reclaim her.
No matter where Zose or the lycon took her, they could not escape.
“Ceil!” Justin called, but she neither answered nor moved from the mantel.
His shout only served to draw the chimera’s attention to him.
Red embers glowed in its maw.
Justin stood in the corner of the hall with nowhere to flee the flames.
Only now did he realize his foolishness.
In the center of the hall, he had room to utilize his time magic to maneuver and avoid the Chimera’s ranged attacks.
The chimera placed Ceil in the corner of the hall, hoping Justin would pursue her.
A cloud of mist formed before the glowing maw and conjured a powerful geyser that shot water deep down the chimera’s throat.
Water hit flame and erupted into steam out of the chimera’s mouth.
His throat swelled and ruptured from the inside.
“Have none of you fought a dragon before?” Byurk hollered.
If he was in the fight, it either meant that their exit was compromised or he felt it secure enough to join.
Justin hoped it was the latter.
The high-pressure steam twisted the chimera’s head and long neck away from Justin.
The chimera flailed for only a moment before the rupture healed and he returned to health once more.
As Justin thought, the chimera was unkillable.
Justin scrambled quickly to climb the aged stone of the wall to reach Ceil as the Chimera changed target to Byurk.
Stone rose below Justin’s feet and sprung him up to the mantel where he was just able to grab the edge.
Byurk sent him to Ceil, but this did not go unnoticed by the chimera.
Ni’inca Ab’pul could not touch Ceil or the time mage, but he did not have to.
His goal was to keep Ceil safe under his protection.
The time mage did not have the power to kill him, so should he eliminate all other opposition, he could keep him captive with her.
Killing him was preferable, only to remove a potential headache, but if not, the time mage could provide her both protection and care.
He would have no other option, just like Inym.
Ceil was in a cavity without an exit.
He only needed to wait for the moment the man climbed in to reach Ceil.
Ceil watched Justin hoist himself up with strenuous effort to rest his chest and arms on the mantel as if an actor from the stage below had climbed up to her balcony seat.
Sammy only watched Justin with endearment, but she did not speak, and Justin did not acknowledge her presence.
Of course he could not.
Ceil knew Sammy was dead.
Ceil stared in mild shock at Justin’s matured and urgent gaze.
Something was different about him, and Ceil knew that the loss of Sammy was the cause.
Justin acted as if he was lifting himself up to the mantel, but once he rested one knee on the stone and was about to stand, he said, “Run, quickly,” and twisted off the ledge.
Ceil lunged out of her seat to the railing of her balcony to see the long, swift tail of the chimera swinging towards the stone below.
The chimera tried to pull his tail back now that Justin fell into the location of impact, but the sudden motion made the end of the tail flick and impact Justin’s chest from the left.
There both Justin and the chimera froze with the tail’s tip as thick as Justin’s arm crushing into Justin’s ribs.
Ceil released her grip on the balcony railing, her hands trembling just above the cold stone.
Her eyes shot to Sammy beside her, but instead of the horror or dread she expected in Sammy’s eyes, she saw exasperation.
Sammy only shook her head.
Ceil did not know how time magic worked, but she could tell that once time resumed, Justin would die.
Ceil was no longer numb; she was confused.
Justin owed nothing to her.
If anything, he should loath her for leading Sammy to her death.
Why then did he risk death to create an opportunity for her to escape?
“Lady Ceil!” Thanysa called from below.
She shouted some instruction, but Ceil did not hear it.
Ceil staggered back away from the edge of the balcony.
She could no longer hear the shouts from the heroes on the stage or the desperate attacks that tried to fell the chimera in its time-frozen state.
The fear and pain she had suppressed with numbness returned with force, stronger than ever before.

Her mind recalled the face of every person who died because of her, starting with the nymph mother and child in the Gallanvale; the young elf girl passed off as her by the marshal; her maid and cousin, Vera; the butchered and lifeless elderly, women, and children inside Nalain; the three elves set erect impaled by spears as a message to her; the faces of everyone she met in Revlan; of Chloe, of Sammy, then Dyson, and now Justin.
Ceil stumbled back, but when she collapsed into her balcony seat, it was gone.
She fell into agony and darkness, spiraled into despair, and drowned in the murky depths of her heart.
She could not breathe, and all she felt was anguish.
There in the eternal darkness she found a form standing before her.
The putrid skeletal hand that often reached out from behind now extended towards her.
She saw the skeletal body rotting and draped in torn and spoilt fabric.
His skull was affixed into remorseful gloom, and his eyes were a void that devoured all light and life.
All that was death stood before her, and all that once was life now remained behind.
He reached, beckoning and offering relief with a silent stare.
Ceil extended to grasp the outstretched hand.
Warm arms of flesh reached from behind Ceil and embraced her.
“No!” cried Sammy’s voice.
“Do not give in!”
Ceil grasped Sammy’s hand for the warmth it provided in the painful dark and found herself spun around to put death at her back once more.
Sammy held her in her arms, cradling her with an arm about her back and another under her legs.
Ceil stared into Sammy’s crying visage.
“I cannot do this anymore,” she whimpered, fighting to hold back the tears her body screamed to shed.
“You do not have to do this alone,” Sammy replied.
“Anyone who tries to save me dies!”
“Then stop waiting for someone to save you.” Sammy smiled across her tear-stained cheeks.
“You are stronger than you know.”
“I cannot stop Tolmyur on my own.” Ceil turned her face away from Sammy in shame and saw again the skeletal form patiently awaiting her return.
She immediately buried her face back into Sammy’s shoulder.
“You don’t have to.
You never had to,” Sammy admonished with a loving gaze.
“But anyone who helps me dies!” Ceil screamed again.
“I cannot end this on my own, and I cannot involve anyone else.
What else am I to do?”
“Live,” Sammy replied.
“Show that you will not be defeated by this.
Prove to yourself and the world that no matter what happens, you can overcome it.”
“Even if more people die because of me?”
Sammy did not answer, but a thought crept into Ceil’s mind.
If she died, then for what reason did everyone sacrifice their lives?
The Tolmyur commander was right.
Her life bore the weight of every life lost for her name.
If she died, all those lives would die with her.
But then how could she bear such a weight?
How could she live with such pain?
“You can ask others for help,” Sammy replied.
“But who would share such a burden with me?” Ceil knew that no one cared for her because of her.
They only cared for her because the position she held, Empress of the Amelian Empire, or as a means to end the war.
They would not sympathize with her burden, because such was expected of all who ruled.
They would work beside her as she was slowly crushed under the weight.
Only a single name came to Ceil’s mind, but she shook it away, denying it even if it were her last hope.
“Remember when I told you how Justin and I met?” Sammy asked, knowing the hope Ceil tried to deny.
“He can help you, too.”
“Justin is dead,” Ceil asserted.
Sammy shook her head.
“If he is to help you, first you need to help him.” Tears fell anew down Sammy’s face, and her face contorted in anguish.
“Please, save him.
Don’t let Justin die!”
Ceil recalled Sammy’s final request during the assault on Revlan.
“If something happens to me, take care of Justin...”
Ceil’s eyes opened.
The arms across her back and supporting her legs were not Sammy’s but Thanysa’s.
Thanysa’s leather armor was blackened, brittle, and decaying from where she held Ceil.
Ceil struggled to loosen herself from Thanysa’s grasp and fell to the hard stone.
Thanysa barely had the strength to carry her.
Ceil quickly looked around and saw she was still in the grand hall near the exit leading to where her chamber resided.
At the end of the hall, lycon swarmed the time-frozen chimera.
Thanysa grasped futilely at Ceil as Ceil ran for the group, Thanysa’s blackened fingers unable to hold her back.
“Let me through,” Ceil ordered.
The lycon who tried to hold Ceil back found her touch painful.
Those who grabbed her reeled as their fur blackened, and soon they all made way.
“Ceil, stop,” Thanysa called, trying to warn her that touching the chimera was dangerous.
Eight lycon stood frozen where their blows made contact.
Ceil ignored Thanysa’s warning, not caring for the reason.
Ni’inca Ab’pul could not be killed by anyone but her.
She latched onto the chimera’s hind leg, and her time froze.
Chapter 17
“Finding Support”
Zose walked through Sen’uon in the brisk morning.
The sun just rose enough above the surrounding peaks to shower dim light to the streets through the ever-overcast sky.
The city looked nothing like his memory.
The Lurr who once lived peaceful lives in the many ruins were replaced by lycon, and more lycon arrived by the day.
The lycon purged the city at the cost of many of their own while Lord Ni’inca Ab’pul was occupied.
None were spared, not even Jeddin, because the lycon did not know who were Lurr and who were not.
They did not revel in their spoils of war, and many were still on edge, because the lord of the land was not dead, just frozen in time for numerous days with no sign of waking.
Every lycon was ready to fight or evacuate in haste should he awaken, and the women and children had yet to be brought to the city.
They did not own the land--not yet, but many were hopeful.
The bane of the lycon had been pacified through one human’s sacrifice.
Zose passed a gathering of lycon distributing provisions that had been secured from the Lurr.
There was plenty within the city to sustain the current numbers for quite a while longer, but soon they would eventually need to hunt again.
Many of the lycon had hoped to use the Lurr for provisions, but Chloe forbade them.
She was wroth that they would attack the city, not knowing of the many generations of ire between the two races.
After a massive display of Chloe’s power, the lycon agreed to show proper respect for the dead civilians and burn them upon pyres like their own fallen.
Chloe spent every following day in a depressed stupor.
She alone remained among her companions, because no one knew what would become of Justin or Ceil.
Tae weaved between the lycon and approached.
“Zose, Kiri wishes to speak with you.”
Zose nodded and followed Tae to one of the largest and most intact ruins of the city.
There the Vallen party had moved camp after the battle.
Kiri sat atop stuffed furs with Byurk, Thanysa, Basara, and Inym around a sunken fire pit.
Thanysa’s hands and arms remained blackened, but thanks to Tyree’s treatment, the blight no longer spread.
However, her limbs and grip remained weak, and she could no longer grasp a sword.
Zose watched as she struggled to lift a bowl of wine to her lips.
“Sit,” Kiri said, offering the cushion across the pit from her.
Zose sat down.
Given the lack of change in Ceil and the chimera over the past days, he felt he knew the topic of this meeting.
“I will not return to Ib’nua,” he said before Kiri could speak.
“Your commission was to take Ceil to the Afarit, and that commission is now void,” Kiri replied, proving Zose’s assumption correct.
“I made the contract to Ceil with payment up front, so only Ceil can terminate it,” Zose refuted.
“I am Ceil’s only remaining family, and as her guardian, I too can terminate the contract in the event that the maker of the contract is incapacitated,” Kiri replied.
“So, she wasn’t lying,” Zose sighed under his breath.
Ceil was Vallen royalty.
Kiri nodded to Inym who sat to Zose’s left.
Without standing, Inym shifted on her knees next to Zose, presented him a coin purse, and loosed the ties.
Glimmering gems filled the purse almost to bursting.
Inym then pulled the ties, sat the purse before him, bowed, and returned to her seat without a word.
Her countenance fell guilty.
“This is payment for your contract termination as well as for a new contract to take Inym with you back to Ib’nua,” Kiri explained.
Zose looked to Basara for an explanation.
She never spoke up, so clearly she was in agreement with Kiri.
She was never mentioned in the contract, so Zose knew she would remain here.

“I will accept payment for termination of the contract, but it is my right to choose my contracts, and I cannot accept the terms of the new one.” Zose claimed a single gem from the purse and then returned it to Inym.
Inym held the purse close with quivering hands, and her guilt grew stronger.
“Zose, please,” Basara pleaded.
“What about you?”
“Return to our daughters.”
“My task does not involve Ceil but Jethro.
So long as Ceil remains here, Jethro will inevitably come.
Byurk and I must persuade him to end this war.”
Zose already knew Basara’s plans, but her stating it again in front of everyone made her words bear even greater weight than when they talked in private.
He had already told her he would not leave, and she was hoping that discussing openly might change his mind.
He loved that tenacious part of her, but for once he could not agree.
She might get mad, and he had always been careful to avoid angering her, but he could endure her ire.
He knew she loved him too much to remain angry at him for long.
He knew that she secretly desired his company, especially when confronting Jethro, not for his protection which she would never need but for the emotional support his presence would provide.
At the same time, she feared for his life, and no one could predict what Jethro would do with Ceil before him.
“I--” Zose began.
Hastened steps entered the room.
“The chimera is moving,” Benab called, winded from his flight.
“Go,” Kiri ordered.
Basara, Zose, and Thanysa followed Benab outside.
The lycon were in a frenzy, many gathering weapons in preparation for another offense against the waking lord of the land.
The bravest of them ran with Zose to the canyon and through the caverns to the grand hall.
The air of the cave was disorienting, but with sight grounding him, he recovered quickly after entering the ruins.
The lycon on the other hand remained unsteady on their feet for a time after entering the grand hall.
Lycon surrounded the back of the hall.
The chimera still appeared frozen at a distance, but as Zose neared, he noticed the nearly imperceptible motions.
“Remove Tyree from the hall,” Zose ordered, noticing her leaning against the side wall.
She was stationed here in the event that either Ceil or Justin recovered and needed treatment.
Should Ni’inca Ab’pul recover, they could not risk losing her.
Her magic was their lifeline.
Zose watched as the chimera’s body lowered ever so slowly, but at the same time, he also saw Ceil grip tighter around the leg.
If Ceil also moved, then the chimera was not beating Justin’s time magic.
Justin’s time magic was weakening.
Zose looked up at where the tail pinned Justin against the wall.
It too was moving, crushing deeper into Justin’s chest.
He ran and dove into the wall, his head quickly appearing just beside Justin.
“Someone grab the tail and pull it away.
It will crush him.
Quickly!”
A dozen lycon built up speed and ran up the wall.
When level with the tail, they jumped out, grabbing the tail as they passed.
Each lycon that touched it appeared to freeze, but not entirely.
They moved slowly outward, pulling the tail with them.
Zose expel himself from the stone sideways away from the direction the tail crushed into Justin.
Zose too slowed nearly to a stop as he pulled Justin with him.
Everyone watched as the near-imperceptible movement became more and more noticeable.
At the same time, they saw the leg of the chimera Ceil grasped rot from her touch at similar pace.
The chimera crouched, and the moment he lunged in slow motion to distance himself from Justin, the force of his lunge shattered his rotten leg, sending him tumbling into the crowd.
The lycon pulled his tail away from Justin, and Zose fell with Justin to the ground.
All at once, time resumed its normal pace for those who were once frozen.
The lycon scrambled to distance themselves from the chimera and readied for battle, but the chimera did not rise.
The rot affecting his leg spread as his body melted.
Ceil looked over at Ni’inca Ab’pul and met his eyes.
Whereas before her eyes were dead, now they held purpose and a deep anger.
Ni’inca Ab’pul’s neck extended.
He saw Zose calling Tyree over to Justin.
His eyes then found Basara, one he knew was powerful among those in the wilderlands.
“Protect her,” he pleaded to Basara.
“Do not let Ceil die or all is lost.”
The rot spread, melting the Lord of Sen’uon, Whinhlem’s primal Lurr, into putrid slop.
Ceil was wrapped in thick fabric and rushed from the hall outside before she could ascertain Justin’s condition.
Benab carried her through the city into a large structure.
Kiri met her at the entrance and followed with Tae to a room with a pool where she could wash herself of the viscous rot of the melted chimera.
Only once she was sat down and left in the care of Tae who quickly stripped her did she realize that the rot faintly stung her skin.
Where Tae touched it, Tae’s skin peeled and flaked into the water.
“Stop,” Ceil ordered, pushing Tae’s hands away.
“I will clean myself.” Ceil recalled the many plants that had blackened and grew brittle at her touch.
She did not want the same to happen to Tae.
“Ceil!” Lemi appeared from the entry, but Kiri stopped her before she could approach.
“Do not draw close yet.
Not until she bathes,” Kiri ordered.
Lemi immediately noticed Tae’s hands and helped her heal them.
Once Sammy finished washing, Tae approached first and grasped Ceil’s hands.
They were cautious of her, and Ceil did not understand why.
“She is safe to touch,” Tae announced.
Lemi immediately ran for Ceil and embraced her, hugging her tight.
Ceil recalled the memories of her imprisonment and realized that Lemi had been there taking care of her for a time.
“Thank you,” Ceil said, pulling Lemi’s head closer with her hand on Lemi’s mossy hair now barren of flowers.
Tae brought Ceil warm clothing, and together with Lemi, helped Ceil dress.
“Come,” Kiri ordered.
She led Ceil to a larger room with a fire pit adorned simply with numerous cushions and stuffed furs.
Thanysa was there with Basara and another emaciated troll Ceil recognized as her second caretaker.
Ceil immediately noticed Thanysa’s blackened arms and made the connection with Tae’s former words and why Benab wrapped her in thick fabric.
For a time after Ceil had met the darkness face to face, its deathly power attacked anyone who touched her.
Kiri sat Ceil at the head and then sat beside her in the second position.
Thanysa then bowed with Inym quickly following.
“I ask that you remain calm and do not speak,” Kiri said.
Ceil wondered what ill news Kiri would tell, but then saw Byurk enter the room across the fire pit from her.
Ceil’s blood immediately boiled.
Her anger was soon replaced with dread.
She recalled the scene of a human soldier fighting beside Benab.
A Tolmyur commander would never side with the fairies, especially the one tasked with their genocide, so Ceil knew immediately what had happened.
She knew why Justin was alive and cursed herself for not realizing it.
Justin was not there to save her.
Her delusions of Sammy were a false hope she created out of desperation.

After the death of Sammy and Chloe, after Ceil fled the battle, Revlan must have struck a deal with Tolmyur to retrieve her and present her in exchange for their survival, no doubt out of necessity after many more lives were lost in battle.
Dharin never would have given such an order, so he surely had died in the early stages of the final battle, leaving those who remained to choose preservation.
Ceil wanted to shout out in anger and frustration, but somehow she felt calm, almost relieved.
This was the proper way of things.
She would now pay for all the lives lost for her name.
She lifted her head and smiled a weary smile to the enemy commander.
“Welcome, Commander Byurk of the Tolmyur Kingdom,” Ceil said in proper manner, ready for the deal to be completed and for her to be handed over to the enemy.
“If only things were as you assume,” Byurk said as he took his place across from Ceil, knowing well what Ceil thought given the situation.
“I am not here to claim you but help you.”
Ceil’s smile faded, and her lips parted lightly in confusion.
Was this all still a delusion of her mind?
Byurk bowed his face to the floor in submission, stunning Ceil further.
“I give no excuse for my role in the fall of Vallen, but know that I am now a traitor to Tolmyur and am on your side until the day I must pay for my sins against your people.”
“General Byurk is our prisoner, and in exchange for a stay of his punishment, he is aiding us in your protection and ending this war,” Kiri explained.
“Then Revlan…” Ceil began, hoping against hope that Byurk was a prisoner of war captured after defeating the armies of Tolmyur.
“Fallen,” Kiri replied.
“After purging Revlan, he led a party into the wilderlands.
Chloe bested him, and Basara took him prisoner and convinced him to aid us.”
“I see…” Ceil said, but then she realized what Kiri said.
“Chloe is alive?
“Benab should be bringing her news of your recovery,” Thanysa explained.
“I trust she will be here before long.”
Relief welled in Ceil’s chest, and after growing accustomed to so much darkness, it was almost too painful to bear.
Another thought immediately entered her mind, the other survivor of Revlan.
“What of Justin?”
Basara shook her head.
“Ni’inca Ab’pul’s tail crushed completely through Justin’s right lung.
Shards of bone tore through the other.
Tyree was slow reaching him in the chaos after his time magic ended.
She is treating him, but she does not expect he will survive.”
Ceil’s painful relief over Chloe immediately vanished back into the comfortable darkness.
She felt tears well in her eyes, but she gripped her fists tight and held them back.
Sammy was not even there for Ceil to apologize.
At least now Sammy and Justin could be together in death.
Kiri began explaining what had happened from the time they fled Revlan.
During the long tale, Chloe appeared with Benab and nearly tackled Ceil to the ground in her heavy embrace, sobbing uncontrollably.

She remained attached to Ceil as the story continued and Ceil learned of the worst possible revelation told them by the sprites, that Jethro was also vital for surviving the approaching calamity and should not be killed.
Ceil waited anxiously for three days to hear news of Justin’s death or recovery.
On the fourth day, Lemi visited with a radiant smile and announced that Justin would recover.
His right lung could not be saved, and several of his ribs could not be healed and had to be removed, but his life was no longer in danger.
Ceil did not breathe a sigh of relief nor did she share in Lemi’s excitement.
She hung her head, part of her hoping that he could have been reunited with Sammy.
“What’s wrong,” Lemi asked, sitting on a cushion covered in soft underbelly fur beside Ceil.
She crossed her legs, leaned down, and looked up into Ceil’s eyes.
“It is nothing,” Ceil lied.
“Is he awake?”
“No,” Lemi said.
She reached her arm over and pulled Ceil close so they could rest against each other.
“Tyree couldn’t give a time, and she did not want to force him to wake.
Zose said he will wait until Justin wakes before taking you to the Afarit, that way you can talk to him.
Both he and Kiri do not think it’s safe for him to travel.”
“I see…” Whatever calamity that is supposed to happen involved Justin, and if the road to the Afarit was dangerous, Justin should remain behind.
Surely the lycon would look after him until she returns bearing whatever good or ill news from speaking to Bydrofe.
After coming so far, Ceil wondered if there was a reason to continue on and speak to Bydrofe.
With both Basara and Byurk present, and under the protection of the lycon, they could remain here in Sen’uon until Jethro arrived.
According to Basara and Byurk, Jethro would never harm a lycon.
“I must speak with Zose,” Ceil said, rising to her feet.
Her legs were weak after sitting for most that day and the three previous.
She had to know why neither Zose nor Basara had considered this option.
Ceil found them downstairs around the fire pit.
Chloe was there with Benab eating dinner.
The day had grown late without Ceil realizing.
“Want some?” Chloe asked, holding out her earthenware plate of dried meat.
Ceil grabbed a single strip and sat down.
Chloe then returned to talking with Benab.
Her Elven had improved tremendously, although her understanding of the grammar was still that of a very young child.
“Zose, Basara, I have something to ask,” Ceil said after sitting beside Chloe.
Lemi then sat on the other side of Ceil.
“Ask away,” Zose said with a smirk.
“Can we not remain here in Sen’uon and wait for Jethro?”
“No,” Zose replied immediately.
“Or, I should be more specific.
You cannot remain here.”
“What do you mean?”
“Not all the lycon are of the same opinion of you,” Basara explained.
“While many view you as a hero, others are wary.
What you did to Ni’inca Ab’pul frightened many, and those who tried to prevent you from initially touching him have already died.”
Ceil’s heart sank.
She had directly killed those who tried to rescue her.
No, not rescue; they were there to kill the chimera, not save her.
While she was the reason for the mission undertaken by Byurk and Thanysa, for the lycon she was only collateral.
But why was Thanysa spared if her touch killed the lycon?
Thinking it over, she held no ill feelings towards Thanysa, but she did towards the lycon due to the one who abducted and injured her in the burster.
“Do not misunderstand,” Zose said.
“They are grateful for what you did, extremely grateful, but with their women and children arriving every day to settle Sen’uon, they fear what harm you may cause them.
They requested that I continue with you north where you will be better protected by the Afarit’s numbers and terrain but have allowed us to wait until Justin recovers.”
“Until Justin recovers, then?”
“Until Justin recovers,” Zose repeated back.
Justin slept for eight more days.

Chloe arrived this time with Benab to retrieve Ceil, and together they walked to a building across the wide road where Tyree had set up a hospital for all the injured from the battle and the lycon who arrived in Sen’uon.
The entryway by the roadside was crowded with lycon, but they quickly parted as Ceil approached, many fearing to draw too close.
Lemi stood with Coby inside to prevent any lycon without business from entering.
“He’s in the single room upstairs,” Chloe said.
“You are not coming?” Ceil asked.
“Lemi and I have already spoken with him, and I think you might have a few things you want to talk about with him in private.”
Sammy, Ceil realized.
She hugged Chloe and scratched at the feathers on the side of Coby’s head as she passed.
Six braziers sat elevated in the spacious main floor that may have been a large tavern or similar originally.
Ceil kept to the wall and away from the many lycon sitting and laying on blankets.
The lycon did not appear to have battle wounds.
Most were sick or frostbitten from their travels.
Those injured from the chimera subjugation and purging of the city were long finished with their treatment.
A single slanted stairway in the back led to the second floor.
There Tyree welcomed her and excused herself back down to the first floor using Tae as a crutch.
Justin’s room was not much smaller than Ceil’s but far more furnished.

The furs and blankets that lined the floors and walls to give the cold stone some warmth were not the same craft as those Ceil recalled from her imprisonment or found in the structure where the Vallen party resided.
They were all clearly of lycon make, gifts for Justin.
Ceil had struck the finishing blow on the chimera, and yet the Lycon seemed to view Justin as the hero, but she could not complain.
Justin noticed Ceil enter and moved two cushions behind his back so he could sit up.
“How are you feeling,” he asked with a tired but genuine smile.
“I should ask you the same,” Ceil responded coolly as she took a seat on a coarse fur beside his bed.
Justin pulled back his blanket revealing a hardened leather breastplate that covered most his left breast and wrapped around on the right side to his back.
It was strapped to him at the shoulder and around the chest.
The leather was black and had a great shine.
The quality was exquisite and matched the shape of Justin’s chest as if no damage had been done.
It was not unlike lycon armor, and no doubt they crafted it for him.
Ceil hesitated to ask what the damage looked like underneath, so Justin worked to loosen the straps before she could.
When he peeled off the leather, a cavity remained where his right breast once had been.
He had no ribs or muscle from his sternum until near his back, aside from the topmost two ribs.
Freshly pink and scarless skin covered what little flesh remained inside.
It pulsed lightly with his heartbeat and swelled a little with each breath that pulled air into his remaining lung.
“Looks worse than it is,” Justin admitted with a smile.
“The cavity should fill with fluid in time.
I feel a little lopsided and can’t lift my right arm yet.
Breathing is hard, but otherwise, Tyree did a good job patching me back together.

I want to say that medical technology on Earth is better because I’m sure they could have created prosthetic ribs or something so that I still look like a normal person, but then again doctors on Earth could never have saved me in the first place.
Life magic is amazing.
Were you hurt at all in the battle?”
“No…” Ceil said, now finding speech difficult after seeing the extent of the injury Justin took for her sake.
She shook her head slowly, now starting to understand what Sammy saw in this self-sacrificing fool, but his kindness irritated her.
“You never should have been injured.
You should have let me be.

I have never once shown you kindness, so you had no right to sacrifice yourself for my sake.” If Justin saw her as some empress of a fallen empire like everyone else, she could justify his sacrifice, but she knew he did not view her in that manner.
He saw her as a person, and that made his injury all the more difficult for her to bear.
Justin chuckled.
“You sound just like Sammy.”
“Never compare me to Sammy!” Ceil shouted, Justin’s words tipping her irritation over its fragile edge.
“I’m nothing like her!
I could never amount to the person she was.” Ceil gripped her sleeves with white knuckles, fighting to hold back her emotions.
“Sorry,” Justin apologized quickly.
“I did not mean it that way.
She was amazing, wasn’t she?
You could never find a better person if you tried.
At least, I wouldn’t think so.”
Ceil’s grip relaxed, and she stared blankly at the cushions on the other side of Justin’s bed, deep within her memories of Sammy.
The time she knew her was so short, but Sammy had made such a strong impression on her, just as powerful as Eydis, and she loved her just as much.
The corners of Ceil’s eyes began to sting, so she quickly closed them and fought back her tears with a pained expression.
“You know, we have a lot of beliefs and superstitions on Earth.
One of them is that those we lose are not really gone but watch over us.
Sammy was there during your rescue.”
Ceil’s eyes shot open, and she stared at Justin in disbelief.
Had he seen her there too?
Were her visions not just delusions?
“You noticed as well,” Justin said with a smile.
“I’m not the superstitious sort, so I try to find reasons for everything that doesn’t make sense, but, I don’t know how else to explain it other than saying she was there.
Wherever she is now, she’s watching over us.”
“She would not be with me,” Ceil retorted, rejecting what she saw in her darkest moments.
“She loved you more than anything.
If she could return, she would be with you.”
“You know Sammy better than that,” Justin chuckled, but it was a weak chuckle like three short breaths.
“You were the one who needed her most back then.”
Ceil could not deny it.
Had Sammy the opportunity, she most definitely would have been by her side, not fighting beside Justin.
“I saw her,” Ceil admitted in a faint whisper.
“I almost fell.
I almost lost myself, but she held onto me and kept me from giving up.
But then she left.
Once you were hurt, she left.”
“Once you were safe,” Justin corrected.
“I saw her too.
I tried to hold the chimera back as long as I could.
When time froze, the pain of the chimera’s tail crushing into me was constant.
I endured it as long as I could so that they could escape with you as far away as possible.
I almost lost focus immediately, but then Sammy held me through the pain until I couldn’t bear it anymore.
Turns out the one who killed the chimera was you.
I never saw that coming.”
“Sammy begged me to save you,” Ceil said, wiping a tear before it could fall.
She fought even harder to hold back her tears, her frustration at her emotions showing on her face.
“She said you could help me, like you helped her….
I am tired.
I feel like I cannot go on,” Ceil admitted.
She was angry at herself both for her weakness and because Justin was the first person she let hear that weakness.
“I cannot do this anymore!
Why did such a fate fall to me?
Why am I forced to carry a burden heavier than I could ever bear?
Am I supposed to live in pain and suffering all my life?”
“Things will get better,” Justin said with a weak but reassuring smile.
“How?!
When?!”
Ceil looked Justin in the eyes not caring to hide the anguish on her face.
She could not see any happiness in her future.
She could not see an end to her suffering.
Even if the discussion between Jethro, Basara, and Byurk ended the war, the guilt of all the destruction caused by her own existence would bear down on her forever.
She would never be free, and she could not see any way to break those chains herself.
Ceil’s thoughts dwelt on Sammy’s final request, on every story Sammy told about Justin.
She was desperate, and Sammy revealed the only thread of hope she thought she could grasp.
“You say the future will be better.” Ceil’s lips quivered, and she struggle to speak her next words.
“Can you create such a future for me?
Can you promise to bring me happiness?”
“No,” Justin replied immediately.
Ceil’s anguished face froze.
Her hands did not rise to wipe the tears that drew lines down the sides of her nose.
She had gathered every grain of courage she had left to speak those words, but by a single word from Justin, her last thread of hope snapped.
“I cannot be that for you.
I will only hurt you.
Everyone I have ever cared about, every girl I have ever loved, has either been hurt or has died because of me.
I do not want that to happen to you.”
Ceil looked up from the bed into Justin’s caring but remorseful eyes.
For the first time she realized that perhaps Justin bore a similar pain.
Ceil had suffered from all the lives lost because of her, but she had never lost a lover.
Sammy was not the first he lost.
There were others, and he blamed himself for each one.
He had lived with all this pain and regret, and yet he remained optimistic for the future of others.
Ceil gritted her teeth.
She felt even worse now that she spilled the hidden pains of her heart upon him as if what he suffered did not matter.
She hated herself for asking him to provide her a bright future when he had still not found his own.
“I am sorry that I bothered you.” Ceil shifted her legs to the side to stand, but Justin grasped her hand.
“I cannot be that for you, and I cannot promise to give you happiness.
What I can promise is that I will do everything in my power to help you through this, so you can find your own happiness.”
“Stop waiting for someone to save you.”
Ceil’s hand fell slack, and she slumped back down on her fur.
She had waited and waited, but she was waiting for the wrong salvation, and so she never found it.
She did not need a hero to save her.
She did not need a lover to provide happiness for her.

It was clear to her now that what she needed most was a friend willing to share in her burden to make it lighter to bear, but she never let anyone in close enough to share in that burden even if they were more than willing.
That was what Sammy meant.
Sammy had tried again and again to be Ceil’s support, but Ceil never peeled away the armor she had built around herself and let in Sammy’s warmth.
Now, more than ever, she missed Sammy.
She missed Eydis.
She missed her childhood friend, Linoa.
She missed her mother, Arlen.
Every shoulder she had ever cried on was gone.
“I don’t know what you have been told or what you have convinced yourself to believe, but it’s okay to cry,” Justin said.
Ceil did not know what manner of face she made that would cause such a flow of tears from Justin’s eyes.
His arm was extended, welcoming her.
Ceil curled her arms to her chest and slowly leaned into Justin.
He wrapped his arm around her and let her release all the pain she had suppressed in the dark recesses of her broken heart.
All the while Justin spoke nothing, only shedding tears with her.
Chloe held Lemi back at the stairs.

The girl wanted to join Ceil and Justin, especially after she heard the silent and strained cries of one who had been long afraid to let her emotions show no matter how deep the pain, but Chloe could not let her.
She held Lemi in a light embrace as tears slowly fell from her own eyes.
Both Ceil and Justin needed this moment, a mutual understanding between two friends who had lost everyone they had ever loved.
The next day.
Thanks to Tyree’s treatment, Justin had little issue walking and could manage his daily needs on his own.
He had always grown tired rather quickly, but missing a lung, he also became winded after only a little exertion.

Tyree promised that with enough training, he should find little difference between having one lung or two, but he would have to work diligently, considering Justin was never all that fit to begin with.
With this knowledge, Justin demanded that he join Ceil’s party heading north.
Kiri agreed only if Justin could receive Thanysa’s approval.
Ceil and Chloe watched Justin drill endurance exercises under Thanysa’s instruction.
Lemi was there as well, but she was preoccupied playing with Coby.
Chloe could only smile at Justin’s pathetic state, but Ceil was determined to bring Justin along.
“Get up,” Ceil ordered when Justin collapsed to his knees, too winded to stand.
“It is time for you to stop relying on your time magic to get you through every hardship.” This new hurdle was one Justin’s time magic would not surmount.
After Justin collapsed again, Thanysa called for a break.
Ceil ran over to Justin who lay flat on his back.
“Do not lie down.
Stand and breathe,” Ceil advised, reaching a hand to Justin to pull him to his feet.
“Kiri gave you two days.
You need to do much better than what you are showing now.”
“I am not… going to…” Justin turned his head aside and hacked out mucus from his throat, “…recover… that fast.”
“Thanysa is not looking for you to be back to normal in two days.
That would be impossible.
She is measuring your limits and deciding if you will become a liability.
Eydis trained you, right?
Did she ever mention motion control?”
“Remove unnecessary movements,” Justin realized.
“Pace yourself,” Ceil added.
“You become a liability if you collapse.
Do that too much, and Thanysa will never give you permission.
If you feel yourself struggling for breath, slow down.
You do not need to keep pace with Thanysa.
That is not what she wants.”
Justin looked into Ceil’s stern gaze and saw a bit of Eydis within her deep blue eyes, but he would never admit it for fear of Ceil yelling at him again.
At least there was life in Ceil’s eyes again, though dim.
For the rest of the session and the next day, Justin took Ceil’s advice to heart but still struggled more than he felt Thanysa would forgive.
Ceil continued giving him pointers she felt would help and eventually joined him in the exercises to demonstrate what she meant.
On the final day, both Justin and Ceil feared that he would not receive permission.
Thanysa’s final endurance test was the worst of them all, and Justin knew he would not last even following all of Ceil’s advice.
The moment Justin was about to collapse, he called for Ceil.
She rushed in and caught his arm over her shoulder.
Together they finished the remainder of the test.
Ceil let Justin sit to rest instead of stand as she had ordered every break previously.
Her expression showed defeat, that she knew Justin had failed the moment he gave in and requested her help.
Chloe sat on the other side of Justin and rubbed his back while Lemi worked to ease his muscle fatigue now that the final session was over.
Thanysa walked over and stood before them.
She folded her blackened arms, a sign of her own struggle overcoming injury.
Justin feared what the final assessment would be.
“You can join us,” Thanysa finally said.
Both Justin and Ceil stared at Thanysa in shock while Lemi excitedly wrapped her arms around them both and Chloe patted Justin on the shoulder.
“Ceil was perceptive in what I was looking for in your training, but there was something you both missed.
I had full intent on failing you.
Justin,” Thanysa continued, glaring down at him, “ever since we entered the wilderlands, you have secluded yourself.
You never accepted anyone’s company.
You never asked for help when you needed it.
Had that mindset continued, we could not risk bringing you through far more hostile lands to the Afarit in your present state.
Your old self would have collapsed and forced us to bear your entire burden or split our party as some take you back to Sen’uon.
After seeing you employ Ceil’s guidance yesterday, I had to push you to your breaking point today to see if you would ask for help.
With Ceil’s aid, you finished the test, and that was the test.
Had you not called out to one of your companions and had they not helped you, you would have failed.”
“You were testing us all,” Ceil realized.
“That is why you made us watch,” Chloe added, just as surprised.
“Get your affairs in order.
We leave in two days.”
Chapter 18
“Heroes of the Lycon”
On the eve before departure, the lycon held a grand feast in the largest square of Sen’uon.

The elderly speaker for the lycon who had worked with Zose, Basara, and Byurk to plan the rescue and hunt now became the speaker for the heads of the seventeen lycon tribes who had migrated to Sen’uon.
He spoke to the feast gathering in Elven first and then repeated in the lycon tongue.
In his opening address to the Vallen party who sat in the center around the largest of many glowing coal fires, he renamed the city Guthrelnin, meaning “long-desired home” in their tongue.
The lycon were not nomadic by choice.
Any attempt to settle permanently in the wilderlands was disrupted and destroyed by the Lurr.
A representative from each tribe stepped forward, each a maiden of their respective tribes.

They circled the Vallen party and then each knelt before a member who was present during the hunt: Byurk and three of his men who survived the combat at the cave entrance, the last remaining High Elf of those who joined from Revlan, Hethyro, Benab, Tae, Thanysa, Chloe, and Basara.
Two knelt before Zose, and the remaining four knelt together before Chloe and Justin.

Each person who had one maiden before them was presented a whistle and clean rag with a promise of protection through the wilderlands or aid in repayment should they request it at the cost of their whistle.
Each recipient rubbed the rag on the nape of their necks before returning it to the maidens.
Zose was presented a knife and white cloth.
He cut light across the top of his forearm and wiped the rag along the shallow wound.
One of the maidens then retrieved the knife while the other held the cloth to her chest like a treasured object.
“Zose, for your past service to the lycon and wisdom in bringing the tribes together united against our common enemy, your call shall never expire.
If you are ever in need, the lycon will heed your call until the end of your days.
Only three in our history have received such honors.
You are the fourth.”
After the announcement, the bloodied cloth was passed first between the heads of each tribe and then to all who were present at the feast.
The rags of the other whistle-bearers then followed.
No gifts were given to Justin or Ceil, but the four lycon remained bowed before them throughout the Exchange of the Cloth.
After the Exchange of the Cloth, the feast grew silent.
The four maidens who knelt before Justin and Ceil each took one hand in both of theirs and prompted them to stand.
Justin and Ceil were led before the tribe leaders and before all those present at the feast.
The maidens then knelt beside Justin and Ceil, pressing the back of their hands to their snouts.
The touch was soft and smooth with a hint of warmth, more like the nose of a human than that of a canine.
The first leader approached Justin, lifted his right hand, and revealed what looked like a piece of dried meat.
The leader then raised the meat to his mouth and swallowed it.
Next, he moved to Ceil, raised his left hand to reveal a short lock of hair the same color as Ceil’s, and similarly swallowed it.
It was then that Justin noticed Ceil’s hair was shorter by about two or three inches.
If the hair was Ceil’s then what was the meat?
Justin realized all too quickly that it must have come from him, from what was removed during his treatment after the battle.
Each lycon tribe leader in turn repeated the same ceremony, eating Justin’s flesh and Ceil’s hair.
When finished, the leaders lined up in front of them and bowed.
All the lycon at the feast bowed with them except the speaker who stood behind.
“Master Ceil.
Master Justin.
Your flesh to our flesh.
Where once you were elfkind and human, you are now lycon, our kin and our family.
Only one other in our history has blessed our people as you have: Bydrofe , Titan of the North, Guardian of Whinhlem.
In our darkest moment, Bydrofe saved us from extinction by creating a bridge across the frozen waters for us to live here on his lands.
Like Bydrofe, you have saved our people from extinction at the hands of Ni’inca Ab’pul and the Lurr of the wilderlands.
Just as the tale of Bydrofe has been told among our people for over two millennia and will continue to be told until the end of time, so too shall your story be told among our people, your people.”
Instead of giving Ceil and Justin a cloth for their scent, each tribe leader approached.
The maidens who knelt at Ceil and Justin’s side lifted Ceil and Justin’s hands.
Each leader touched their snout to the back of their hands and breathed deep.
Once finished, every lycon family in turn approached, bowed, and then repeated the same.

Ceil did not seem bothered by such ceremony, but Justin noticed that many lycon were hesitant to approach her, and while they touched their noses to the back of Justin’s hand as they drew in his scent, only a few dared to touch Ceil’s hand.
The speaker stood again once the procession finished.
At last, two whistles were presented on incredibly soft cloth the color of lycon fur.
“Master Ceil.
Master Justin.
We present you with every gift provided to the whistle-bearers this night, but we know such a debt will never balance.
You may dine with us.
You may travel with us.
You may live with us.
You may find a mate among us.
We will live for you.
We will die for you.”
For the first time Justin noticed Ceil’s expression darken.
Too many had died for her already, and though they stated that she may live among them, Justin was told the truth, that she was leaving Sen’uon because the lycon feared her.
The maidens led Ceil and Justin back to their seats, and after a howling cheer from all present, the feast began anew, now with as much strong wine as could be gathered from the spoils of Sen’uon.
Ceil held her bowl of wine but did not drink.
Her eyes gazed past it into some memory or thought.
Justin clasped his hand on her shoulder and rubbed it lightly.
“I am fine,” Ceil said a length before taking a light sip of her wine.
“I will not lie and say I am not bothered, but I also expected such discrimination.”
“Expecting it doesn’t mean it doesn’t hurt,” Justin spoke for her, and Ceil nodded after a short pause.
“Remember, Chloe and I am here for you whenever you want to talk.
No need to keep your feelings locked inside anymore.”
Justin raised his bowl of wine to Ceil, and she raised hers back.
He was glad that she was finally opening up, not just to him but to herself.
He tried to remain light on the wine to keep Ceil company through the feast, but due to the strength of the drink, he was the first out, much to the entertainment of the others.
Ceil awoke with the first hangover of her life.
Lycon after lycon approached to drink to her, and she in turn had to take a sip with them out of courtesy.
She could not remember who brought her to her room, but Lemi was there with Coby when she woke.
“I thought your head might hurt when you woke, so I brought some hot water and meat,” Lemi said in a quiet voice.
“After you eat a little, I will help with the pain.”
“Thanks,” Ceil replied, reaching over for a strip of warm meat, so soft and tender that it nearly fell apart at her touch.
Despite the melting texture, a pulse hammered at the inside of her head as she chewed.
“When do we leave?”
“Noon, so that the coldest part of the day is behind us.
At least that is what Zose said.”
Ceil looked at Lemi sitting in front of her holding Ceil’s steaming goblet of water and Coby beside her begging for some of the meat.
Ceil tore a piece and held it out for Coby.
“Has Zose told you what the Afarit is like?”
“No, but I have an idea,” Lemi admitted.
“Then you know that you cannot come with us.”
“I’m going with!” Lemi protested.
“The Afarit is a fire waste.
One accident or misstep and you will die,” Ceil explained without any force or anger in her voice.
“I’ve come with you all this way.
I don’t want to go back now.
Tyree and Tae are going.”
“Lemi,” Ceil said with all her love and gratitude for the Melian girl softening her voice.
“I am glad that you have come with us this far.
I cannot even begin to think what would have happened, how terrible our journey would have been without you, but your time with us ends here.”
“I am not leaving!” Lemi protested harder.
Ceil’s head throbbed from Lemi’s shout, but she swallowed her irritation, drowning it in her love for Lemi.
“Although my mind was distant, I remember everything you said, everything you told me while you took care of me.
Remember our deal back in Melia?
You said that if you were pregnant, you would go back home.”
“But Sammy… Sammy said I could stay with you,” Lemi tried to explain.
“And now Sammy must go with you,” Ceil explained, hoping that Lemi was mature enough to understand.
“You have a daughter now.
You should think of her more than anyone else.
You are in charge of Sammy’s safety.
The Afarit is too dangerous for you… and so am I.”
Lemi’s eyes widened.
She now knew that Ceil had heard everything, even what Lemi told Inym concerning the damage Ceil’s proximity to her caused.
Tears filled Lemi’s eyes, and she shook her head in denial.
“Sammy will live on through your daughter.
That is your responsibility now.” Ceil reached over and pulled Lemi in, holding the young mother close.
Lemi remained with Ceil the rest of the morning as she finished preparations for departure.
All the Vallen party and a small guard of Lycon met at the north pass out of the city ready for departure.
Ceil explained the decision concerning Lemi to everyone present, including revealing publicly for the first time that Lemi was expecting and the name Lemi gave her daughter.
Both Justin and Chloe expressed their congratulations while at the same time shed tears for the parting of a dear friend.
Ceil knelt in front of Coby, looking up into his eyes.
She scratched lightly at his breast feathers.
He was intelligent, and so she knew he would understand the importance of his task.
“You once protected Sammy.
Now Sammy lives on through Lemi.
I want you to take Lemi back home  and keep her and her daughter safe.
If all goes well in the Afarit, I will go back and see you there.
Can you do this?”
Coby answered with a confident cry.
Ceil hugged him and held on for a long while.
This was not a parting of one companion but two.
Ceil chastised Sammy for saving Coby and bringing him along in the beginning, but now Coby was as much a dear friend as Lemi, and he had protected Ceil time and time again.
She hoped that he would continue that same devotion towards Lemi.
Ceil wrapped a thick fur cloak around Lemi.
After Lemi’s final farewell to her friends and a promise to meet again after their business was finished in the wilderlands, Coby grabbed Lemi and carried her off into the sky.
“To the Afarit,” Ceil announced, ready to do her part to convince Bydrofe to end this war.
The party left the cold mountains for much hotter lands.
Ephora breathed a sigh of relief.
Although the events were all different, and the death of the ancestral Lurr of Whinhlem was an astounding surprise, Ceil was able to continue north.
The events would unfold as predicted from here, she hoped, but for a time she was fearful.
Because of her mistake in revealing that Jethro was vital to surviving the calamity Ceil would bring, all the sprites were blind to the future.
She had thought that their predictions would cloud over for a few days at most as all her former involvement had done, but the darkness persisted, strong and unyielding.
She had admonished the Arkhon for acting without consulting the sprites, but now she did the same with far worse consequences than any independent action he had taken.
He made calculated risks, never taking any action that might result in prolonged blindness , but she did not weigh the risk properly, and she realized this too late.
More than simple fear, the unknown was terrifying to a being who should always know the future.
That was the very reason she feared Sammy so.
Ceil almost slipped into darkness multiple times.
The comfort offered by the Aspect of Death was death.
One mistake and Ceil could have died, releasing death where it could spread unabated.
Now that fate resumed its course, Ephora trusted that Ceil would die as predicted in the Afarit where Bydrofe could directly mitigate the initial fallout of the Aspect of Death’s release.
Chapter 19
“The Key to the Prize”
Jethro stared into the dark, his vision seemingly passing through the cold stone of his studio into the night sky.
He was watching, waiting.
He directed his ven to monitoring the inter-world-teleportation-inhibiting magic cast on him by the sprite, checking the timer on it as if it was a pocket watch.
He checked it again and again, counting down the invisible seconds.
He gave Eydis time and an offer to return her to Whinhlem.
He never gave away his location, but through her magic and the cooperation of the United States government, she had many options to make her will known.
Still, he waited in vain, and now she was out of time.
He thought that his threat would be sufficient incentive.
He thought she cared about that young girl married to Emperor Yuro, but he was mistaken.
Perhaps he should have used that time mage as the bargain instead.
Even the coldest in heart still clung to their lover.
Jethro did not know where that man was on Whinhlem, only that he was there, just like Ceil.
Perhaps he would search for him after eliminating the girl.
“Do you have everything?” Jethro asked Fect.
Fect slung his backpack over his shoulders.
“Ready.”
Jethro stood, his eyes continuing to stare into nothing.
He raised his hand, carefully monitoring the ven he channeled through it to activate the spatial teleportation formula.
After a deep breath, he thrust his fingers into the space before him.
The tips disappeared into a crack that split vertically in the air.
Jethro’s heart quickened.
He peeled the crack open revealing a black portal that no light could penetrate, especially in the dark of night.
Jethro had no time to voice his relief or excitement.
He could not take any more chances.
He grabbed Fect by the collar and pulled him through.
The darkness wrapped around and constricted him, resisting as if he was standing deep over his head in a muddy flowing stream, but his spatial formula pulled him against the flow.
Jethro and Fect exited into an unknown location, certainly not where Jethro had planned to teleport.
They landed in a jungle of variegated ivy.
The moment their feet touched the dense leaves, vines grew and latched onto him.
He sent Fect away to Tolmyur in an emergency transmission but was too slow to save himself.
He felt pain in his legs, then numbness.
His ven seized before his second transmission formula activated, and he could no longer take action for himself.
The moment he realized who owned the ivy, his vision grew dark.
Keeya never expected to see the return of her former master.
The moment she detected spatial magic and felt two pairs of feet step on her dense ivy that covered the palace’s central courtyard, she immediately tried to create two new thralls.
The minum escaped, but now that she knew the second was Jethro, she had reservations.
She owed him nothing.
Her contracted servitude was broken.
Why then did she hesitate?

Like every thrall she dominated, she read the thoughts and memories of the individual, transplanting them into the verdant garden of her endless mind, now bright under the sunlight and cultivated instead of dark and overgrown as it had once been before she let her roots grow free.
What saved Jethro from a mindless fate and eternal servitude to the apogee of dryad power were his genuine feelings of companionship towards Keeya.
True, at first she was no more than a tool to him and a means of controlling Emer, but over the days spent in study and research together, a kinship had grown.
He held ire for Emer due to Emer’s elf heritage, but Jethro reserved none for her.
In its place there was pity towards the plight of the Kissiae, a truth that could not be hid, pulled directly from his inner-most thoughts.
So, she spared Jethro, desiring instead to speak with him.
Although she knew his thoughts, she could only theorize how he would react to what she had done to his soldiers, to the Amelian Palace, and to Amel.
Keeya did not fear Jethro’s wrath, because now the combined knowledge and experience of both Emer and Jethro were planted in her mind’s garden.
Through Emer, she had access to not only spatial magic but also the four natural elements, and of course her own life magic now far more powerful as a Hamadryad than it had ever been.
For now, she wanted first to better examine the bizarre plant that was Jethro’s knowledge and memories.
All the plants in her mind’s garden were similar enough in form divided into two major species between the elfkind of Amel and the humankind of Tolmyur.
Cultures and customs in their roots were alike within individual races.
They had similar knowledge and experience in their branches.
Only the leaves of thought and the fruits of their actions differed between individuals.
Those of Tolmyur were of a hardy and weathered breed, strengthened through endless storms that threatened to uproot many, but their roots grew stronger and bound together through such trials.

The outward appearance of the elfkind was majestic and beautiful, and their branches intertwined with those who were alike, but their roots were shallow and weak and only held together by fragile fibers of unity through the Amelian banner.
Keeya understood how the empire had fallen so quickly.
The storm brought by Tolmyur had moistened the soil, and the races of elfkind were torn away from each other through the landslide of Jethro’s might.

Despite the differences between elfkind and humankind, they appeared nearly identical and familiar to Keeya when compared to the foreign abomination that was Jethro’s mind, appearing as if an alien plant had grown in a failed attempt to mimic the Tolmyurin flora of her garden.

Jethro’s roots branched little with one single shoot digging deep into the ground, anchoring him into his upbringing on his home world Trattnou, a world of advanced magical society and unified global populous where their god governed personally; a world of incredible science, art, and terrifying weaponry, where people lived both on their mother planet and in the void of space.
Keeya spent four days among the memories of Jethro’s world, absorbing his education on magic, the mind, and technology.
He was only a young man when he came to Whinhlem by chance, and she could only guess just how rich Jethro’s mind would have become had he remained on Trattnou.
Although the single shoot of Jethro’s roots dug strong and deep, a small number of lateral roots branched out to anchor the few he could trust to the knowledge of his world.
He taught little and only when necessary, fearing the impact his world’s knowledge might have on Whinhlem.
The magical technologies of Trattnou could destroy this world.
Only through the oversight of Trattnou’s god could that world survive itself.
The stalks of Jethro’s memories differed from the people of Amel and soldiers of Tolmyur.
They were colored by trials, companionship, and love of those he met in the eastern wilderlands.
From there the branches mimicked those of Tolmyur, but as they grew, they twisted and deformed.
Keeya uncovered the source of Jethro’s pain and malice, a loss of loved ones held dear, and a plea for help from Amel that was answered with the darkest evil.
Racial prejudice grew strong in the roots of the High Elves.
An individual convinced that another was inferior and undeserving of even the most meager of graces could justify and relish in the most grievous of atrocities committed against them.
Despite searching three days through her garden, she could not find the order that led to the death of Jethro’s infant daughter, his last remaining family.
None of the council members present when the order was given or those who executed the order were among her thralls.
All in power were killed when Jethro seized Amel.
Keeya only had Jethro’s memories that malformed the ends of his branches, and those memories pointed at Eydis as the perpetrator.
Although his leaves were beautiful to behold, the fruit he bore was a strong poison that threatened to affect Keeya the longer she tasted, drawing her into his malice.
Keeya distanced herself from Jethro’s memories and watched him in the soft ivy bed of the palace’s west garden.
She pitied him.
He once had all the makings of the greatest king to have graced Whinhlem.
He could have brought about the longest golden age since the height of the ancient human civilization.
Now he was nothing more than a creature of vengeance the High Elves created.
“Jethro,” Keeya spoke, waking him from his slumber.
Jethro roused but did not startle.
His eyes examined the overflowing garden and clear sky painted in sunset.
He sat up finding Emer sitting before him on a mound of coiled ivy like a lush and verdant blister in the center of the garden court.
Keeya remained latched to Emer’s back, and her ageless eyes stared into him, no longer the meek child she had once seemed.
Other Kissiae watched from the branches of the trees or hidden among the shrubs on the ground.
Four giants and three High Elves stood guard around the perimeter of the garden.
The guards were alive but not.
Their skin was withered like old men, and their features were sunken.
A few ivy leaves sprouted from between their armor, and thin vines coiled and crawled on and under their skin.
Their eyes saw Jethro but at the same time did not see him, as if their senses came only from the focus of the controlling ivy’s attention.
These were Kissiae thralls, and the variegated coloring of the leaves informed Jethro to whom the thralls belonged.
Keeya carefully monitored Jethro’s thoughts such that he would not notice her presence in his mind, searching for his response to seeing her domination of his men.
