He was curious more than scared or angry, but then his curiosity changed to worry.
In his mind, he never thought Keeya would betray him, and so his only conclusion was that something had happened that forced her drastic actions.
His intellect was as bright and beautiful as the leaves of his plant in her mind’s garden.
“Keeya, what happened?” Jethro asked, not condemning her but out of honest worry.
Jethro was unaware that her control spread throughout all the capital city of Amel.
He thought she had created a haven within the palace gardens for protection, possibly from his soldiers.
His assumptions were not far from the truth.
“I am a hamadryad now,” Keeya informed him.
Emer stood, showing where her Ivy hair rooted into the ground.
Unlike most hamadryads whose bodies grew into majestic trees, ivy dryads took root with their hair and had range of motion around where they rooted.
Jethro’s thoughts alternated blame towards his men to his own lack of foresight.
Keeya was the matriarch of the Kissiae, the eldest among them.
He knew this.
He was familiar enough with dryad physiology to know that resisting the change to a hamadryad was incredibly difficult to nigh impossible.

He reasoned that the hamadryad process had begun in the span of time he was on Earth, and because he had ordered Keeya to remain on the palace grounds, she had no choice but to take root in the west garden.
The thralls under her command were the unfortunate who were snared during her evolution.
In all this, Jethro never once considered blaming Keeya.
“You are mistaken,” Keeya answered Jethro’s thoughts, revealing that she was in his mind.
Suddenly, Jethro’s thoughts froze into perfect silence, a skill he perfected in his own world to protect his research knowledge from those who could scry thought.
He trusted her in his memory, but that did not mean he would continue to do so should the balance change between them.

He was cautious, and the last fleeting thought of his mind before it grew silent was a fear that Keeya would learn of the knowledge from his world, so perhaps silencing his mind was for her protection, not his.
Keeya had no way to know without taking control of his thoughts, and doing so would betray Jethro’s trust in her, creating a rift between them.
Again, Keeya questioned why she did not want to dominate him.
It would be simple and advantageous for her to do so.
Was it his honest feelings of companionship towards her, or was it her feelings of pity towards him?
She did not know.
“Tell me what happened,” Jethro said, his words and the worried emotions accompanying them breaking the silence of his mind for but a moment before the silence returned.

“As you wish.” Keeya shared with him her memories of first discovering the dryads cooked by the chef staff, the feeling of the first Kissiae dying in Vallen, her travel to Elos to discover that the Kissiae had been conscripted for the assault on Revlan, and her attempted rescue and failure to save fifteen of her daughters.
She finished by sharing her regret and how she felt that she had failed as the matriarch of the Kissiae.
She sent it all directly to Jethro’s mind without a single spoken word as if those memories were his.
She left out the involvement of the Tolmyur generals or who gave the order.
What would he do with that knowledge?
How would he react?
Keeya wanted to test Jethro, to see if she could trust him.
Thankfully, Jethro assumed that Keeya did not withhold any of her memories pertaining to the event, making him assume she did not know why such a tragedy occurred.
Jethro’s mind lit with the spark of inquiry that quickly grew into a blaze of cogitation.

Possibilities of events in his absence, mainly concerning the Vallen campaign, flashed one after another searching for what could have led to the Kissiae being conscripted into the final battle at Revlan.
Byurk would not conscript the dryads.
He wanted to spare as many of the races as possible, even his enemies.
Something led to a call for reinforcements from Amel for which the generals present did not feel their stationed forces adequate.
The Vallen campaign was progressing smoothly and quickly when Jethro left for Earth.
Something changed, but what?
If the dryads had chosen to aid Vallen, that might have been cause enough for emergency aid from Amel, but all the dryads were on Tolmyur’s side assaulting the city in Keeya’s memory.
A greater force was at play.
Jethro’s mind continued to draw back on the massive explosion of fire that killed the final Kissiae that Keeya could not rescue in time.
No mage could have produced it.
A name and face of a woman from Jethro’s past flashed in his mind, Basara.
She had the power, but Basara would never create such a coarse flame.
Hers were far more elegant.
And he doubted that she would join the war against him.
“A bomb?” Jethro whispered.
Such technology did not exist on Whinhlem.
None of the races had discovered gunpowder, and their reliance on magic lessened the need for it, but the nature of the explosion certainly did not look like a magical flame.
It appeared catalytic, chemical.
Various images of explosions flashed through Jethro’s mind until he found the nearest match to what he saw in Keeya’s memory, and oil-based explosion.
Such an explosion could be possible on Whinhlem with the right ingenuity and enough fuel.
Fairies lived in harmony with nature.
They would never, even in their most dire of times, create an oil-based bomb.
Suddenly the face of the sprite on Earth dominated Jethro’s thoughts.
He tried to send some humans from earth to Tolmyur, but his teleportation was intercepted mid-cast by a sprite.
Sprites, like humans, lived on every world Jethro had been to, but on Whinhlem sprites were allies of the Amelian Empire.
If that sprite changed the destination of his magic to Vallen, those humans from Earth could have aided the fairies against their common enemy, Tolmyur.
Earth was far more technologically advanced than Whinhlem.
Although Jethro was careful about what knowledge he shared with people of this world, those humans might not be so reserved.
Keeya was amazed that with only the information she gave him, he nearly deduced what had happened.
Humans from the world Jethro invaded appeared in the Vallen campaign shortly after Jethro contacted the palace to inform them that his invasion of Earth failed.
The generals could not take any risks and so sent a support army from Amel to ensure victory in Vallen, but they felt their forces insufficient against people from a world that defeated him.
They conscripted dryads for the battle, including the Kissiae whom Jethro promised to protect, and turned those who refused into food reserves for a siege.
Jethro brought humans from Earth to Whinhlem, beginning the chain that led to the death of the fifteen Kissiae.
Keeya noticed guilt appear in Jethro’s heart, but it was fleeting.
He specifically gave an order that the Kissiae were under the protection of Tolmyur and were to be spared from any danger.
His generals disobeyed that order.
Jethro’s expression changed to one Keeya had never seen.
Jethro was usually lighthearted in demeanor, and occasionally she had seen his wrath when it was directed at Emer, but now his face bore the rigid determination to right a wrong.
He once held a strong sense of justice that had warped over time due to his trauma, but here it sparked as true as it had in his youth.
There was no deception or guile in his heart.
Keeya began to feel that she could trust him.
“Do you have the commander who gave the order to conscript the Kissiae among your thralls?”
“I do not,” Keeya replied.
“They have returned from Vallen and are camped without the city walls beyond the reach of my vines.
If he survived the battle, he would be there.”
“Allow me to find the one responsible so that he may answer to both you and me.”
“Go,” Keeya said in the more childlike tone of her pre-Hamadryad self and released her hold on Jethro.
A light smile rose in her lips.
She did not care whether Jethro would return after hearing the tale from the perspective of his commanders.
She had no need to kill or enslave him.
She trusted now that he would not try to harm her or her daughters, and that was enough.
Perhaps he would continue his agreement to protect them.
In a world that she felt was united against the Kissiae, this man who came from a different world might be her one and only ally.
However, should he ever cross her, she now had both the power and knowledge to end him.
Jethro stood on a barrier high above the former capital city, Amel.

He had assumed Keeya’s vines did not spread further than the palace when she told him that his soldiers were without the walls outside her reach, but dense variegated ivy spread all the way to and up the far walls of the city, not the walls of the palace.
What had once been a thriving metropolis was now a verdant jungle.
The plants of the city were overgrown, empowered by Keeya’s vines.
Vines reached across the bridges crossing the thin river that ran southeast.
Although the sunset painted the city in deep shadows, Jethro could see countless thralls lumbering through the streets and alleys, men, women, and children alike.
The thralls nearest the palace were his soldiers.
Bodies hardened by war made better protectors.
From the numbers, all his men who were stationed elsewhere around the city were gathered there.
In all, he assumed he lost anywhere from three to six thousand depending on how many were able to flee the city as the vines spread.
He could learn the exact number from those in the army camp.

The camp was situated on the north side of the city in what had formerly been the commerce block outside the walls where local farmers and merchants traded and managed supplies in bulk without needing to crowd the grand marketplace near Amel’s south center where the general populous dealt business.
He had sent his soldiers directly into the city during the assault on Amel, so the outer areas were largely spared the destruction.

The numerous warehouses for storage and wide fields for livestock trade made the location ideal for the hundreds of thousands of soldiers he initially brought, turning it into a camp city rivaling Amel in size.
He was relieved to see that the vines never reached the camp, but at the same time, the camp seemed odd.
Jethro teleported directly to the city-facing entrance of the camp.
The guards stationed at the entrance were so inebriated that they did not notice him.
Unintelligible shouts hummed through the air like a sick breeze.
No one within the camp recognized Jethro standing at the entrance because he was not wearing his usual robes.
He was dressed in Earth attire, had hair nearly to his shoulders, and had grown a goatee, so he could understand at least a little why no call to attention was made at his approach.
He snagged a cloak from the passed-out watch and walked into the camp under his shroud of anonymity, more worried that anyone could have walked into the camp without alarm.

The air was always foul in a war camp, but it hung heavier than in his memory, either because he had grown accustomed to the cleaner living on Earth or because the cleanliness of the camp had grown slack.
No one appeared to be working in any form.
One tent Jethro passed was filled with sleeping men, mostly unclothed.
He could not tell if the sole elf woman among them was alive or dead.
He transmitted her into the city to either become a thrall or nutrients for the overgrown plants and vines.

In other tents, the soldiers cast lots over games of tibrem where a forked stick and small ring were tossed between co-betters in a game of skill to hook the ring on the stick once both fell into a circle drawn on the ground.
Only now Jethro realized that the camp was in the middle of the traditional twelve-day victory celebration.
They must have just returned from the Vallen campaign.
If that was the case, he could not judge them too severely, but the lack of security, especially after the city was overtaken by Keeya, was simply aggravating.
Perhaps they were so lax because they were also mourning the many lost not only in Vallen but also Amel?
Jethro sighed.
He needed to speak with a captain or general to ascertain the truth of what was happening in the camp.
The camp’s commander headquarters was established in the former trade office.
Jethro was relieved to find a lone, rather young soldier at attention guarding the structure, the first he had seen in all the camp.
The boy could barely be a year and a half of age.
Jethro approached and was greeted with a spear aimed at his chest.
He was not alarmed.
His face was shaded in the hood of his grunt soldier cloak, so the boy could not have recognized him.
“Only officers are permitted beyond this point.
State your name and business,” the boy ordered.
Jethro faintly recognized the boy’s face but not his name, having seen the headquarter guard in the scant times he personally visited the camp.
A faint smile spread across his lips.
He relaxed his throat to deepen his voice.
“The security of your camp is lax.
Anyone could enter disguised as one of your own, and you would be none the wiser.
A pity.”
The boy called for reinforcements while thrusting his spear an inch from Jethro’s chest.
“Identify yourself!”
“That will not be necessary,” Jethro replied as three lieutenants and the captain in charge of the camp exited with weapons drawn.
“I am sure Captain Drommer could do that for me,” he said in his regular tone.
Captain Drommer, a minum, peered up into Jethro’s hood.
His eyes squinted and then grew wide.
“Lower your weapons,” he hollered, kneeling to the ground.
“Forgive us, Commanding General Jethro.
We did not recognize you.”
The young guard aiming his hostility at Jethro dropped his spear in terror and pressed his face into the ground.
“Forgive me, my Lord.”
Jethro smiled and knelt to the ground.
Grasping the guard by the hand, he lifted the boy to his feet.
“There is nothing to forgive.
Instead, you should be commended.
Of all my soldiers, of the many men in this camp much older than you, you alone had wisdom to confront a stranger who entered the camp.
What is your name?”
The boy looked into Jethro’s eyes in awe.
“Atson , son of Meton, son of Hemlet,” he replied.
Stating a third generation was uncommon, and only done when descending from a name of renown, and General Hemlet was indeed renowned.
“How is the grandson of a hero of the Coastal War a mere guard?”
“My father is the eleventh son, the youngest, and I am my father’s seventh, also youngest,” Atson replied with conviction in his voice, lacking any spite for his lowly placement in a hero’s lineage.
“You take great pride in your lineage,” Jethro replied, rather pleased.
Although he never met the old general personally, his feats were nearly comparable to Jethro’s own.
The southern shores would have become desolate beyond recovery if not for his efforts.
“Yes.
It is an honor to carry the blood of a great man, no matter how thin,” the boy replied.
“Captain Drommer, see that this boy receives proper training under your care to become captain of our camp guard.
Our men could learn much from his character.”
The boy bowed deep before Jethro’s declaration.
“As you will,” Captain Drommer replied.
“Is a general present?” Jethro asked now that his ruse and inspection of the camp met its conclusion.
“General Bregon has claimed the officer’s quarters on the third floor.
His mood is fowl, and he has demanded not to be disturbed.
I hope your return will lift his spirits.”
Captain Drommer’s news was ill. Perhaps the Vallen campaign was not as successful as Jethro hoped.
He made his way to the third floor and opened the door.
General Bregon’s massive frame was hunched over a table covered in a map and scattered documents.
He looked up, and like the others before, he did not recognize Jethro at first, but his realization came swift.
“I knew you would return,” General Bregon said, returning to sifting through the piles of documents.
“After your urgent message, we feared the worst, but one of your strength would not fall so easily.”
“I have been sorely reminded numerous times that there are those far more powerful than I both on this world and on others.
I was bested beyond compare.
Now I return from my internment on Earth to find we have lost control of Amel and our soldiers lacking all order.
Do Tolmyur’s armies become incompetent with the absence of one man?”
General Bregon tensed, and Jethro could tell it was not from guilt but anger.
The source was yet to be seen.
“For all your knowledge and power, you are not free of error, Commanding General.
Byurk, whom you left in command of the Vallen campaign, has in his own poor judgement let Yuro’s widow escape into the wilderlands beyond our reach.”
“Byurk is no fool.
If the widow escaped to the wilderlands, I doubt any of our officers could have prevented it.”
General Bregon sat up straight in his stool, the wood crying under his weight.
“He took pity on the fairies, and that pity lost us our prize at great cost.
The Vallen campaign was for naught.
In addition, I have often been critical of the free reign you gave that half-breed elf and Kissiae slave, and now you see the state of Amel.
We lost nearly five thousand of our best soldiers and all but four of our commanding officers to that Kissiae.
Order is broken because we lack those to keep it.

I alone remained to rebuild our chain of command, sifting through whatever scant military records not in the palace to find suitable men who could shoulder such responsibilities,” General Bregon grumbled, crinkling a sheet of rough parchment in his fist.
“You should be with your men to find those of worth, not hiding among stacks of parchment.

I found one promising boy guarding the door of this very building, but these stone walls have made you too blind to notice,” Jethro quipped as he scanned through a sheet of parchment that General Bregon discarded.
“Spare me the ridicule.
You may have climbed ranks through your own merit from a mercenary, but those who you enabled to do the same are now dead or thralls of the Kissiae.
If we are to restore order, we need men of proper lineage and education from known families, military lines that soldiers will obey out of obligation.”
Jethro breathed an aggravated sigh.
The young guard was one such man, but the documents General Bregon trusted would never tell him.
He dropped his casual demeanor and continued with the seriousness born by his position as master of all Tolmyur’s armies.
“When I look for who can lead the armies of Tolmyur, I choose men who produce results no matter the difficulty of the order given.
You have chosen to take command of parchment, not men.
As such, I am removing you from your position.”
General Bregon stood from his chair, his head nearly touching the arched ceiling.
“Even as Commanding General, you would need approval of three other generals to remove me, and those in Amel would assuredly agree with my methods.”
“I would rather not use force,” Jethro warned, his eyes daggers.
Bregon reached behind him for his broad-leafed spear knowing well that he could never defend against Jethro should Jethro decide to eliminate him.
Before Bregon could grab it, his body locked inside a barrier and his voice seized.
“Do not get hasty.
My plan was to be lenient depending on what I learned, but you forced my hand.
I said you were removed from your position, but you still could have been of use elsewhere.
As you stated, we are severely lacking those who could keep order.
Now I know that you are incapable of following orders let alone being able to give them.
You are right that if I wanted to remove you due to incompetence, I would need the vote of three other generals.
I am certainly not the type to circumvent that step by eliminating you as past Commanding Generals would have.
Lucky you.
However, I can remove you for disobedience without the need for approval.”
Jethro paced around the table and cleared the parchment off the map.
It was extravagantly drawn, likely something Bregon had pillaged from Vallen.
His hand fell on Dhuillir, and his finger tapped the unmarked location of Elos.
“I gave an order to all generals and captains that the Kissiae were not to be touched.
You led a support army from Amel to aid Captain Byurk in Vallen, and as you passed through Dhuillir, you conscripted the Kissiae along with other dryads.
Is this correct?”
Bregon found himself able to speak, and he knew that if he answered anything other than what Jethro asked, his voice would be silenced once again.
“The Kissiae joined us of their own will, their matriarch leading them.”
“Are you saying you never gave an order to involve the Kissiae?
The road to Vallen through Dhuillir does not pass near Elos.”
“Captain Kolbur chose to enlist the Kissiae for--”
“I have heard enough,” Jethro sighed and locked Bregon’s voice.
He did not recognize a captain by that name--a new appointment perhaps.
Assuming what Bregon said was true, he still would have had to give the order.
No small party could have reached the Kissiae in the center of the Elos marshes.
Bregon was commander of the support army, so any captain would have needed his permission to take a platoon well off course to Elos.
Not only did Bregon disobey Jethro, but he was also shirking responsibility.
Removing him was the best decision.
“Your choice to involve the Kissiae has resulted in the loss of Amel and the nearly five thousand soldiers stationed there.
As such, you will be punished, but the manner of punishment will not be mine to decide.”
Bregon vanished, and Jethro immediately followed, reappearing atop a barrier floating above the ground in the palace garden.
Keeya roused, and Emer sat up upon the mound of ivy.
“I did not expect you to return so quickly,” Keeya spoke into both Jethro and Bregon’s minds so her voice would not have to carry.
Jethro smiled.
“You weren’t completely truthful when you shared your memories with me,” he realized.
“Or should I say, you did not share everything.
Before I hand him to you, I must be certain.
Did this man give the order to involve the Kissiae, leading to the loss of your sisters?”
Joy welled within Keeya strong enough for the emotion to pierce Jethro’s mind.
Only now did he realize that when she had hold of him, she left behind a connection to him.
He did not know the strength of the connection, but she may have been monitoring his conversation with Bregon at the camp.
He felt the faint thought in her heart, that she was happy to have an ally in him.
“Yes,” Keeya replied.
“Then he is yours to do with as you will.” Jethro dropped Bregon into the vines and released the barrier.
Bregon struggled for only a second before the Kissiae’s domination took hold.
“The request came from a human named Kolbur, but Bregon gave the order,” Keeya explained into Jethro’s thoughts.
“However, you should know that had my daughters not come to his aid, he and his support army would have fallen to the dryads resisting his advance into Vallen.”
“That only shows his weakness as a leader of my armies.
And what of the Vallen campaign had that happened?”
“Given the status of the city, your friend, Byurk, would have won through starvation, but the one you seek would most likely have escaped north still.”
“I see,” Jethro replied, pondering how he would search for the widow now that she escaped to the wilderlands.
He was familiar with the heavily forested eastern wilderlands where he first arrived on Whinhlem, but the western wilderlands were mostly unknown.
“In gratitude for your understanding and willingness to support the Kissiae, I can locate the widow of Yuro for you.”
Jethro’s eyes widened in surprise.
Did Keeya always have this ability, unknown to him?
How quickly could he have finished his revenge had he known?
Could he have taken Keeya to Earth with him to locate the princess as well?
“It would have been impossible for my former self,” Keeya replied, knowing Jethro’s thoughts.
“My power has grown immensely as a Hamadryad, and without Bregon, I would not know whom to seek.
The widow was sheltered away from most in the palace.
None who remained from your occupation knew her.
Only by giving Bregon in atonement have you made this possible.
Located within his memories is the widow’s appearance.
He met her in Revlan of Vallen, so now I can search for her among the lifeforces of the wilderlands.
The wilderlands are vast, but my magic can reach.
It will take time.”
Chapter 20
“The Afarit”
Sweat ran as a stream down Ceil’s nape to her back.
The once wing-like bow of her bind now hung drenched and clung to her skin.
Dyson had warned her that she would miss the cold, but she never could have imagined the severity of his warning and just how wrong she was to think he only spoke in jest.
The snow had continued only for the first two days after departing north from Sen’uon.
The road was rocky but flat enough for easy travel.
The mountains were behind them giving way to rolling, rocky hills littered with ruins here and there.
From there the rain fell hard and heavy, muddying the ground slick and deep to be nearly impassible.
Justin grew ill from the frigid rain and had to be carried for that day as Tyree monitored him.
With only a single lung, Ceil worried that any respiratory illness would debilitate him despite both his and Tyree’s assurance that with dryad care she had no need to worry.
Even Ceil found it odd how she worried for him.
In the past, any worry regarding Justin was on Sammy’s behalf, but now her worry was for Justin himself.
After all, he was one of the few people she had left who cared for her as a friend, who cared for her for her sake and not for her position or role in what future may come.
If Justin cared for Ceil for her sake, she wanted to care for him for his.
The rain warmed and became sparse the following day, but it was not a rain Ceil had ever experienced.
The moisture in the air stung her eyes, and the clouds above their head glowed brown.
The rain tasted bitter, and Zose warned that she should not drink it.
The many large water skins they had filled when the rain was frigid were now their only source of clean water until they reached an Afarit settlement in four or five days.
Their only water mage was Byurk, and he alone could not supply enough to sustain their party, especially when fighting off his own dehydration in the intense heat to come.

The hills became jagged with massive spines of black stone like barbed spearheads eating away at the crumbling ruins now so widespread that the land in its entirety was more akin to a devastated city as far as the eye could see.
The gravel of the road cut at the soles of Ceil’s sandals, and if she let her toes slip forward past the edge of the hardened leather, they would bleed.
Justin was amazed at the geological structures all around him, calling the razor-sharp, black monoliths obsidian.
Zose warned that the stones absorbed heat, creating a barrier that kept the outer lands they already traveled cooler.
Once they passed the black crystal band, their final two days would be the hardest.
And they were.
Ceil wanted to strip her bind and skirt and walk naked in the unbearable heat.
Only Chloe and Hethyro were unaffected, and somehow Basara beamed with energy.
All the land glowed orange with rivers of molten stone flowing in the distance.
Flame spat at the road but never reached.
The road snaked and bent following the only safe route through the fire wastes, climbing up and down often sheer rock faces of coarse volcanic stone.
The terrain could not be altered using earth magic to ease travel for fear of awakening underground veins of fire or molten rock and destroying their path outright.

They had no other choice but to struggle across narrow cliffside passes with lakes of fire below, climb vertical sheets of stone where the only aids were small footholds created by those who came before, and trudging through hot and deep pumice sand that sapped what endurance might have survived.
The sparse stretches of flatter, winding road through dried lava fields were a paradise by comparison.
“How could anything live in such a place?” Ceil moaned.
“If not for the afarit, there would probably be many mining communities living here.
The concentration of resfahil deposits only grow the closer we reach the center.
Past the wastes the heat dies down a little.
It shouldn’t be any worse than the hottest summer days on the Filinceil Plains,” Zose explained.
“There are areas of the deserts in Tolmyur that are as hot as we are here,” Basara explained.
“Stay hydrated and you will be fine,” she said as she handed Ceil a frigid water skin Hethyro just cooled with his fire magic.
Ceil gulped down water so fast her throat stung and her head ached from the chill.
She then handed the skin to Justin.
He had his arm over Chloe’s shoulder just barely managing to keep pace.
Ceil had helped for a short time, but then the heat became so unbearable that she could no longer stand another body against hers.
“I wish I could cool my body,” Chloe said with a sigh.
She was now comfortable enough in Elven to use it in general conversation when around others besides just Justin and Ceil.
“I do too,” Justin chuckled.
Certainly, hanging on her shoulder would be far more pleasant were that the case.
“Nothing can be done,” Basara said.
“Normal fire mages can use their fire magic to cool, but maenads cannot.”
Chloe retrieved the water skin from Justin and held it in her hand.
Frost gathered on the edge where she touched.
“I am human.
I am not a maenad.”
Basara stopped walking.
Her brows narrowed as she stared at Chloe who stopped a few paces ahead.
“That cannot be,” she said.
“You must have some maenad in you.”
“I am a human of Earth, like Justin,” Chloe replied, and Justin nodded.
“Impossible.
No human could have that strong of magic.
Even Jethro’s ability solely comes from his knowledge and experience, not the strength of his affinity to spatial magic.
Humans simply do not have strong magic affinities.”
“They are humans of Earth,” Ceil replied in Chloe’s defense as she trudged ahead using her Hamadryad staff as a crutch.
“You should learn how to cool down your body,” Basara said to Chloe.
“You can cool water, so the same technique can be applied to your body.
You should not have any problem overheating if you are not a maenad.” Mild exasperation seeped into her expression.
With how often she heard warnings of Chloe’s potential to overheat, she simply thought there was nothing that could be done for it, because Chloe was a maenad.
“I try, but I cannot,” Chloe admitted.
“When my body is hot, if I use magic, I get hotter.”
“Control,” Basara admonished.
“Your power surpasses mine, but you lack control.” That was all Chloe’s weakness amounted to.

Before Basara could continue her lecture, she grabbed the water skin from Chloe and ran to the small pack of lycon acting both as guards for their party and ambassadors to the Afarit now that they conquered the southern gateway through the Hemenonan range.
Another of the lycon had collapsed from the heat.
Once again Ceil was reminded that she had no right to complain.
She could remove clothing if necessary, but the already naked lycon who doffed their leather armor long ago could not remove their fur.
One more day.
That was the sole mantra that kept Ceil walking.
On the evening of the following day, all at once the fire wastes ended as if some all-powerful hand had drawn a line in the land and heavens.
The road sloped downward into a massive caldera that stretched to the horizon.
The vortex of brown fire-clouds ended at the lip of a massive caldera opening to a clear sky like the eye of a storm.
Deep within the caldera was a ruined city of stone that sparkled like starlight mirrored in still waters.
It surrounded a circular crown of mountains rising higher than the rim of the caldera to reach the heavens.
The shape of the ruins of the ancient human civilization looked familiar, the same as Revlan.
It was a sunken city of such a grand scale as to surpass any existing on the continent.
Ceil did not doubt that ten of the capital city of Amel could fit within its borders.
However, the lights were sparse.
The city was inhabited, but not by many for its size.
“Welcome to the Afarit,” Zose said noticing Ceil’s mouth hung agape.
“Largest city in the world, although in ancient times it is believed to have stretched to the Hemenonan.
The wilderlands are not as abandoned as many think.” He then nodded to Basara who raised her hand into the air.
A flare of ocean blue and sunlight gold launched into the air and burst into a shower of silver sparks twinkling in the night.
The sparks faded to gold and dimmed to blue before vanishing.
There they waited.
Ceil asked the reason for the flare, but both Basara and Zose remained silent.
Kiri alone spoke up, only stating that they could not enter the valley without permission.
Her lips bore a small grin.
“Watch,” she said at last when a small line of firelights grew from the base of the caldera’s central crown.
As the line slowly neared, Ceil noticed it was two lines, not one.
It extended past the borders of the city to where the ruins became rubble up the slope of the caldera.
At its head grew a pair of vibrant blue and gold flames carried by two robed figures, and behind them was a procession.
As the two at the head advanced, those in the procession moved to the side and lit small flames in their hands to continue lighting the path to the city.
Zose and Basara and everyone knelt to the ground almost in unison with Justin and Chloe quickly following.
“You alone should not kneel,” Kiri admonished Ceil when she was about to do the same.
The procession behind the lead flames grew short only a few yards ahead of where Ceil stood, and when only one remained, the flames parted and stood beside the path at the head of both lines.
The sole remaining man from the procession wore only a skirt gird about his waist that hung to his calves.
His legs were similar in shape to spriggans, but his tail that hung behind was forked at the tip.
His body was large and built, toned with aged muscle behind his dark, reddened skin like dried blood.
A simple cord woven from white hair hung from his neck and adorned his chest.
His hair was long and similarly woven into cords that hung down his bare back past his waist.
Thick but flat horns grew from the center atop his forehead and extended to his temples where they bent into a mild wave along the sides of his head.
Many tassels hung from where the tips of his horns curled upwards, and two dark iron rings hung from his earlobes, stretching them to his shoulders where the rings rested.
“You come bearing the colors of Amel, and yet I do not see the house of Amel,” the man spoke in Elven.
His voice had a deep but smooth timbre that made the back of Ceil’s neck shiver.
Kiri stood and knelt before the man.
“Hain-henel, Lord of the Afarit, before you stands Ceil of the Ceilian Empire, widow of Yuro Amel, who has claimed all within the borders of the former Amelian Empire.
Hain-henel’s eyes bored through Ceil as if piercing her to her core.
“The house of Amel held contract with the Afarit to pay respects to the Guardian of Whinhlem when the heir reaches their third year.
The house of Amel is a year late coming, and it is not their heir that visits but a widow in her third year in company of mercenaries, lycon, and Tolmyur.”
“A widow she may be, but the heir she remains, now Empress of all that the Amelian Empire once was.” Kiri responded.
Ceil grew nervous.
No one spoke or added in defense of Ceil’s standing.
She knew that she held no political power.
Her claim to a new empire was made in anger in a city that had long fallen.
Both the Amelian Empire and the Ceilian Empire did not exist.
“And what is your name who speaks for her,” Hain-henel answered, breaking the deafening silence.
“I am Kiri, Queen of Vallen and subject of Ceil, Empress.”
This was the first time Ceil had heard Kiri refer to herself as queen.
Certainly after the destruction of Vallen, Kiri was the sole surviving direct descendant of the Vallen royal line.
The hollow pit in Ceil’s stomach grew wider.
Just like Amel, Vallen was no more.
Both Ceil and Kiri bore empty titles bereft of any authority.
“An empress of a broken house announces herself without tribute or gift to the Guardian of Whinhlem.
And here her enemy joins in her entourage.
What is the meaning of your arrival in our lands?”
Ceil took a deep breath and walked forward.
“I have come to supplicate the Guardian of Whinhlem for aid in ending the conflict that has plagued the continent for many generations.”
Kiri’s shoulder’s tensed.
Ceil knew immediately that she spoke out of place, destroying the ceremony of her introduction, but her agonizing nerves could wait no longer.
Both Zose and Byurk approached and knelt beside Kiri.
“I, Byurk, a general of Tolmyur, also desire an end to this war,” Byurk replied.
“I am prepared to receive proper punishment for the betrayal of my country so long as we achieve this end.”
“Empress Ceil is not without tribute,” Zose added.
“Her life is a king’s bounty to be paid by Tolmyur from the coffers of the Amelian Palace.
I have brought Empress Ceil here to the Afarit so that your Lordship may claim the bounty on behalf of the Guardian of Whinhlem in lieu of tribute.
Your Lordship need only present her to Tolmyur once they arrive in the days following her supplication.”
“And does she willingly give herself for a chance to speak with the Guardian of Whinhlem?” Hain-henel asked.
Ceil’s mind grew blank.
In order to speak with Bydrofe, Zose had arranged for her to be given to Tolmyur.
She looked beside her to Zose who only caught her glance for a moment before returning his gaze forward.

Justin and Chloe exchanged glances between each other, and Ceil wondered if they fully understood the conversation in Elven, that their friend whom they tried so desperately to rescue would be given to their enemy.
The faces of the few surviving Tolmyur soldiers lit with epiphany as if only now realizing why their general had surrendered so readily.
Lastly, Ceil’s eyes fell upon the back of Kiri’s head.
Kiri never moved or reacted when Zose spoke.
This had been an arrangement between Zose, Basara, Kiri, and Byurk without her knowledge, perhaps because they knew she would refuse.
Zose and Basara had planned this from the beginning.
They never asked for payment because they knew of the bounty and her identity the moment Basara saw her two tails, and they planned to claim a portion of the bounty as payment for their work.
Ceil could not speak ill of them.
This was her fate, and she had no choice but to accept.
She could only hope that Byurk and Basara would be successful in convincing Jethro to spare her life as they promised.
Ceil’s eyes widened.
She realized the crux of the plan, but it came too late for her to reply.
The Lord of the Afarit raised his hand after enduring Ceil’s long silence.
Veins of fire extended from his neck, up his arm, and to his hand, a racial trait of the afarit commonly called ignition that enabled them to strengthen their bodies with fire.
When his fingers curled to a fist, a flash lit for only a moment.
All lights along the path extinguished, and the entourage marched back towards their city.
“If you wish to take shelter from those who pursue you, the Afarit will welcome you, Ceil, but I cannot permit you to see the Guardian of Whinhlem.
For now.” He turned his back to Ceil and walked back down the path.
Ceil cursed herself for not realizing.
Kiri never abandoned her.
Neither had Zose nor Basara.
Their plan was a gamble relying on Ceil’s own ability.
If she was successful in convincing Bydrofe to come to her aid against Tolmyur, then she would not be surrendered.
The payment for the bounty, her surrender to Jethro, would only happen should she fail.
The Lord of the Afarit’s final words hinted that she might still have a chance to meet Bydrofe.
Because of her silence, her task grew more difficult.
She both had to do whatever was needed to make that meeting occur and then be successful in persuading him to action.
Ceil grabbed Kiri’s shoulder and pulled her to her feet.
“Why did you not tell me your plan earlier?
I made things worse not knowing,” she demanded in a harsh whisper.
“Do not blame her,” Byurk said.
“Kiri was opposed to the plan, and we felt you would be as well, so it was Zose, Basara, and my decision to keep it from you.
We do not plan on giving you to Jethro if it can be helped.”
“But that all depends on me, does it not?”
“Yes,” Zose said, nudging Ceil forward.
“For now, we have been allowed into the city.
We can rest for a few days.
We will not get a regal welcome, but there is sure to be at least a small feast tomorrow in your honor.”
“Come,” Kiri said, walking down the dark path of the caldera’s steep slope towards the city.
Back at Amel, Keeya contacted Jethro through his thoughts.
“I found her.
She has just been taken under the protection of the Afarit.”
Jethro stood from the table, interrupting his dinner with his ten current and prospective officers.
“The widow of Yuro has been located,” he announced to the confusion of those present.
“How do you know,” Atson asked.
No message had come that any of them could see or hear.
“The Kissiae that took over Amel is cooperating with me.
She found her.”
Astonished glances traded across the table.

Jethro had informed them that Keeya was not dangerous to them so long as they did not provoke her--in fact, he forbade anyone from approaching the ivy-covered walls of the fallen city to not risk antagonizing her--but none had even considered that the Kissiae would cooperate with them.
To them, she was an enemy.
“Shall we organize the soldiers?” Captain Drommer asked.
“Not yet, but inform the men that we may deploy at a moment’s notice and to be prepared.
I will return shortly.”
Jethro vanished and reappeared in the west garden of the Amelian Palace atop a barrier suspended in the air so that his transmission would not damage Keeya’s vines.
He sat down cross-legged on the mound of Ivy beside Keeya.
“That was faster than I thought.
You said it would take time.”
“Had she gone into hiding in some remote hovel, it might have.”
“The safest location for her in all the wilderlands is the Afarit, so you assumed she would head there?”
Keeya nodded in unison with Emer’s unconscious head.
“I searched the road north from Ib’nua and found her the moment she entered the city.”
Jethro extended his hand.
“Can you give me her location?”
“Yes, but you alone will be insufficient.
She is in the presence of a powerful guard, and your past awaits you there.”
“What do you mean?”
“Byurk, and by his actions, he is cooperating with her.”
“A prisoner?”
“No.
He is not bound nor is he under watch.
You know he dislikes the war and the task you gave him.
He may have betrayed you.”
Jethro sat in thought with his arms crossed.
Of all those from his mercenary days, Byurk alone remained most loyal to him.
He doubted Byurk would ever betray him, but he could not be certain.
There was more at play than Jethro knew.
That could be the only answer.
But Byurk was not part of Jethro’s past--he was a current captain under Jethro’s command--so Keeya’s warning made little sense.
“Basara also personally guards her,” Keeya said, knowing Jethro’s thoughts.
Now Jethro made the connection.
Both Byurk and Basara were members of his hunter mercenary party, and it appeared that they were cooperating together.
“From your memory, she is equal to you in power, but that was over a year ago.
There is no telling who of you the stronger now is.
In addition, a pack of lycon--”

Jethro’s mind flashed to the smiling memory of his wife, a caring and compassionate woman who endured hardship with love, the woman to whom he was eternally bound both in life and death, one who was part lycon.
“--ould you remove your feelings and kill lycon to capture her?” Keeya continued, although Jethro missed part of her explanation.
For the first time, she saw mild distress in Jethro’s eyes.
“To kill the one you seek, you may have to kill your longing for your past.
Can you?”
Chapter 21
“Cold Feet in Warm Waters”
The Afarit were a peculiar people.
Although they lived in the ruins of the ancient city, they did not seem to live there.
They did not decorate nor adorn their chosen abodes.
They never embellished the ruins of their city as Revlan had.
Their attitude towards the ruins of the ancient civilization was one of reverence, not reform.
They slept where the ground and ruins enabled them to do so.
They cooked communally in open clearings that had existed from ancient days.
Sparse arid plants grew freely in the soil where nature let their roots take hold, and those that were edible were nourished to be harvested where they held.
Not even a single stone that had crumbled onto the road long ago was moved from where it lay.
Where dryads lived in harmony with nature, the Afarit lived in harmony with the past.
The city ruins grew in size and density as it neared the center, becoming a crumbling maze of shattered ruin along the many tiers of the city.
Only the widest of roads remained clear enough to walk.
The heat grew the closer to the city center that Ceil, Justin, Chloe, and Basara walked despite being in the shade of the towering earthen crown.
The ruins never touched the crown but crumbled into a deep crevice of molten lava over three-hundred yards wide from steep cliff to steep cliff.
The river of fire itself was not even a quarter the width, but the crevice was such a staggering depth that on the night before when standing on the edge of the caldera the glow was not visible.
At least that kept the heat from growing as unbearable as the fire wastes.

“No one knows at what point the Afarit came to claim the ruins after the fall of the ancient civilization, but their community is many times older than the Amelian Empire,” Basara said as she showed them where they could wash, find food, and barter for basic necessities.
“I fled here before I was even a year old,” she explained at length when Justin grew curious about how Basara knew her way around the city so well.
“When other maenads learned that my mother was harboring a human--my father--they came for him.
Like all nymphs, males are very rare among maenads.
In a fit of jealousy and rage, my mother killed my father before other maenads could claim him.
I was young at the time and had no control of my emotions either.
I had an unhealthy infatuation with my father, so I killed my mother in revenge and fled.
The Afarit took me in and taught me how to survive, and once I could manage on my own, I lived as a hunter mercenary ever since.”
Basara chuckled lightly.
“I did not understand my mother’s feelings back then, but now that I have Zose, I do.
I would never let anyone take him from me.”
“Would you do the same as your mother?” Ceil asked, mildly worried for Zose.
“Never.” Basara’s lips widened into a sly grin.
“I only have to kill the other party trying to claim him.”
Chloe chuckled.
“When did you first meet Jethro,” Ceil asked as she picked through ornamental tassels arrayed on leather spread across the ground.
“This matches your hair,” the elderly craftswoman said in broken Elven as she lifted an intricate braid of wheat-blond hair with interwoven darkwood beads and red-dyed feathers.
Ceil retrieved it, and after inspecting it lightly, she set it back on the leather.
She had nothing to barter, and she felt such adornments were wasted on her, but her interest in the ornament did not go unnoticed.
“A gift,” the woman stated, lifting the braid to Ceil again.
Chloe quickly thanked the woman and claimed the braid.

When Ceil thought Chloe would tie it to her own hair, thinking it fit Chloe far better, Chloe tied the cord high around a lock of hair on the side of Ceil’s head letting it dangle in front of her ear.
Basara then knelt before the woman and cut a lock off the end of her own hair about six inches in length to give back to the woman.
As the hair sat in the woman’s hands, it faded to pristine white like a perfect diamond.
The woman encased the hair gently in her fingers and brought it to her chest with a bowed head.
“I thought the tassel was a gift,” Ceil said as they continued walking.
She toyed with her tassel between her fingers as she spoke.

“She never expected a gift in return,” Basara explained, “but by giving her a lock of nymph hair, she could create an ornament of far greater appeal than the one she gifted, showing to her that our gratitude for the beauty of her gift was far greater than how she originally valued it.
To the Afarit, gifts increase in value through giving.

By giving that tassel to you, her hope was that it would no longer be an item to be bartered but something you would treasure, and perhaps at some point in the future you would pass it to another, telling the tale from whence it came, its value increasing even further through the growth of its own history.
There could be no greater joy for a craftsperson of the Afarit.
I expect that once she creates an ornament from my hair, she will give it to another without requesting payment, passing my gift forward.”
“For all the talk of tribute and payment yesterday, I had thought they would be far more materialistic,” Ceil replied.
Basara smiled warmly.
“Have you seen a single grain of gold or precious metal in all the city?
No, the tribute is not to increase the wealth of the Afarit nor does it reach Bydrofe.
The Guardian of Whinhlem has no need for material possessions, and the values of the Afarit differ greatly from other materialistic races.
The entire purpose of the tribute is to show how much you personally are willing to sacrifice for the honor of meeting Bydrofe.

That is why we thought to use the bounty, because although the treasures of Amel are no longer yours to give, for them to claim it, you would need to surrender yourself to your enemy to imprisonment, torture, and possible death.
There is no greater gift than your own life for the opportunity to meet Bydrofe.

Also, by Zose and me relinquishing our collection of your bounty and Byurk’s willingness to use the bounty to allow you to meet Bydrofe in betrayal of his own nation, we are showing the level of our own convictions on your behalf.
“However, you must be careful with your offering.
If you offer your life for the opportunity to meet with Bydrofe, Hain-henel will comply by killing you once you return.
An agreement is binding to the Afarit, and it can never be rescinded.
Should you gain the opportunity to speak with Bydrofe by offering yourself to Tolmyur, the Afarit will personally see to it that you are surrendered to them.
Should you resist in any way, this city will become your enemy.
Only Bydrofe himself can free you from your payment.”
“I see…” Ceil realized that had she answered Lord Hain-henel with conviction, he might have given permission immediately.
His final statement was likely to say Ceil still had time to prove how much she desired to meet Bydrofe.
Her first task was finding how to prove it.
She did not want to surrender herself to Jethro if she could avoid it.
Another payment was preferable, but she had nothing else to offer but her life.
“And about your question concerting Jethro,” Basara began, but Ceil cut her off.
“It is fine.
Had you desired to answer it, you would have already.
I was foolish to ask.”
“Thank you,” Basara replied, breathing slowly and deep with sorrow tinting her eyes.
“Is that the feast preparations?” Justin asked in English looking ahead to a large, rectangular, city square sat at the edge of the deep ravine.
The space was open save eleven pillars unique and distinct from each other that dotted an inner circumference.
A small rectangular altar sat atop a low circular platform on the side facing the ravine.
Byurk stood alone by the alter inspecting it while two rather tall afarit stood guard.
No small number of Afarit was arranging woven baskets on large rugs.
Others lined pillows of a myriad of colors on the largest of the rugs, coordinating colors and patterns of both the rugs and cushions.

Seven large bonfires lit one after another, and the rare and extremely valuable wood quickly succumbed to the heat of the flames, creating beautifully black coals under the management of skilled firekeepers.
The coals were then cooled to wait for the moment the meal would be prepared.
The lingering smoke in the air bore a hardy flavor that Ceil imagined would beautifully season whatever was cooked above the coals.
Metal grates were sat atop the coals balanced in the corners by intricately carved ceremonial stones.
None took notice of Ceil’s party watching the arrangements at length and kept to their individual tasks as if unnaturally compelled for excellence.
“The welcome will be grander than I expected,” Basara said with mild joy.
“You are the late emperor’s widow, so it must be out of respect for your connection as a member of the family possessing the longest-held contract with the Afarit of all the races on the continent.”
“How long has Amel been pilgrimaging to meet Bydrofe?” Ceil asked.
“It is never much of a pilgrimage.
From what I know, the royal family simply teleports directly to the rim of the caldera.
You might be the first of the house of Amel since before the founding of the empire to walk here.”
“Amel has been meeting Bydrofe before the empire was created?” Chloe asked.
“I am not too sure of all the history.
A single man, Amel, was the first among the elves to meet Bydrofe and gained favor with him, eventually leading to the establishment of the Amelian Empire after several generations.”
“The Amelian Empire was created because of Bydrofe?” Justin asked, amazed.
“No, the Amelian Alliance was first created out of fear of the humans that once held the more fertile territories now owned by the elves.
Alone, the humans were too great, but with the combined strength of the elves, trolls, spriggans, fairies, sirens, pixies, and dryads, the balance of power swayed far into the alliance’s favor.
It is my speculation that the elves created the alliance with the intent of eventually driving the humans from the more fertile lands, because it was they alone who did so.
Some of the other races in the alliance even supported letting the humans join the alliance or were otherwise opposed to the elven aggression.
The humans could not fight back for fear of the overwhelming power of the alliance crushing them outright.
Not long after the humans were driven out and the bounty of their lands was claimed by the elves did the elves gain enough power to found an empire with the Amel house at the head.”
The light of realization lit behind Justin and Chloe’s eyes, making Ceil nervous.
She knew in part of this history from what Basara had already told her but held it back from Justin and Chloe, unsure how they would react if they learned the truth.
Guilt weighed on her heart.
“Tolmyur can hold quite a grudge,” Justin said in English with a mournful glance at Ceil.
He too realized that there was little need for such a longstanding hate between the two nations if it happened so long ago in ages past.
Ceil’s heart felt ease knowing her friends would not blame her for the crimes of her ancestors.
“Do you know who was opposed to the elves attacking the humans?” Justin asked Basara.
“Not for certain,” Basara admitted, “but I do know the trolls and sirens supported the invasion with food and other resources.

Once the empire was formed, the sirens were rewarded the freshwater sea in the southern empire, and the trolls were given the verdant mountains south of Fiorrae so that they no longer had to struggle for survival in the volcanic lands at the west of the empire.”
“Why is Jethro after Ceil?” Chloe asked.
“She was the emperor’s wife, but the empire is gone.”
“Jethro was wronged by the royal family,” Basara explained simply.
“His is a personal grudge, and with his power and influence, he brought all of Tolmyur into it, feeding Tolmyur’s festering anger at the Coastal War and past grievances.
I fear that until all the royal family is gone, he will not relent.
Ceil is a victim of the current Amelian family, just like Jethro is.
I wish he knew this.”
“Is there no way to reconcile?” Ceil asked.
“I do not even know how Jethro was wronged.”
Basara held her hand to her mouth as if ill, and for the first time Ceil saw in the powerful woman a flicker of weakness.
Basara knew, and the knowledge of what transpired troubled Basara deeply.
Ceil’s heart sank.
She understood that look, the faint pain in Basara’s eyes.
“You… You feel Jethro’s actions are justified,” Ceil spoke softly.
Basara breathed slow and deep.
“No, that is not completely true.
I support his actions against the royal family and would even have aided him in claiming the head of the first princess, but he has taken this war too far, and he has no reason to target your life.”
“What did Eydis do!
?” Ceil screamed, but Basara remained silent, aggravating Ceil further.
“If you will not tell me, I will order Byurk to explain everything.”
Ceil marched off with Chloe and Justin quickly following, trying to calm her down.
Basara leaned back against the crumbling wall along the border of the open square.
She felt guilty keeping silent, but she could not allow Ceil to waver here.
Jethro would not stop, and any sympathy from Ceil would only make her capture or death easier for him to accomplish.
She breathed out a long sigh.
Two arms appeared from the wall and wrapped gently around her, and Zose’s head popped out to rest on her shoulder.
“You are far too considerate at times,” he said, leaning his cheek against hers.
Basara pulled Zose out from the wall, and he stood beside her, their arms interlocked.
“Ceil will find no answers from Byurk.
I alone know the truth, unless Jethro and Byurk’s mutual trust had grown substantially in the time I have been away.
It is not something Jethro would ever talk about unless absolutely necessary.
I doubt he has revealed the truth to anyone.”
“Can you tell me?”
Basara leaned over and whispered into Zose’s ear.
Zose’s back slid down the wall until he sat on the rough, arid grass, his elbows on his knees and his fingers irritably massaging his temples.
“Ceil can never learn of this.
She worships Eydis.
If this is the truth, it would destroy her.”
“Your holiday is over.
The time for rest has passed.
This is your final chance to prove yourself.
We capture that cowardly widow tonight!”
Jethro watched as Captain Mackrum inspired the soldiers as about fifty-thousand prepared for departure.
The former lieutenant was yet too inexperienced to be a captain, but with the need for leadership, Jethro trusted he would grow into his role.
“Are you sure you do not want to send the army into the Afarit?” Keeya asked in Jethro’s mind.
She had originally volunteered to send his army directly into the city.
“No, the perimeter is fine.
We do not have the power to come as invaders.
We will announce our arrival like all others must.”
“The widow may flee.”
“I do not think so.
She has not met Bydrofe yet, correct?
If she flees into hiding, she will lose her chance.
And I trust you can find her if she does.
She can no longer hide from us.
The pursuit ends tonight.”
“Are you sure you are able to do what is needed?”
“Yes,” Jethro answered without any waver in his conviction.
“When my soldiers are ready, I will send them to the city walls for you to teleport them to the borders of the Afarit.”
“Act quickly.
You cannot let the widow convince Bydrofe to act against you.
No matter what you do or what happens, you must avoid meeting Bydrofe.”
Jethro felt an immense pressure from Keeya’s final words.
This was not a warning but an order.
Ceil sat disgruntled on a thick rug in the festive square.
She learned nothing from Byurk, and she had no way to know if he simply did not know about what Eydis did to Jethro or if he refused to answer her inquiry.
“Don’t worry about it,” Chloe beamed.
“We know Eydis is not the type of person to do something atrocious.
Enjoy the party.” She passed a goblet of chilled wine into Ceil’s hands.
There was no ceremony to the feast.
No welcome was held, and Ceil was not presented before the people.
The party was simply a banquet where a couple hundred Afarit gathered to eat, converse, and dance around the numerous pillars of the square.
The only courtesies shown to Ceil and her group were higher-quality rugs and cushions and their own personal fire pit and firekeeper to provide food.
“You are a guest, not royalty,” Zose had explained just before the feast began.
Ceil eyed the wine in her chilled goblet.
She had already eaten her fill, so there was little else to do but imbibe a little here and there.
Like the land, the wine had a sharp fire even when cold while simultaneously being soothingly warm and smooth.
It was quite the confusing mix.
“It’s like if cayenne and cinnamon had a baby,” Justin said when he took a sip after seeing Ceil’s perplexed reaction to the drink.
“Your explanation means nothing to me when you use words unique to your world,” Ceil replied.
She took another sip.
“Do not pass out early this time.
I prefer to have a conversation partner.”
Justin smiled ruefully, remembering how quickly he succumbed to wine at the lycon feast.

“How about you go dance,” Chloe suggested, pointing to the nearest pillar crafted like stacked spheres wound in stone vines; although the top had long fractured and was lost to time, so no one could know what the top of the pillar once looked like.
“You can feel free,” Ceil replied after another light sip.
Chloe smiled and shook her head.
She stood and grabbed Benab’s hand, pulling him away from his meal.
As Chloe passed Justin, Ceil heard her whisper, “get her to dance,” before dragging the startled spriggan to the pillar.
“I am fine without dancing,” Ceil told Justin before he could muster any thoughts towards that end.
“She means well,” he replied.
“I know that much.”
They watched Chloe stumble over the intricate taps and stamps to the hollow stone drums and bone and metal flutes.
The upbeat yet eerie tune carried well over the banquet clamor.
Benab knew the dance and instructed Chloe for the woman’s part.
In further bewilderment, Ceil watched as Chloe picked up the rhythm all too quickly.
“Is there anything she cannot do?”
Justin only smiled.
Ceil watched Chloe’s vibrancy as she spun, changed partners, and fully enjoyed the festivities.
But the longer she watched, the more she noticed a hollow emptiness to Chloe’s smile like a hidden pain.
It was then that she realized she had seen this before, what felt like forever ago back in Lemi’s village.
Chloe wrestled with the Melian children to put her mind and heart at ease or perhaps to draw her thoughts away from her troubles and worries about arriving in a new and unfamiliar world.
Back then, Ceil questioned if she should join Chloe in wrestling with the children.
Again, she questioned if she personally had the right to partake in any form of joy.
She looked to the side.
Justin too was smiling, but the pain she saw behind the façade was much deeper than Chloe’s.
She did not take long to think of the reason.
If Sammy was here, she would have pulled Justin in to dance.
If Eydis was here, she might have asked Justin to dance.
Guilt gripped tight in Ceil’s chest, and anxiety made her back shiver despite the drowning heat.
Her hand shook, but in a burst of will, she grabbed Justin’s wrist and pulled him to his feet.
“Dance with me,” Ceil said, much to Justin’s astonishment.
She pulled Justin not to the nearest pillar but the one beside it with the fewest dancers near the circular platform and altar.
They stood a bit further off to not be in the way of the other dancers.
The heat from the nearby crevice was a bit stronger, making Ceil sweat, or perhaps the reason for her sweating was her anxiety.
She did not want to do this, but she knew she would feel worse had she done nothing after seeing Justin watching the pairs dance.
Ceil swallowed her inhibitions and positioned Justin in front of her.
“This is one of the oldest dances, so most everyone knows it.
The beat is three-five-three-seven-three-five-seven.
For the masculine part, the steps for the three-beats are syncopated,” she explained quickly, hoping that Justin would understand without her needing to explain further.
Justin’s confusion was directed not at the complicated stepping but something unrelated to the dance.
“How did you learn English?
How do you know what syncopated means?
I doubt Eydis in all her studying ever encountered that word.”
“Its translation is a common word in Elven,” Ceil began to explain, but her voice trailed off.
After a moment of silence, she continued.

“I did not realize until Sammy could speak every language that the reason I understood the sprite tongue, English, so well was likely because the Sprite Arkhon did the same to me as he did to her, but only for English and slowly over time so I wouldn’t notice.
He probably did that so I could speak with Sammy and Chloe and you when you all arrived.
They knew you would come to Fiorrae, after all.
Now that I think about it, Eydis learned the sprite tongue, but it did not sound like English.
Perhaps they only started speaking English once I arrived in Fiorrae.
That is certainly something the Sprite Arkhon would do.”
Ceil’s eyes diverted from Justin and caught Chloe and Benab watching them.
Chloe smiled and turned back to continue dancing.
“Enough of that.
Back to the explanation.” She showed Justin the masculine stamps and movements first and then had him repeat.
When he repeated, she answered with the feminine accompaniment.
Justin’s skill was horrid, and Ceil did little to hide the frustration leaking onto her face.
“Sorry,” Justin said.
“I have two left feet.”
“An odd phrasing,” Ceil replied as she showed him his part once again.
“I assume it comes from stepping with your left foot when you should your right?”
“I think that’s where it comes from,” Justin smirked, finally succeeding in his first syncopated stamp.
Ceil nodded in approval.
They could now at least dance in part.
Ceil watched the other dancers in-between instructions and could not help but notice the joy on everyone’s face, joy she did not feel in return.
The music was a little different, mostly in instrumentation, but the dance was still the same as what was used during festivals at her childhood village.
Her mother taught her the dance almost as soon as she could walk.
Festivals were a reason for merriment amid the hardships caused by the drought, even if there was no reason for celebration due to the lack of a harvest.
Still, Ceil had vivid memories of the genuine smiles of the villagers.
Everyone forgot about the drought for an evening and danced their sorrows away.
Even now, Ceil felt the calm that accompanied nostalgia, brought upon by the festivities.
“Is there a similar saying to ‘two left feet’ in Elven?” Justin asked after noticing a small change in Ceil’s demeanor, hoping to get her to speak more and open up.
“Hilm-mer-fer-mel.
It is a nonsensical label roughly meaning ‘to mistake one’s tail for one’s leg.’”
Justin laughed lightly.
They finished their first full pattern, and Ceil nodded again in mild approval.
“Sounds like someone falling backwards,” Justin continued.
“The label is usually meant for someone who is clumsy and trips often, but it is also applied to those poor at dance.”
Just as Ceil finished speaking, Justin missed a step and tripped over Ceil’s leg as she extended it to where Justin should have cleared.
He fell on his butt and shook his head.
“I don’t have a tail, so what does this make me?”
A swift breath escaped Ceil’s lips, almost a hiccup, but when Ceil realized that it was the faintest of a chuckle, she felt as if a knife was plunged into her heart.
She stepped back as guilt weighed on the knife, driving it deeper.
Her body shook with unrestrained anxiety.
Tears fell down her cheeks.
She receded further and then fled.
“Ceil!” Justin called, greatly confused, but Chloe was there beside him before he could chase.
“You were perfect,” she said, patting him once on the shoulder.
“Leave the rest to me.”
Ceil did not know where to run or why she was even running.
Her arms stiffened around her chest.
A painful tingle spread across her shoulders, neck and back.
She quickly jumped up a crumbling wall to the empty second story of one of the ruins where most of the floor aside from near the walls had long crumbled.
She sat in a dark corner and tried to calm down, but her efforts only made her breathing grow more erratic.
She began to hyperventilate, and before she could suppress the sudden onset of nausea, she vomited on the floor in front of her.
She did not know what was wrong with her, and that fear broke out the first of many silent and strained sobs.
Her arms felt locked, crossed over her chest, and she could not move them.
She curled over, staring at her sick unable to do anything more than cry.
“Ceil,” Chloe called as she struggled to climb the wall Ceil had so nimbly scaled.
When she saw Ceil’s pitiful state, she rushed over.
“Sorry, I did not think you would be this bad.”
“What were you trying to accomplish!
?” Ceil squealed, barely able to finish her statement before vomiting again.
“I only wanted you to have some fun.
I didn’t think you would react that way…” Chloe knelt down beside Ceil and held back her hair.
“Breathe slowly, in then out.
Follow me.
In, then out.”
Ceil resisted Chloe’s coaching at first but slowly and after some time she managed to control her hyperventilation.
“I do not deserve fun… or happiness,” she finally said as her mind began to clear, but her words twisted the knife in her heart, bringing back the tears and sobs she fought to keep from escaping.
“Of course you do!” Chloe scolded.
“You have as much right as anyone, especially after everything you’ve been through.”
“Everything that has happened because of me--” Ceil began but cut herself off knowing Chloe would just counter by saying none of it was her fault.
“If happiness feels this horrible now, I do not want it…”
Chloe gently rubbed Ceil’s back as Ceil knelt, bent over like a wilted reed.
“Like dipping your frozen toes in warm water,” she replied.
“When in the cold for so long, your toes grow numb.
You can’t really feel it because you get used to the numbness.
Afterwards when you dip them in warm water, they hurt a lot.
The sting might be unbearable at first, but the thing is, the cold is harmful and the warm water, even though it hurts, is healthy.
And it only hurts at first.
Once you get used to the warmth again, it feels good.”
Ceil understood quickly.
“You wanted Justin to be the warm water.”
“I wanted the dancing to be, sort of.
I wanted you to do something fun.
It’s just that when Sammy and Justin were together in the past, she would always talk about how Justin had this knack for spontaneously making her laugh because of how awkward or clumsy he is.
I thought putting him and dancing together would be enough to make you smile… and you did.”
Ceil lifted her head and looked up at Chloe.
Chloe’s smile was warm like a loving mother.
“There is nothing wrong with being happy.
In fact, you need happiness more now than ever.
That’s all I was trying to do.
Sorry for making you uncomfortable.
Are you okay now?”
Ceil assessed her breathing.
Her nausea had passed, and the pain was gone.
Whatever emotional trauma her body broke under was over for now.
“We should return to the banquet before others worry.
Here.” Chloe lifted the hem of her gown and was about to wipe Ceil’s mouth.
“No, do not soil Basara’s gown like that,” Ceil quickly warned, knowing Basara’s distaste for anything filthy.
She undid her bind in the back and used the end of the thin cloth to wipe her face.
A spark flashed above the empty, broken floor, and a wisp of flame appeared hovering in the air.
It quickly took the form of a small body.
“An emergency,” a sharp tenor voice called.
“Jethro is in the Afarit!”
“A flame sprite?” Chloe asked in shock.
“Jethro is here?” Ceil shouted back.
In the distance at the rim of the caldera visible from almost anywhere in the city except the lowest tiers, a flare burst into yellow and green.
“Tolmyur’s colors,” Ceil said with fear tinting her voice.
A deal had not yet been struck with the Afarit.
She needed to meet Bydrofe now.
Back in Fiorrae, the sprites were in a panic.
“Jethro was never supposed to be there.
Why did we not see it?” One sprite asked.
“Wasn’t he supposed to still be on Earth?” Another followed.
The panic spread to the children rescued from Vallen, and a small number of the youngest began crying.
“She held him as long as she could without causing greater interference with our predictions,” the Arkhon replied, seemingly unperturbed compared to the other sprites around him.
“But we are already blind,” Ephora retorted.
“Because you told them that Jethro was vital for the future,” the Arkhon quipped.
“She did not want to make it worse.”
“Why do you seem so happy about this?” Ephora found the Arkhon’s twisted smile sickening.
“How can you take independent action without consequence, but I cannot?”
“I am still bound by the same laws as you,”  he laughed.
“Most of my interference is in preparation for futures we do not see.”
“But if we do not see them, then they shouldn’t happen,” Ephora grumbled.
“How did this happen, and how did we not see it before my blunder?”
“Can you think of nothing?”
Ephora’s eyes narrowed, and she vanished.
The Arkhon followed and appeared in a grove with the remains of a body suspended in the air.

The skeletal structure of a human was at its core, but the rest of the body was perfectly dissected, each piece of tissue down to the individual nerves were separated and suspended as if in a cloud of flesh.
“Sammy is dead,” Ephora protested once the Arkhon arrived.

“She could not have caused this.” Every day since Sammy’s corpse was brought to Fiorrae, Ephora had examined the body for clues as to why Sammy was invisible to sprite foresight, but so far, she had found nothing.
“The answer is quite simple.
Not only are her immediate actions invisible to us, but the expanding ripples of those actions too remain unseen.
Think, what is the largest difference between our current present and what we had predicted?”
“Keeya is a hamadryad,” Ephora realized quickly.
“She helped Jethro find Ceil.”
“Exactly,” the Arkhon exclaimed gleefully.
“You knew this would happen!
What are you plotting!
“Nothing, if you will believe me.
I am simply curious how this will all unfold.”
“You are lying,” Ephora said with a glare, her hands on her hips.
The Arkhon spread his arms in a welcoming gesture.
“Read me.
I will hide nothing.”
“I refuse,” Ephora replied.
“One of your power could devour me if I tried.”
“I would hardly do something so uncouth,” the Arkhon laughed.
“In any case, we have no choice but to see how Jethro’s involvement in the Afarit changes things.
I am hoping for a good show.”
Chapter 22
“The Beckoning of Death”
Zose appeared from the wall beside Ceil shortly after the fire sprite’s announcement of Jethro’s arrival.
“Zose, I must meet with Hain-henel,” Ceil said after her brief surprise.
“Where is he?”
“You must get armored first,” Zose ordered.
“I did not expect Tolmyur to be here for another thirty-two days at least.
If Tolmyur is here, Jethro might be also.”
“He is.
This sprite told me,” Ceil said, but when she turned back to the sprite, he was gone.
“I must speak with Hain-henel,” she repeated.
Zose pulled Ceil to where the outer wall had crumbled and helped her down.
Chloe slowly followed.
“Tolmyur does not have a visitation agreement with the Afarit, so they might conduct business with them at the perimeter for a time.”
“I will speak with Hain-henel during that time,” Ceil answered.
They returned to the large square to see it far more crowded than before.
The music and dancing had ceased.
Already a procession was starting from the south end of the square as Afarit lined the wide road lighting flames in their hands.
Ceil realized that this square was the origin of the lit path she saw upon her arrival.
At the back of the square, Hain-henel stood by the altar.
Ceil broke from Zose’s grasp and weaved her way through the dense crowd.
Zose sank into the ground to follow after her while Chloe met up with Justin to explain what happened.
“Lord Hain-henel,” Ceil called.
She bowed when she approached, using that time to think of something she could say or offer to him to prove her conviction to meet Bydrofe.
Nothing came to mind other than Zose and Basara’s original plan.
It was all she had, so it was all she could give.
“I must meet with Bydrofe.
I will offer myself to Tolmyur after, but you must let me see him before Jethro enters the city.”
“When a guest calls, we answer without delay.
We must abide our laws,” Hain-henel replied without care for Ceil’s plight.
Zose rose from the ground beside Ceil.
“Lord, you must understand, if Tolmyur enters the city, they will claim Ceil before she has a chance.
Jethro is here for her.”
Ceil looked behind and saw that the procession was already near the border of the city as more and more lights dotted the road in the distance.
Soon they would climb the miles of slope up to the rim of the caldera.
Hain-henel stepped down from the circular platform and took his place at the back of the procession.
“Is there no way we can reach an agreement,” Zose pleaded.
Hain-henel looked back to Zose, his eyes unwavering.
“Did you send word to Tolmyur that Ceil would be here for them to claim?”
“I did, but for the purpose of using that agreement as compensation for Ceil’s audience with the Guardian of Whinhlem.”
“Do they know of this?”
“No,” Zose replied honestly.

“Whatever your true purpose may have been, you entered a contract with Tolmyur to present Ceil, and you must abide.” Without further argument, Hain-henel followed the back of the procession through the square.
Ceil paced pensively around the altar.
“Is there another way to meet him?
How do the Afarit arrange a meeting?”
“The pathway must be opened by Hain-henel or the Guardian of Whinhlem himself,” one of the large Afarit guarding the altar replied.
“None else knows the way.”
“The altar is the entrance, but no one knows how to use it but them,” Byurk said as he hopped up onto the circular platform.
He awkwardly carried Ceil’s plated jack under his arm and handed it to Zose.
“They let me freely inspect it earlier, but I was not able to understand it.
I have only seen one such alter before in Melia, but it was in a far worse state.
There are ven channels woven through the stone, so I expect it is an enchantment of some form.
Few have learned the craft.
I tried channeling my ven into it but to no effect.
Jethro might be the only other who could understand it.”
“And that is not an option,” Zose replied as he finished lacing up Ceil’s jack.
The thick fabric was unbearable in the heat, but Ceil understood that the resfahil plates interlaced within were her only true protection.
“Do I hide?” Ceil asked.
“I doubt that will be possible.
The Afarit know I sent for Tolmyur, and they will require me to surrender you to them.
If I betray that agreement, we make enemies of the city.
Agreements are binding here.”
Basara arrived with the rest of their party.
The Lycon took stance, surrounding the circular platform in the now far less crowded square to guard Ceil.
Chloe took her place in front, ready to fight for her friend if needed, and Justin stood beside Ceil to activate his time magic at a moment’s notice.
Thanysa, Hethyro, and the last High Elf stood at the head of the lycon perimeter.
Benab was missing, but Ceil understood that he was likely hidden in one of the nearby ruins to make use of his archery.
