Kiri, her faintly glowing translucent wings unfurled, hovered above the group to spy out threats from her higher vantage.
They would protect Ceil no matter the cost.
“Once Jethro is welcomed into the city, I will speak to him first on your behalf,” Byurk said.
He jumped down from the altar and stood at the end of the procession, not far in front of Chloe.
The few remaining soldiers under his command followed.
“Is it smart to let him speak first?” Justin asked.
“I do not know,” Ceil replied.
She was unsure how much she could trust Byurk now that his commander had arrived, but Basara did not speak against his proposal, so perhaps his intentions were true.
From the side of the square, a pair of afarit  escorted Benab to the altar platform from wherever he was perched, and another led both Tyree and Tae as well.
It seemed that all in Ceil’s party must be present for the discussions.
Both Benab and Tae’s bows had been confiscated but were returned once they reached the platform.
The afarit would allow no hidden threats.

Unlike the quick extinguishing of the lights when Ceil failed to satisfy Hain-henel’s demands for proof of her conviction, the lights at the tip of the path to the city flew into the air one-by-one as Tolmyur was led to the city.
Whatever the conversation had been, a deal was struck between Jethro and Hain-henel.
Ceil watched in agonizing anticipation, unsure of what would unfold should they meet.
She had only seen Jethro once before.
Memories of his brutal execution of the young girl posing as her in the Gallanvale repeated over and over in her mind.
Basara professed Jethro mad, and how could anyone confront or reason with a madman who held such power?
Ceil felt a chilling grip on her shoulder.
The skeletal hand returned and beckoned her to use his power.
She shook the horrid vision from her mind, but the overwhelming anxiety never faded.
It only grew stronger.

She would soon meet her enemy from whom she had fled all these many days, and enemy whom even if she had the power to kill, she could not, because his survival was necessary to the future, just like hers.
The approaching horde was like a death march, the rhythmic steps of the thousands of soldiers now entering the city like the grinding of an executioner sharpening his blade.
Ceil wanted to run.
Every nerve in her body told her to run.
She no longer had time to meet Bydrofe.
She would be handed over to Jethro to death or worse at the hands of his men.
Justin steadied Ceil’s trembling hand.
“I won’t let him have you,” he said without a waver in his voice.
“None of us will.”
Instead of comfort, Justin’s words terrified her more.
He did not hear the exchange between Zose and Hain-henel.
If Justin or Chloe or anyone protected her, not only Tolmyur but all the Afarit would rise against them.
She was not protected in a city surrounded by multiple stone walls like Revlan.
She no longer had an army to guard her.
Ceil knew that hope had faded and was lost.
Her greatest fears were a repeat of Sammy’s sacrifice.
All those promising to protect her would die.
“If I must surrender myself to Jethro, do not interfere,” she ordered Justin.
“He is here for me alone to satisfy Zose’s agreement to collect the bounty.
So long as you do not act, I do not think the Afarit will let anyone else come to harm.”
“You know I cannot--”
“This is not like it was in Revlan,” Ceil hissed.
“Please.
I cannot lose anyone else… Not Chloe, or you.
Byurk and Basara will convince him not to kill… me…”
Ceil’s voice fell silent as she saw Jethro enter from the far end of the square with a few hundred soldiers, and she found herself unable to breathe.
Hain-henel walked on his left.
The rugs, cushions, and all the feast preparations were cleared quickly by many hands.
The remaining Tolmyur soldiers filled the road, extending far back to the edge of the city.
“Tolmyur has arrived on their own errand to meet with Ceil, widow of Emperor Yuro.
Their Commanding General has not received word nor agreement from Ceil’s party for her surrender, so each side is presented as equals in discussion,” Hain-henel announced.
Ceil turned to Zose who was just as confused as she.
This could not be a lie, because if Zose’s message had indeed been received by Jethro, then surely he would have used it to claim Ceil with the blessing of the Afarit.
Both Zose and Basara immediately understood.
Inym was not sent by Jit.
She learned of Ceil’s identity by intercepting the spik Zose released but kept this secret from them.
No doubt it was she who informed Ni’inca Ab’pul and placed them all in peril.
A flicker of anger lit inside Basara, and those near her felt the heat.
“If I ever meet Inym again, I will burn her to ash,” Basara said in a subdued voice.
At least Hain-henel had taken Ceil’s plight into consideration and guaranteed the equality of the two parties.
He must have confirmed Jethro’s motives first without revealing Zose’s assumption about those motives.
For that, Ceil considered herself fortunate, but how long would that fortune last?
Seeing that Ceil would not immediately be surrendered to Tolmyur, Byurk walked forward and stood alone in the center of the square to welcome Jethro.
His men followed after him but continued onward to stand with their fellow soldiers on the far side of the square.
Jethro looked past Byurk to Ceil’s group and the circumference of Lycon guarding her.
“I have personal matters to address first.
It will not take long,” Jethro said to Hain-henel beside him.
“You may oversee the discussions between Tolmyur and the Amel house after it is completed.”
Hain-henel raised his hand, and the Afarit who had guided Jethro and his soldiers into the city moved to surround the square.
Neither Jethro’s soldiers nor Ceil’s party could leave.
Jethro’s hand reached into empty space before him, vanishing at the wrist, and removed a thin whistle.
He blew the sharp note, and Ceil immediately knew from where he received that instrument.
The ambassador of the lycon walked forward past Byurk and met Jethro first.
Byurk turned back to Ceil’s party, to Basara, for an explanation.
He did not know that Jethro was in possession of a lycon whistle.
“We will try to appeal to him first,” Basara told Ceil before she quickly trotted to Byurk.
She crouched beside him, whispering something into Byurk’s ear that Ceil could not hear.
The lycon ambassador embraced Jethro and confirmed the scent.
Ceil hoped that the whistle was ill-gotten and the lycon would become Jethro’s enemies, but from the reaction of the ambassador, that was not the case.
“Friend of lycon, what is it that you ask of us,” the ambassador asked.
“In honor of our favor, I request you not interfere with my dealings here.
I will return the whistle once my business is done,” Jethro replied.
His voice was not an announcement to all but a personal conversation that was barely loud enough to reach Ceil’s ears.
“Though your scent has weakened with time, we would honor your favor if not for Lady Ceil being welcomed as family of lycon,” the ambassador replied.
Jethro’s face twisted in consternation.
He peered past the ambassador to Ceil, sending a cold shiver down Ceil’s back.
There was an immense difference between the favor as a friend of the lycon and as family, and he could not imagine what fortune had enabled her to gain such favor.
“I too am family of the lycon,” Jethro explained to the ambassador.
“One of yours has chosen me as her mate, and although she has passed, I refuse to fine another due to my loyalty to her alone.”
“I do not know your story, only your scent and the whistle you carry.
If what you say is true, then you too would be family.
However, Lady Ceil is the savior of all lycon, and we cannot abandon her.
Should you wish to do her harm, you will become the enemy of all lycon.
Keep your whistle.
If there is another favor you would ask of us, we will accept, friend of lycon.”
Jethro’s eyes met Ceil’s again after the lycon ambassador turned his back to Jethro.
Ceil could not be sure from her distance, but she thought she saw the outward animosity in his gaze increase substantially.
“Is your personal business finished,” Hain-henel asked Jethro.
“It is,” Jethro replied, walking forward to finally meet Byurk and Basara in the center of the square.
Hain-henel stood between the two parties off to the side.
Veins of fire lit in his left leg which he stomped into the ground.
A ring of embers surrounded their group as a sign that what they would discuss should not be interrupted by those outside the circle.
He then stood silent and still to oversee.
“It has been long since we last met,” Basara said to initiate the discussions.
“I am glad to see you well.”
Jethro ignored Basara’s greeting and glared at her.
“You of all people should understand.
Was it your plan to set the lycon as a barrier against me?
Did Elina mean nothing to you?”
Fire lit in Basara’s eyes, but Byurk interceded before Jethro’s misdirected accusation ruined negotiations.
“Do not blame her.
You know just how fond of your late wife Basara had always been.
Our involvement with the lycon came as a direct result of my pursuit of Ceil and the bounty we placed on her head.”
“And you are not against using their favor to hinder me, knowing what you do?” Jethro asked, his calm voice bearing an incredible weight.
“If we must,” Byurk answered.
“And how is it then that my most trusted friend has become my enemy?” Jethro asked Byurk before glaring once more at Basara, directing his blame.
Byurk’s expression softened.
“My actions may make me a traitor to Tolmyur, but I have always been loyal to you, even now.
I only guard Lady Ceil against you because of what I have learned of her fate and future, a future you and her both share.
I will continue to guard her so long as you seek her death.
Basara and I agree to surrender her to you so long as you promise to spare her life.”
“Enough!” Jethro said, and at that same moment, Byurk vanished with a pop, reappearing unharmed in a flash of light next to his soldiers at the entrance to the square.
Byurk was swiftly bound with prepared cords.
Hain-henel stood in front of Jethro.
“I will not permit hostilities between parties,” he warned.
“I apologize, but this is another personal matter.
It is my duty to discipline my officers.
My dealings are not with traitors and betrayers.
I am here to speak with the widow of Emperor Yuro as agreed.”
“General Byurk has formerly stated his conviction on behalf of Ceil by agreeing to receive proper punishment for the betrayal of his country, so I will permit it,” Hain-henel announced.
He then turned to Ceil’s party.
“The commander of all Tolmyur’s armies requests audience with Ceil of the House of Amel.”
Ceil’s hands gripped into fists in a meager attempt to hold in her fear-drenched anxiety.
Her feet felt shackled to the stone alter platform below her.
She could not find the strength to take a step, but neither could she remain silent.
She had learned in the fairy council in the Gallanvale and in the meeting of commanders at Revlan that by remaining silent, others would speak for her and direct her future.
Sammy was right.
She needed to stop waiting to be saved.
She determined her future, no one else.
Ceil took a deep breath.
“Lord Hain-henel, as you saw when Jethro detained Byurk, I would only endanger myself by joining you before Jethro.
No matter what power you may hold to oversee our discussion, Jethro’s magic is more powerful still.
He laid ruin to all of Vallen to find me, throwing away countless of his own soldiers’ lives.
I do not doubt that he would willingly kill me knowing well that the Afarit would see to the destruction of his army.
Jethro alone could escape unharmed with his spatial magic.”
Those near Ceil admired her boldness and foresight to the dangers of approaching Jethro.
They felt the weight of the long pause after her accusation against Jethro bear down on those who heard it.
However, the truth of the pause was far different.
Ceil’s body shivered.
Her breath ran out, and she struggled to refill her lungs.
While her words were true, she only feared approaching her enemy who would see the world to ruin if only he had a chance to kill her.
Jethro wanted to end the line of Amel at any cost.
“And…” Ceil continued with much less force to her voice.
“And I hold no attachment to the Amel name, to an emperor who would see me live in sorrow.”
Ceil gritted her teeth, both in fear and anger.
“I am not Ceil Amel!
I am Ceil FeSeras, sole daughter of Arlen of Seras and Lum of the line of Dharin of Kellendale, Thorn General of Vallen.
I am a daughter of Heivleil, an innocent town you razed for the sole crime of being the home of my childhood!
I was sold by my father to Emperor Yuro to be his possession, not a member of the Amelian line.
Yuro would never allow me, a descendent of fairies, to bear him impure offspring.
If you seek audience with a royal line, you should address the line of Vallen to answer for your unjust genocide of the fairies.
Kiri of the line of Dharin, successor to the throne of Vallen, can then speak with you.”
Ceil took a deep breath, filling her lungs with all the pain she bore and the light of hope that Sammy left her.
“As for me, I will not barter my life with a madman!”
“Jethro, she is also a victim of the royal family,” Basara said, hoping to dissuade Jethro from rash action.
Jethro ignored her.
A wide, dimpled smile spread on his face as he walked forward.
“Jethro, should you leave the circle, your right to negotiation will end,” Hain-henel warned.
Jethro stopped at the edge of the embers.
“Did you not hear her?
She clearly does not want to speak with me.” He then stepped outside the circle.
“The Lord of Contracts, Hain-henel, has born witness here that Ceil has renounced her attachment to the Amel line.
The role of Tolmyur in pursuit of her life is over.
This is Tolmyur’s victory.
At last, we have obtained our revenge for the Coastal War and the crimes of Amel against us.
No one remains on Whinhlem who can continue the Amel name!”
Jethro raised his hands in a halfhearted shrug.
All at once his army cheered with shouts and pounding armor.
Without fanfare or ceremony, the war ended.
Basara watched Jethro saunter forward over the dusty square towards Ceil’s party.
Suspicion wormed its way into her thoughts.
Were negotiations truly over?
Was the answer as simple as Ceil denouncing the Amelian royal line?
Jethro looked over his shoulder at both Basara and Hain-henel and smiled.
“All that remains is my personal feud with Eydis FeAmel.
My actions from here on are my own without connection to Tolmyur.”
No…
Basara raced to catch Jethro, but he vanished.
In the near-imperceptible moment of time that Jethro appeared in a flash of light in front of Ceil, Justin was already moving Ceil behind him to shield her.
Jethro felt the distinct sensation of time magic.
He eyed the young man who was now far more mature than the terrified boy he remembered back on Earth.
Justin’s eyes pierced Jethro with anger, not fear, and Jethro could not help but be impressed.

Jethro had considered killing him to deal a grave emotional blow to Eydis, possibly sending his head to the capital building of that nation where it was sure to be noticed, but the skill of a time mage who disregarded the very laws of the art was too rare a treasure to spoil.
Before Justin finished positioning Ceil behind him, before anyone else in Ceil’s party had the time to react, Justin vanished with a snap.
Jethro sent him where he had initially planned before the sprite’s interference, to Tolmyur and more specifically, Jethro’s home.
Life in Tolmyur was harsh, but Jethro did not worry.
His house servants and Fect would be there to greet him.
If Jethro wanted a head to send to Eydis, there was another candidate now unguarded in front of him, the widow of Emperor Yuro.

The Vallen party and lycon moved immediately to attack Jethro and secure Ceil’s safety, but Jethro grew a barrier around him and Ceil, forcing it outward to push everyone else off and away from the circular altar platform.
At that distance it held, preventing anyone from interfering.
The two large afarit who guarded the altar landed on their feet and backed away from the altar platform toward the deep ravine unperturbed and unangered.
The afarit at the borders of the square rushed to subdue the Tolmyur army, but none of the soldiers moved.
They remained still, showing that this was, indeed, a personal matter unrelated to them.
The afarit cordoned them off to prevent interference should that stance change in the future.
Ceil jumped back and brandished her staff, knowing well that it would be useless against a mage of Jethro’s quality.
Even Justin’s time magic that was strong enough to freeze and ancient Lurr was useless against him.
Ceil worried what had become of Justin.
“I apologize.
I truly have nothing against you,” Jethro said with a fake sigh.
“Eydis FeAmel, however, was apparently quite fond of you.
Thought of you as family.
For that reason alone, you must die.”
Ceil felt cold despite the heat.
She grew pale as if a titan had his foot raised above her, ready to crush her into the stone.
She wanted to ask what crime Eydis had committed against Jethro to drive him to such madness, but she knew that time had passed the moment she refused discourse.
Ceil felt the darkness return and a painful, bony grip on her shoulder.
She lacked the composure to reject it.
A suffocating beckon met her ears and seeped into her thoughts.
If I am to die to Jethro now, why can I not kill him?
If we both are vital to the future, and one of us will die now anyway, why should it be me?
Did I not find a chance of support after so long?
Did I not smile not long ago?
Why should I give all that up now?
The hamadryad staff in Ceil’s hand blackened, and the air around her grew stale.
Zose launched himself from the stone platform behind Jethro with his bone sword aimed at Jethro’s lower spine.
He knew he should not kill Jethro, but if he could injure him enough to end the attack, Tyree could heal any damage done.
The bone sword hit its mark but failed to penetrate.
It snapped at the tip and heel.
Zose’s incredible momentum he thought would knock Jethro over did nothing against the firm barrier Jethro always had around himself.
Zose collided into the barrier with the full force of his momentum.
His head hid, and the resulting impact knocked him unconscious.
Zose’s limp body bounced back and crumpled to the stone, his right arm and shoulder completely disfigured.
“Zose!” Basara charged the barrier, each step leaving smoldering stone in her furious wake.
Chloe quickly followed with her arms aflame.
Those futilely assaulting the seemingly impenetrable barrier gave a wide birth.
Only Hethyro had courage enough to keep up the assault, not fearing Basara’s flame.
Chloe readied to clap to release a powerful, directed explosion, but Basara syphoned Chloe’s fire, forming it into a massive ribbon that fell like an enflamed guillotine on the barrier.
Jethro’s entire body locked up from the recoil.
He glanced behind him to see what pathetic attack hit his back and who was assaulting the outer barrier.
He expected to see Basara, but not even she had that much power, at least not in his memory.
Ceil swung at Jethro with her staff in his moment of distraction.
Jethro expected the defensive barrier he placed around himself to repel the measly attack, but when the staff struck, the barrier at the location of impact crumbled.
The destruction spread rapidly from the location of impact until his barrier vanished like the shattering of tempered glass.
There was no recoil, no force.
The ven used to construct the barrier simply died.
Jethro vanished and reappeared on the other side of the strange alter, still within the outer barrier.
He quickly breathed off his surprise and shook the feeling back into his arms.
“I was not expecting that,” he said with an exasperated smile.
The young elf was not as helpless as he had assumed.
Behind her, a male oread lay motionless on the stone.
The Earth woman, whose enflamed visage strangely did not pale in comparison to Basara’s, fought alongside Basara to break the barrier.
He did not doubt they could, given enough time.
Ceil, emboldened by his retreat, charged.
“I guess I should take this elsewhere,” Jethro sighed.
He readied a quick transmission formula and cast it on Ceil once she was close enough, but she did not disappear.
Ceil screamed out and collapsed into the altar in her charge.
Her body burned as if it was being eaten away by poison.
She tried to lift herself to defend against her enemy standing on the other side of the altar, but the light exertion caused her to vomit blood.
Life magic told her that her insides were torn in an impossible manner.
She did not know what kind of magic Jethro cast on her, but she knew that she could not recover in time to defend herself.
Her attacker walked leisurely around the alter to stand in front of her with a quizzical stare, but he nearly collapsed as the recoil of Chloe and Basara’s assault seized his body.
“Could you hold off for one moment,” Jethro moaned.
He was sweating heavily from the heat of the barrage that was too hot for his barrier to completely suppress.
He turned back to Ceil and shook his head lightly.
“You are full of surprises, aren’t you.
Enough of this.
Sending Eydis whatever remains should suffice.
She should be skilled enough in life magic to learn it’s you.”
Ceil managed to pull herself to her trembling legs using her staff as a crutch in her right hand.
If she was to die, she wanted to die standing and facing her enemy.
She recognized the form Jethro took.
It was burned into her memory.
She would suffer the same fate as that young Gallanvale girl.
Ceil scowled at Jethro through seeping, bloody lips as he extended his hand.
Spatial magic left Jethro’s hand in an explosive wave, rejecting everything in front of him.
The force of the attack blew Ceil into the alter behind her.
Her back slammed against the top, and she nearly flipped over it.
Her head barely missed hitting the ancient, impervious stone.
There she lay, sprawled on her back widthwise across the altar.
She could not feel her legs or her left arm.
She had shielded her face with the staff in her right hand and her left arm in front of it.
She tried moving her left arm, but nothing happened.
She quickly realized as her body entered shock that her arm was not there.
The fabric of the jack had shredded, revealing the plates of resfahil.
Below, her left leg and part of her hip was missing.
The hamadryad staff infused with death magic had protected her right leg, her right arm, and her head.
The resfahil-plated jack had protected her torso.
Those who had given her their support, the hamadryad and the craftsmen of Revlan, had protected her, but not well enough.
Ceil lost the strength to lift her head.
She did not notice Jethro’s barrier finally breaking or the erupting sounds of battle.
Ceil was conscious enough to know that she was bleeding out and barely coherent enough to use life magic to stem what bleeding she could, but the damage was too severe.
She knew well enough that she would not survive.
Even if Tyree was there trying to treat her, Ceil doubted it would help.
The horrid apparition of the Aspect of Death floated above her.
His faceless expression under his void-like eyes seemed almost to smile.
He reached forward as if beckoning to her, like he had before Sammy pulled her back to the light.
But there was no going back this time.
Already, Ceil felt herself fading.
The Aspect of Death reached, but instead of touching Ceil, he placed his putrid, skeletal hand on the altar.
Ceil felt herself get sucked inward, and she vanished.
Chapter 23
“Bydrofe’s Favor”
Ceil
The encroaching blackness creeping from the edges of Ceil’s vision vanished.
She could see a river of stars far above in the cloudless night, undimmed by the smaller of the two moons in half-wane.
She felt the breeze and heard the rustling of lush plants.
Despite the dark of night far above, inside the mountain crown of the Afarit was bright as noonday as if it had its own sun.
A verdant paradise saturated with ven surrounded her, and for a moment Ceil thought she had returned to Fiorrae.
This land was unnatural, an idyllic garden in the center of the fire wastes.
Fiorrae was a land saturated with ven--every rock, river, and plant was enriched with it--but even the home of the sprites could not compare.
Life ven hung so thick in the air that Ceil felt revitalized.
Solely by existing in this place, she had been pulled momentarily from the grasp of death.
However, the vitality Ceil gained removed the state of shock her body entered to protect her from being overwhelmed by her injuries.
The moment she realized where she was, the garden of Bydrofe, Guardian of Whinhlem, she writhed and screamed, unable to bear the pain.
Something in the garden stirred.
Ceil’s cries summoned the attention of a massive body that rose as he stood, so tall that the curls of his long, black hair nearly reached the rim of the massive, mountainous crown.
He emanated an authoritative power from his presence, not unlike the Sprite Arkhon.
Each step of his refined, godly body that no artist could ever fashion into metal or stone landed in silence without even a tremor.
The plants at his feet moved for him, and the ground cradled his feet.
Bydrofe looked down at the small, writhing girl with pity and sadness.
“Hain-henel sent you to me in such a state?
Child, no harm or injury is worth a meeting,” he spoke in a deep, fatherly voice like being wrapped in a soft blanket.
“To give an arm and a leg… The Afarit should stop accepting such tribute.”
The immense pain Ceil felt slowly ebbed as shock returned to her body.
The surge of vitality from the abundant life ven could only help her so much as close to death as she was.
Ceil’s screams grew to sobs.
She watched the enormous figure she had hoped to meet struggle to sit back down in front of her, although the proximity was an illusion caused by his size; he was still afar off.
Only then did she realize that Bydrofe was injured himself.
This land that was so full of life was his medicine.
It was a place of healing.
Someone of immense power had injured Whinhlem’s guardian.
“Please,” Ceil cried, begging for mercy and hope in her waning minutes.
“Are you the emissary of Amel?
Hain-henel informed me of your arrival and that you lacked tribute.”
Bydrofe looked south to the inner wall of the earthen crown.
“Hain-henel says you have renounced the Amel House that I have spent these many years cultivating.
Though, you are not a direct descendent.
The blood of Amel runs through you as it does through most High Elves who obey my counsel, but it is impure.”
Bydrofe looked to the east, upwards towards the sky.
His calm demeanor vanished.
“Tolmyur has ended the line of Amel.” A deep, calm anger saturated his voice, like distant rolling thunder, and the forest shook.
Once again, Bydrofe faced south.
“Tolmyur’s commander seeks your life.
I chose the elves to succeed humanity when the humans failed and turned against their creators.
The humans have gone too far again.
I showed them mercy by not eliminating their kind when they transgressed the greatest taboo.”
Ceil recalled the story told her on her travels to the Afarit and what she learned from Ni’inca Ab’pul.

It connected with the truth of the history between elves and humans that Basara had told her, her indoctrination in the Amelian Palace, the elven hatred for humanity, and everything else she had seen and learned.
The ancient human civilization had pulled a god from divinity and in return was destroyed.
Bydrofe was that god, and in the battle, he was injured.
He became the guardian of Whinhlem in his weakened state and lost divinity, a powerful entity honored by all except the human races.
Of all the races on the continent, the descendants of humans alone did not have a contract with the Afarit for visitation.
When the first Amel made pilgrimage to the Afarit, Bydrofe chose the elves to succeed the ancient human race.

Bydrofe indoctrinated them with a hatred for humanity and a desire for purity of their bloodline, and so Amel gathered all those who were not descended from the ancient humans to drive out and suppress them.
The elves were Bydrofe’s tool, and after ages passed and the descendants of humanity had no relation to the sins of their forbearers, Tolmyur yet remained the eternal victim of elven cruelty.
“As for you, your blood is impure,” Bydrofe continued.
“I must find another to succeed Amel.
However, out of respect for your courage and conviction, I will have the Afarit purge the city of every descendent of the race of humans.
If Gaea agrees, perhaps we should finally purge them all.”
“No!” Ceil cried with all her waning strength.
The exertion left her weak, and the darkness began creeping in.
Ceil could not die yet.
She had to tell him.
If these were her last words, she had to use them to save the life of her friends, true friends that had pulled her from the darkness of her suffering.
“Not Chloe, not…”
Ceil tried to say Justin’s name, even Basara and Zose who were descendants of the ancient humans, but her weak breath ran out.
She did not know where Justin was, where Jethro sent him, but if he was still somewhere within the city, she wanted him safe as well.
Ceil remembered the Sprite Arkhon’s test, the lesson he wanted her to learn as she traveled with Sammy, Chloe, and Justin through Fiorrae and Melia.
Humans were not her enemy.
Not all humans were evil.
Even if Bydrofe had a deeply rooted hatred for the humans of Whinhlem…
“Chloe…and Justin… not from… Whinhlem.” Ceil managed to finish with the last her body would give.
All the air within the earthen crown’s paradise grew still as if time froze.
Not a leaf rustled or blade of grass bent.
Bydrofe glared down at Ceil with power and authority.
Ceil now saw Bydrofe not as a powerful being that guarded and protected Whinhlem, but as one of Whinhlem’s gods.
His fury was not from a personal grudge against humanity but from the breaking of divine law, the same that brought his judgement against the ancient humans.
“I must purge this infestation before it spreads.”
Bydrofe vanished from the still air, and with his disappearance, the tranquil breeze returned.
A sudden tremor came from the south, and Ceil knew he had appeared on the other side of the crown to kill her friends.
She had made a terrible mistake.
She had only desired to save her friends but instead had doomed them.
Her life truly was a farce.
She was a plague that killed everyone near her, everyone she loved.
Ceil tried to cry out, but her lungs would no longer receive air.
She felt cold.
The contest between death and the enriched life of the garden was over, and death had won.
The shadow of death spread from Ceil to the surrounding foliage.
All the plants grew brittle and slowly crumbled into powder.
The healing ven in the air twisted and became a poisonous miasma that killed all the ven it touched.
Please, save them, Ceil prayed to anyone or anything who would listen.
All light left Ceil and her world grew dark.
The putrid skeletal form stood above her in the nothingness with his arms extended.
She heard not a voice but felt a message within her soul, a part of her that was not her.
“Is that your final wish?”
Ceil could not answer.
Before another thought could trace a path across her worn and tired mind, her body grew still, and rest at last claimed her.
“As frail as this woman is, her will was too strong,” a voice spoke through Ceil’s cold, lifeless lips.
“Resisting until the end.”
Ceil’s body sat up and inspected its surroundings and itself.
It eyed its missing arm and leg with annoyance.
The miasma spread out and consumed all life in the immediate vicinity.
When the miasma returned, the body quickly mended, first from bone and then flesh, but its skin remained a pale, deathly pallor.
It moved the fingers of its regrown hand and found the newly regrown tails extending out from under it.
“Peculiar things,” the voice said, never having had a tail, let alone two, in its past life.
It did not care much for the body, but now that it was in control, it could claim another should the opportunity present itself.
Ceil’s body stood and tested the new leg.
It held firm, stronger than it had ever been in life, but legs could not reach the friends that Ceil held so dear.

Although the revived Aspect of Death held no love for them, he could honor Ceil’s dying wish and save them by confronting his eternal enemies, the gods, of which Bydrofe was one he had failed to kill when he ruled all of humanity on Whinhlem as their God King.
The Aspect of Death drew upon Ceil’s dormant royal fairy bloodline to manifest black-feathered wings that radiated decay from the death ven they were composed of.
With a single grand flap that spread miasma in its wake, the Aspect of Death shot into the air.
Chapter 24
“Divine Judgement”
Members of Ceil’s party watched in fear, anger, and panic as Jethro’s attack blew Ceil back into the altar.
For a moment, time felt frozen as many thought her instantly dead, but the slightest movement of Ceil’s body spurred them to action.
Against all odds, she survived, but if they did not reach her quickly, she would surely die.

Hethyro, who had kept some distance and had assaulted the barrier with fire magic now dove into the heat of Basara and Chloe’s attacks, heat he knew was beyond what his fire affinity was capable of resisting.
He pummeled the barrier using enflamed strikes with all the might his massive, Mountain Elf frame could summon.
Thanysa, who stood at the barriers left perimeter, readied a practiced stance and placed her palm against the barrier.
She was never as strong nor as skilled as her mother, Symra, and her arms were still blackened and weak, but her ven channels and wellpoints remained true.
She waited for the precise moment of Basara and Chloe’s next cleaving attack.
Basara and Chloe’s ribbon of flame, now more akin to a massive blade, cleaved into Jethro’s barrier like an executioner’s axe.
The moment it struck, Thanysa released the disrupting pulse of her stance.
Sparks showered the party as the barrier repelled the attack and spread as far as the afarit who stood guard along the edges of the square.
Kiri barely managed to fly out of the way of the strike.
When all thought the barrier had successfully resisted the assault, Hethyro’s clenched fists shattered what sliver of life the barrier had left.
Basara ignored Jethro and Ceil and fell to her knees beside Zose the moment the barrier fell.
Her love and concern for him quenched her maenad rampage before it could peak.
She almost grabbed him but stopped at the last moment.
In her emotional distress, she was too hot to touch him.
Chloe charged Jethro alone in Basara’s place, but the far swifter Lycon would reach him first.
An arrow released by Benab bounced off Jethro’s shoulder, informing the nearest lycon that Jethro was still protected.
The lycon continued unabated, ready to tear apart this horrid man who had gravely injured and possibly killed both the saviors of the lycon.
Jethro recovered from the recoil fast enough to raise his hand in a motion to strike down his attackers.
Chloe recognized the attack, the same he had once used to try and kill her back in Gullivan and would have succeeded if not for Justin’s time magic.
She heard tales of the attack, that Jethro could sever anything with it.
Chloe was behind the lycon, but that attack would slice through them and her without effort.
She had no way to dodge and quickly prepared her heart for the end.
But, the attack never came.
Jethro hesitated to strike down the lycon.

Kiri dove down to Ceil to secret her away to the two dryads while Jethro was distracted, but once she saw the extent of the damage Jethro had dealt, she knew that Ceil should not be touched for fear of the shock killing her.
Her young cousin who had to bear the weight of the future in the face of an unknown calamity that would soon envelope them all was beyond her ability to help.
“Tyree!” Kiri called to the Melian who was awaiting a safe opportunity to rush to the altar, but before Tyree and Tae could near the altar, light flashed behind Kiri.
Tae collided with a barrier Jethro reformed around him and the altar to keep the lycon and other assailants back.
Kiri looked up at her enemy, questioning how this evil man could ever help them through the calamity.
She had no means to protect herself or Ceil.
She had no magical affinity aside from the flight enabled by her bloodline.
“The last successor to the rebellious Vallen line,” Jethro said, oddly calm despite the opposition against him.

“One day you will look back on your actions here and curse your ignorance, but by then, it will already be too late,” Kiri warned right before Jethro split her in half with a simple swish of his index and middle fingers.
The moment Kiri’s body fell to a bloody heap on the altar platform, Ceil vanished.
Jethro’s eyes grew wide.
In Ceil’s place was a portal he had never seen before, and had he not recognized the distinct feel of teleportation magic, he never would have suspected it to be a portal.
Those outside his outer barrier were likewise surprised and stopped their assault.
Spatial ven rose like threads through a funnel from the top of the platform until they met at a wisp-like sphere of faint rainbow light.
No one had cast the magic; it originated from some enchantment on the altar and altar platform.
There was no perimeter to the portal, no tear or rift cut in space.
The destination was not visible.
Much like Jethro’s transmission formula, it acted solely as the catalyst to move a body from the origin to some destination.
If Jethro understood the sudden disappearance of the widow’s body correctly, contact with the portal was sufficient to facilitate teleportation.
Jethro tried to touch the bizarre portal--those outside his barrier renewed their assault futilely trying to prevent his chase--but the portal repelled him like a barrier had been placed over it.
His brief read of the spatial ven revealed a formula far beyond his comprehension, a complexity not unlike the spatial magic used to block his teleportation on Earth.
He did, however, glean one piece of understanding that made him so excited that he momentarily forgot that his target had escaped through the portal.
The secret to the stability of the portal was the external barrier.

The stability function within a teleportation formula was in essence a barrier applied within to maintain the structure of the portal long enough for the one using it to arrive safely at the destination.
That was why regular transmission did not need a stability function; it was near-simultaneous.
That was not so with this portal that continued to hold itself open with perfect stability, unlike any other portal Jethro knew.
They were all unstable and prone to collapse.
This external barrier was managing the same stability function at a far more advanced level from the outside.
Jethro placed his hand on the external barrier once again and registered the formula to memory the best he could with his infinitesimal understanding of its structure.
He could spend days picking it apart, and that thought excited him to no end.
The only question remaining was why the portal had appeared and where it sent Yuro’s widow.
“Cease all hostilities,” Hain-henel called.
Following the order with reluctance, those attacking Jethro’s barrier eventually stopped as the order was translated to the lycon who could not understand it.
The two dryads took the opportunity provided by the ceasefire to circle around to Zose and Basara.
The rancor in the glares Jethro received, however, did not cease.
Jethro almost sighed in relief.
He was sure he would feel the ghost buzzing of the numbing recoil for the next couple days from all the attacks against his barriers.
Jethro expected to be reprimanded or otherwise threatened for his actions as Hain-henel approached the altar platform, but he did not care.
There was nothing Hain-henel could do to him other than forever prevent Tolmyur from having visiting rights to the Afarit.
He walked around to the other side of the altar and faced the Earth woman whose body was so hot that her maenad gown wafted faint smoke.
Shown by the power of her flame that Basara had utilized to assault his barrier, Jethro understood that she alone was a threat to him.
Hain-henel stopped before the group that stood both on and off the circular platform.
“Lady Ceil’s conviction and sacrifice has been accepted.
Bydrofe, Guardian of Whinhlem, has summoned her,” he announced.
No cheers erupted from members of the widow’s party.
They all saw the extent of the damage Jethro had done to her.
Even though she was summoned by Bydrofe, she would soon die.
“Your role in this is finished, commander of Tolmyur’s armies,” Hain-henel told Jethro.
“By providing for Lady Ceil the means to show her conviction, we will forgive your transgressions here.”
“Do you have any idea what he has done?” Thanysa shouted at Hain-henel.
“The sprites have foretold that Ceil has a role in the future, and that her death would cause dire, unforeseen consequences.”
Jethro ruffled his hair.
“Can I at least have her body once this is all over?”
“No!” the Earth woman screamed.
She lashed out and struck Jethro’s barrier with an enflamed punch.
The flame that burst from the rebound nearly engulfed those around her who already stood somewhat distant to avoid her radiating heat.
Jethro’s hand’s locked up, so he quickly shook them out.
“I said cease…” Hain-henel began, but his eyes were quickly drawn towards the monolithic, earthen crown.
His demeaner suddenly changed.
Veins of fire lined his arms and legs and the coarse rings along the surface of his flat horns glowed a deep red.
His eyes sharpened to a glare.
“Who among you is named Chloe and Justin?”
Those on the altar glanced at each other but did not answer.
Benab, sensing the heightened hostility, rushed onto the altar platform and stood with Chloe at his back.
An arrow was nocked in his bowstring but the string was not drawn.
Thanysa cursed Benab under her breath, but now it was too late.
“Trespassers!
Violators of divine law!
All those who hear my voice, eliminate the party of Ceil!” Hain-henel called.
All the Afarit who had watched the brief discussions and Jethro’s momentary assault from the perimeter of the square charged the altar.
Each of them glowed with veins of fire coursing through their skin.
Jethro’s army joined in the charge from the far end of the square, taking Hain-henel’s call as permission to aid Jethro in eliminating Ceil’s party.
The lycon in their immutable honor were the first to run out and defend the altar platform, but without magic, they were swiftly eliminated.
They were emissaries at the banquet and unarmed.
This troubled Jethro, but he remained within the safety of his barrier to watch the spectacle as he leaned on the bizarre portal’s barrier behind him.
Basara left Zose to Tyree and seized control of any approaching fire thrown by the afarit, weaving it into a fine ribbon and sending it back at the charging horde.
The afarit, however, were mostly unharmed by the condensed flame.
Benab fired arrow after arrow at Hain-henel, but each arrow was batted away into cinders by Hain-henel’s glowing hand.
Hethyro used Benab’s distraction to charge and tackle Hain-henel but quickly realized that despite his larger stature, the afarit’s ignition enabled Hain-henel to quickly overpower him.
Hain-henel threw Hethyro across his shoulders and snapped his neck in a single fluid motion.
He then dumped the troll off his back.
“Be careful.
Bydrofe seeks your life,” Keeya spoke into Jethro’s mind.
“You should flee, now.”
The moment that the horde of Afarit nearly reached the altar platform, a thunderous earthquake shook the square, toppling everyone to the ground.
A massive figure as tall as the mountain crown stood towering from the ancient city.
His feet had crushed into the many tiers of ruins below him.
His gaze filled with divine authority bore down on the square.
All but Chloe and Jethro felt its weight and could not rise from the ground.
Jethro felt an immense wave of spatial magic when Bydrofe appeared.
The sensation was complex and not dissimilar from the altar.
By appearance, the teleportation magic Bydrofe used was not unlike Jethro’s transmission.
Jethro recalled his transmission experiments with Emer back in Tolmyur and the massive, heated explosion caused by a tree that would be dwarfed by this towering figure.
There was not so much as a ripple in the wind when Bydrofe appeared.
Jethro understood immediately that this titan’s spatial magic was far superior.
He now thought he understood why Keeya warned him what might happen if Bydrofe personally acted against him.
There was nowhere on Whinhlem Jethro could flee.
What Jethro did not know was that Keeya’s warning was far graver.
“Two trespassers from other worlds,” Bydrofe spoke with the sound of thunder into the minds of all who saw him, transcending language.

The ground shook with his voice, and several of the ruins along the edge of the fissure separating the city from the mountain crown crumbled down into the molten depths carrying whatever afarit that resided within to their deaths.
“By divine decree of Gaea, all who have seen or heard word spoken by the trespassers must perish.
Their influence on Whinhlem must be expunged.”
While the Tolmyur soldiers began to panic in their immobile state, the afarit pressed their faces to the ground, accepting Bydrofe’s judgement.
“Where is Justin,” Chloe quickly asked Jethro.
“He is safe in Tolmyur,” Jethro replied honestly in English.
“Good,” she replied.
“Keeya, what chance do I have against him?” Jethro asked, feeling the slight onset of fear, something that seemed almost foreign to him after so long.
“On your own, none.
With help, very little.”
“Can you defeat him?”
“Perhaps, but at great cost.”
“Then that is not an option,” Jethro replied before Keeya could reject his proposal, knowing full well she would.
Keeya would never place the few remaining Kissiae in danger to save him.
Jethro felt gratitude from Keeya welling in his thoughts.
“There is little I can do, but I can still help.
I can send you my ven through our connection.
It will be slow, but use it as you need.”

The moment Jethro felt the immensity of the foreign ven entering him, he immediately understood the process: a combination of life and spatial magic that perhaps only a Kissiae Hamadryad fused with a spatial magic master could ever achieve.
This was far more help than Jethro could have ask for.
Chloe’s eyes flitted from Bydrofe to Jethro, unsure what to do.
At first, she thought Jethro was speaking to her in a language she did not understand, but when the one-sided conversation seemingly continued on its own, she knew otherwise.
He seemed ready to fight, meaning that this was an opponent not even Jethro could escape.
Instead of fear, that thought brough Chloe some comfort.

After hearing Bydrofe’s declaration, the first thought that entered her mind was that out of everyone here, she and Jethro had to survive for the sake of the future, if what the sprites prophesied was correct.
That realization tormented her.
She did not want to abandon any of her friends here.
She had already lost so many to war and conflict.
She couldn’t forsake Benab, Thanysa, Basara, Tae, or anyone.
If she was to die, she wanted to die protecting those she loved.
She asked if Justin was safe, and thankfully, he was far away in Tolmyur.
At least should Jethro and her fall, perhaps Justin alone could do something about the future on his own.
“How strong are you,” Jethro asked in English.
“I need time to create a portal.”
Chloe’s heart sank.
As much as the thought of abandoning the fight brought her anguish, she knew that Jethro had made the correct choice.
He was preparing for escape.
Chloe did not have the luxury to respond or question whether Jethro’s escape plan included her.
Bydrofe stomped his foot into the ruined city.
The massive tremor knocked both Chloe and Jethro prone.
A section of the top tier of the city no less than four or five hundred meters wide upheaved and fell their direction.
Should it land, it would cover the entire square and all those who had associated with Jethro or Chloe.
Chloe righted herself and drew upon all the ven she had remaining.
Thankfully, Basara’s masterful control over Chloe’s flames in the assault against Jethro’s barrier prevented unneeded waste.
She still had most of her ven.
Chloe’s arms ignited into a massive inferno that rose high into the air.
She forced the flame to condense at the tips of her middle fingers as she swung her arms into a clap.
She never saw the effect of her desperation.
Chloe blacked out instantly from the force of her own attack.
Jethro quickly repurposed his outer barrier to slow Chloe’s momentum as she was blown through and tumbled to his side.
Had he left the barrier rigid and true, she likely would have died on impact.
Chloe’s hands and arms were burnt and blistering.
The sleeves of her maenad gown that was clearly of Basara’s weave, a gown that should have been impervious to all fire, had burnt away.
He had never seen such self-destructive power.
Jethro returned to his feet and watched the explosion blow through the right end of the massive section of city.
Roofs, walls, and columns from the many structures scattered like shrapnel far larger than any person.
The right end that broke off from the force of the explosion fell into the ravine to the north.
The force of the blast was such that the trajectory of the remaining slab of the city ruins tilted downward to the left.
When it hit the ground and crushed the top layer of ruins, the long slab buckled and split down the middle.
The stone crumbled, raining down on the left end of the long square.
The split section crashed across the center of the square, the tremor of the impact dropping Jethro to his knees.
He did not know how many of his soldiers had been crushed, but at least the majority were still at the far end of the square.
There should be plenty who were lucky enough to avoid the falling debris of ruins and stone.
Jethro then realized that none of the debris had fallen on the altar platform.
None of Chloe’s allies who remained unmoving under Bydrofe’s pressure had been injured.
Was that intentional, or was it impossible luck?
Was the ancient altar to blame?
Some unknown protective magic to safeguard the portal to Bydrofe?
Jethro glanced aside to the unconscious woman.
Or was it deliberate?
“I need more ven!” Jethro called to Keeya as he continued constructing his formula through the chaos.
The dust was slowly settling, and soon Bydrofe would see that his attack was ineffective.
Chloe bought him some time as he had hoped--better than he had hoped--but it was not enough.
The attack was ineffective?
Something felt off in how Bydrofe chose to eliminate Chloe and him.
Bydrofe was the Guardian of Whinhlem, a known being if immeasurable power.
And yet, that attack was incredibly weak.
The scale and power came solely from Bydrofe’s size and could be countered by a single fire mage, albeit a powerful fire mage.
Jethro could imagine any of the earth mages in his army, should they be scaled up to the size of Bydrofe, they could accomplish the same or better.
“I cannot supply you any faster, and you are also at your capacity,” Keeya finally replied.
If that was true, Jethro’s plan was impossible.
His former hope was to catch Bydrofe unawares using instantaneous magic, but that was no longer possible.

If his capacity was simply too small, he could still cast a spell outside his capacity if he broke it down into its sub-formulae and initiate each as Keeya refilled his ven, but then Bydrofe could detect and counter.
Bydrofe was an incredible spatial mage…
…or was he?
The spatial ven signature Jethro felt when Bydrofe appeared was similar if not identical to the portal on the altar beside him.
What if Bydrofe had not cast the magic itself but had a similar portal at his former location.
“This might still be possible, but it’s a gamble.
Keep me topped off,” he asked Keeya.
Now he only needed time, far more time than Chloe had provided.
Bydrofe stabbed his hand into the mountainous crown and slowly started pulling the entire south face of the steep mountain towards the square.
He did not have time.
Jethro began casting the preliminary steps of the largest transmission spell he had ever created while simultaneously completing the formulation of the final steps.
He felt his ven levels plummet, but Keeya kept them steadily rising.
He was now racing against whatever unknown time he had until the mountain face fell and crushed his entire army.
A streak blacker than the night sky above flew down from the top of the mountain crown.
The Aspect of Death saw the destruction of the square where Ceil’s companions were gathered.
He quickly spotted them still on the altar platform unharmed.
They were prostrate against the stone, unable to rise or defend themselves, all except Jethro who could never be affected by the divine pressure of Whinhlem’s god, being from a different world.
“Weak fools, succumbing to borrowed power,” the Aspect of Death chuckled.
He dove down with incredible speed and impaled Ceil’s staff into the arm peeling away the sheer mountain face.
As the Aspect of Death, he felt compelled to fulfill Ceil’s dying wish, and should the mountain fall on her companions, they would certainly die.
The once divine flesh of the titan resisted the corrosion at first, but he was the Aspect of Death.
The rot soon spread, and Bydrofe took notice of the tiny body on his arm.
He released his grip on the mountain and swung his arm with all his strength.
The Aspect of Death was flung off at incredible speed.
He tried to slow himself using Ceil’s fairy wings, but it was not enough.
He collided with the rooftops of the top tier of the ancient ruins, cracking and breaking stone.
He bounced off roofs and walls and crashed down into the lower tiers of the city.
All that remained of Ceil’s body was a heap of mangled flesh and scraps of fabric and leather.
The nearby afarit who were too far from Bydrofe to succumb to his pressure neared the gory heap out of fear and curiosity.
A wave of miasma spread from the body, and all those caught within melted into black sludge.
Their bones crumbled.
Even the stone cracked, losing its binding strength.
When the miasma returned, the once mangled body regrew into what it once had been.
The Aspect of Death sat up and inspected his body once more.
“A very inconvenient body, indeed, only having life magic.
Seeking another should be priority.”
He looked around at the fleeing afarit.
None of them were appealing, as they only had fire magic.
He would be worse off with one of them.
Ceil’s black wings manifested, and the Aspect of Death flew back toward Bydrofe who was still fighting to suppress the slow decay eating up his arm.
“You have fallen farther from divinity than I ever could have hoped, Bydrofe.
I never did get to see the results before Gaea struck me down,” the Aspect of Death said as he hovered not far in front of Bydrofe’s distressed face.
“To see you in such a pitiful state… What happened to the divine titan who laid waste to my perfect empire?”
Bydrofe’s eyes narrowed into a furious glare.
“Surmal,” he realized.
“You know that the created cannot rise against their creator.”
“Drop the tired rhetoric.
You are not our creator.
Gaea is.
You, in your pitiful state, can only borrow a fraction of her divine power now, and it no longer can suppress me.”
The Aspect of Death flapped his wings, sending a wave of miasma at Bydrofe’s unguarded face.
Bydrofe howled, making Jethro’s ears ring.
The widow had somehow survived and was now single-handedly fighting the titan, but Jethro could not tell who was stronger.
Although the wife had peculiar magic that could break his barriers without effort, she had been weak, so he could not trust her to defeat Bydrofe.
However, her intervention bought him enough time to finish the formula and cast the last of the preliminary steps.
Now, he could activate the transmission.
Jethro was gambling on whether Bydrofe had the spatial magic competency to block it.
Should it activate, he could not send the titan somewhere on Whinhlem.
That would only delay the destruction.
So long as Jethro sent Bydrofe somewhere he did not know, Bydrofe would have no way to return.
Jethro understood this well.
A teleportation trace was left at the location of origin, not at the destination; otherwise, he could have gone home long ago.

Bydrofe blew the Aspect of Death away tumbling through the air using wind magic, but in flight and with the nullifying ability of the few resfahil plates clinging to the remaining scraps of armor he was able to right himself and dash back.
Before he could reach the titan, he sensed an immense spatial distortion with a distinct teleportation signature.
Everything around Bydrofe was slowly being drawn in towards the writhing titan.
Jethro had cast some form of teleportation magic.

The Aspect of Death could not lose his target; not after waiting ages for his strength to return; not after waiting even longer to find a compatible twin-soul who could bear him, only to be trapped in the frail body of a woman who simply would not die no matter how hard he tried to make her loathe her very existence; not after the only other possibility of possessing her first offspring failed when the emperor whom she wed refused to lay with her.
He could not let Bydrofe escape.
The Aspect of Death drew all the strength he could into the black wings, but something held him back.
Two arms reached around from behind him and held across his chest.
They were not physical but bore a strength of soul, a soul stronger than his.
“You cannot take her with you,” a familiar woman’s voice spoke from behind him.
“Fine,” the Aspect of death said as he pulled himself from Ceil’s body into a cloud of miasma, “but remember, the dead will forever belong to me.”
He wanted a new body anyway, and there was a prime target right in front of him.
His cloud of miasma raced forward and let itself get pulled into the transmission’s suction.
After a snap like the crack of thunder, the titan vanished.
The black of Ceil’s wings faded to a dull, ashen grey.
Their strength faded, and the body slowly descended, building momentum until Ceil’s lifeless body crashed through the crumbling roof of a ruined abode not far from the grand square.
Chapter 25
“Declaration of War”
“Forty-eight minutes ago, we received word of a nuclear-level explosion.
This is the satellite image taken eleven minutes ago.”
Eydis watched the large screen at the end of the conference table in the White House Situation Room.
It displayed a distant image of a mountain range.
Near the center, a long tail of cloud, debris, or dust ran westward until curving south.
“Do we know if it was nuclear?”
“No, Mr. President.
The common double-flash nature of nuclear explosions was not detected by satellites.
Only a single flash registered.”
“What about volcanic?”
“Unlikely given the nearest fault lines.”

Despite the military’s order that information access would be restricted to Eydis, she had been called to this meeting along with Sean, Miriam, and Symra solely because the explosion happened right over Gullivan.
No one wanted to believe Whinhlem was involved, but given the location, those who called the meeting could think of few other possibilities.
A couple of the top heads among the military and government personnel were missing due to the urgency of the meeting, given the explosion happened on United States soil.
Adding further urgency to the meeting, everyone but Symra and Eydis felt un unnatural pull westward in the direction of the explosion.
The sensation carried an irresistible feeling of submission and fealty, like there was an unknown something or someone there that they had no choice but to obey.
That feeling was telling them to act, and act quickly.
“No magic of that scale exists on Whinhlem,” Eydis added to the discussion.
If not Whinhlem, from where did the explosion originate?
This question hung on the faces of many around the table.
“If it was nuclear, why Gullivan?”
“It would have had to be a personal device.
No ICBMs were detected.”
“We are still awaiting radiation readings, but we have been unable to get close to ground zero,” the man at the screen replied.
“You can see how the dust trail curves south.
A massive storm is building not unlike a hurricane with Gullivan at the epicenter.
Although air seems stable at the eye, at about a thirty-mile radius, the windspeeds have already reached category five at the time of this photo and are expected to rise further.”
“Was this caused by the explosion?”
“Could it be some experimental weather-controlling technology or magic?”
“What of the people?
How many are still in danger, and how can we rescue them?” the President asked.
“What of the survivors?”
“Until the storm dies, we likely cannot reach them.”
“We need to know if this threat is foreign--international-foreign,” the Secretary of Defense elaborated, “or from Whinhlem.” He looked at Eydis with narrow eyes.
She had endured his glare plenty of times before.
After all, she had brought a war from her world to Earth.
“I will go,” Eydis said.
“No,” Miriam protested.
“I advise against it,” Symra added.
Eydis glanced at Symra’s prosthetic arm.
The last time Eydis ignored Symra’s council, Symra got hurt, but this time, Eydis would be going in personally.
“I am the only one who can.
My wind magic should keep me safe from the storm, and should there be radiation, it will have less effect on me because of my life magic.
My spatial magic should handle everything else.”
Agreement came readily from the heads around the table.
“When can you leave?” the Secretary of Defense asked.
“Now.” The dust in the image was traveling south-west, so Eydis created a teleportation formula targeting the side of the interstate about eight miles north of Gullivan.
Before anyone could stop her, she opened it there in the room and jumped through.
Torrential winds momentarily whipped the papers on the table around the room until Eydis closed the portal behind her.
Bydrofe lay on the slope of a massive crater carved into a mountainside.
The entire air around him was clouded with dust, and debris as large as a common house continually rained from the sky.
He struggled to stand and found numerous lacerations draining thin ichor all over his body.
His insides were likewise torn.
His affinity to life magic was very weak by divine standards, but it was more than sufficient to prevent his otherwise fatal injuries from killing him outright.
Had Surmal not reduced him to his current state all those years ago, such injuries could have been ignored.
His feet were unstable, but he managed to stand, rising taller than the nearby mountain range despite standing in a crater as deep as his shins.
The night scene of the Afarit caldera was gone, replaced by a dusty midday.
The dust continued to rise, carried off by the wind.
He cleared the dust at his feet with wind magic and notice the soil and stone did not match any formation on Whinhlem.
The mountain range at his back was likewise foreign.
As one who had played part in the entire history of Whinhlem alongside his wife, Gaea, he knew even the minutest of details of his world.
A god should have no reason to fear, but here Bydrofe was terrified.
He was a trespasser on another god’s world.
As this realization hit him, the clouds around him changed course and spun into a massive storm.
Over the passing minutes, all the land he could see from his towering height vanished in the veil of clouds.
A small being no larger than a human appeared in the air before him, and Bydrofe knew immediately which world he had trespassed upon.
“Kalya, forgive me,” Bydrofe began before coughing out ichor, some of it now tinted a putrid black.
The god before him appeared human but for her extra two arms that were folded and crossed over her bare chest.
Her skin held a pristine onyx tone.
Her hair, darker even than her skin, was woven into a loose braid down her back and extended beyond her feet for another full length of her body, the tip whipping about in the wind.
A red mask bearing a merciful smile engraved in gold adorned her face.
“Bydrofe, I have shown mercy on you and Gaea already for those of your world who have trespassed here.
My world is not so weak than such an infection cannot be cured without my aid.”
Kalya removed her mask.
Her deep golden eyes glared with a judgmental scowl at the cowering titan.
“However!
Gaea’s inability to quell the Lurr threat in your world has now led that infestation to mine.
Now your presence here spells further disaster!
The people of my world might endure the Lurr if dealt with quickly, but it cannot endure you.
Already your presence and mine will hinder the progress of my world for ages to come.
Already the hearts of my people are drawn to me now that I am forced to intervene.
I must eliminate you before my world discovers you are here to prevent further damage to my design.”
The mask of mercy in her hand vanished, replaced by a spear of light that grew ever larger as her hand raised above her head.
Nearby dust and clouds were drawn to it and coiled about its length with clashes of lightning as it grew as long as Bydrofe was tall.
“Killing another god is forbidden,” Bydrofe pleaded, but Kalya would not be moved.
Her judgment was final.
“It was Gaea who proposed these laws, and we all agreed to them for both our benefit and detriment.
By striking you down, I will break no laws, for you are no longer a god.”
Eydis continued southward portal after portal as she deemed the land safe.
The air felt burnt and was nearly too hot to endure, but otherwise, once she broke through the border of wind, there was no danger.
She arrived in burnt plains far north of where Gullivan had once stood.
The city and foothills of her memory that should have been visible in the distance were gone, replaced by a massive crater that extended far beyond the city’s outer farmlands.
In the city’s place stood a towering figure that grew ever more visible as the dust in the air was drawn into a massive glowing spear shrouded in storm clouds and lightning.

Eydis had never met him, because as her father explained, “The indoctrination you would receive upon your visitation will be detrimental to your future.” She did not know him, but she knew of him, both by the education she had received as a child and by the innate reverence she felt towards him.
This was Bydrofe, the Guardian of Whinhlem.
The massive spear thrown by a hand too small and far for her to see struck Bydrofe through the chest.
The pull Eydis felt toward her guardian deity vanished as the titan fell into the broken mountainside and the spear dispersed.
The sight drew tears from the corners of Eydis’s eyes, and she fell to her knees.
“Do you judge me, daughter of Whinhlem, for striking down Bydrofe,” a voice spoke into her mind.
“I could never think of judging the Guardian of Earth,” Eydis managed to reply, quickly wiping her tears.
As Eydis wondered what would become of Whinhlem now that its guardian had fallen, the titan pushed himself up from the mountain.
A massive burnt hole remained in his chest oozing rivers of black.
In place of the reverence that Eydis had felt, Bydrofe’s body now radiated a creeping darkness that slowly blackened the earth around him.
The darkness spread quickly, and before Eydis could think to teleport away before it reached her, she found herself in a field staring at a wall of clouds miles high and hundreds of miles wide.
The Aspect of Death rejoiced in his fortune.
After abandoning Ceil’s body, he struggled on his own to overtake the fallen titan god.
His soul had power, but on his own against a fleshen body, his influence was limited.
Victory was uncertain until the god of this new world ended Bydrofe’s life for him.
Now, he had his next target, another god to fell, and a new body to defeat her with.
He looked at the gaping hole in his chest and expelled miasma far and wide.
The mountains at his back crumbled, and the burnt fields and forests beyond the crater blackened and dissolved into powder.
As the miasma returned, Bydrofe’s body reformed and regained the strength it had lost from the chronic injury Surmal dealt Bydrofe long ago.
Although not yet as powerful as a true god, Surmal no longer feared the god hovering in the air before him.
Surmal eyed the small goddess who stared back in confusion.
Kalya looked around her and witnessed the devastation his existence brought upon her world.
Bydrofe was only a threat through the terror his presence would invoke upon the people of her world.
This new enemy was a direct threat that could lead to her world’s destruction.
Only once before had a similar threat appeared, the Lurr, and many worlds had fallen desolate to it.
At that time, Earth was young, and Kalya managed to save her world through a mass extinction.
Earth was still young, but her people were now more matured as she raced to see how quickly her design could cultivate a species to godhood.
“All the gods are hypocrites,” Surmal spoke, enjoying the new tone of his voice, far better than the feminine chime it had been before.
“The purpose of creating a world is to create more of your kind, is it not?
And yet, when a race encroaches upon you, you fear them.”

“You are blight that must be cured before your destruction spreads,” Kalya called, readying for an unknown battle against an opponent she was unsure she could defeat without having to restart her world anew once more.
“I am Death,” Surmal replied, “a necessary Aspect of existence, one that the gods seem to have forgotten.
You live by your rules for your own convenience, expecting your immortality and the endlessness of time to make all things right, but even you make exception when it is convenient for you.”
Surmal’s glare twisted into a scowl.
“The Lurr, who even you stated are a threat to the worlds, are invaders whose influence must be eliminated by your divine law.
I and my people were creations of Gaea who were reaching the purpose of our creation.
Yet, why was it that I and my people had to die when Gaea and Bydrofe let the Lurr live?”
Kalya could not answer.
In her judgement, the Lurr should have been dealt with, and yet Gaea alone let them survive on her world.
All other worlds either eliminated them or fell to them and had to be destroyed.
“It is because you fear those like you,” Surmal answered in Kalya’s silence.
“Is that not why you forbid interference between other gods and create your worlds so far apart?
Oh, right.
Interference is okay if you see them as less than you and they are beneficial.
Is that not why the gods enslaved the sprites?”
Surmal laughed.
“Many of you gods could never manage your worlds on your own without their help, the titans most of all with their weak elemental affinities.
I can sense that even you employ several.
Why not have them eliminate me in your stead?”
Kalya considered it, but pulling the sprites from their tasks came with an equivalent risk which Surmal immediately voiced.
“You can’t, because by your own inability, your world would destabilize without them.”
Surmal crouched down and spread his arms as if lifting a massive weight over his back.
“I think it is time that the current generation of gods ends and the next rises.
No doubt the sprites after their eons of servitude, and others like them living under the fear that their creators harbor for them, could manage their world more peaceably.”
Instead of attacking Surmal, Kalya shrouded herself in a divine barrier as miles of mountains rose and crushed her from both sides.
All nearby gods felt an immense sense of foreboding from the world governed by Kalya.

Such an ill omen had not been felt since the advent of the Lurr, or more precisely, the destruction of Lurr’s world at the hands of gods who believed that Lurr, who lacked a physical form or divine ability, had no right to govern a world.
Those who had lost their former worlds to the Lurr threat began immediate preparations to protect their new, young worlds.
Those who had resisted the Lurr threat held confidence in their mature worlds and watched with judgmental eyes.
Only one goddess watched the events on Earth without thought of the imminent danger.
Gaea had always watched her world like a master admiring her garden, often unattentive as she let Bydrofe tend to it in her stead.

She had observed listlessly Bydrofe’s confrontation with the trespassers after he enquired about the elven house he had so meticulously cultivated, relaying the answer she received from the sprites who acted as her eyes and ears on the surface.
She did not doubt that Bydrofe could defeat simple mortals, but then he vanished.
She felt the divine authority she had given him emanating from Kalya’s world.
Gaea could only watch as Kalya struck her husband down in the name of justice and divine law.
All titans who managed worlds of their own governed by rule of strength.
Only the most powerful of sentient species could gain the god’s favor and be nurtured.
Gaea saw such rule as barbaric, and for this reason she was scorned.
Only Bydrofe shared her view that greater strength came from diversity.
Together they founded a world on the far rim of a galaxy far from the influence of other gods to prove their vision.

There they proved Gaea’s theory in the advent of the Lurr when only her world, which contained numerous sentient species, managed a symbiotic relationship while others could only eliminate the threat or fall.
Bydrofe helped make her dream a reality, but now she watched the only man who shared in that dream, the man she grew to cherish more than her dream, perish.
All of Whinhlem felt Gaea’s immense anguish, then anger.
In a divine declaration to all gods, for the murder of Bydrofe she promised the destruction of Kalya and all her worlds, both past and current.
And so began the first War of the Gods.
Conclusion of
ACT 1
Epilogue
“A Title Bestowed unto Oneself”
Ephora grew tired of the panicking sprites around her and the crying children who mimicked the fear.
She, herself, was so far beyond panic that she felt only exhaustion.
“I have made a summons,” the Arkhon told her.
“This is beyond what we can cope with now.”
Despite the graveness of the first declaration of war between gods, the Arkhon seemed happier than he had ever been, and that disgusted Ephora, although she withheld from showing it.
Ephora did not have to wait long before a woman appeared in the garden amid the children.
She wore a simple loose, sleeveless gown of modest white tied with a tan sash.
She appeared as human if not for the presence she emanated that transcended the divine, but that presence was not oppressive but comforting, bearing a deep love for all things.
“Is she truly the Allmother?” Ephora asked Arkhon.
“Only an image,” the Allmother replied as she walked among the children.
Each child that saw her stopped crying immediately.
She tousled an older child’s hair as she passed, and the boy giggled as if Gaea’s oppressive voice he had just heard and the panic of the sprites never happened.
“No world could endure me if I came in person.
Even now, my time here is short, and once I leave, I can never return.”
She stood before Ephora who could not help but be drawn in.
Before Ephora realized her own actions, she was embraced in the Allmother’s hands against her bosom.
“How could our predictions have gone so wrong?” she asked, spilling her troubles and guilt.
Their foresight was still blind, and Ephora was to blame for it.
“Your Arkhon has told me that you have an anomaly.
Can you show me?” the Allmother asked, lifting Ephroa from her bosom and cradling her in her hands to speak with her at eye level.
Ephora nodded and led the Allmother to where Sammy’s dissected body remained suspended in time.
The Allmother viewed the body for only a moment.
“Nothing is wrong.
She is a simple human from Kalya’s world.”
The Arkhon’s grin grew wider as Ephora grew more distressed.
“How can that be?” Ephora cried.
“Sammy Thompson was the cause of all this.”
“Sammy Thompson is not here,” the Allmother replied.
“This is only the mortal shell she had used in life.”
As Ephora contemplated what the Allmother said, the Allmother’s attention changed to a peculiar black curse locked within a barrier.
It’s tendril-like arms grasped at nothing but always pointed just off from north.
“What is this?” she asked.
The Arkhon spun through the air, ecstatic beyond reason that he could show the Allmother something unknown to her.
“This!” he exclaimed, raising the spherical barrier above his head and spinning it like a ball.
Throughout the spinning, the black mist continued reaching north.
“This is a weak but unique curse created using death magic cast on Sammy.”
“And it is not drawn to her body,” the Allmother observed as she paced around the Arkhon.
“Then what is it drawn to,” Ephora asked.
“Sammy Thompson,” the Allmother replied.
“She is still on Whinhlem and has not moved on.
Her soul must be quite stable.”
“Let’s find her!” The Arkhon immediately vanished, and Ephora quickly followed.
The Allmother simply smiled at her adorable little children and quickly followed as well.
All mortals on Whinhlem who heard Gaea’s declaration cowered.
None knew who Kalya was, and most knew Bydrofe, but only those at the Afarit knew Bydrofe was injured and somehow vanished.

Released from the divine pressure they were bound under, the surviving afarit around the square rose to eliminate the party they suspected was the cause of Bydrofe’s downfall, the cause of the anguish of their Goddess.

The Tolmyur army who had cheered their commanding general for eliminating the threat to their lives now fought under the command of General Byurk a losing battle against the seemingly innumerable afarit.
They could not fight their way around the massive section of city that lay in ruins across the center of the square to reach their Commanding General.
Jethro fought alongside the survivors of Ceil’s party against the afarit horde, solely to safeguard the unconscious Chloe whose power and ability he could not help but respect.
However, he knew a losing battle.
He quickly checked the detection barrier in the teleportation room of his home in Tolmyur to make certain it was clear and sent Chloe there.
As Jethro was contemplating who else and how many he could save among his army as the slaughter intensified and Keeya continually replenished his ven, all feelings of hostility ceased.
As if everyone engaged in combat had decided to stop at the same time, weapons dropped, magic extinguished, and the ignited veins of the afarit cooled.
Atop the rubble crossing the long city square stood a single woman.
Beside her, two wind sprites floated, one carrying a strange orb.
“Over here,” called a voice behind Jethro.
A small whisp of flame led a suspended corpse Jethro recognized immediately as Ceil.
As the whisp neared, Jethro saw it was a flame sprite.
The sprite passed through Jethro’s external barrier with the body as if the barrier wasn’t there.
He placed the body across the altar whose portal had long since disappeared.
The woman of unfathomable presence slowly walked towards the altar platform with the two sprites in tow.
None hindered her, not the afarit nor Ceil’s party.
She passed Jethro with a warm and caring smile that felt as if she understood and sympathized with all the pain Jethro had experienced.
The male wind sprite with the orb containing black, mist-like tendrils ignored him completely, but the female sprite stopped in front of his face.
