A faint worry shot across Jethro’s mind, but the calm he felt so close to the mysterious woman prevented him from taking defensive action.
Although this sprite looked different, the sprite from Earth came to mind.
“We need to stop you from causing any more problems until we figure out what’s going on,” the sprite said as she placed her hand on Jethro’s forehead.
His worry became reality all too quickly.
He felt all his ven freeze--not just his teleportation magic, but all his magic was blocked.
His connection to Keeya was frozen.
His outer barrier disappeared, allowing Ceil’s companions to surround her corpse.
Jethro had never felt so vulnerable.
Thankfully, the calming aura prevented anyone from retaliating against him.
“Oh, and there are probably going to be things you shouldn’t hear, so sleep for now.”
Jethro blacked out and fell backwards onto the stone platform.
At least Ephora was kind enough to cushion his fall.
At the request of Thanysa, Tyree quickly checked Ceil’s vitals.
“Ceil is dead,” Tyree said to the mourning party.
They had a resurgence of hope when Ceil appeared seemingly healthy and fighting Bydrofe to protect them, but sure enough, falling from that height had been fatal.
The lone High Elf of the Vallen guard who survived the ordeal fell to his knees.
Tae dropped before the altar and cried into her arms.
Benab turned his back to Ceil and instead stood over Jethro, but no matter how he tried, he could not muster the will to strike down his vulnerable enemy.
He likewise wanted to ask what Jethro had done with Chloe but couldn’t.
Basara held Zose who was just coherent enough to understand that he had failed his mission.
Thanysa turned to Ephora whom she recognized as the one who had been in contact with Ceil and Chloe, the one who told them Jethro should not be killed.
“What should we do now?

What kind of future awaits us?” A war between gods, one that involved her world, had been declared, and Thanysa could only see this as the worst possible outcome caused by the death of those who were vital to mitigate this calamity.
Ephora did not know how to respond.
She did not want to give false hope nor further wound the troubled emotions of this party.
The Arkhon continued forward, and as he circled the altar, the curse continually reached out towards Ceil’s body.
In a spurt of inspiration, he removed the encasing barrier.
“What are you doing?
!” Ephora screamed, but she failed to contain the curse before it entered Ceil’s body.
“What’s the harm?” the Arkhon smirked.
“Ceil’s already dead, so it’s not like it can make her more dead.
Besides, while you spent all your time studying Sammy’s mortal shell,” he emphasized using the Allmother’s words, “I was studying this curse.”
“What kind of curse is it,” the Allmother asked.
“A rather benign one, in all actuality.
It only causes illness, nightmares, exhaustion--anything to make living uncomfortable.
Ceil cast it on Sammy to make Sammy suffer, back when Ceil directed her hatred toward the whole of humanity.”
“How is that important here?
I thought it was supposed to lead to Sammy?” Ephora questioned.
“That is what I am hoping to find--”
A swift hand lashed out and grabbed the Arkhon.
Despite being the wind, the hand clasping him held him firm and prevented his body from dispersing.
Ceil leaned forward and looked at him with a wide smile.
“I got you!
I caught you, Arkhon.
I finally caught you!” she exclaimed.
“Lady Ceil!” Thanysa dropped to her knees and clasped Ceil’s outstretched arm with gentle, trembling hands.
The others raised their dejected faces and stared at the miracle.
“Your eyes are as beautiful as always,” Ceil said to Thanysa who was staring with tear-filled eyes.
“Sorry to disappoint you, but I’m not Ceil.”
The Arkhon rested his one free elbow on Ceil’s forefinger and leaned his head against his hand.
A warm, fatherly smile spread across his lips.
“Welcome back, Sammy,” he said.
““Sammy?”” both Ephora and Thanysa repeated in near unison.
“Then where is Lady Ceil?” Thanysa asked.
“She’s still here,” Sammy replied as she fully sat up and turned to let her legs hang off the altar.
“God, this body is stiff.” She rotated her shoulders and stretched her arms, still holding onto the Arkhon with one hand.
“She’s just sleeping for now.”
“When Ceil died, that bastard Surmal locked Ceil in her body so she couldn’t pass on.
I guess he needed access to her magic or something.
I don’t really understand it all,” Sammy tried to explain.
“Most know that when a body dies, the ven within it disperses.
However, the truth is that ven is less connected to the physical but more relates to the soul,” the Allmother explained.
Sammy’s eyes lit up.
“That’s why the flow is different or why the wellpoint in the forehead that’s supposed to be connected to the soul makes reading ven easier, right?
At least that’s what Eydis taught me.
Wait, then what about Justin’s condition?
How does that relate to all this?”
Sammy looked around but could not find him.
“Where is he?”
“He’s in Tolmyur,” the Arkhon explained.
Sammy moved the Arkhon in front of her face.
“Seriously?
God damnit, I wanted to surprise him…” A longing smile graced her lips.
“I know my death has caused him a lot of pain.”
Sammy took a deep breath, exhaled slowly, and then rested the Arkhon in her lap, refusing to release him.
“Anyway, back to Ceil.
When Bydrofe was about to be teleported away, Surmal was going to drag Ceil with and then dump her somewhere when he found a body he liked better.
Like hell I was going to let that happen.
She’s still stuck in here!
So, I made him choose between Bydrofe and Ceil.”
“You had the strength to hold back the Aspect of Death,” the Allmother said, her eyes narrowing.
“I guess so?
Well, there was this emptiness in Ceil that was left behind when he left, so I kind of just claimed it.
I now understand a bit why Surmal was so pissed at Ceil, though.
Even though Ceil was dead, I couldn’t break through.
It was like she was asleep at the wheel, and I was stuck in the back seat.
That is, until something that reeeaaalllly wanted to get to me suddenly appeared and pulled me to the front.” She glared annoyedly down at the Arkhon, but then she smiled.
“Thanks!
I don’t think I could have done it on my own.
Ceil is more stubborn than me at times, I guess especially so when asleep.”
“Considering the curse carries Ceil’s will, I can understand how it unlocked the metaphorical cage and pulled you to the surface.
For now,” the Arkhon drew the curse once more from Ceil’s body and entrapped it as before, “it is still harmful.
Once Ceil wakes, she should be able to let you out whenever she wants.
Just don’t go seclude yourself until she does, or you might find yourself stuck again.”
None but the two sprites and the Allmother understood Sammy’s analogy or the Arkhon’s explanation, so Ephora elaborated.
“Ceil is a twin-soul.
Bydrofe had been cultivating the Amel line to produce elves with a larger strength of soul after Surmal successfully ripped him from godhood by damaging his soul.
He wanted to understand the nature of souls better to prevent the same from happening again.”
“He never truly succeeded, but a side effect was the rare appearance along the elven line of those who had room for two souls in a single body,” the Arkhon explained further.
“Ceil’s two tails are a physical indicator of this rare trait.”
“Anyway, I am going to let Ceil rest for as long as she needs.
She’s tired after everything that’s happened,” Sammy said.
“Does this mean Ceil is still alive,” Zose asked as Basara carried him closer with his good arm over her shoulder.
“No, we’re both still very much dead,” Sammy said with a light chuckle.
“Ceil is way too cute for me to call us a zombie, and I think terms like living dead are stupid ‘cause it’s a blatant oxymoron.
I think Surmal has something to do with this, but I don’t know what it is.”
“She is right,” Tyree confirmed.
“I still sense no life from Ceil’s body.” She grasped Sammy’s free hand to check her vitals and then placed her hand on Sammy’s forehead for a better reading.
“Her body is functioning as normal but lacks the essence of life.
I cannot explain it.”
“I guess it’s not all that important anyway.” Sammy brushed off her startling declaration.
Tyree confirmed that she and Ceil could act as normal, so that was all Sammy cared about.
“Your young anomaly is quite anomalous indeed,” the Allmother said with an understanding grin.
“Have you learned why Sammy is invisible to our foresight?” Ephora asked.
“Are there any other beings whose actions are difficult for you to read or calculate?” she asked back.
“None,” Ephora replied flatly.
“You are thinking too narrow,” the Allmother kindly admonished.
“The gods,” Arkhon answered.
“But Sammy is not a god.”
“What about those not unlike the gods that are more prone to rampant action driven by their natures?”
Arkhon understood immediately.
Ever since the Lurr rampaged over the universe, he had studied these bizarre Aspects of Being.
He wriggled himself free from Sammy’s grip and floated in front of her face.
He kept his composure calm to not alert Ephora he had discovered the reason.
She was still contemplating the Allmother’s cryptic answer.
“Sammy, do you remember the bet we made back in Fiorrae?”
Sammy looked confusedly at him.
She had already thought their bet was over after what happened in Melia.
He had given her a hollow victory and rewarded her with understanding over languages.
“What was your reason for taking that bet?” he asked.
“You said I was unimportant.
You wanted to sacrifice me for some pointless test to see if Ceil would kill me!” Sammy replied, some of the anger of the past welling up in her.
“I wanted to prove to you that I was important.
I wanted to show you that I could change the future.”
The Arkhon smiled warmly.
“A powerful soul, heightened by a strong, pure desire that becomes the focus of your actions.
Our bet became the catalyst for you to develop your entelechy, an innate power that refines the possible into actuality and leads to the fulfillment of your potential.
A pure entelechy is the root of every Aspect of Being.”
Sammy understood nothing that the Arkhon told her, but Ephor quickly realized what the Allmother wanted them to discover, what the Arkhon had discovered immediately given the pointed hints.
“In all our foresight, we had been wrong in predicting the most suitable candidate.
It was not Chloe but Sammy!” the Arkhon exclaimed with an areal cartwheel.
“Prytanis!”
A whisp that had brought Ceil’s body reappeared beside the Arkhon and quickly formed into a flame sprite.
“Chloe is at Jethro’s home in Tolmyur.
Observe her and nurture her entelechy.
See if you can indeed prove my theory.”
The flame sprite grew excited and vanished.
“What are you saying,” Ephora said, exasperated.
“It cannot be so easy.”
“No, this wasn’t easy.
It was luck.
Chance!

It is a probability so infinitesimal that there is no way our foresight could have ever calculated it!” The Arkhon flew into the air and spun around the alter at incredible speed, releasing a small burst of wind in his excitement when he stopped.
“Don’t you see?
Sammy’s soul was stronger than ours from the start.
That was why we were blind to her!”
The Arkhon lowered himself slowly in front of Sammy, and in a gesture of humility, he crossed his hands over his chest and bowed low.
“Our bet back in Fiorrae is over, and I have lost.
You have not only proven your importance, but you have also shown that your very existence is vital and irreplaceable.
I know you have envied the titles that the sprites have bestowed upon your friends.
After your death in Revlan, we had planned to give one in your honor for finding a way to send Ceil north to the Afarit, but in the end we could not decide.”
The Arkhon raised his head but remained bowed.
“We can now no longer bestow upon you a title because you have earned one for yourself.
As payment for my loss in our bet, and on behalf of all the sprites throughout the universe, we recognize you, Sammy Marie Thompson of Earth.”
He beckoned Ephora forward, and she clasped the Arkhon’s hand.
Together they bowed and spoke with complete understanding of the other.
““We recognize you, the nascent Aspect of Chaos.””
Eydis watched the wall of storms far in the distance and felt the ongoing but subtle tremors of the unimaginable battle raging deep within.
Her phone was ringing incessantly, calls from either Miriam or Sean, but she had not answered.
What she saw, the death of the guardian of her world and the unknown horror who had claimed his body to fight the guardian of this world, had overwhelmed her.
“The Aspect of Death’s power has far exceeded what I had assumed,” Kalya’s voice spoke into Eydis’s mind, momentarily frightening her.
“Our battle will be prolonged, so I must request of you a favor.”
“What favor could I possibly provide the Guardian of Earth?” Eydis asked.
After seeing the attack that struck down Bydrofe in a single blow, there should be nothing beyond Kalya’s power to perform.
And Eydis was not from Earth.
She was a trespasser on Kalya’s domain.
“The Aspect of Death is a great threat, but another danger from your world remains on Earth that perhaps you may be able to solve.”
“What is it you ask of me,” Eydis replied, bowing to the ground in the direction of the wall of storms.
“You know of the Lurr who had once impersonated you.
She is pregnant.
Before Lurr can infest this world and lead it to ruin, you must eliminate her and all her spawn.
In all the peoples of my world, only you hold knowledge of the Lurr.
Should you successfully complete your task, I will return to you your loved ones, Chloe and Justin, and permit you to live with them here on my world.”
Eydis’s eyes grew wide.
As tears quickly formed and dripped off her eyelashes into the grass, she readily accepted the task Kalya had given her.
